Office of Weekly Paper in Riverdale Is Firebombed
LEAD: The offices of The Riverdale Press, a family-owned weekly newspaper in the Bronx, were heavily damaged by at least one firebomb shortly before dawn yesterday, but the authorities said the identity of the attackers and their motive were mysteries.


Trainers: Body Building, Ego Massage
LEAD: WHEN Dan Myers first hinted that he might leave her, Ellen Zeisler was justifiably upset.
After all, they have been seeing each other for more than six months now, and - Ms.
Zeisler is the first to admit it - she has become somewhat dependent on him.
He makes her feel good, puts up with her complaints and doesn't make fun of the way she looks in tights.

LEAD: The prices that farmers got for raw products declined seven-tenths of 1 percent in February from January levels, but still averaged 14 percent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ad Spending On TV Rises
LEAD: Total spending on broadcast television advertising almost reached $25 billion in 1988, the Television Bureau of Advertising said yesterday.
Advertisers spent $24.9 billion on the medium last year, the highest amount ever and an increase of 7.1 percent over 1987.

Abdul-Jabbar Convicted
LEAD: A Phoenix Municipal Court judge yesterday convicted Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the Los Angeles Lakers' center, of two misdemeanor offenses that arose from a shoving incident in a shopping mall last April 21.
Judge John L. Wiehn set sentencing for March 29.
The 41-year-old defendant, who is in his 20th year in the National Basketball Association and has announced his retirement, could be fined up to $1,750, sentenced to 10 months in jail and put on five years' probation in the convictions on single counts of criminal damage and assault.

Treasury Notes and Bonds Up a Bit
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds posted moderate gains yesterday, while bill rates plunged as the debt market tried to absorb conflicting economic data.
One result was that institutional investors continued to stand aside, which reduced trading activity and may have exaggerated price moves.

Gervin Treated
LEAD: George Gervin, the former Spurs' forward who led the National Basketball Association in scoring four times, was treated at a hospital in San Antonio last Saturday for what the police investigated as an apparent drug overdose, The San Antonio Light reported yesterday.
According to a police report, Gervin told an officer that he snorted what he ''thought was cocaine'' and later said he did not know what it was, the paper said.

LEAD: BAKING with flour is not the microwave oven's best trick, nor is browning.

The filling for a lemon-orange meringue pie can be made in the microwave oven.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Bloom Gets Buitoni
LEAD: Nestle Foods has taken its pasta business south in switching the account for its subsidiary Buitoni to the Bloom Agency in Dallas.
Bloom already handles the accounts of several Nestle products through Carnation, a Nestle subsidiary.
Buitoni was made part of the Carnation unit after Nestle acquired the Italian company last year.


Konrad Lorenz, Pioneer in Study Of Animals' Behavior, Dies at 85
LEAD: Konrad Lorenz, perhaps this century's most widely known experts on animal behavior, died Monday at his home in Altenburg, Austria, east of Vienna, at the age of 85.
The Austrian Press Agency said he died of kidney failure.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.H.L.
North Stars 4, Capitals 3: Dino Ciccarelli scored a power-play goal with 16 seconds left in regulation time as Minnesota scored twice in the final minute.
Brian MacLellan tied the score with his 15th goal of the season with 55 seconds left.
Washington's Scott Stevens took a roughing penalty 29 seconds later and Ciccarelli poked a rebound over Don Beaupre, the Washington goalie, for his 32d goal.

4 Guardian Angels Surrender
LEAD: Four Guardian Angels surrendered to the police today on charges of assaulting three teen-agers while patrolling a South Philadelphia neighborhood, officials said.
Charges against the four, who range from 12 to 16 years of age, were filed Monday after a three-day investigation.
The incident occurred Friday night in front of a vacant house that Curtis Sliwa, the founder of the Guardian Angels, said was used by drug dealers.

Edwards Barred
LEAD: Eddie (the Eagle) Edwards of England, a ski jumper who gained international fame through his inept jumping, has been barred from competing in World Cup events, at least through the end of the current season.
The British Ski Federation said it had decided to keep Edwards on lower-level events for the time being.

Bush still pinballing around and his entourage on tilt.

METROPOLITAN DIARY
LEAD:  THE scene: The women's locker room of the Vertical Club, one of the more fashionable midtown gyms.
The time: A few days before Lent.
Dramatis personae: Lorinda Ash and two women whose heart-to-heart conversation she overhears.
The women, it soon becomes apparent, are: single, middle-aged, a tad overweight, as well as unhappy with their romantic involvements, their too-small apartments, the high cost of living in New York, their unrewarding jobs.

LEAD: A defense attorney yesterday sought to have the former sports agent Lloyd Bloom tried separately from his colleague, Norby Walters, on Federal charges including racketeering and extortion.
Both men are accused of using cash and threats to line up college athletes as clients.
At a brief hearing, United States District Judge George Marovich said he would rule on the motion today before empaneling the jury.

Lasmo Oil Deal
LEAD: The British oil company Lasmo said it would buy International Thomson Organization Ltd.'s British North Sea interests for $:358 million, or $623 million.
Lasmo, formally called the London and Scottish Marine Oil P.L.C., is one of Britain's largest independent oil and gas exploration companies.
It said the purchase of Thomson North Sea Holdings from Canada-based Thomson would almost double its North Sea production to 49,000 barrels of oil equivalent a day.


Connecticut Sells $175 Million Issue
LEAD: Connecticut priced $175 million of general obligation debt yesterday through competitive bidding, won by underwriters led by J. P. Morgan Securities Inc.


WASHINGTON TALK: Foreign Affairs; Afghanistan Pullout: Joy and Worries Overlap
LEAD: The morning after the last Soviet combat troops left Afghanistan, an intelligence official told a friend: ''Feb. 15 was the first day in history that the Soviet empire was smaller at sunset than at sunrise.''


Firefly Lights the Way To New Medical Tests
LEAD: The chemical ingredients that make firefly tails light up on summer evenings are being marketed commercially as fast-acting detectors of infections in medical tests and for measuring the active ingredients in some pharmaceuticals.


IRAN AND BRITAIN MOVE NEAR BREAK
LEAD: Iran and Britain moved closer today to a break in diplomatic relations, as Iran threatened to sever ties unless the British Government withdrew its support in the next week for Salman Rushdie and his right to publish his novel ''The Satanic Verses.''


G.M. and Hughes Institute Settle Dispute on 1985 Deal
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation today settled its dispute with the Howard Hughes Medical Institute over G.M.'s 1985 purchase of the Hughes Aircraft Company through a series of financial arrangements that could be worth more than $2.5 billion to the institute through 1995.

BOSTON (AL) - Agreed to terms with Rob Murphy and Steve Ellsworth, pitchers, on one-year contracts.


Two Bills on Steroid Use
LEAD: All high school athletes in New York State would be tested for use of anabolic steroids under one of two steroid-control proposals being considered by the Legislature.


Tour Bans Square Grooves
LEAD: Saying that the use of square or U grooves in golf irons ''has changed the nature of the game,'' the PGA Tour Policy Board today declared clubs with square grooves illegal for use in PGA Tour events starting Jan. 1, 1990.
Thus, all competitiors in a tour event must use clubs with the traditional V grooves.

LEAD: Naomi Brauer Koshkin and Jack Barry Friedman were married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in Longview, Tex., by Rabbi Bernard Honan.
The bride is a daughter of Mrs.
Benjamin B. Brauer of New York and the late Mr.
Brauer.
Her husband is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs.
Mendel Friedman of Shreveport, La.

LEAD: A District of Columbia court ruled yesterday that the Catholic University of America was not obliged to retain the Rev.
Charles E. Curran as a teacher of theology.
Father Curran, suspended from his teaching duties after the Vatican declared him ineligible to teach Catholic theology, had filed a lawsuit accusing the university of violating his contract as a tenured professor.

PERSONAL HEALTH
LEAD: Nature is neutral, sometimes good and sometimes evil.
It is good when it produces foods that nourish or chemicals, like penicillin, that cure.
It is bad when it dishes up microorganisms that sicken or chemicals, like botulinum toxin, that kill.

LEAD:  Q. In periods of high humidity, our toilet sweats a lot on the outside - so much so that I have to put towels on the floor to catch the dripping water.
Is there some way we can solve this problem?
A.
When you talk of the toilet sweating, I assume you are referring to the toilet tank behind the bowl.

J.
Wayne Rabalais of the University of Houston.

Tests to Be Discussed
LEAD: The president of the United States Olympic Committee said in Washington yesterday that the Soviet Union and the United States, in an effort to expand their agreement on reciprocal steroid testing, would discuss setting up testing sites in each country for use by the other nation's testers.
The United States Olympic official, Robert Helmick, said he would like to see testing sites in Moscow staffed by American scientists and sites in the United States staffed by Soviet scientists.

LEAD: Jordan will ask the International Monetary Fund for a standby credit and is working on a general restructuring of its foreign debt, the central bank's deputy governor, Maher Shukri, said Tuesday.

Review/Dance; Bryan Hayes In 'Crossing'
LEAD: Dancegoers who saw Bryan Hayes's ''Crossing Slowly,'' as performed by Bryan Hayes and Dancers Monday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio might have found themselves wondering not what time it was, but what century.
As its title implied, this was a study in slow motion.
Although it lasted only 70 minutes, it seemed to take forever - and that remark is meant as praise.


School Board Praises Green for His First Year
LEAD: The Board of Education declared yesterday that Schools Chancellor Richard R. Green performed well in his first year and urged him to ''build on the record he had achieved,'' the board president, Robert F. Wagner Jr., said.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  In the first 20 days of February, net deposit outflows at the nation's savings and loan institutions were at a monthly rate of $5.2 billion, while in January the outflow was about $7 billion.
Bank Board officials said the report reflected some regained confidence by consumers in the industry.

LEAD: FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT enthusiasts can now collect something besides this year's biography.
It's ''Prairie House,'' a cassette tape of songs about the pioneering American architect.
While Wright so often compared architecture with music, this may not be quite the type he had in mind.

St. Simons Island Journal; A New Debate Is Raging In the 'Debatable Lands'
LEAD: Nearly 250 years ago it was a Spanish fleet of 30 ships at the mouth of the Frederica River that threatened Fort Frederica, then the southernmost outpost of the 13 original colonies.
It was near the fort, sandwiched between Spanish and English settlements in a buffer area called the ''Debatable Lands,'' that the English fought and defeated the Spanish in the Battle of Bloody Marsh in 1742.

LEAD: The Defense Department has begun to shape President Bush's new military budget without making cuts in the disputed plan to build a space shield against nuclear missiles, Pentagon officials said today.

WPP Group Reports Big Jump in Earnings
LEAD: WPP Group, the marketing communications conglomerate, said its 1988 earnings more than tripled, to $71.8 million, or $1.96 a share, from $23.7 million, or $1.08 a share, in 1987.
Gross revenues more than doubled, to $974.7 million in 1988 from $477.3 million in 1987.


Home Improvement
LEAD: ELECTRICITY in a house or apartment is supplied by paths of wiring called circuits.
By making a map of them, you can know at a glance which circuits serve which outlets.
You can also determine whether any circuits are overloaded, which can create a fire hazard.

Wider British Trade Gap
LEAD: Britain's merchandise trade deficit widened to $:2.09 billion, or $3.63 billion, in January, from a revised deficit of $:1.76 billion in December, the Government said today.
The January gap compared with a deficit of $:1.45 billion a year ago, the Department of Trade and Industry said.
The figures showed that exports totaled a record $:7.37 billion in January, but imports also set a record, at $:9.47 billion.

Topics of The Times; Why Shrink Democracy?
LEAD: Though registration drives have added hundreds of thousands of new names to New York City voter rolls, the total number of registrants isn't growing.
The reason: State law requires enrollment to be canceled if an individual hasn't voted in four years.
A new lawsuit by a coalition of civic and civil rights groups challenges that misguided policy.

Senate Confirms Sullivan and Watkins
LEAD: Dr.
Louis W. Sullivan easily won confirmation today as Secretary of Health and Human Services, with the Senate voting 98 to 1 to place the 55-year-old physician and educator in charge of the Government's largest agency.
The Senate then voted 99 to 0 to confirm James D. Watkins, a retired admiral and former Chief of Naval Operations, as Secretary of Energy.


Bridge
LEAD: One of the fundamentals of card play, as of life, is the need to search for small advantages or improvements that a lesser person might overlook.
A fine example is the diagramed deal, played in a recent Chicago game at the Cavendish Club in Manhattan.


Review/Theater; An Idyll Is Smashed In 'Nest'
LEAD: Marriage for Kurt and Martha is the sheerest bliss, despite the fact that Kurt's income as a truckdriver is limited.
In ''The Nest'' by Franz Xaver Kroetz, the two go through their daily routine.
When Kurt comes home from work, his wife automatically gives him a bottle of beer.
They have dinner and settle down with television, then convert their couch into a bed and go to sleep.


Weekends in Jail for Synagogue Fire
LEAD: A 16-year-old who was convicted of setting fire to a synagogue in Brooklyn last year was sentenced yesterday to spend weekends in jail and perform 200 hours of community service and was ordered to write an essay about the history of the Jewish people.


Mexico May Allow Vote by Nationals in U.S.
LEAD: As part of a sweeping overhaul of the country's electoral code, the Mexican Government is considering a politically explosive proposal that would grant voting rights to several million Mexican nationals living in the United States.

LEAD: More than 1,000 of the world's most prominent writers, publishers and booksellers appealed to governments today to act to insure that Iran withdraws its death threats against Salman Rushdie, the author of ''The Satanic Verses.''

Reviews/Music; Before the Modern Piano
LEAD: The Bach, Mozart and Schubert works that Radu Lupu played at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening were composed before the piano had evolved into its modern form.
But his performances were so deftly shaded and splendidly transparent that one could put the more historically appropriate sounds of the harpsichord and fortepiano out of mind with only the slightest twinge of guilt.

LEAD: Global production of coca, marijuana, opium poppies and hashish increased sharply in the last year, partly because of political and economic instability in drug-producing countries, the State Department reported today.

Secretary of State James Baker grudgingly sells stock worth millions.

Tower called Senator Bentsen at his home Monday night to ask for his support.

LEAD: Arkansas would pay $104 million over the next 10 years and encourage desegregation around the state under a proposed settlement in a six-year-old Federal court case, according to reports today in both Little Rock newspapers.

LEAD: THERE is a place not far from my house where people go to cheer up.

The place sells food.


The Poison's Foothold in the Food Chain
LEAD: Aflatoxin, a natural substance found in many foods around the world, is toxic to the liver and has been shown to cause cancer in test animals.
It is considered a particular threat to the food supply in developing countries.

American Express Bank
LEAD: The American Express Company said yesterday that Robert F. Smith would retire as chairman and chief executive of its banking subsidiary by July 1.
A replacement has not been named.
Mr.
Smith, 56 years old, joined American Express as senior president and treasurer in February 1981 and six months later was elected vice chairman of American Express Bank Ltd.

LEAD: Ever since the Panama Canal reduced Valparaiso to a minor spot on world sailing maps, its future has seemed as insecure as the houses clinging to its hillsides in perilous disequilibrium.


New Xerox Copiers
LEAD: The Xerox Corporation introduced new copiers today, including two low-volume models and a copier with a beveled edge that can make copies from books without ruining bindings.
The machines were displayed at the company's manufacturing center here.
The low-volume copiers, the 5012 and the 5014, make 12 copies a minute and represent Xerox's attempt to increase its presence in the low-volume market.


India Reduces Its Military Budget As Links With Neighbors Improve
LEAD: India has reduced its military budget for the first time this decade, an aide to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi said today.

Can your nomination make it in light of it?


Coach Leaves Hospital
LEAD: Norm Stewart, the coach at the University of Missouri, was released from Columbia Regional Hospital in Missouri Tuesday, two weeks after undergoing surgery for colon cancer and a diseased gallbladder.
Stewart walked out of the hospital, his physician, Dr.
Jay Ward, said. ''He's doing a little better each day,'' said Ward, who added that Stewart's convalescence will be six weeks to two months, removing any possibility that Stewart could coach in post-season play.

LEAD: The first payments from the Agent Orange settlement fund have been mailed to the families of 172 Vietnam veterans whose deaths were linked to the defoliant.

LEAD: Here we have it, plain, painful and perfidious, in a State Department report to the Congress of the United States:

LEAD: Although money market accounts at banks were designed to be competitive with money market mutual funds, the only similarity between the two these days is their name.


Adding Polish to Promise
LEAD: Dixieland Brass would be the early star of most racing seasons, certainly the focus of any other Florida Derby Day.
But on Saturday at Gulfstream Park, he will be a secondary attraction.

Henry Gerard Bruns, Broker, 84
LEAD: Henry Gerard Bruns, a retired investment broker and railroad executive, died Wednesday at his home in New London, N.H.
He was 84 years old and had lived in Montclair, N.J., before moving to New Hampshire in 1977.


Baby Taken in Foiled Robbery Is Recovered
LEAD: A 5-month-old baby, who was kidnapped after his parents crashed through a window in their apartment to escape a robbery attempt, was recovered yesterday at a Brooklyn subway station, where the police arrested a man who tried to collect a ransom.


12 EUROPE NATIONS TO BAN CHEMICALS THAT HARM OZONE
LEAD: In an unexpectedly strong move, the 12 European Community countries agreed today to eliminate by the end of the century their production and use of chemicals that harm the atmosphere's ozone shield.


Another Cost-Cutter To Head Phelps Dodge
LEAD: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the nation's largest copper producer, said yesterday that Douglas C. Yearly, an executive vice president, would become chairman and chief executive, replacing G. Robert Durham, who is retiring in May.


Garvey Resigns Post
LEAD: One week after two women said he had fathered their children, Steve Garvey, the former major leaguer, has resigned as a trustee at the University of San Diego.
Officials at the Roman Catholic university released a statement yesterday confirming Garvey's resignation but gave no reason.
Dan Petrie, a spokesman for Bishop Leo Maher, chairman of the university's board of trustees, said Garvey attended the board's annual retreat at La Quinta, Calif., last weekend and turned in his resignation after a talk with the bishop.


Bonn Asks Talks Now on Short-Range Arms
LEAD: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany called today for immediate East-West negotiations to cut short-range nuclear missiles.


Used Mercedes Warranties
LEAD: Mercedes-Benz of North America said today that it had begun issuing warranties on some of its used cars in an effort to support their resale prices.


Retailers Report a Strong February
LEAD: Many of the nation's largest retailers yesterday reported a strong sales increase for February, but some analysts said that rising interest rates might restrain consumer spending in coming months.

Koch Won't Oppose Challenge to Purge of Voters
LEAD: New York City officials, led by Mayor Edward I. Koch, said yesterday that they would not oppose a legal challenge to the removal from the voting rolls of 312,000 mostly black and Hispanic people who did not vote in the last four years.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Bankers Trust Co. appointed Allen D. Wheat chairman of its principal foreign subsidiary, Bankers Trust International Ltd.


Video Festival
LEAD: The Brooklyn Museum will begin its Eighth Annual Thomas A. Edison-Black Maria Film and Video Festival Sunday at 2 P.M.
The videos run from the purely artistic to documentaries on social injustice.
The program is free, with a suggested museum contribution: $3; students $1.50, and the elderly, $1.
The museum is at 200 Eastern Parkway, at Washington Avenue, in the Crown Heights section.


Other Shoe Dropping On Johnson
LEAD: Ben Johnson has already lost his Olympic gold medal for taking steroids.
His further punishment was slinking out of Seoul with the whole world watching.


Urban Developer Sells Zero Coupons
LEAD: The Urban Development Corporation is offering $155 million of zero-coupon debt securities in the taxable market through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

LEAD: ''Cargo X,'' which had its local premiere with the Merce Cunningham Dance Company on Wednesday night, is one of Mr.
Cunningham's mixtures of serenity and bemusement.


Airlines Plan to Add Service to Offset a Strike
LEAD: With a strike against Eastern Airlines threatened for 12:01 A.M.
Saturday, other airlines and Amtrak said today that they would step up service to offset any reduction in Eastern's 1,040 flights a day worldwide.

Review/Television; Could Hitler Have Won? A Look at His Mistakes
LEAD: The meat of ''How Hitler Lost the War'' is sandwiched between a stale account of the rise of the Nazi leader and a thick slab of cliches (''It is our obligation to remember so that it will never happen again.'') The 90-minute documentary on Channel 13, at 10:20 P.M.
Sunday, advances the argument that Germany would have won World War II if the Fuhrer had heeded the advice of his generals.

Shearson Unit May Be Sold

Reviews/Theater; Artist or Monster? The Life and Myth of Ezra Pound
LEAD: Of all the great contemporary literary figures, Ezra Pound is the most contradictory.
He was a poetic genius (by his measure and that of others) and an inspiration behind modernism in the arts - as well as a fanatical racist and anti-Semite.
In ''Incommunicado'' (at the Wilma Theater here), Tom Dulack makes a bold dramatic assault on Pound's outrageous life and myth.

LEAD: In the latest border hostilities between New York and New Jersey officials, state legislators here today introduced ''retaliatory'' bills to raise income taxes for some of the 100,000 people who live in New York but work in New Jersey.

LEAD: WITH interest rates rising, there is a great temptation for investors to run for cover, which is one reason mutual fund companies say withdrawals have been on the rise in both bond and stock funds since the markets began to weaken last month.

Review/Film; Nick Nolte As a King, Self-Made
LEAD: In John Milius's ''Farewell to the King,'' Nick Nolte plays Learoyd, a renegade American soldier who, having escaped the Japanese invaders of the Philippines in 1942, has somehow managed to sail to Borneo.
There, in rain forests that are trackless, beneath mountains that tower and beside waterfalls that cascade, he forges a kingdom by uniting primitive tribes that are innocents.

LEAD: Military-style assault rifles and short-barrel shotguns have become illegal here under a law that critics say has turned thousands of citizens into lawbreakers.

LEAD: In the broadest sweep yet this year, Federal savings and loan regulators today placed 37 insolvent institutions in six states under their direct control.

LEAD: A 24-year-old police officer was shot and killed early this morning in a shootout with a gunman on a street in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, officials said.

LEAD: Administrators of drug abuse programs in New York said yesterday that if a proposed liberalization of rules on the use of methadone was adopted, all of New York City's approximately 200,000 heroin addicts could be receiving daily doses of the synthetic narcotic in a matter of weeks.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 455 money market mutual funds increased by $1.63 billion, to $294.06 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The 138 institutional funds' assets decreased by $1.70 billion, to $72.73 billion.
Assets of the 224 general-purpose funds were up by $2.39 billion, to $95.19 billion.

U.S. AIDES CRITICAL OF SOVIETS ON IRAN
LEAD: State Department officials asserted today that the Soviet Union appeared to be trying to exploit the Salman Rushdie affair to improve ties with Iran and delay any Iranian reconciliation with the West.


Candidate for F.T.C.
LEAD: Janet D. Steiger, the chairman of the Postal Rate Commission, is considered the leading candidate for chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, which enforces antitrust laws, along with the Justice Department.
She would succeed Daniel Oliver, a conservative Republican whose term ended in September.


Cuomo Gets the Respect But Dangerfield, the Votes
LEAD: Asked to name the people they would most like to hear give a speech, students at the University of Florida here put Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo of New York among the top five - but declined to make him the No. 1 vote-getter, an honor that went to the comedian Rodney Dangerfield.


U.S. Agency Agrees Not to Single Out the Hispanic
LEAD: The Immigration and Naturalization Service, under a settlement reached in Federal District Court, has agreed that its agents will not single out Hispanic-looking people to see if they are illegal aliens.


Discover Card In Visa Link
LEAD: The credit card processor Visa U.S.A. has agreed to an electronic link with Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company's Discover card that could lead to greater acceptance of Discover by merchants, a Sears spokesman said today.


Review/Rock; Grim Metallic Tidings From 2 Bands
LEAD: Bulletins on corruption, war casualties, drug addiction, nuclear threats, embattled freedom of speech and homicidal rampages turn up regularly in the news.
They were also heard from the stage Wednesday when Metallica and Queensryche performed at the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., to a sold-out house filled with raised hands and fists.


Transcisco to Seek Sale of PLM Stake
LEAD: Transcisco Industries said it would seek to sell its 35.7 percent stake in PLM International Inc.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Transcisco said it believed it could get the best price for its stake by selling the shares of the financial-services concern in one block.

LEAD: Storehouse P.L.C. said Asher B. Edelman, the American takeover specialist, had raised his stake in the British retailing group to 7 percent from 6.1 percent.
Mr.
Edelman notified Storehouse that he had increased his holdings to 28.8 million shares, continuing the slow stake building begun late last year, the company said.

75 Boat People Flown Home in Effort to Reverse Tide
LEAD: Wearing new clothes and carrying bundles of small souvenirs of their brief life here, 75 Vietnamese boarded a jet for Hanoi today, volunteers in the first full-scale effort to return boat people to their own land.

LEAD: Labor Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole will outline a Bush Administration proposal on Friday to raise the minimum wage to $4.25 an hour over three years, but with a $3.35 hourly ''training wage'' for some new workers, Administration officials said today.

Just Like the Movie
LEAD: The President's choice of a nominee for a Cabinet-level position leads to division and controversy in the Senate.
He stands by the unpopular nominee.
He fights for confirmation.
Familiar?
It happened in Allen Drury's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel ''Advise and Consent.''


New York Pulling Out of 13 More Welfare Hotels
LEAD: With New York City moving ahead in its plan to stop using welfare hotels to shelter homeless families, Mayor Edward I. Koch announced yesterday that the use of 13 more hotels would be ended by September.


Two Yanks Are Injured
LEAD: The Yankees played an intrasquad game today before opening their exhibition schedule on Friday, but all it did was lengthen their injury list.


U.S. Calls on Sudan To Sign a Cease-Fire It Rejected Last Year
LEAD: The United States said today that the Sudanese Government should immediately accept a comprehensive cease-fire agreement that it spurned in December, and an American official warned that continued fighting there would lead to a ''tragic repetition'' of last year's famine.

At the Bar
LEAD: Baseball, sex and litigation.
They are three of America's national pastimes, and they are all on the docket of a Southern California lawyer named James McGee.


F.D.A. Approves the Use of an Experimental Drug for AIDS Patients' Eye Infections
LEAD: Under pressure from officials at the National Institutes of Health and from AIDS patients and their advocates, the Food and Drug Administration has decided to allow patients with the disease to receive an experimental drug for eye infections, even if they are not enrolled in clinical trials to test the drug.


Review/Art; Going Beyond Slickness: Sculptors Get Back to Basics
LEAD: IN a season when the New York art world may seem to be wrapped in slick surfaces, status and money, three surprising sculpture shows, in three different boroughs, zero in on a more naked and physical reality.
Each show is, in a way, exclusive.
All 11 artists in one are black; all six artists in another are women; in the third, the four artists are men.


7 Companies Given Awards
LEAD: The Council on Economic Priorities, a nonprofit research organization, presented its third annual America's Corporate Conscience Awards last night to five corporations that it regards as exemplifying corporate social responsibility.
Two other companies received honorable mention.


Review/Film; High-School Romance
LEAD: About 20 minutes into ''Dream a Little Dream,'' a couple of teen-agers, Bobby and Lainie (Corey Feldman and Meredith Salenger), collide at high speed.
As they lie unconscious, Bobby absorbs the spirit or persona of a mystically inclined neighbor (Jason Robards) and Lainie may be imbued with the qualities of his wife (Piper Laurie), though the movie is not clear on that point.

Dividend Is Declared By Shaklee
LEAD: The Shaklee Corporation, a target of takeover speculation, today declared an extraordinary cash dividend of $20 per share of its common stock.
The action was seen as a way of rewarding company shareholders and discouraging takeover interest in the company.


AT THE MOVIES
LEAD:  A Happy Day


Cellist and Pianist
LEAD: Antonio Meneses, the cellist, and Cecile Licad, the pianist, are to play Mendelssohn's Sonata No. 2 in D (Op. 58), Britten's Sonata in C (Op. 65) and the Brahms Sonata No. 2 in F (Op. 99) tonight at 8 o'clock at Weill Recital Hall.
Mr.
Meneses, who is from Brazil, won the gold medal at the 1982 Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow.


Land Sought as Buffer Around Parks
LEAD: With conservationists saying the days of creating large new national parks in the lower 48 states are largely over, nature preservation groups have stepped up a campaign to protect areas around existing parks or add smaller parcels to the wilderness system.

Flag Exhibit Upheld In Chicago by Judge
LEAD: A Cook County Circuit Court judge ruled today that an American flag spread on a gallery floor could remain on display at the School of the Art Institute here.


Sallie Mae to Sell Nonvoting Shares
LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, said it expects to sell two million nonvoting common shares through a public offering in the United States domestic market and Euromarket after Monday.


Economic Scene; The Darker Side Of the Budget Gap
LEAD: THE National Economic Commission, created by Congress in the wake of the 1987 stock market crash in hopes of working out a bipartisan solution to the budget problem, died this week.
It was the victim of electoral and post-election politics and, according to commission members, an inability to ''horse-trade'' in private to reach compromise agreements.


Julius L. Tucker, Radio-TV Minister, 92
LEAD: The Rev.
Julius Lafayette Tucker, a radio and television minister, died Tuesday.
He was 92 years old.

Review/Art; After All These Years, Still Hoping to Shock
LEAD: Like so many artists who emerged in Europe and the United States around 1960, Hermann Nitsch has based a career on taking the action in action paintings to extremes - on canvas, in performance and in real life.
In 1959, when he was 21 years old, this Austrian artist christened his activities the Orgies Mysteries Theater, making the announcement in a rented beer hall in Vienna to an audience of one.

Boat People in Hong Kong Are First to Return to Vietnam


Baker's Staff Incomplete 6 Weeks Into Bush Era
LEAD: Six weeks into the Bush Administration, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d still does not have much of his senior foreign-policy team in place.
But whose fault is it?
State Department veterans and leading members of Congress say that Mr.
Baker and his aides have been slow in making crucial appointments - particularly those of assistant secretaries for various geographical regions - and in pushing the paperwork for confirmation through the bureaucracy.


France Asks Slower Buying of Iranian Oil
LEAD: France quietly signaled its major oil companies today to slow the purchase of Iranian oil, according to the French news agency and oil industry sources here.
It thus apparently joins a move by Japan, which has ordered similar cutbacks.


Flipping for Dollars
LEAD: The Cincinnati Reds settled a contract dispute with Kal Daniels yesterday when the team's owner, Marge Schott, flipped a coin in the parking lot of the training complex in Florida and the outfielder won.
Jon Braude, a Reds spokesman, said that Schott had called heads but that the coin had come up tails.


Jail Influx Brings Plan For 2 Barges
LEAD: With a surge of arrests, most of them on drug charges, adding 200 inmates a week to New York City's overcrowded jails, the City Correction Department proposed yesterday a package of emergency measures that include housing prisoners on barges moored on both sides of Manhattan by the early summer.


The Old Vices Are Out And New Morality Is In
LEAD: Raymond Strother, a Democratic political consultant, recalls wistfully that the rules of good behavior in politics used to be very simple.


Making and Honoring History
LEAD: The debate over the Tower nomination carried a grim sense of history, a sense underscored as Congress celebrated its Bicentennial.

A Son's Ambitions and a Father's Doubts
LEAD: The father stood a few feet away from the son, who stepped to the top of the pitcher's mound, stared toward home plate and then heaved one pitch after another to a man wearing a catcher's mitt.
The father neither moved nor spoke.
Sunglasses hid his eyes and his emotions.
After a few minutes, he walked away without a word.

LEAD: Phil Esposito, the general manager of the Rangers, announced yesterday that Marcel Dionne would remain with the organization's minor league team in Denver until next Monday.
Esposito, who admitted that the latest decision merely postponed an inevitable one about the future of Dionne, said he was considering a wide range of options.

Jaguar Pay Offer Fails
LEAD: Workers at Jaguar P.L.C., the British luxury car maker, have narrowly rejected a pay offer by the company and have scheduled a ban on overtime starting this weekend and weekly one-day strikes after Monday.


I.R.S. Grace Period Satisfies Few Critics of Benefits Rule
LEAD: The Internal Revenue Service said today that the nation's three and a half million employers have until July 1 to begin complying with an ambitious new law covering benefit plans, and it said no penalties would be imposed this year so long as honest efforts to comply with the measure are made.


Botha to Resume Duties Later This Month
LEAD: President P. W. Botha, who is recovering from a stroke suffered six weeks ago, today squelched speculation about his possible retirement by disclosing that he plans to resume his official duties later this month.


COURT TOLD NORTH AIDED REBELS IN '85
LEAD: A former Central Intelligence Agency operative testified today that he took part in a June 1985 meeting in Miami in which Oliver L. North helped contra leaders plan their war against the Nicaraguan government.

Cone and Mets Settle
LEAD: David Cone, who got into a salary dispute with the Mets after winning 20 games last season, agreed today to sign for $332,500, two days after the Mets threatened to renew his contract unilaterally at $310,000. ''We met halfway,'' the 26-year-old pitcher said. ''That's all I can ask.
And once I sign, it's behind me.


West Germans Raid Spy Ring That Violated U.S. Computers
LEAD: The West German police said yesterday that they had broken up a major computer spy ring that worked with Soviet intelligence agents to steal United States military computer passwords, software and other data.
Five people were arrested as investigators searched more than 15 houses and apartments in three cities.

Britain, in Talk Aimed at Iran, Calls Rushdie Book Offensive
LEAD: Two days after Iran threatened to break off diplomatic relations, Britain's Foreign Secretary today sharply distanced the Government from Salman Rushdie's novel ''The Satanic Verses.'' He said the book was not only offensive to Muslims but had also compared Britain to Hitler's Germany.

New-Home Sales Up 4.9% In January
LEAD: Sales of new single-family homes increased by 4.9 percent in January, the biggest gain in seven months, but analysts said the rise resulted in part from unusually mild winter weather.


Security Council Post
LEAD: Arnold Kanter, a former State Department official, has been chosen as the senior director on the National Security Council staff for arms control and defense policy.


Charges Filed
LEAD: Formal accusations were filed yesterday by the racing board in California against D. Wayne Lukas and Laz Barrera, who each train a horse that tested positive for cocaine.
Lukas and Barrera are expected to have a hearing within 15 days before an administrative law judge, who will then issue non-binding recommendations to the state board.

Distinctive Jazz From Two Singers
LEAD: Of all the musical arts, singing is the most personal.
The full brunt of a narrative sung by a person on stage, eyes flashing with hidden tales of jealousy or joy, can land in the lap of an audience.
This weekend, two of jazz's most distinct singers - Abbey Lincoln and Leon Thomas - both eclectics who have seen jazz move from the big-band era into more political and varied contexts, will be performing rare concerts.


New Rail Line to Atlantic City
LEAD: Amtrak will open the first major new rail route in its 18-year history when it begins service to Atlantic City on May 23.
The Atlantic City Express will include five round trips on weekdays and several more on weekends, said Amtrak's vice president of marketing, Timothy P. Gardner.
One direct line will originate in Washington and another will start in New York, Mr.


Helmick Sees a Silver Lining
LEAD: The president of the United States Olympic Committee, Robert Helmick, said yesterday that the testimony of Ben Johnson's coach about the sprinter's use of performance-enhancing substances might have a positive effect on the sport.

Gems and Minerals
LEAD: ''A Festival of Gems, Jewelry, Minerals and Fossils'' will take place at the New York State Armory, 125 West 14th Street, today and tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. and Sunday from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.
Contemporary and estate jewelry will be on display and can be purchased; the Lapidary and Gem Society of New York will demonstrate stone cutting and gem faceting.

Paris Board Picks Globex
LEAD: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange announced today that the futures exchange in Paris had agreed to join Globex, the after-hours trading system recently approved for financial futures markets.


COMPANY NEWS;
LEAD: A United States Bankruptcy Court judge approved a $4 million agreement for Yugo America Inc., the importer of the Yugoslav-made minicars that has filed for bankruptcy protection.
The accord, approved by Judge Vincent J. Commisa, replaces an interim pact and is expected to keep Yugo operating for four months.

LEAD: Grey Advertising said yesterday that it would show its well-publicized 90-second television spots for the Mitsubishi Eclipse on three cable networks - WTBS, MTV and the Arts and Entertainment Network.


4 Arab Guerrillas Slain By Israelis in Lebanon
LEAD: Israeli troops patrolling in south Lebanon this morning shot and killed four Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas making their way to the Israeli border, the army said.


F.B.I. Report on Tower Provokes Bitterness as Senate Opens Debate
LEAD: The dispute over the Federal Bureau of Investigation's report on John G. Tower erupted with extraordinary bitterness today as the Senate began debate over his nomination as Secretary of Defense.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  GOLF  Rain Suspends Play: Only half of the 144 golfers in the $700,000 Honda Classic were able to complete their first rounds yesterday before thunderstorms suspended play with 72 players on the course.

Carlyle Group Lifts Stake in Fairchild
LEAD: The Carlyle Group, a Washington investment firm, has raised its stake in Fairchild Industries to 13.5 percent from 9.9 percent.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Carlyle said that ''based upon a review of available alternatives,'' it believed Fairchild's stock was an attractive investment at current market prices.


Fear Rules the Salvadoran Refugees
LEAD: When darkness descends on these rugged mountain highlands, the Salvadoran refugees encamped here can look down across the Honduran-Salvadoran border to see what they have fled.

Robert M. Grosse, Investment Banker, 52
LEAD: Robert M. Grosse, an investment banker, died of heart failure Sunday at his home in Bondville, Vt.
He was 52 years old and also had a home in Scarsdale, N.Y.


Three Young Singers Make Show Tunes Hum
LEAD: IF the American musical comedy is an endangered species, its precarious state cannot be attributed to a shortage of talented singers.
Not only in New York, but around the country where light-opera companies and community theaters perpetuate the classic shows of Broadway's golden age, young performers are emerging who have been bitten hard by the musical-theater bug.


Review/Opera; 'Telemacco,' Gluck Rarity
LEAD: Without New York's expansive cultural atmosphere, splendid events like Gluck's ''Telemacco'' at Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon might not happen.
In this concert version by Bart Folse's Pro Arte Chorale and La Stravaganza Classical Orchestra, all the necessary instincts for survival in a very competitive concert business have found the right subject and the proper means.

SOLIDARITY PLANS TO JOIN THE REGIME IN ASKING DEBT AID
LEAD: Negotiators for the Government and the Solidarity union have agreed in principle to issue a joint appeal for relief of Poland's crushing foreign debt, diplomats and members of the two negotiating teams said today.
Such a plea that would challenge Western governments to lift the last vestiges of the financial quarantine imposed after martial law was declared seven years ago.

Caracas Seethes, Washington Snoozes
LEAD: ''The I.M.F. set fire to the streets of Caracas,'' screamed a Venezuelan newspaper this week as riots left hundreds dead in what had been one of Latin America's most stable democracies.


Slow Bangladesh Growth
LEAD: Bangladesh will be even poorer next year as economic growth slows because of flooding and a trade imbalance, the World Bank reported this week.
It said the economy would grow only 1.2 percent in the fiscal year that began last July 1.

Review/Art; Jean Helion, An Unsung Frenchman
LEAD: Too few people know Jean Helion's work, but those who do tend to think of it as a puzzlement.
Helion's career divides into two parts, the first his activity as a leader of the abstract art movement in Paris during the 1930's, the second his conversion to representational painting during the 40's, a phase that continued until his death in 1987 at the age of 83.

Reviews/Theater; When One Tenor Is Much Like Another
LEAD: A farce should be cleverly built, energetically directed and buoyantly acted, but there is one thing it absolutely must be: consistently funny.
As staged by Jerry Zaks and performed by a cast led by Philip Bosco and Victor Garber, ''Lend Me a Tenor,'' the jolly play by Ken Ludwig at the Royale, is an impeccable example of how to construct and mount a farce -up to a point.


Buyout for Sherrill
LEAD: Jackie Sherrill, the former Texas A&amp;M athletic director and football coach, received more than $500,000 and a house when he resigned with his program on probation last Dec. 12, the university said yesterday.
The school said it had agreed to pay Sherrill's corporation, J.S.J.S.
Inc. of Pennsylvania, $542,000 in cash to buy out his contract.

John P. McGrath, 82, Lawyer, Banker and Developer, Is Dead
LEAD: John P. McGrath, a lawyer, banker and real-estate developer who served as New York City's Corporation Counsel and as a member of the Waterfront Commission of New York and New Jersey, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness.
He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''We do understand that the book itself has been found deeply offensive by people of the Muslim faith.
We can understand why it has been criticized.
It is a book that is offensive in many other ways as well.
We are not upholding the right of freedom to speak because we agree with the book.''  - Sir Geoffrey Howe, Britain's Foreign Secretary, speaking about ''The Satanic Verses.

LEAD: In the early hours of Nov. 11, the police arrested a Queens woman, saying she had planted a bomb at the Norwalk headquarters of the United States Surgical Corporation.
The bomb plot - called a protest against the company's use of dogs in surgical training - was quickly condemned by the company as an example of growing fanaticism in the animal-rights movement.

Car Dealers Lose Ruling
LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission said today that Detroit-area auto dealers broke Federal antitrust laws by agreeing among themselves to close showrooms on Saturdays and most weekday evenings.
The dealers were ordered to remain open 64 hours each week for a year.

LEAD: Georgia's highest court, relying on a recent United States Supreme Court decision on affirmative action, today overturned a widely copied program that has guided Atlanta construction contracts to minority groups.

Unit of G.M. Signs Pact With Hewlett
LEAD: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company signed an agreement to develop new integrated computer products.

Houston Journal; In the Eye of a Storm, Oasis of Peace and Quiet
LEAD: Shirley Johnson lives in a dark, cramped two-bedroom apartment with her two children and two nieces.
It is one of a thousand such apartments in Allen Parkway Village, a 37-acre low-income housing complex that is a maze of squat brick buildings and bare playgrounds.
Downtown is a short walk across a road.

Reviews/Film; Of Butchers and Love
LEAD: Meat obviously means a lot to Malcolm Mowbray, whose 1985 ''A Private Function'' was about a purloined pig and whose new comedy, ''Out Cold,'' has as its principal setting a butcher shop.
But Mr.
Mowbray's tastes are more sophisticated than they may sound. ''Out Cold,'' which opens today at the Criterion Center and other theaters, is a droll, clever, essentially British comedy that happens, almost by accident, to be set in California, a place for which Mr.


Reviews/Film; At War With Faith
LEAD: When Maurice Pialat approaches more psychological subjects, as he has in such films as ''A Nos Amours,'' ''Loulou'' and ''Police,'' his deceptively straightforward manner and his ability to suspend judgment can have the look of naturalism (though his scrutiny is so keen that it becomes extraordinarily penetrating over a period of time).

Review/Film; Melodrama, 'Heart of Midnight'
LEAD: ''Heart of Midnight'' is a suspense melodrama that makes even less sense than its title.
It's about - and seen through the eyes of - a young woman who may or may not be crazy.
This gives the director license to be bizarre without having to justify anything.


Safer Cigarettes
LEAD: Premier, RJR Nabisco's smokeless, ashless, tarless cigarette, has gone up in smoke.
Sales in two test markets fell far short of expectations and the financially pressed tobacco giant was unwilling to risk millions in search of a market.

Sytek to Hughes
LEAD: Sytek Inc., which produces computer networks for large companies, agreed to be acquired by the Hughes Aircraft Company, a unit of the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation.
Sytek, a private company based in Mountain View, Calif., is 57 percent owned by the General Instrument Corporation.
General Instrument said it would receive about $50 million for its stake.

LEAD: A multi-racial coalition of New York University Law School students, concerned about a series of racial incidents on the campus, are holding sit-ins and rallies that they vow will continue until their demands for a better climate for minority group members are met.


Marvin A. Block, 86, Expert on Alcoholism
LEAD: Dr.
Marvin A. Block, professor emeritus at the State University of New York at Buffalo and an early advocate of medical treatment for alcoholics, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Buffalo General Hospital.
He was 86 years old and lived in Buffalo.

LEAD: A man who said he swallowed seven grams of cocaine to avoid arrest died Wednesday of an overdose two hours later, the police reported today.
He was identified as Samuel M. McBeth, 36 years old, of Fostoria.

LEAD: New York's Department of City Planning proposes to close a loophole that has allowed builders in all boroughs but Manhattan to fudge on floor area allowances.

LEAD: Industry and Government officials are expressing increasing concern over the erosion of the little-known but crucial American industry that supplies the silicon wafers, etching equipment and other machinery and materials used in making computer chips.

Johnson's Coach Casts Doubt On Sprinter's World Record
LEAD: Ben Johnson's coach testified today that anabolic steroids were a major component of the sprinter's training program leading to the 1987 world track and field championships in Rome, where Johnson set a world record in winning the 100-meter dash.


Shamrock Lawsuit
LEAD: Shamrock Holdings Inc. filed a lawsuit in United States District Court in Delaware against the Polaroid Corporation's plan to buy back $1.1 billion in stock.
The suit contends that Polaroid has given its shareholders misleading information about its future earnings and possible damage payments arising from the patent-infringements case with the Eastman Kodak Company.

LEAD: Following the lead of the two larger American automobile makers, the Chrysler Corporation raised its annual cash dividend today by 20 percent.

LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, also known as Freddie Mac, is making its first offering of pass-through certificates of participation backed by loans for new and used mobile homes.


John A. Michaels, Stockbroker, 47
LEAD: John A. Michaels, a stockbroker and a managing director of the Kidder, Peabody Group Inc., died of heart failure Tuesday at New York Hospital.
He was 47 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.


Champion Retiring
LEAD: Dmitri Bilozerchev, a star gymnast in the Soviet Union, has decided to bow out of competitive sports, according to a report in Tass, the official Soviet news agency.
The 22-year-old Olympic champion was quoted as saying that throughout his 15-year career he has been under constant psychological and physical strain and has been plagued by injuries.


Dollar Strengthens in U.S. While Gold Prices Retreat
LEAD: The dollar strengthened against most major currencies in thin trading yesterday after turning mixed overseas.

LEAD: Breaking an eight-year taboo, a Soviet publication has printed a long and surprisingly amiable interview with Lech Walesa, the Polish labor leader who was regularly excoriated in the Soviet press before Mikhail S. Gorbachev became the Soviet leader.

LEAD: In Senate hearings that ended today, William J. Bennett faced nearly as many questions about his outspoken stands in his previous Cabinet post as about his goals in leading the fight against drugs.

Cuomo Appoints Judge to Appellate Bench
LEAD: Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo today named New York State's Chief Administrative Judge, Albert M. Rosenblatt, to be a justice on the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.


Gooden Suit Settled
LEAD: Dwight Gooden of the Mets filed two lawsuits in connection with his arrest for assault in Tampa, Fla., on Dec. 13, 1986.
One was settled this week when Tampa General Hospital said it would pay Gooden a sum less than $10,000 for releasing information on his blood-alcohol level, an action Gooden said ruined his chances for commercial endorsements and hurt his reputation.


School Board Elections Draw Few New Faces
LEAD: Despite efforts by New York City school and community leaders to encourage more people to seek election to community school boards, only 668 candidates have filed qualifying petitions to run, virtually the same number as for the last election, three years ago.


Oglivie Out 2 Months
LEAD: Ben Oglivie, a former outfielder for Milwaukee who spent the last two seasons playing in Japan, was attempting a comeback with the Brewers this spring.
But the 40-year-old Oglivie injured his right knee in a workout on Tuesday and learned yesterday that he would miss the rest of spring training while undergoing two months of rehabilitation.(


Pechiney Charge Seen
LEAD: Max Theret, a financier close to the governing Socialist Party, was charged today with insider trading in connection with the $1.25 billion takeover of the American company Triangle Industries by a French state-owned company, Pechiney, judicial sources said today.


A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown
LEAD: Last summer a group of ethnic Chinese from Vietnam threw a bomb loaded with .22-caliber bullets at a police car on Canal Street in Chinatown, slightly injuring two officers.
The bomb was retaliation for the arrest of several local merchants for selling counterfeit Rolex watches, the authorities said.

LEAD: The armed forces, especially the Army, are experiencing a shortage of Roman Catholic chaplains that appears to be more severe than the shortage of Catholic priests in civilian life, according to spokesmen for the Army, Navy and Air Force.

LEAD: *
Acceptance Insurance Holdings Inc., Omaha, and KCP Holding Co., a privately held company, reached a preliminary agreement to merge, with Acceptance being the surviving company.

Patents; Melanin in Sun Lotion
LEAD: Frances C. Gaskin, a nursing teacher in Albany, has developed a sun-tanning lotion incorporating melanin, the skin pigment that absorbs ultraviolet rays.
Dermatologists have long known that melanin can protect the skin, but Ms.
Gaskin said no one had determined how to dissolve the compound to incorporate it into a cosmetic composition.

LEAD: In recent decades, refrigerators have gotten bigger, more stylish and - since the mid-1970's at least -more energy efficient as well.
But a growing conflict between rules intended to improve the energy efficiency of appliances and measures to protect the earth's ozone layer may produce a new generation of more costly, less convenient refrigerators and freezers in the 1990's.

Experience, Not Rules, Guided United Jet's Crew
LEAD: United Airlines Flight 811 from Honolulu was between 22,000 and 23,000 feet, passing through thunderstorms, clouds and lightning, but otherwise everything was normal.
Then a section of the right side ripped away from the Boeing 747 jumbo jet, and Capt.
David M. Cronin and his crew had to put a career's worth of flying experience and judgment into the next 18 minutes.

Meeting Postponed By Pennwalt Board
LEAD: The Pennwalt Corporation disclosed that its board of directors had voted to postpone the company's annual meeting, which had been scheduled for the last week of April.
Pennwalt is trying to fend off a hostile $850 million bid from Centaur Partners, a New York investment firm.
Centaur has requested that Pennwalt call a special meeting of its shareholders on March 30, so that it can try to place its own directors on the company's board.


Suitor Seeks De Laurentiis
LEAD: Carolco Pictures Inc. said yesterday that it was offering to buy the De Laurentiis Entertainment Group.
No terms were disclosed.

Review/Theater; A Love Story Set in Stalin's Russia
LEAD: ''The Paper Gramophone,'' which is having its American premiere at Hartford Stage, is both an artifact of Stalinist Russia and a gentle love story about the purity that can survive in a repressive environment.
Given its dramatic limitations, it is a touching evocation of a young woman's attempt to reach beyond despair to a kind of idealism.

LEAD: Five former Metro-North Commuter Railroad police officers involved in making a videotape at Grand Central Terminal in which nudity was shown and racial slurs heard have been divested of their police powers.

LEAD: The caption of a picture from The Associated Press on Thursday, about ethnic strife in Yugoslavia, misidentified the flag carried by a Serbian youth outside Parliament.
It was the flag of the Yugoslav republic of Serbia, not the Yugoslav national flag.

North Defense Allowed Inquiry on Superiors
LEAD: The judge in the trial of Oliver L. North said today that defense lawyers could explore the roles of Ronald Reagan and George Bush in aiding the Nicaraguan rebels so that Mr.
North could prove his contention that his activities were sanctioned by his superiors.


Soviet Wheat Purchase
LEAD: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 485,000 metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department said Thursday.
Melvin E. Sims, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said the wheat was part of an authorization on Jan. 25 of more than two million tons under the Export Enhancement Program.


Patents; Drug Patch on the Body Is Powered by a Battery
LEAD: By adding a small jolt of electric current to the natural process of osmosis, a Long Island entrepreneuer, Dan Sibalis, has developed what he calls a programmable drug patch.


EASTERN LINES UP NEW WORK FORCE
LEAD: Officials of Eastern Airlines said yesterday that the company would contract out much of the maintenance on its airplanes to independent companies to help deal with the strike by its machinists' union.


Iran Rebuffs Britain on Rushdie's Novel
LEAD: Iran today rejected conciliatory comments by Britain's Foreign Secretary in the dispute over the novel ''The Satanic Verses,'' dismissing the remarks as ''playing with words.''


Review/Dance; Cheryl Jones in Feld's 'Echo'
LEAD: Cheryl Jones, one of the most affecting dancers of the Feld Ballet, returned to the company on Wednesday in the solo work ''Echo,'' and gave a performance of memorable lyricism and nuance.
Miss Jones, who had been on a leave of absence from the company, was the dancer for whom Eliot Feld created ''Echo'' in 1986.

Norman Scott, determined that he had torn cartilage in his right knee.


Trying to Make Books Fun on TV
LEAD: Over the years, television seems to have settled on two ways of dealing with books and authors on camera: 1.Flash the book jacket and then quickly, before even the fastest zapper in the home audience can reach for the remote control, change the subject. 2.Ask the author to talk about the book and watch the ratings dive.

Lawyers Against Homelessness
LEAD: The once-startling idea that poor people need legal counsel has become nearly a settled value in modern society, yet every day in every city the courts order evictions of people who don't have lawyers and can't afford them.
Many of these tenants have valid legal defenses but the housing courts enter eviction decrees anyway, often not realizing that the law favors the tenant.

LEAD: The Bush Administration, other governments and commercial banks are preparing to grant Venezuela close to $2 billion in emergency loans to help the country weather an economic crisis that has brought rioting and killing to Caracas, government and banking officials said today.

LEAD: The Government's main economic-forecasting index climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in January, the second consecutive sizable increase, the Commerce Department reported today.

A Late-Night-Cab Tip For Penn Station Users
LEAD: To the Editor:


Fix the Thrifts, or Pay and Pay
LEAD: How much will it cost to clean up the savings and loan mess?
The best answer at this point is a bundle, and it will be higher still if the thrifts continue to prevail with the help of their pals in Congress.
Rather than haggle over the cost, it is far more important that Congress move quickly to reshape the thrift business.

Takeover Talk Spurs Lockheed
LEAD: The Lockheed Corporation's stock jumped yesterday after Business Week magazine reported its aerospace rival, the Boeing Company, might try to buy the company.
The ''Inside Wall Street'' column in the March 13 issue of the magazine, published late Thursday, quoted unidentified sources as saying Boeing is keenly interested in Lockheed's enormous military contracting business.


Baker Plea for Interim Contra Aid Evokes the Skepticism of Congress
LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d urged Congress today to continue aiding the Nicaraguan guerrillas, but Democratic lawmakers and Central American diplomats said the proposal seemed to conflict with a regional peace agreement that calls for disbanding the contras.


Following His Father
LEAD: John Kelly, son of the late Dan Kelly, will take his father's place as a play-by-play announcer for the St.
Louis Blues in their home game against the Detroit Red Wings today, and may become a regular broadcaster for the team next season.
Dan Kelly described Blues games for 20 years before his death last month.


Coniston Revises TW Services Offer
LEAD: Coniston Partners said it was dropping a key condition from its $1.4 billion offer for TW Services Inc. and said it planned to wage a proxy fight for seats on the food services company's board.
Paul E. Tierney Jr., a Coniston Partner principal, said in a letter to TW Services' chairman, Frank L. Salizzoni, that his group was dropping as a condition of its $29-a-share offer that the TW board approve the proposed merger.

Patents; Cornea Tool For Severe Myopia Cases
LEAD: David M. Lieberman, an eye surgeon at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn, has invented a tool to cut microscopic grooves in the cornea of the eye and, he said, correct the most severe cases of near-sightedness for the first time.


Hotels Letting Guests Choose Checkout Times
LEAD: The bane of many hotel guests is the early hour at which they must check out of their rooms so the hotel can get them ready for the next occupants.
Those catching evening planes after business meetings or anxious to freshen up before the end of the day are among the people particularly inconvenienced by normal checkout hours, usually from 11 A.M.

He was 60 years old.

N.B.A. Fines Mahorn
LEAD: Rick Mahorn of the Pistons has been fined $5,000 by the National Basketball Association for elbowing Mark Price of the Cleveland Cavaliers in the head in a game Detroit won Tuesday, the league announced yesterday. ''Throwing an elbow can be just as damaging as throwing a punch, and if it is deliberate, the penalties will be just as severe,'' said Rod Thorn, a league vice president.


Historical Society Names Head of Museum
LEAD: The New-York Historical Society has named Holly Hotchner to a new position as the director of its museum.
The appointment is part of an administrative reorganization of the society, which was shaken last summer by disclosures that its finances had been mismanaged and some of its paintings and manuscripts had deteriorated in storage.

LEAD: A crowded ferry capsized today in southern Bangladesh, and least 23 people were drowned, news reports said.

Three bodies were recovered from the hull of the ferry after rescue teams hauled the boat out of the swift currents of the Kancha River, the United News of Bangladesh said.

Upper West Side
LEAD: To the Editor:


Ex-Migrant Worker Struggles to Keep Farm Museum Alive
LEAD: WENTWORTH T. PHILLIPS said he had always banked on simple basics like self-sufficiency and knowing the skills of the laboring class to make it in life.
Based on those tenets, he founded the Bloomfield Farm Implement Museum in 1980.
As he will explain over and over, he started his museum with ''the kids, the kids, the kids,'' especially inner-city children, in mind.

Laying Floor Tiles
LEAD: RESILIENT floor tiles made of vinyl, asphalt or cork are easier to apply than many other types of finish flooring.
Little skill is required to attach them, and, because the tiles are manageable in size - most are 12 inches or less on each side - trimming is less of a chore than it is with sheet vinyl or carpeting.

LEAD: To the Editor:


CORRECTION
LEAD: In an article last Sunday about ''Day One,'' a TV drama about the building of the first atomic bomb, James F. Brynes was misidentified, and his involvement in the decision to drop the bomb on Japan was incorrectly described.
He was Secretary of State under President Truman and argued in favor of using the bomb.

LEAD: DAVID ROSINSKY, a dancer, sometimes twirls his partner, Michele Evans, so that her body barely skims the floor.
At other times, he spins her above his head in a move that the two call the ''helicopter.'' In another move, Mrs.
Evans seems to kneel on Mr.
Rosinky's shoulder. ''I don't know what to call that, but it's interesting,'' Mr.


Not So Mythical
LEAD: To the Editor:


'Carrie's Choice,' A World Premiere
LEAD: ONE of the most rewarding aspects of the season at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale is that it always includes a world premiere.


PASTIMES: AROUND THE GARDEN
LEAD: For This Week: Prune, prune, prune, everything from grapevines, to summer-flowering shrubs to overgrown hedges to small trees; leave the tending of large shade trees to professional arborists who have the ropes, saws, equipment and knowledge to tend them.
Keep up with seed planting indoors.
Finish planning the garden.


QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Should The Mets Trade Strawberry?
LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.


Zapping A Season Of Opera
LEAD: If life were as easily controlled as a movie on the VCR, who could resist the urge to toy with those buttons?
Reverse and fast forward would probably get the most play, though an occasional Faust might opt for the stop mode or at least the slo-mo.
Looking back at the new productions offered this season by the Metropolitan Opera, I myself find the erase button most tempting.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Track and Field  World Marks Tumble: Paul Ereng of Kenya, the Olympic champion, broke Sebastian Coe's six-year-old world mark in the men's 800 meters yesterday, and Javier Sotomayor of Cuba set a world record in the men's high jump at the world indoor championships in Budapest.
Two other world marks also fell: Elly van Hulst of the Netherlands slashed nearly six seconds off the women's 3,000-meter best and Kerry Saxby of Australia lowered the mark in the women's 3,000-meter walk.


CLARA'S GIFT 109 pp. New York: Penguin Books. Paper, $6.95.
LEAD: Among contemporary American writers there are many accomplished stylists, for ours is an age of intense literary activity, much idiosyncratic virtuosity and invention.
The general assumption may be that ''realism'' is not an experimental literary convention but simply ''the way things are''; but practicing writers know that all genres, all visions, all artful employments of language are conventions, freely available to the virtuoso.

J.

Barely Bilingual
LEAD: To the Editor: ''Abroad And Barely Bilingual'' described my delight mixed with trepidation when among strange tongues where I make it a rule always to carry a piece of paper in my pocket bearing the name of my hotel.
This served me well in downtown Tashkent when boarding a trolley I learned by agitated gestures of the ticket taker after reading the name of my hotel, that I was on the right trolley going in the wrong direction.

LEAD: An article last Sunday about the founding congress of the first Soviet bar association referred incorrectly to the name it selected.
The congress adopted an amendment changing the name from the Soviet Advocates' Association to the Soviet Advocates'


Review/Recital; A Pianist From Brazil
LEAD: Claudio Richerme, a Brazilian pianist, devoted most of his Thursday-evening program at Weill Recital Hall to music by two of his country's best-known composers, Mozart Camargo Guarnieri and Heitor Villa-Lobos.


Injured Rangers Stay on Top
LEAD: For the Rangers, the injuries have hit hard and often recently, depleting their defense and disarming their attack.
Their consolation has been that for all their recent injuries, there has been almost no damage to their position in the Patrick Division.


Correction
LEAD: A discography on page 27 of the Arts and Leisure section today with an article about the pianist Vladimir Feltsman misidentifies the orchestra and conductor for a Prokofiev series on CBS Masterworks, and the works involved.
The recordings, of the First and Second Concertos, are by the London Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Michael Tilson Thomas.


Review/Theater; Oedipus and Dionysus, Set to Music
LEAD: There may be more to Dionysian ecstasy than meets the eye in Ellen Stewart's ''Dionysus Filius Dei,'' performed by the Great Jones Repertory Company at La Mama.
But since there are no words in this ''dance opera'' except a minimal vocal score in Greek provided by Elizabeth Swados, what eludes the eye often escapes comprehension and baffles the emotions.

But the Selectmen have resisted anything but demolition of the 1907 Mission-style structure for a new housing development.

Miss Klein, a graduate of Brandeis University, is in the account management department of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon &amp; Eckhardt, a New York advertising agency.

It is interesting to note that Mr.
Reich is from Harvard's school of government, not its business school.

Costa Rica
LEAD: To the Editor: We were planning a two-week vacation in Costa Rica this winter with about half of our time on Isla Jesusita, a small island off the Pacific Coast scarcely mentioned in guidebooks.
For three weeks we and our travel agent tried to call the 800 number for the Costa Rica National Tourist Bureau in Miami.


Arena of Big-Time Athletics Is Showcasing a Younger Act
LEAD: High school athletics have become the latest entree on the American sports menu, served up to help satisfy the voracious appetite of the fan.
As a result, scholastic athletes are on the verge of becoming as important to the billion-dollar sports industry as their college brothers and sisters - and just as vulnerable to big-time exploitation.


2 Men Charged in Slaying Of a Policeman in Flatbush
LEAD: Two men were charged yesterday in the slaying of a plainclothes police officer who, the authorities said, was killed with his own gun in a struggle with the suspects on a Brooklyn street early Friday.

LEAD: In a move that could provoke a sharp reaction from Catholic colleges and universities, the Vatican's Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith has published an oath of fidelity to all official church teachings that will be required of teachers of Catholic theology as well as church officials.

Guillem Joins Royal Ballet
LEAD: Sylvie Guillem, a principal dancer with the Paris Opera Ballet, has joined the Royal Ballet of London for three years as principal guest artist.
She is expected to dance at least 25 performances a year, beginning with ''Swan Lake'' on April 15.
She will do guest appearances in Paris.

POSTINGS: Fairview Conversion; 4 Buildings, New Uses
LEAD: A $4 million renovation is under way in Fairview, N.J., that will convert four buildings used over the last 25 years as truck terminals, garment factories and warehouses into a mixed-use office-commercial complex.


'Kiddie Tax' Makes Saving for College Harder
LEAD: Parents should begin setting aside money for their children's college educations as soon as possible, financial planning experts say.
Tax changes have killed many of the popular devices that once helped to increase the value of college funds.


Keeping Fit in Economy Class
LEAD: WHEN Ruth Bocour of New York took an economy-class flight to California some years ago, her leg began to hurt and she thought she had a charley horse.
Mrs.
Bocour, a former professional dancer who now helps injured people improve mobility, said that when the plane stopped in Las Vegas, she ''walked around like crazy'' and tried to exercise the leg to get the cramp out, but to no avail.


LEVERAGED BUYOUTS
LEAD: Robert B. Reich's article ''Leveraged Buyouts: America Pays the Price'' (Jan. 29) says all the things that my friends and I - people of average income and investment - have felt about this legalized thievery for years.
The biggest crime is that the brokerage houses, the executives settling gently to the ground in their golden parachutes and the huge law firms who do all the paper shuffling are the only winners.


COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Secondary Office Space; In a Sluggish Market, the Pressure's On to Renovate
LEAD: WITH Manhattan office users slowly absorbing a wave of new construction, the owners of less-than-stellar older buildings are coming under intense pressure to renovate their space, sometimes dramatically, to compete in a sluggish rental market, industry professionals say.


Trammell in Accord
LEAD: Acting as his own negotiatior, Alan Trammell agreed yesterday to a $6.5 million, three-year contract extension with the Detroit Tigers that runs through the 1992 season.
In a five-minute session, Trammell suggested a figure to Bill Lajoie, the Detroit general manager, who agreed and shook hands on it.


Strawberry's Big Bat Speaks Loud and Clear
LEAD: ''What's done is done,'' Darryl Strawberry was saying, after his one-day exile was done. ''I'm back.'' He was back, all right.
With flourishes, a hug and a kiss for Keith Hernandez and a mighty three-run home run for the Mets, he was back today, ending his walkout, burying his contract blues, turning boos into cheers and even stealing the show from Tommy Lasorda and his ''team of destiny.


Week's Choices Range From Opera to Pop
LEAD: Vocal music will hold its own against the instrumental competition this week.
The options range from grand opera to a pops songbook, not to mention a recital by Roberta Peters combining both.


England's Rothschild Chateau
LEAD: MY first great architectural encounter beyond American shores took place on an autumnal weekend in the Loire Valley in France.
Silhouetted against a gray sky was the majestic roof line of the 16th-century Chateau of Chambord, with its symmetrically massed turrets, towers and cupolas.
It made a lasting impression on someone reared on the simplicity of American Colonial architecture.


Hanson's Meteoric Rise
LEAD: Once again, Hanson P.L.C. has Wall Street guessing.
In the past few months, Hanson Industries, the British conglomerate's American arm, has bought 9.8 percent of the shares of the Cummins Engine Company, the diesel engine maker based in Columbus, Ind.
