TALKING: Roommates; Co-ops Face Loss Of Control
LEAD: NEW YORK CITY co-op boards have traditionally enjoyed the right to screen incoming residents and even restrict occupancy to shareholders and members of their immediate family.
That right was always underscored and confirmed by the terms of the proprietary lease.


Bronx Apartment Fire Kills 2
LEAD: Two people died from smoke inhalation early yesterday after fire raced through their ground-floor apartment in a five-story building at 36 Bedford Park Boulevard in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx.
The police said the victims, Bernadette Dolan, 31 years old, and Robert Dolan, 39, were believed to have been smoking in bed.


Audited? No Need To Panic
LEAD: Few phrases cause as much terror as ''tax audit.'' It conjures up visions of sinister agents disallowing deductions and imposing penalties and back taxes that rival a New York condominium in cost.


French Castle Holds Relics of Medieval War
LEAD: In an amber-colored castle clinging to an amber cliff, towering far above the Dordogne River in southwest France, a military museum of the Middle Ages has opened.


Prospects; The Budget Panel Fizzles
LEAD: The National Economic Commission, a bipartisan panel appointed by the President and Congress in the aftermath of the Oct. 19 stock market collapse, failed to come to an agreement last week on a blueprint for cutting the Federal budget deficit.
The failure of the commission means that next October it is more likely that Congress will be forced to accept the automatic cuts of the Gramm-Rudman Act, a process known as sequestration.


U.S. Lyme-Disease Aid Sought
LEAD: EFFORTS to stem Lyme disease could be strengthened under a bill co-sponsored by Congressional legislators from Westchester County, which last year reported more new cases of the debilitating infection than any other county in the nation.

LEAD: There could not have been more than two dozen spectators in the stands when Ron Guidry walked from the bullpen to the mound and made his pitch to win a job with the Yankees today.


Electronic Filing Speeds Refunds
LEAD: Once every 15 minutes the smiling face of Bob Mirsberger, Manhattan director of the I.R.S., flashes on an electric color billboard over Times Square with an enthusiasic exhortation to ''Make Your Taxes Less Taxing By Filing Early &amp; Electronically.'' This year, some two million taxpayers will take that advice to heart by having their tax data sent by computer and modem as part of the Internal Revenue Service's electronic filing program.

Mr. Woodcuter, Spare That Tree!
LEAD: A BAY WINDOW overlooking the Supreme Court park is a pleasant place to sit at breakfast, especially early on a holiday morning, when Constitution Avenue is devoid of traffic.
At times like this, Capitol Hill is so quiet you can hear your heart beating, and if you are lucky enough to have a great glossy pine growing close to your house, you will sometimes catch another sound, the purest in nature: wind hissing through needles.

Social Events; Artists' Retreat
LEAD:  March 5 - An artistic sampling of what the Millay Colony for the Arts is all about will be offered at a benefit reception at the Victoria Munroe Gallery, 415 West Broadway (near Prince Street) from 4 to 7.
The colony, the former home of Edna St.
Vincent Millay, is a 600-acre retreat in Austerlitz, N.Y., where artists can spend a month without cost working at their craft.


FICTION
LEAD:  KILL THE POOR.
By Joel Rose. (Atlantic Monthly, Paper, $8.95.) Sharp, savage and extremely well written, this provocative first novel examines a politically troublesome and ethically troubling issue - the gentrification of impoverished urban neighborhoods - with the stylistic flair and easy nihilism characteristic of New York's downtown scene.

LEAD: Gov.

FICTION
LEAD:  FIFTY YEARS OF ETERNAL VIGILANCE: And Other Stories.
By Carolyn Thorman. (Peachtree, $14.95.) The characters in Carolyn Thorman's first collection of stories are quirky Lithuanian- and Polish-Americans with varying attitudes about the benefits, and costs, of assimilation.
They wouldn't understand the word, but they know everything about the idea.


FICTION
LEAD:  PAUSE BETWEEN ACTS.
By Mavis Cheek. (Simon &amp; Schuster, $17.95.) When her trendy television-director husband leaves her for another woman, Joan Battram finds, to her surprise, that she likes living alone.
Her problem is that no one will leave her alone.
Though this London schoolteacher strives mightily to discourage them, her neighbors and acquaintances insistently invite her out, her parents fret and phone, a muscular young colleague pursues her slavishly, her ex-husband changes his mind and, finally, the famous, meltingly handsome West End actor Finbar Flynn stumbles into her life.


Nancy Kaneb to Wed George Soule
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs.
Albert J. Kaneb of Weston and Osterville, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Ellen Kaneb to George deLancey Soule, a son of Richard H. Soule of Canterbury, N.H., and Emily M. Soule of Darien, Conn.
A May wedding is planned.


A Chip With Supercomputer Power
LEAD: Intel plunges boldly into the world of reduced instruction set computing.
THE Intel Corporation has introduced a new chip, the i860, that is believed to be the first commercial microprocessor to incorporate more than a million transistors on one piece of silicon.
It is also the first to handle data in 64-bit chunks.


Crippled Oil Ship Floats Free
LEAD: An oil tanker that ran aground off the Hawaiian island of Oahu floated free Friday night after salvage workers lightened the ship's load to prevent more crude oil or fuel from spilling into the Pacific Ocean and washing up on Hawaii's beaches.
The 800-foot Exxon Houston ''suddenly just started floating,'' a Coast Guard spokesman said, and the ship was towed to deeper water.


Peruvian Rebels Said to Kill 39 Villagers in Revenge Act
LEAD: Shining Path guerrillas killed 37 men in a rural village by cutting their throats, and shot to death a mother and her baby when the woman tried to flee, a Peruvian military official said today.


A 'Masters Show'
LEAD: EVERY year, the J. Richards Gallery here has what it calls a ''masters show.'' The gallery, at 64 East Palisades Avenue, is a brightly lighted storefront, and its masters are strictly 20th century.


STYLE MAKERS: Oribe; HAIR STYLIST
LEAD: Women who fancy $125 haircuts by Oribe are now making appointments for January 1990.
This is chancy, they realize, since when the big day arrives, the Cuban-born stylist may be off in exotic climes arranging models' tresses for high fashion photography.
Even if Oribe (pronounced or-REE-bay) happens to be at one of his two uptown Manhattan salons, he may decide, as he did the other day, not to cut.

LEAD: If ever a show had competition, it is ''Cezanne: The Early Years 1859-1872'' at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.
The competition in question is not from any other artist, but from Cezanne himself - or, to be precise, from the supreme importance of late Cezanne in the accepted hierarchies of art.

Passing to Pros
LEAD: Because of what he described as a lifelong dream of playing in the National Football League, Timm Rosenbach, the nation's most efficient passer while at Washington State last season, has decided to forgo his final season of college eligibility to pursue a professional career. ''I have weighed all the facts and I'm confident that I have done what is best for Timm Rosenbach,'' he said in announcing his intention of making himself available for the N.F.L.


Starlight's Stars Brighten A Ballroom
LEAD: Across town at the New York Hilton, stars glittered at the Starlight Foundation's New York benefit.
More than 1,200 people attended a dinner and show, which included dancing and singing by Melba Moore and Ben Vereen.
Mr.
Vereen performed on stage and off, whirling through the ballroom and on and off several chairs.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. The oil base paint applied to my concrete ceilings three years ago is peeling, but the same paint is not peeling from the walls.
I was told that this is due to a faulty concrete mix when the building was put up 35 years ago.
A friend suggested I cover the ceilings with canvas that could then be painted over.

For AIDS Inmates, Prison in a Prison
LEAD: To prisoners, Dorm 7 at the Limestone Correctional Facility here is a prison within a prison, a white masonry-block barracks in which Alabama segregates all prisoners who tests indicate carry the AIDS virus.

LEAD: The letter from Herbert Jaffe (''What if Shoreham Doesn't Open?'' Feb. 19) contains several errors and at least one omission.


Vocal Programs In the Spotlight
LEAD: WITH the approach of the Easter holidays, the yearly surge in vocal programs has arrived.
In fact, this week is neatly bracketed by choral concerts, starting at 4 P.M. today as the Congregational Choir under John Schuder sings the Durufle Requiem at the Church in Scarsdale (723-2234).


Olive Oil Replaces Butter in Many Dishes
LEAD: MORE and more, I find myself using olive oil for cooking instead of butter.
For someone raised in the English tradition of butter on everything - even baked beans - this is something of an accomplishment.
But nowadays I find that I like olive oil even on something as butter-prone as a baked potato.


The Kirov Claims Its Balanchine Legacy
LEAD: GEORGE BALANCHINE DIED IN 1983, BUT two weeks ago his legacy returned to the land and city of his birth.
For the first time, works by the master choreographer - ''Scotch Symphony'' and ''Theme and Variations'' - were danced by the Kirov Ballet, direct descendant of the company in which Balanchine himself performed in the early 1920's.


Probert Banned After Arrest
LEAD: Bob Probert, the troubled Detroit Red Wings forward, was expelled from the National Hockey League yesterday, two days after he was arrested and charged with smuggling cocaine.


Traditional Sex Roles Plague the Computer Age; Sexist Generalization
LEAD: To the Editor:


Cable TV Operators Are Guilty of Greed
LEAD: Cablevision's positions in the MSG dispute are defenseless.
MSG is not ''expensive'': including the new Yankee contract, it costs less than $1 per month per subscriber.
It is also not ''specialty programming'': 9 of the 10 most-watched cable programs in 1988 were sports.


PASTIMES: BRIDGE
LEAD: In social games, using either four-deal scoring or the traditional rubber bridge scoring, it is common for a player to fail in a part-score contract by three or more tricks.
The opponents are left regretting that they failed to pull the trigger, doubling to collect a large penalty instead of a small one.

His Third Congressional District takes in some 500,000 residents in coastal Monmouth and Ocean Counties, from Keyport to Seaside

LEAD: If gambling fever made Darrell Waltrip and his crew take the chance that won the Daytona 500 last month, the man they may have caught it from was Gary Nelson, a former crew chief for Waltrip's teammate, Geoff Bodine, and someone always willing to go the extra mile on fuel consumption.

LEAD: The closed and competitive world of symphony orchestras has been shaken in recent weeks by an extraordinary show of political pressure to change the hiring practices of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra.

LEAD: IN 1985, President Reagan declared that terrorists who harmed Americans would have to answer for their crimes in Federal court.

Question Of the Week; How Will Vandeweghe Affect The Knicks?
LEAD: The addition of Kiki Vandeweghe will certainly improve the team.
I think he is a great shooter.
There is no question in my mind that Kiki can shoot the lights out.
He can bring to this already respected club a new, positive dimension.
In my mind, he will be the 1989 Knick version of Mychal Thompson's addition to the Lakers.

POSTINGS: Warranties for New Homes; Law Aids Buyers
LEAD: New York State has a new law intended to give buyers of new homes increased protection against defects such as leaking roofs and faulty plumbing by defining the legal responsibilities of contractors.
While state law already had held contractors liable for deficiencies in new homes even in the absence of a formal warranty, the law that went into effect Wednesday defines what is included in the implied warranty.


Rates Are Down, Complexities Up
LEAD: As Americans get ready for their annual April tax-filing ritual, the once-heralded concept of simplification seems to have fallen through the cracks.
Even those who turn to professional preparers are having to devote extra hours to learning enough about the tax laws to get all their financial records in order.

From Bumpers to Hoods, Detroit Opens the Door for Plastics
LEAD: Plastic producers have had a tough time shifting out of low gear as they try to sell Detroit on the plastic car.
Over the last decade, auto makers have increased their use of plastics in car interiors and in small parts to make them lighter and more fuel-efficient.
But they have been unable to justify plastics for body panels and structural frames because in large-scale production they cost more than steel.

Shades of McCarthyism
LEAD: George Bush now has on his desk a little noticed executive order that threatens to revive one of the excesses of the McCarthy era.
The order, prepared in the final days of the Reagan Administration, would scrap the appeals process for Federal security clearances.
This, in turn, would allow the Government to deny clearances to Federal workers or to the employees of Government contractors, without any explanation.

Even diehard solo travelers are tempted by the variety of arrangements offered by tour companies and airlines.
Today the package need not shape a vacationer's entire trip, locking him or her in a mobile cocoon.
It often offers a compromise, mixing hotels and local transportation with freedom to explore, dine out and take side trips.

Olive Oil Replaces Butter in Many Dishes
LEAD: MORE and more, I find myself using olive oil for cooking instead of butter.
For someone raised in the English tradition of butter on everything - even baked beans - this is something of an accomplishment.
But nowadays I find that I like olive oil even on something as butter-prone as a baked potato.

Patients' Rights
LEAD: MY DOCTOR put me on a beta blocker,'' a friend told me last week. ''I hate the side effects, but I couldn't argue with him.'' Many, perhaps most, patients feel that way: they don't really have much say in the matter.
Yet, according to a famous New York Court of Appeals decision in 1914, ''Every human being of adult years and sound mind has a right to determine what shall be done with his own body.

LEAD: When I was a young girl, my favorite afternoons were spent at the counter of the local drugstore.

The stools in the drugstore are long gone, but my desire for those perfect ice cream confections remains.


Alternative Tax Trap
LEAD: There is actually good news concerning the alternative minimum tax, namely the A.M.T. credit, which goes into effect for the first time this year.
With careful planning, professionals say, it could significantly reduce many taxpayers' liabilities.
The bad news is that, with the restructuring in tax rates, the alternative minimum tax will apply more broadly than ever before.

Web of Laws Ensnares An Immigrant Investor
LEAD: When Jack Pointeau came from his native France eight years ago and eventually settled in this small west Texas town, he did everything by the book.

He renewed that visa every year.
He opened a business and paid his taxes.

Photography After Daguerre is Celebrated at the Wadsworth
LEAD: THE official birth of photography took place in March of 1839, when Louis Daguerre revealed his daguerreotype at a scientific convention in Paris.
Six months later, details of the process had reached the United States and within a couple of years there were daguerreotypists at work the world over, producing mirror images of people and places on silvered copper plates.

IDEAS &amp; TRENDS: Fear of Aflatoxin; The Debate About The Carcinogens That Man Didn't Make
LEAD: IN the war against chemicals that cause cancer, most of the attention has been on man-made substances like pesticides and preservatives.
Increasingly, however, some scientists are arguing that the public has been infected with a bad case of chemophobia.
Most cancers, they say, come from natural causes - the food, sunlight, plant poisons, tobacco and other things people encounter every day.

LEAD: Although they share a surname and a reverence for the American West, one would be hard pressed to find two more dissimilar landscape photographers than Ansel Adams and Robert Adams.

Capital Gains
LEAD: To the Editor:


A Hunger to Write
LEAD: Born in 1921 in Robinson, a small town in rural Illinois, James Jones was a curiously American phenomenon: the great novelist who comes out of nowhere, equipped only with talent and a fierce determination to write.
Jones's love of literature was untutored, innate.
Without money for college - his father was an alcoholic dentist whose fate is described in these letters - and without prospects, Jones enlisted in the Army Air Corps in 1939 and was shipped off to Hawaii.

LEAD: AT DUSK, WHEN ALL THE WESTERN relief workers have left for the day, blue Chinese-made trucks drive up to Site 8.

Soldiers in green Chinese-made fatigues supervise the loading and unloading of the sullen cargo - men and women compelled under guard to carry Chinese ammunition, weapons and mines to Khmer Rouge forces fighting inside Cambodia.

LEAD: In pursuit of a painless method for containing hospital costs, American industry now has a new white knight: utilization review.

Walter Thayer, 78, Herald Tribune President, Dies
LEAD: Walter N. Thayer, a lawyer, partner in the Whitcom Investment Corporation and former president of The New York Herald Tribune, died of pneumonia yesterday at New York Hospital.
Mr.
Thayer, who was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan, had been admitted to the hospital more than three weeks ago.
He had suffered from emphysema for several years.

THE WORLD: Fallout Over Rushdie; The Muslim Presence In Western Europe Is Suddenly Starker
LEAD: TELEVISION magnifies reality, and the image on French television screens a week ago was shocking.
In the heart of Paris, at the Place de la Republique, some 1,500 Muslims, many of them Pakistanis, screamed into television cameras for the death of Salman Rushdie.
With close-up camera work, the smallish crowd suddenly seemed to represent a fanatic Islamic fifth column that had surfaced in France just as it is celebrating the 200th anniversary of its republican, anticlerical revolution.

It's Academics
LEAD: Topping the 1989 GTE Academic all-America men's basketball team are Michael Smith of Brigham Young University and Alec Kessler of the University of Georgia.

Plan for Homeless Offers Hope
LEAD: That there exists continued difficulty in providing adequate housing for the homeless should not come as a surprise (''State Plays Bigger Role for Homeless,'' Jan. 22).
There is clear precedence for this problem.
Historically, there have been enormous problems coordinating and centralizing social services, including housing, for former psychiatric patients, many of whom are represented in our homeless population.

LEAD: Sears began its new life as an ''everyday low prices'' retailer.

The Civilian Conservation Corps
LEAD: To the Editor:


For Investors, More to Learn
LEAD: Investing and taxes used to be a simple matter.
If taxpayers made money on investments, they paid a tax.
If the money was made by selling a security held longer than six months, the profit was considered a long-term gain and they paid a reduced tax.
And if they borrowed money to pay for the investment, they generally got to deduct the interest.

Now, a Rush to Speed Up Protection of Ozone
LEAD: JUST two years ago when 31 nations met in Montreal and agreed to cut the production of chlorofluorocarbons in half by the turn of the century, the accord was hailed by environmentalists as an unprecedented example of international cooperation.

Laying Floor Tiles
LEAD: RESILIENT floor tiles made of vinyl, asphalt or cork are easier to apply than many other types of finish flooring.
Little skill is required to attach them, and, because the tiles are manageable in size - most are 12 inches or less on each side - trimming is less of a chore than it is with sheet vinyl or carpeting.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. The oil base paint applied to my concrete ceilings three years ago is peeling, but the same paint is not peeling from the walls.
I was told that this is due to a faulty concrete mix when the building was put up 35 years ago.
A friend suggested I cover the ceilings with canvas that could then be painted over.

LEAD: In a conclusion that seemed foregone long before the season began, Kenny Anderson of Archbishop Molloy in Queens has been named high school basketball player of the year by Parade Magazine.

Things That Go Buzz in the Night
LEAD: WHEN the buzzing began under my bed in the middle of the night, I thought at first that my dreams had been enriched by a new realism.
When the buzzing continued and I realized I was not dreaming, I thought I had left the telephone off the hook.
When I found the receiver in place, I became, in quick order, annoyed, mystified and a little unnerved.

LEAD: Residents of New York City still have the unenviable distinction of paying the highest combined Federal, state and local tax rates in the nation - 41 percent for those in the 33 percent Federal bracket and 36.6 percent for those in the 28 percent Federal bracket.

'Within the Plantation Household'
LEAD: To the Editor:


North Africa's Family Meal
LEAD: COUSCOUS is the kind of dish nouvelle cuisine set out to defy.
No matter how it is judged - by sheer volume, by the ferocity of its spices, or just by the whole ceremony of eating it - the North African specialty built on mounds of semolina, vegetables, lamb or chicken is not for the faint-hearted.


North Stars Edge Islanders
LEAD: Frantisek Musil's first goal of the season, at 13 minutes 13 seconds of the third period, snapped a 3-3 tie and lifted the Minnesota North Stars to a 4-3 victory over the Islanders today.


Latin Refugees Fleeing Texas for Mexican Haven
LEAD: To their utter astonishment and consternation, Mexican immigration officials have in recent days apprehended Nicaraguans, Salvadorans and other Central Americans swimming across the Rio Grande from Texas.


Over and Under


McEnroe Wins Fifth W.C.T. Title
LEAD: John McEnroe shook off the fatigue of a four-set match he played only 12 hours earlier and earned a record fifth World Championship Tennis finals title today with a methodical 6-3, 6-3, 7-6 victory over Brad Gilbert.


The Poison in the Corn
LEAD: Last summer's drought left a legacy of poison that threatens the country's food supply.
Dry weather spurred the spread of the fungus that makes aflatoxin, a highly potent inducer of liver cancer.
Dangerous amounts of aflatoxin contaminate a fifth or more of the Middle West's 1988 corn crop, much of which is still in storage.


Smoking Bill Draws Criticism From All Sides
LEAD: IN an unusual display of unanimity, tobacco-industry representatives, local business owners and health advocates took turns Wednesday night condemning a county legislative bill to regulate smoking in Westchester's public spaces.


Threats From Imports - and Environmentalists
LEAD: Even Mr.
Robinson's friend might marvel at just how prevalent plastics have become since his prediction about their promising future in ''The Graduate.'' Last year, sales of resins - the raw materials that plastics are made from - grew to $28 billion.
That was up 30 percent from 1984.

LEAD: War usually takes a toll on coinage.

LEAD: Dogs, not diamonds, are a man's best friend.
However, men are not immune to the lure of a few appropriately placed baubles.
From cuff links to tie bars to collar pins, masculine details that once were traditional have returned in force to business and formal dressing.


Ratings Give Rank to the High Schools
LEAD: These days, the country's No. 1 high school basketball team is St.
Anthony of Jersey City.
Who says so?
The sports editor of the LaPorte (Ind.) Herald-Argus.
His name is Dave Krider, and he has become the nation's basketball star-maker, even though he rarely sees any of the teams he selects.


In Jazz, Young Players Turn to the Old Hard-Bop
LEAD: Throughout the 1980's, promising young jazz musicians have been looking back.
Defying the notion that music evolves in one immutable direction - that as one era's style succeeds another, there is inevitably progress in art - they devote themselves to the jazz approaches of the 1950's and 1960's.
Recent albums by or featuring Ralph Peterson, Wallace Roney, Marcus Roberts and Mulgrew Miller show a generation mastering one of the most complex musical languages ever conceived.


Car Theft Is Epidemic
LEAD: Yesterday, five minutes after I read the article concerning the car-theft situation at Green Acres Shopping Center  [ ''Car Theft Fraud Rampant at Nassau Shopping Mall,'' Feb. 19 ] , our family left for the Roosevelt Field movie complex, discussing your article during the entire trip.
We realized we'd not patronized Green Acres in years, and felt doubly secure in sighting two mounted policemen on horseback as we arrived at Roosevelt Field.

LEAD: TWO caramels, four Tootsie rolls, four lollipops and a napkin full of jellybeans!
Well, that wasn't enough.
I knew my friend, Irene, had more than that, and noon on Holy Saturday was still two weeks away.

Big Cocoa Surplus Seen
LEAD: Record world cocoa production this season is likely to lead to the biggest surplus ever and a substantial rise in stockpiles, Gill &amp; Duffus, a cocoa merchant, said Friday.
The company estimates world cocoa production from October 1988 to September 1989 at 2.31 million metric tons, 5.4 percent more than last season and 199,000 tons more than world demand.

Reviews/Music; Sonatas on Cello and Piano
LEAD: The sonata program of Antonio Meneses and Cecile Licad, cellist and pianist, at Weill Recital Hall Friday evening was the kind of honorable, solidly played concert that sustains musical life on a night-to-night basis in New York.
If those are lukewarm words for a pair of accomplished artists whose capabilities are well known, it was hard to feel that their own responses to the Mendelssohn, Britten and Brahms they played were much more than high-level workaday.

Piano Competitions: New Path to Success
LEAD: Competitions began, no doubt, with two cave men and one piece of raw meat.
Not much has changed in 10,000 years, though in these lethal fights for survival, death for the loser has come to be less sudden, more lingering; the bleeding is inner and psychic, not the kind you get on your shirt.
Struggles for pre-eminence may in fact be sharper and more pervasive today than prehistory ever dreamed of, and art is not exempt.

Claims Dismissed In Lotus Lawsuit
LEAD: A Federal District Court in Boston formally dismissed all remaining claims in a suit against the Lotus Development Corporation and its founder, Mitchell D. Kapor.

Chess
LEAD: The Pan-American intercollegiate championship for 1988 was won by the Harvard team in New Brunswick, N.J., on Dec. 30 with a score of 7 1/2 out of 8 matches.
This was the first time that Harvard has won outright, although it has entered every year since the origination of the competition for four-man teams in 1946 and tied for the championship twice, in 1975 and 1986.


EASTERN SLASHES ALL BUT 3 ROUTES AND LAYS OFF 5,000
LEAD: Eastern Airlines shut down operations on all but three routes yesterday and laid off 5,000 workers, saying it could not maintain a full flight schedule because nearly 90 percent of its pilots were honoring picket lines set up by striking machinists.


Oklahoma Review
LEAD: The University of Oklahoma is still reviewing an incident that led to the arrest of the Sooners basketball star Mookie Blaylock, and won't make any decisions on him before the investigation is completed, Donnie Duncan, the athletic director, said yesterday.
The police in Norman, Okla., said they arrested Blaylock, 21 years old, on a charge of public intoxication outside a convenience store Sunday following an argument between Blaylock and a female companion, who also was ar-rested.

Corrections
LEAD: An obituary on Feb. 23 about Allen Eaton Throop, a lawyer and former general counsel to Federal agencies including the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, misstated the corporation's origin.

Robert M. Lunny, 81; Led Historical Society
LEAD: Robert Miller Lunny, the former director of the New Jersey Historical Society, died Saturday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital after a long illness.
He was 81 years old and lived in Oldwick, N.J.


The Editorial Notebook; The Appearance of Honor
LEAD: The word ''appearance'' has haunted the ethical debates of the Bush Administration so far, notably the present battle over John Tower's nomination for Secretary of Defense.
The arguments would be clearer all the way around if the parties settled on what they mean.


First Group of Inmates Moves to Prison Barge
LEAD: Sixty prisoners last night became the first group of inmates to be transferred from the city's overcrowded jails to a prison barge docked in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, officials said.


Dietary Fat Linked to Breast Cancer
LEAD: A CAREFULLY conducted new study has provided the most convincing evidence to date that a diet low in fats, saturated fats and animal protein can reduce the risk of breast cancer.


Parking Rules
LEAD: Because of the weather, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today.
Other regulations remain in effect.

LEAD: Two days after 13-year-old Kelly Tinyes was found stabbed and strangled in a neighbor's basement, there are plenty of questions but no arrests.

LEAD: The Soviet Union said today that it needed more evidence that certain chemical compounds destroy the ozone layer before it joined plans by the United States and other countries to ban them by the end of the century.

LEAD: With Eastern Airlines virtually shut down by a machinists' strike, pilots of other airlines have been asked to fly by the rule book beginning today, a move that could slow flights and further disrupt the nation's air transportation system.

LEAD: Senator Edward M. Kennedy today sharply criticized his party's 1988 Presidential campaign as being devoid of ideas and urged the Democrats to emulate former President Ronald Reagan's consistent sense of political purpose.

Olajuwon Fined
LEAD: Akeem Olajuwon, the Houston Rockets' all-star center, was fined $5,000 by the National Basketball Association yesterday for punching Michael Cage of Seattle in the SuperSonics' 118-108 victory over Houston last Friday.
The incident occurred with 3 minutes 46 seconds to go in the first half.
Cage put Olajuwon in a hammerlock after Olajuwon grabbed an offensive rebound.

Our Towns; Incineration? Or Just Recycle Him in Effigy?
LEAD: It's an enormous job for ordinary citizens to stop a garbage incinerator planned in their area.
For two years Marlene Mendelsohn, a substitute teacher, has run a kaffeeklatsch a week, raising $100,000 to pay lawyers and anti-incinerator experts.
In her garage she has 37 boxes of files; in the laundry room is a stack of clippings to be filed; by the kitchen phone she keeps crates of her best files handy for emergencies.

Creative Training Nurtures Hurdler
LEAD: When Monifa Taylor was 7 years old, her father strung a piece of cardboard between two chairs in the backyard, and a hurdling career began.
When she was 9, she trained in a Pathmark parking garage in the Bronx, and the chairs were replaced by shopping carts.
When she was 10, Robert Taylor built wooden hurdles, and his daughter and her friends jumped over them in the same garage.

LEAD: Gulfstream Park closes after today's racing, but not for the year.
The track will run its shortest and latest meeting ever eight months from now, when it reopens Nov. 3 for a three-day stand centered on the seven Breeders' Cup races Nov. 4.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Lord, Einstein Victory
LEAD: Lord, Einstein, O'Neill &amp; Partners is free to solicit and serve clients who left Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein after last March 18.
The ruling by Justice Herman Cahn of New York State Supreme Court clarifies a letter of agreement between Lord, Geller and the firm formed last March by several of its top executives, which allowed the new agency to solicit personnel from the older firm, but prohibited it from pursuing existing Lord, Geller clients.

LEAD: Morning at the Shoreham nuclear power plant: Today, just as they have every day for the last four years, 1,000 workers run through their rituals of readiness.

Some Addicts Find Medication Can Ease Craving for Cocaine
LEAD: DRUGS commonly used to treat depression can help some cocaine users remain abstinent during the initial period when their cravings are overwhelming, recent studies show.
And if they take cocaine while using antidepressants, one new study indicates that the pleasurable effects of cocaine are blunted.

Knight-Ridder Strategy
LEAD: Knight-Ridder Inc., a leading newspaper chain, said today that it would ask stockholders to approve defensive steps against hostile takeover attempts.
The company, whose papers include The Miami Herald and The Philadelphia Inquirer, seeks charter amendments that would require approval by 80 percent of the common stock for certain mergers and certain foreign ownership arrangements.

A few might have cheered.
Winter was back to normal.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Saturday about filings for local school boards in New York City misidentified a Bronx community school district where an indicted board member, Jose M. Cruz, is running for re-election.

Harper Helps Mavericks Top Nets
LEAD: Derek Harper scored 13 of his 28 points in the fourth quarter tonight to lead the Dallas Mavericks past the Nets, 105-99.


Electronics Trade Gap
LEAD: The United States had a $9.6 billion trade deficit in electronic products last year, a 25 percent improvement from 1987's $12.7 billion deficit, the American Electronics Association said today.
The electronics trade deficit with Japan grew 2 percent, to $20.5 billion from $20.1 billion.


New Findings Delay Resettling of Love Canal
LEAD: Plans to resettle parts of the Love Canal neighborhood in Niagara Falls, N.Y., will be delayed because contamination found nearby has raised questions about the study used to determine the area's safety, state health officials said today.


Congress Seeks to Reduce Greenhouse Effect
LEAD: To the Editor:


School Embezzlement Charged
LEAD: Warrants were issued Friday for the former student body president of San Francisco State University and three other students accused of embezzling $9,000 from the student government, the district attorney's office said.
Each faces a felony charge of theft of public funds, said George Beckwith of the district attorney's special prosecution unit.


U.N. Human Rights Group Faces a Key Test
LEAD: An American-led campaign to make the United Nations Human Rights Commission a less political and more effective watchdog against oppressive governments is facing its most critical test in three years, diplomats say.


Josephine S. Margetts, Assemblywoman, 87
LEAD: Josephine S. Margetts, a former three-term Republican Assemblywoman from Morris County, N.J., died Friday at her home in Harding Township.
She was 87 years old.


In Protecting the Atmosphere, Choices Are Costly and Complex
LEAD: AS the world moves toward a ban on ozone-destroying chemicals to head off an epidemic of skin cancer, experts searching for substitute chemicals predict that the technical and economic cost of the change will be high.


Detention of Refugees Is an Unlawful Policy
LEAD: To the Editor:


Goetz Victim Held in Mugging
LEAD: Barry Allen, one of the four young men shot by Bernhard H. Goetz in December 1986, was charged with mugging a man in the Bronx, the police said yesterday.
Mr.
Allen, 22 years old, was arrested on Feb. 28 but gave the police a false name and his identity was not learned until a check of his fingerprints returned, said a police spokesman, Officer Joseph Gallagher.


Dow Up by 20.53; Bond Strength a Factor
LEAD: Stocks rose yesterday, buoyed by the strength in bond prices and the dollar.

Fish and Eggs Destroyed in West After Disease Strikes Hatcheries
LEAD: An untreatable fish disease, never before found in North America, has been detected at two salmon hatcheries in the Pacific Northwest, prompting biologists to kill nearly four million eggs and young fish in an effort to halt the spread of the virus.


Vatican Newspaper Faults Rushdie Book
LEAD: The Vatican newspaper has declared that parts of ''The Satanic Verses'' could be considered blasphemous, but it denounced the death threats against the book's author, Salman Rushdie.


B.P. Guaranteeing Unit's Debentures
LEAD: BP America Inc., a subsidiary of the British Petroleum Company P.L.C, is offering $250 million of guaranteed debentures, due in 2004, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.

Emory S. Basford, Educator, 90
LEAD: Emory S. Basford, a retired chairman of the English department at Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass., died Wednesday at Asbury Village, a retirement community in Gaithersburg, Md., his residence since 1970.
He was 90 years old.


Careers; University Heeds Advice on Management
LEAD: W. EDWARDS DEMING is known as the management expert who advised the Japanese on how to improve their industries after World War II.


S.E.C. Upheld On Magazine
LEAD: The Supreme Court today turned down the free-speech arguments of a financial magazine accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of violating an anti-touting provision of Federal securities law.

Review/Theater; Baryshnikov in 'Metamorphosis'
LEAD: It's hard to guess who will suffer most at Steven Berkoff's theatrical version of ''Metamorphosis'': devotees of Franz Kafka, whose story is distorted into Marxist kitsch by this adaptation, or fans of Mikhail Baryshnikov, whose stage debut as a dramatic actor, however dignified, amounts to little more than a sideshow to the loud circus surrounding him.

BARRY ASSOCIATE FACES APRIL TRIAL
LEAD: Charles Lewis, the subject of a drug investigation in Washington that has involved the city's Mayor, appeared in Federal District Court here today for a preliminary hearing on charges that he sold crack to an undercover agent posing as a tourist.


What With Snow and Strike, Travel in Northeast Is Travail
LEAD: On the first business day since Eastern Airlines machinists walked off their jobs, there was foul weather in the Northeast and foul tempers throughout the country.

Goldsmith Teams With Rothschild
LEAD: The British-French financier Sir James Goldsmith formed a partnership with Jacob Rothschild, a member of the European banking family, to make takeover bids.
No targets were announced, but Mr.
Rothschild did not rule out hostile bids.
The takeover vehicle will be a new company, Newco, which is linked to Mr.


Metro Datelines; 5- to 15-Year Term In Stabbing of Wife
LEAD: A Long Island man was sentenced to 5 to 15 years in prison yesterday for stabbing his estranged wife 33 times in 1986.
She survived the attack.


Socialism Grabs a Stick: Bankruptcy in China
LEAD: One of the things Chinese companies do best is lose money.
One-fourth of the businesses run by the central Government lost money last year, and the Government spends $11 billion each year - more than 15 percent of its budget - keeping them afloat.


2d Departure At Shearson
LEAD: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. experienced another important departure yesterday -its second in three weeks -when its vice chairman, Peter J. Solomon, resigned to pursue other interests.


At the Top Level of Play, It's Often All Work
LEAD: When Kenny Anderson was asked to summarize his basketball career at Archbishop Molloy High School, the high-scoring all-American from Queens offered a penetrating insight into the current state of high school sports.
Reflecting on the hours of study, practice and competition he had put in during his four years, Anderson concluded that his experience had essentially been like work.

The S &amp; L Sticker Standoff
LEAD: While Congress grapples with the main elements of the savings and loan crisis, a sticker standoff between banks and thrifts highlights the pettiness of competing interests.
At issue is whether the S &amp; L's may display the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's logo after they come under F.D.I.C. jurisdiction.


Tokyo Office For Salomon
LEAD: Salomon Brothers A.G., the West German banking arm of the American securities firm Salomon Inc., has won Finance Ministry permission to set up a representative office in Tokyo, a representative of the firm said today.
The office is the first step in Salomon's plan to open a bank branch here, the spokesman said.


Marietta Journal; Winds of Change Rock A Classic Rocking Chair
LEAD: Joel Chandler Harris used to rock on a Brumby while he contemplated Br'er Rabbit and his other tales of the South.
Jimmy Carter took five Brumbys to the White House.

LEAD: To the Editor:


American Air
LEAD: American Airlines plans to spend as much as $3.5 billion for up to 100 small jets and 200 turboprop commuter planes, The Fort Worth Star-Telegram reported.
The small jets, which seat about 100, would cost up to $2 billion, and the commuter planes, which seat between 35 and 50 passengers, would cost up to $1.5 billion, the newspaper said.At American, a spokesman said no final decisions had yet been made.

'Ghetto' Previews
LEAD: ''Ghetto,'' a play with music by the Israeli playwright Joshua Sobol, is to begin previews April 7 and open April 30 at Circle in the Square. ''Ghetto'' is the story of a theatrical troupe operating under Nazi rule in the Jewish ghetto of Vilna, Lithuania.
It is being directed by Gedalia Besser, who staged the original production in Haifa in 1985.

Gasoline Prices Rise
LEAD: The price of leaded gasoline rose by more than a penny a gallon in the last two weeks, an industry analyst, Trilby Lundberg, said on Sunday.
A nationwide survey of gasoline stations last Friday found that the average cost, with taxes, of all grades of gasoline was 99.22 cents a gallon, up about a half-cent from Feb.

Mass Migration of Chinese Floods a Prosperous Canton
LEAD: A mass migration officially estimated at more than 2.5 million Chinese has flooded this city in the last few weeks, responding to the lure of southern China's prosperity.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Feb. 26 about insurance to supplement Medicare coverage misstated a legal requirement for such policies.
Federal and state laws do not require such policies to include a $75 deductible for physicians' care.


Arkansas Youth Wins the Science Talent Search
LEAD: A 16-year-old high school senior from Arkansas today won the 48th annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search, the pre-eminent competition for aspiring scientists.

NASA Turns From Custom Design to Standard Models
LEAD: WITH custom-built spacecraft growing so expensive, new vehicles for American planetary missions will take on the mass-produced look more commonly associated with Detroit.
Nearly all of them in the next decade and beyond will come in one of two standardized models - either a no-frills runabout for neighborhood trips to the inner solar system or a larger sedan for long journeys to the outer planets.


Barbara Bush Announces Formation of Literacy Foundation
LEAD: Barbara Bush today announced the establishment of a new foundation to fight illiteracy in the United States, a problem she has long worked on as a volunteer.

Siblings of Retarded
LEAD: Studies on the interaction between children with Down's syndrome and other children in the family show that the disability does not prevent the retarded child from having normal sibling relationships; in fact, a more positive interrelationship was noted.

Overturned Murder Conviction Spotlights Dallas-Style Justice
LEAD: For the second time in five years, justice in Dallas is under a national spotlight.
First it was Lenell Geter, a young black engineer who was freed from prison in 1984 after being given a life sentence for an armed robbery he did not commit.
Now it is Randall Dale Adams, who narrowly escaped being executed for a murder conviction that was unanimously overturned this week, 12 years after his trial.

Levi Strauss President
LEAD: Thomas W. Tusher was named the president of Levi Strauss &amp; Company today and a member of the board of Levi Strauss Associates, which owns the jeans maker.
Mr.
Tusher, 47 years old, executive vice president and chief operating officer since 1984, retains the chief operating role.
He becomes the second president who is not a descendant of Levi Strauss, the founder.

Lloyd (Tiny) Grimes, A Jazz Guitarist, 72; Played With Tatum
LEAD: Lloyd (Tiny) Grimes, a jazz guitarist known for his work with Art Tatum and Charlie Parker, died of meningitis Saturday in Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.
He was 72 years old.


Highest Bidder to Make Car 'Boots' for New York
LEAD: In an unusual deal, New York City has decided to award an $85,500 contract for metal ''boots'' that immobilize cars to the company that submitted the highest of five bids.


Electronic Help at Tax Time
LEAD: TAX software is getting better each year.
A few years ago, when we first started looking at programs to aid in the preparation of Federal income tax returns, the choices were limited, the documentation was confusing, the on-screen ''help'' was frustrating or nonexistent, and the net results were usually more trouble than they were worth.

The firm, Alpine Capital


Bridge
LEAD: A year ago Jay Feigus of Middletown, N.J., apparently set a world record for the oldest winner of a substantial competitive event of any kind.
Playing in Pittston, Pa., with Edwin Utan of Scranton, Pa., he won a two-session Open Pair Championship at the age of 95.


North Trial Jury Hears Testimony On U.S. Arms-for-Hostages Plan
LEAD: Over the judge's objections, the jury in the trial of Oliver L. North heard testimony for the first time today about the Reagan Administration's arms-for-hostages initiative with Iran.
Although the arms sales and subsequent diversion of profits to the Nicaraguan rebels are at the heart of the case, the Iran initiative had been mentioned only fleetingly before today in the trial of Mr.


Reviews/Orchestra; Thomas Conducts The London
LEAD: The London Symphony Orchestra is, if anything, the busiest of our international ensembles.
Self-run and flexible, the orchestra is a model of free enterprise: ready for important artistic challenges but not above less edifying enterprises when the money is right.
Its ability to respond quickly and substantially to almost any musical situation has been long an object of respect.

LEAD: THE only advertising executives happier than those who have recently sold their agencies to larger partners appear to be those who have just bought themselves back from their corporate parents.

U.S. Fines Rockwell $5.5 Million
LEAD: Imposing one of the largest penalties ever on a military contractor, a Federal judge fined the Rockwell International Corporation $5.5 million today for defrauding the Air Force of $446,000 on a navigation-satellite contract.


ARAFAT REFUSING TO CONDEMN RAIDS
LEAD: With the new dialogue between Washington and the Palestine Liberation Organization in jeopardy, Egypt has sought without success to persuade the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, to condemn guerrilla raids into Israel, officials here say.


Shuttle Delayed At Least 2 Days
LEAD: NASA today postponed the launching of the space shuttle Discovery, planned for Saturday, for at least two days.
The postponement came because of failure of a system that separates the booster rockets and fuel tank from the orbiter.


Friend of Defendant Turns Witness in Police Slaying
LEAD: Less than two hours before a New York City police officer was murdered, one of the men later charged with the execution-style shooting drove past the officer's car and pointed him out to a friend, the friend testified yesterday.

Rig Count Climbs a Bit
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs increased by four last week, to a total of 761, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
A year ago the count, a widely watched industry index of drilling activity, was 978.
The count reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q.I can understand how to collect hydrogen and oxygen by electrolyzing water, but how are rare gases obtained?
A.Many rare gases do not form compounds, but are distributed in the air in tiny amounts.

Molecular's Deal With Shionogi
LEAD: Molecular Biosystems Inc. said Shionogi &amp; Company would market Molecular's ultrasonic medical-imaging product in Japan, Taiwan and South Korea.

Review/Television; Living a Year Among the Criminals
LEAD: ''One Year in a Life of Crime,'' on HBO at 10 P.M., brings you as close as you may care to get to the wasted lives of Mike, Rob and Fred, three New Jersey shoplifters in their 20's.
Jon Alpert, a venturesome television reporter, tags along on their forays up and down the aisles of the stores that supply them with anything from bedsheets to silverware to burglar alarms, which they promptly dispose of at knockdown prices.


Honor for Wade
LEAD: Virginia Wade of Britain, who won the women's singles title at the first United States Open, held at Forest Hills in 1968, and who won at Wimbledon on the tournament's 100th anniversary in 1977, has been elected to the International Tennis Hall of Fame.
Gerald Patterson of Australia, a Wimbledon men's singles winner in 1920 and 1922, was also elected, 22 years after his death.


Dollar Rise Helps Notes and Bonds
LEAD: Helped by a rise in the dollar and a report suggesting that the pace of economic activity may be easing, prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher yesterday.

LAOS DELAYS HUNT FOR U.S. WAR DEAD
LEAD: Laos has postponed a joint excavation to search for the bodies of Americans missing in action because of the Bush Administration's censure of Laos last week for not helping the United States in its crackdown on drug trafficking, the State Department said today.


Appointee at Salomon Has Brash Reputation
LEAD: Lee H. Kimmell, 39 years old, who has been named to head the merchant banking efforts at Salomon Brothers, is a figure with a colorful reputation on Wall Street.
He is viewed from inside and outside the firm as a smart investment banker who built Salomon's financial institutions advisory business into one of the most profitable areas of investment banking at the firm.


52 Illegal Aliens Found
LEAD: Fifty-two illegal immigrants, many with plane tickets and most of them from Brazil, were arrested at a place where smugglers keep such aliens, the authorities said today.
The action Sunday night brought the number of such aliens arrested over the weekend to 89.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service has been concentrating for a week on stopping them from using commercial airlines.

LEAD: After dominating the nation's bedding business for much of the last three decades, the Ohio Mattress Company, known for its Sealy and Stearns &amp; Foster brands, is being sold by the family that founded it 82 years ago.

LEAD:  COMPANIES  Shares of Time Inc. surged $9.25 as rumors swirled that other bidders would appear and undermine its plan to merge with Warner Communications.
Although industry experts acknowledged the possibility that another suitor could emerge, most believe that the chances of that happening are small.

LEAD: IT has no real chance of replacing San Francisco's sourdough bread, but an Italian dessert called tiramisu has become something of a local obsession.
Discussions of ''my favorite tiramisu'' have even reached the level of legitimate dinner-party conversation.

British Spending Drop
LEAD: Britain's spending boom appears to be slowing, based on the latest Government figures.
The Treasury said Monday that retail sales had dropped by 2.4 percent in January, revised from a provisional 1.5 percent fall.
Sales had risen in December by three-tenths of a percent.
Britain also said that new consumer credit in January was $:3.49 billion ($6.04 billion), down from December's $:3.52 billion.

Affluent German Unions Fear 1992
LEAD: Unionized workers in West Germany enjoy the highest pay and shortest working hours in Western Europe.
And they are worried that the plan for a single European Community market in 1992 could erode that status and send jobs to southern Europe, where labor is cheaper and less demanding.

LEAD: For some high school sports stars, borderline grades and low scores on college aptitude tests are obstacles to an athletic scholarship, threatening to bring a premature end to aspirations nurtured since childhood.
For the colleges and the professional leagues, which need these stars, such academic problems are potential leaks in the pipeline that provides them with a steady supply of talent.

Tony Battle Over Robbins's Show
LEAD: In a dispute that involves the two biggest theater owners on Broadway, the Tony Awards administration committee is scheduled to meet tomorrow to decide whether ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' will be eligible in the category of best musical.
Millions of dollars are riding on the decision because it is almost certain to affect the financial future of both the Robbins show - a compilation of numbers from 11 of his musicals from 1944 to 1964 - and the other potential nominees.

LEAD: One of the strongest solar flares ever seen has erupted, and scientists said yesterday that it might signal intense solar radiation that could threaten radio communications, satellite operations and television transmissions over the next two weeks.

Ogilvy Unit Gains
LEAD: The Ogilvy &amp; Mather Public Relations Group announced a jump in revenues and used the occasion to roll out a new name for itself.
The group reported revenues of $47.6 million in 1988, a 24 percent jump from the previous year.
The public relations arm of Ogilvy &amp; Mather, which is made up of Adams &amp; Rinehart, O&amp;M Public Relations and Ogilvy &amp; Mather Public Affairs, will now be known as the Ogilvy Public Relations Group.

Publishers Swear Off Acidic Paper
LEAD: Dozens of publishers and authors gathered at the New York Public Library yesterday to call attention to a villain turning millions of books to dust: acidic paper.


Regional Wineries Produce Winners
LEAD: IN contests last week, a dry 1987 riesling made by King's Road Vineyard won the Governor's Cup in competition with 94 other New Jersey wines, and an off-dry '87 gewurztraminer from Sakonnet Vineyards was voted the best-of-show grape wine among 49 New England wines.
Eastern wine makers are increasingly mastering the vineyard and cellar techniques required by such cool-climate vinifera grapes as riesling and gewurztraminer, which yield crisp, fruity, well-made wines in northern Europe, especially in West Germany and Alsace, France.

3 Slain in Northern Ireland
LEAD: Gunmen shot and killed three men at a village gas station today and drove away, the authorities said.
The Irish Republican Army took responsibility, saying in a statement that the gas station, in Coagh, 50 miles west of Belfast, was a stronghold of the Ulster Volunteer Force, an outlawed Protestant group.


First Union to Acquire Florida National Bank
LEAD: The First Union Corporation, based in Charlotte, N.C., said yesterday that it would acquire the Florida National Bank of Jacksonville in a deal worth $849 million.
In doing so, First Union would nearly double its operations in Florida and become the state's second-largest bank.


U.S. Notes and Bonds Down a Bit
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped slightly in extremely light trading yesterday, as dealers took some profits following Monday's small rally and awaited more data on the economy and inflation.

Review/Film; Boswell of the Rust Belt
LEAD: Tony Buba, the director of ''Lightning Over Braddock: a Rustbowl Fantasy,'' seems particularly fond of the television reports about him that have aired on various Pittsburgh stations, so fond that he includes snippets of them in his film.
For one thing, Mr.
Buba no doubt likes being known as Braddock's Boswell, the premier (if only) film maker to have devoted his career to immortalizing this Pennsylvania steel-mill community now in an advanced state of decline.

LEAD: More than 15 years ago a group of NATO and Warsaw Pact representatives gathered in Vienna to negotiate troop cuts in Central Europe.

Federal Express's Afternoon Delivery
LEAD: The Federal Express Corporation will begin an overnight service on April 1 that delivers documents and small packages in the afternoon instead of midmorning at a slightly reduced rate, the company said.
The new Fedex Standard Overnight service promises next-afternoon delivery for packages up to five pounds, arriving by 3 P.M.

LEAD: John H. Sununu, the former Governor of New Hampshire, has passed on to his successor a state budget riddled with the same kind of problems for which he denounced a fellow Governor, Michael S. Dukakis, in last year's Presidential campaign.


Abbott Makes Debut As Angels' Pitcher
LEAD: ''There were a few butterflies out there,'' Jim Abbott admitted in Phoenix yesterday after facing a big-league lineup for the first time and struggling for two innings as his California Angels beat the Oakland Atheltics, 9-4. ''I got caught up in who was out there, rather than what I could do.''


Israelis Kill Arab in West Bank
LEAD: Israeli troops shot and killed a Palestinian today in Nablus, in the West Bank, while hunting for the killers of a soldier who died there 10 days ago, the army said.

Corrections
LEAD: An article by The Associated Press on Saturday about the removal of police powers from five Metro-North officers referred incorrectly to the status they will have after their case is heard by arbitrators.
If the officers, who were involved in improper videotaping in Grand Central Terminal, are reinstated by the arbitrators, they could be recertified for police work.

Bucknell Beats Lafayette And Gains N.C.A.A. Berth
LEAD: Mike Joseph scored 12 points in the second half, including four free throws in the final minute, as top-seeded Bucknell defeated Lafayette, 71-65, last night in the championship game of the East Coast Conference tournament at Towson, Md.
The victory put the Bison (23-7) into the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament for the second time in three years.

Reviews/Music; A Choir's Conviction
LEAD: Rinat, an Israeli choral group, was founded in 1955 and since 1975 has also been known as the Israel National Choir.
The 36-voice ensemble, which is directed by Stanley Sperber, sang a program of mostly sacred settings and folk music on Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, as part of a North American tour.


Socialists Retain Mayoralty in Burlington, Vt.
LEAD: The socialist party of Mayor Bernard Sanders was victorious today as a former community development director was elected to succeed the four-term Mayor.

Reuschel Agrees
LEAD: Rick Reuschel, who would have been eligible for free agency after this season, has agreed to a one-year contract extension through 1990, the San Francisco Giants announced yesterday.
Reuschel, a 39-year-old right-hander, was 19-11 last season and tied for the National League lead with 36 starts.

Dillard to Buy D. H. Holmes
LEAD: Dillard Department Stores Inc. agreed to acquire the D. H. Holmes Company for stock with an indicated value of about $40 million.
Dillard owns 146 department stores in the central and southwestern United States.
Holmes operates 18 department stores and two clearance centers in Alabama, Florida, Louisiana and Mississippi.


Cayton Sues King
LEAD: Bill Cayton, manager of Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, filed suit yesterday in Federal court in Manhattan charging Don King, the promoter, with racketeering, antitrust violations and tortious interference with Cayton's contracts with Tyson.


Soviet Nuclear Ship Denied Entry at 4 Ports
LEAD: A Soviet nuclear-powered container ship has been denied entry at four ports in the Soviet Far East because of public protests, Soviet press reports said.

Cypress Fund Spurns Conversion
LEAD: Cypress Fund Inc., a closed-end mutual fund, said its board had rejected a demand by a group of investors to convert the fund to open-end status.
But the fund said it would repurchase up to 1.35 million of its 8.92 million shares in the open market and said it would begin paying out at least 10 percent of its net asset value to holders each year, with part of the payment representing a return of capital.

Loomis J. Grossman, Developer, Dies at 85
LEAD: Loomis J. Grossman, a real-estate developer whose career spanned more than half a century, died of congestive heart failure Monday at White Plains Hospital.
He was 85 years old and lived in Harrison, N.Y.

LEAD: A Catskill youth was arrested today and charged with setting a fire at a local tire dump that burned for six days.

Evidence Is Lacking on Texas Visit
LEAD: The bulk of available information suggests that John G. Tower did not visit Bergstrom Air Force Base in the years that a former sergeant said he saw Mr.
Tower drunk on the base.
But documents that could help establish the full truth are incomplete or were destroyed years ago.


Pollution By Kodak Brings Sense Of Betrayal
LEAD: If ever there was a company town, this is it.
Since its founding more than a century ago, the Eastman Kodak Company has given steady paychecks to generations of workers and an identity to the city of Rochester.
Today, Kodak employs 47,000 people, almost one tenth of the region's labor force.


Cincinnati Milacron To Sell Subsidiary
LEAD: Cincinnati Milacron Inc. sold the assets and business of its subsidiary, Cincinnati Milacron Semiconductor Materials Inc., to Cincinnati Semiconductor Inc., a subsidiary of the OTC Semiconductor Corporation, a California company in which the Osaka Titanium Company of Japan holds a majority interest.

'Mommy Career Track' Sets Off a Furor
LEAD: To the outrage of many feminists and the applause of much of the business world, the head of a group devoted to advancing women's careers has written in the Harvard Business Review that corporations ought to recognize two different groups of women managers: those who put career first and those who need flexible a schedule to be with the children.

LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday announced the price of its secondary offering of 2 million nonvoting common shares.

Review/Music; From Yemen and Iran
LEAD: Sunday's concert at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, featuring Jewish musicians from Yemen and Iran, offered two radically different types of music.
As played by the singers and percussionists Sara Harat and Sara Malachi, the Yemeni music, filled with flowing steppe-like melodies and meant for weddings and dancing, had a raw, functional quality to it.


Irving Wax, 61, Dies; Jewelry Manufacturer
LEAD: Irving N. Wax, former chairman of the Wasko Gold Products Corporation, died of cancer Monday in the Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla.
He was 61 years old and lived in Woodmere, L.I., and Boynton Beach, Fla.


Raymond Picard, 74, Ex-Chemical Executive
LEAD: Raymond Jean Picard, who helped establish subsidiaries of major French chemical companies here and in Canada and Mexico, died of cancer Monday at Doctors Hospital.
He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Blame the Law, Not the Strike
LEAD: Should Eastern Airlines strikers be permitted to hold other airlines, rail freight and even commuter rail lines hostage to their demands?
Surely not, but under the Railway Labor Act, which covers labor relations in both the rail and airline industries, sympathy walkouts are apparently legal.
Congress needs to act promptly to prevent this abuse of the right to strike.

Parking Rules
LEAD: Because of the weather, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today.
Other regulations remain in effect.

LEAD: Wes Dove, who played for the Seattle Seahawks for one season after graduating from Syracuse University, died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound last weekend, according to the Montgomery County police.

He was 60 years old and lived in Winnetka, Ill.

LEAD: *
D'Arcy Masius Benton &amp; Bowles has acquired Holko-Somerset, an Australian marketing concern, and merged it with Promotional Thinking to form the largest promotional marketing company in Australia.


Muslims Find Deep Isolation In British Life
LEAD: The angry protests by Muslims against the novel ''The Satanic Verses'' and the astonished reaction among other Britons have served to illustrate a gulf in understanding that has made each side a suspicious stranger to the other.


Wine Talk
LEAD: AN Italian sparkling wine, a gewurztraminer from Alsace, France, and two cabernet sauvignons, one from California and one from Israel, were the gold medal finalists in a recent wine competition in New York.
Aside from quality, the wines had only one thing in common, and the wine from Israel should be the tip-off: they were all kosher.

LEAD: On the heels of a report urging Americans to change their eating habits or risk acquiring a variety of chronic diseases, a call has gone out to require food manufacturers to include nutrition information on all product labels.
From the president of a major food company to the head of the Food and Drug Administration, speaker after speaker at a conference here last week on promoting healthful eating sang the same refrain: the time is right for mandatory nutrition labeling.


To Some, Koch Book Is Artful Politics
LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch's new book, an exploration of social and moral issues with John Cardinal O'Connor, has convinced political experts that he is going to focus much of his re-election campaign on conservative but wavering voters.


Harry Andrews, Actor, Dies at 77; In 'The Hill' and 50 Other Movies
LEAD: Harry Andrews, a British film, stage and television actor, died Monday at his home in Salehurst, England.
He was 77 years old.


The Nephew Who Doesn't Cry Uncle
LEAD: For the Milwaukee Brewers' 20-year-old shortstop - who might be the American League rookie of the year - learning to hit a fastball has never been that much of a problem.
Gary Sheffield was 8 years old when he first swung at his uncle's fastball.
But his uncle was not another pot-bellied fellow out there in the backyard, puffing while chasing a plastic ball that his little nephew squibbed past him.


Murder-Suicide Seen In Couple's Deaths
LEAD: A school teacher apparently shot his wife to death and then committed suicide while their three mentally disabled children were in another room, the Passaic County prosecutor, Ronald Fava, said yesterday.

Taiwan Inflation Rises
LEAD: Inflation rose to 4.07 percent in February, the highest official rate in almost seven years, the Taiwan Government announced today, but private economists said the real level could be about 15 percent.
The economists said official figures did not take into account increases in property prices.

LEAD: SINCE the 1600's, Bavarians have handpainted their furniture for the same reason other people do - to make a plain wood like pine look rich.
But they are not minimalists.
What gives Bavarian painted furniture its identity is its extravagant layering of pattern upon pattern.

Hospital Aide Charged in Rape of Patient
LEAD: A cleaning aide at the Metropolitan Hospital Center in Manhattan was arrested late yesterday and charged with raping and sexually assaulting a psychiatric patient at the hospital in January, the police said.


Pat Cummings Is Out
LEAD: Pat Cummings, the Miami Heat forward-center, has been sidelined for the rest of the season by a stress fracture in his left tibia.


DOLE EXPECTS LOSS
LEAD: The battle over the nomination of John G. Tower to be Secretary of Defense all but ended today as Senate Democrats apparently secured a majority of votes against confirmation.


Review/Opera; Cast Changes in 'Salome'
LEAD: The two newcomers to the Metropolitan Opera's ''Salome'' - Katarina Ikonomu, who made her house debut in the title role Saturday night, and Neil Rosenshein, who has been singing Narraboth since the opening, which he missed because of illness - sang their parts in the ranting style that has become all too standard at the house when voices of the desired easy projection cannot be found.


Senator Asks Study of Time Deal
LEAD: Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, chairman of the Senate antitrust subcommittee, is urging the Government to examine closely the proposed combination of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. for adverse effects on competition and choice of programming.


Dow Tops 2,300, but Selling Trims Gain
LEAD: Stock prices moved higher yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average topped 2,300 before wide program selling apparently cut the gain.
The session ended with a 4.83-point increase to close at 2,295.54.


SOVIETS TO ACCEPT WORLD COURT ROLE IN HUMAN RIGHTS
LEAD: Underscoring its new support for international organizations, the Soviet Union said today that it would accept the binding arbitration of the International Court of Justice in disputes over five important human rights agreements.


I.B.M. Gives Scholarship Fund $2 Million
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation has given the Boston Latin School a $2 million scholarship fund, one of the largest amounts ever given to a single public school.


Judson Philips, 85, Author, Dies
LEAD: Judson Philips, who wrote more than 100 mystery and detective novels under the pseudonym Hugh Pentecost as well as his own name, died of complications resulting from emphysema Tuesday in the Sharon (Conn.) Hospital.
He was 85 years old and lived in Canaan, Conn.


Politics of a Polish Forest; Indictment of Soviets in Katyn Massacre Reflects Warsaw's Opening to Opposition
LEAD: Poland's accusation that Soviet forces carried out the Katyn Forest massacre of Polish officers in World War II, overturning what for 45 years had been the official explanation of the mass murder, reflects a widening search by the Communist leadership for forms of legitimacy as it seeks accommodation with political opponents.

LEAD: The annual White House Radio and Television Correspondent's dinner usually lures the President, the bulk of the Administration as well as all those television stars who appear on the White House lawn each morning and evening.
This year, however, the prize guest won't come to dinner.
President Bush is planning to spend the night of the event, March 16, in Colorado Springs addressing the National Business Hall of Fame dinner.

LEAD: Pitching was their priority, but today it became the Yankees' first significant worry of the spring.
John Candelaria, the team's best starter in 1988, remains troubled by a sore right knee that could require surgery and force him to miss at least the start of the season.


Faberge-Avon Tie Focus of Rumors
LEAD: Rumors were widespread on Wall Street yesterday that the chairman of Faberge Inc., the maker of Aquanet hair spray and Brut cologne, would use the proceeds from the company's $1.55 billion sale to Unilever N.V. to buy Avon Products Inc., the cosmetics company.
Avon's stock rose 62.5 cents, to $23.75, in heavy trading of 983,800 shares.

LEAD:  Q. My bathroom is next to the bathroom in the next apartment, and we hear noise through the wall.
A soundproofing company said I would be wasting money on soundproofing and suggested putting a radio in the bathroom.
Have you any other suggestion?
A.I'm afraid the soundproofing contractor was right.

Atari Plans To Divest Retail Unit
LEAD: The Atari Corporation said today that it planned to dispose of the Federated Group Inc., a consumer electronics retailer it purchased in 1987.

Fur Venture in Moscow
LEAD: The Jindo Corporation, South Korea's largest fur coat producer, said today that it would enter a partnership with a Soviet company to open stores in the Soviet Union.
It would be the first business venture between the Soviet Union and South Korea.
Jindo officials said their company, which produces 400,000 fur garments a year, signed a contract on Tuesday in Moscow with Interlink of the Soviet Union to set up the venture with an initial investment of $800,000.

Results Plus
LEAD:  TRACK AND FIELD  Kingdom Ties Foster's Mark: Roger Kingdom of the United States tied Greg Foster's world indoor record of 7.36 seconds for the 60-meter hurdles yesterday at a meet in Piraeus, Greece.
Foster set the record in Los Angeles on Jan. 16, 1987.
Kingdom took the lead at the start and was never threatened.

LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation and the French auto maker Renault S.A. plan to set up a separate company to operate their joint venture that will produce the JJ small Jeep in North America and Europe, Chrysler officials said today The venture will be similar to Diamond-Star Motors, Chrysler's venture in Bloomington, Ill., with the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation.

LEAD: The Angolan Government announced Tuesday that it would cut back oil production by 5 percent in the second half of this year, the state press agency Angop reported.

Levi's Ad Is Removed
LEAD: A Levi's jeans commercial has been pulled from Channel One, the daily television news show started this week in six schools, because Detroit school officials found it sexually suggestive, program creators said yesterday.
The decision to pull the advertisement comes as the project begins a 25-show test amid complaints from educators about the appropriateness of television commercials in classrooms.

Louis yesterday from Florida to have his pitching elbow examined, knocked over a television cameraman at Lambert Airport and then walked away, a videotape of the incident showed.

LEAD: Jeff Innis, a sidearm pitcher who studied psychology at the University of Illinois, allowed no runs in spring training last year and still didn't make the Mets.
This spring, he is spending his free time reading murder mysteries, but gets most of his suspense wondering what he'll have to do to make the best pitching staff in baseball.

Review/Music; Danish Radio Big Band
LEAD: Big brassy chords and burnished ensembles are the pride of the Danish Radio Big Band, which opened a three-night stand Monday at Sweet Basil.
The 20-piece band led by its pianist, Ole Kock Hansen, played with gleaming precision in a set that included blues-flavored tunes (two by Thad Jones, who led the band in 1977-78 and in 1984), ballads and post-bop pieces that could slip into convoluted counterpoint or move into marches with a rock-funk beat.

LEAD: Lyudmila Filimonova, a Soviet speed skater, has been banned for 15 months after failing a drug test taken at the European championships in January, an International Skating Union official said yesterday in Berlin.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation acknowledged that an analyst was correct in reporting that the company had experienced delays in shipping its 3090-S mainframe because of a problem in manufacturing some key logic chips.
A spokesman for I.B.M. said that the problem was behind the company now and that it would not have an impact on the computer maker's earnings for the year.

Soybean Prices Off Sharply; Big Brazil Harvest Awaited
LEAD: Soybean futures prices fell as much as 10 3/4 cents a bushel yesterday, erasing much of the past week's gains.
Speculators backed away from the market, unnerved by the looming Brazilian harvest and an increase in farmer selling.


Gunmen Rob Brooklyn Bank
LEAD: Two masked gunmen robbed a Brooklyn bank of an undetermined amount of cash yesterday.
The men announced the holdup at 6:17 P.M. after the Williamsburg Savings Bank at 2301 81st St. in Bensonhurst had closed for the day, said a police spokesman, Sgt.
Raymond O'Donnell.
The men forced a security guard and a teller who were putting money in the bank vault to lie on the floor, then took the cash.


Former Top Bureaucrat Held in Japan Scandal
LEAD: Japan's bribery and influence-peddling scandal spread to the country's usually highly respected bureaucracy today as prosecutors arrested a former high-ranking official of the Labor Ministry and charged him with accepting bribes.

Finland's Insider Bar
LEAD: The Finnish Parliament approved legislation Tuesday to outlaw insider trading.
The Security Markets Act would be the first law regulating Finland's stock exchange, and it would provide for a maximum penalty of two years in prison for using privileged information to profit in market transactions.
The act must now receive presidential approval.


Review/Theater; A Subversive Farce From Joe Orton
LEAD: There are no butlers in ''What the Butler Saw,'' the play the English writer Joe Orton completed only weeks before he was murdered in 1967.
Orton's title, with its prurient whiff of Edwardian peep shows, is generic: it announces a low farce rife with fallen trousers, sexual indiscretions, mistaken identities, lewd puns.


Reviews/Dance; Fleeting Patterns Evoke An Ephemeral World
LEAD: Merce Cunningham has long been fascinated by the curious patterns dancers can make as they pass through space.
Therefore it was only appropriate that he should call his newest work ''Field and Figures.'' A choreographically, scenically and musically dense production, it received its New York premiere by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company on Tuesday night at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street.


New Device Is Saving the Limbs Of Some Young Victims of Cancer
LEAD: After nearly a decade of research, doctors and engineers have developed a device that may spare thousands of children with bone cancer the additional trauma of amputation.


Deal Reported Between Teamster Official and U.S.
LEAD: As the Government's huge case against the International Brotherhood of Teamsters moved toward a trial scheduled to begin Monday, lawyers said yesterday that an agreement had been reached on settling the civil lawsuit's claims against an important union official.

LEAD: To the Editor:


New York Cancer Specialist Says Bush Has Chosen Him as Physician
LEAD: Dr.
Burton J. Lee 3d, a New York cancer specialist, says he has been selected as President Bush's personal physician and expects the appointment to be announced shortly.


Shea &amp; Gould Paring Office
LEAD: The law firm of Shea &amp; Gould said yesterday that it would scale down its office in Los Angeles to ''a small nucleus.'' A third of the lawyers there announced earlier this week that they were defecting to the new firm of Myerson &amp; Kuhn.


Alexander Bookstaver, 77, Unions' Adviser
LEAD: Alexander Bookstaver, a retired banker and financial consultant to unions, died of a liver ailment Tuesday at his home in Miami Beach.
He was 77 years old.


Another Setback for Seabrook
LEAD: The Governor of New Hampshire announced yesterday that the state would seek to block low-power testing at the Seabrook nuclear plant because of doubts about the plant's ever being allowed to operate at full power.
The new position reverses more than 15 years of staunch state support for the Seabrook reactor.


Rebels Say They Attack Big Afghan City
LEAD: Afghan rebel spokesmen said today that the battle for Jalalabad, the eastern Afghan city, had begun and asserted that two army posts east of the city had been captured.
