China Buys More Wheat
LEAD: Private exporters have sold an additional 400,000 metric tons of United States wheat to China at subsidized prices under the Export Enhancement Program, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday.
The sale increased to more than 7.8 million tons the amount of wheat sold to China for 1988-89 delivery under the program.

LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it would take an additional reserve against its first-quarter earnings to cover losses related to student loan defaults that were developing into a messy legal affair involving several major banks.

LEAD: Representative Porter Goss, Republican of Florida, has bought a house here with an ill-starred recent history.

Strategies For Social Visionaries
LEAD: ''I TRIED this experiment with my kids,'' Tony Schwartz, a media consultant, said yesterday. ''I would burn toast in the morning, and with a stopwatch I'd tell how long it took the children to tell me the toast was burning.
Then I would burn toast on another day when the radio was playing, and it took much longer for them to tell me about the toast.

LEAD: Spokesmen for Poland's Government and the Solidarity union said tonight that they had reached broad tentative agreement on restoring Poland's second chamber of Parliament, with members chosen in open and free elections, and on instituting an office of president with broad powers for foreign and security affairs.

LEAD: A United States Army espionage ring in West Germany that was broken up last summer was larger and more serious than first realized, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation is now investigating as many as five former soldiers as part of the case, according to Government officials and documents.

LEAD: A Federal agent who was killed last week while on a narcotics investigation on Staten Island was simultaneously involved in an undercover operation to determine whether corruption existed in an early-release program for prisoners, Federal law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

Back on the Water
LEAD: The Circle Line sightseeing boats begin their 1989 season of daily three-hour sails around Manhattan today.
The boats, which have been sailing since the mid-1940's, depart at 10:30 A.M. and 2 P.M. from Pier 83, at 43d Street and the Hudson River.
The number of daily cruises is to increase to 12 by the summer, and evening cruises are to begin on June 10.


U.S. Sprint in Atlantic Cable Deal
LEAD: In a move to expand its international presence, the U S Sprint Communications Company today announced an agreement to buy a 50 percent stake in the first private telecommunications cable linking the United States and Europe.


How They Voted
LEAD: Following is the 53-to-47 roll-call vote by which the Senate today rejected President Bush's nomination of John G. Tower to be Secretary of Defense.
Voting yes were 3 Democrats and 44 Republicans.
Voting no were 52 Democrats and one Republican.
Adams, D-Wash., no; Armstrong, R-Colo., yes.


Mayerling Journal; Lurid Truth and Lurid Legend: A Hapsburg Tale
LEAD: One hundred years ago, the heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne brought a 17-year-old mistress to his hunting estate in this sylvan village, shot her through the head and turned the gun on himself.
Or did he?
Was Prince Rudolf murdered, as die-hard monarchists hold?
Or was he really killed in a drunken brawl with the uncles of his mistress, young Mary Vetsera?

Offering by P.&amp;G.
LEAD: The Procter &amp; Gamble Company is offering $200 million of 10 percent notes due 1990 at a price of 100 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

Bass Brewing Adds 38 Canada Hotels
LEAD: The British brewing conglomerate Bass P.L.C. agreed to buy the Canadian hotel chain Commonwealth Hospitality Ltd. from Scotts Hospitality Inc. of Toronto for $285 million (Canadian), or about $237.5 million (United States).
The purchase involves 38 hotels in Canada totaling 8,742 rooms.
Thirty-two of the hotels operate under franchise from the Memphis-based Holiday Corporation, two operate as Briarwood Hotels Inc.

Super Rite Agrees To Buyout Plan
LEAD: Super Rite Foods Inc. agreed to be purchased by a management group that includes its chairman, Alex Grass.
The agreement is worth $127 million in cash, plus preferred stock and warrants, up from an offer of about $118 million.
The chief financial officer, William K. Schantzenbach, said the stock and warrants had not been valued yet.


Emhart Rejects Topper Offer
LEAD: The Emhart Corporation, a diversified hardware manufacturer, yesterday rejected a $2.4 billion takeover offer from Topper L.P. as inadequate and said other parties were interested in the company.

Ex-Unisys Official Admits Paying Bribes to Get Pentagon Contracts
LEAD: In a significant advance in the Federal inquiry into Pentagon purchasing fraud, a former vice president of the Unisys Corporation pleaded guilty today to bribing a Defense Department official, drawing from a secret $5 million fund set up with Unisys money.

LEAD: Sid R. Bass and Lee M. Bass, the Fort Worth investors, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they own 5.5 percent of the Bay Financial Corporation, a Boston real estate concern, only as an investment.


Chronic Shoulder Injury Forces Horner to Retire
LEAD: At the age of 31, after 218 home run in 10 major league seasons, Bob Horner announced his retirement yesterday in Miami, where he had been trying to catch on with the Baltimore Orioles as a free agent.
The right-handed power hitter, who slammed four home runs in one game for the Atlanta Braves July 6, 1986, said his left shoulder had not healed sufficiently from an operation last Aug.

Computer Stars on Collision Course
LEAD: The wizards at Sun Microsystems Inc., which makes engineering work stations, have long viewed the Macintosh personal computer of Apple Computer Inc. as a nice toy, not a serious machine.
At the same time, the marketeers at Apple have long scoffed that they sell more machines in a month than Sun sells in a year.


Johnny Carson to Stay As 'Tonight' Show Host
LEAD: Johnny Carson is to stay on as host of the ''Tonight'' show on NBC for at least another year - his 28th -through Sept. 1990.

2 Committees Urge Congress to Stop Abuse at Adult Care Centers
LEAD: The Federal Government should immediately establish minimum standards for residential institutions that house elderly, disabled or mentally ill adults, two Congressional committees declared today.


South Africa's Ruling Party Fails to Persuade Botha to Step Down
LEAD: South Africa's governing National Party today offered President P. W. Botha a facing-saving solution to the leadership crisis but failed to persuade him to yield power.


General James H. Rumbaugh, 49, Director of Army Medical Center
LEAD: Army Maj.
Gen.
James H. Rumbaugh, commander of Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, died after making a parachute jump in Honduras, the Pentagon said today.
He was 49 years old.


Metro Datelines; Incinerator in Jersey Is Fined $180,000
LEAD: A Warren County garbage-to-energy incinerator has been fined $180,800 for air pollution violations, New Jersey State environmental officials said yesterday.


Richard Diamond And Ellen Minsky Exchange Vows
LEAD: Ellen Minsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Arnold I. Minsky of Brookville, L.I., and Richard B. Diamond, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Morris Diamond of New Hyde Park, L.I., were married last evening at the Lotos Club in Manhattan.
Rabbi Saul I. Teplitz officiated.


Stake Raised In Infotech
LEAD: Avacus Partners, an investment group led by the Dutch investment firm of Reiss &amp; Company, disclosed this week that it had raised its stake in Infotechnology Inc. to 9.2 percent from 8 percent.

LEAD:  EASTERN'S BANKRUPTCY  Eastern Airlines filed for bankruptcy protection in an attempt to conserve cash and to gain time to persuade striking employees to return to work.
Meanwhile, Eastern continued to operate limited flights.  [ Page A1. ]  Thousands of Eastern ticket holders, confused and angry, turned travel agents' offices into chaos.

Sunday at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800).

Candelaria Feels Better
LEAD: The good news: John Candelaria's damaged right knee showed minimal swelling overnight, and today the Yankee pitcher said he felt better after having fluid drained from the knee on Wednesday.
But Candelaria also said he learned two days ago that there was the possibility he had a cyst in the knee, and he said that if he does, it might require arthroscopic surgery.

Egypt Accused Of Big Advance On Poison Gas
LEAD: Egypt has made a major effort to improve its ability to produce poison gas by acquiring the main elements of a plant from a Swiss company, Swiss and American officials say.


Dow Slips 4.11 Points in Listless Trading
LEAD: The stock market turned in a listless performance yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 4.11 points to close at 2,291.43.

LEAD: In the sense that both groups perform 20th-century music nearly exclusively, the Arditti String Quartet is the British equivalent of America's Kronos Quartet.
But there are big differences, as indicated by the Arditti's marathon three-hour-plus concert Wednesday night at Town Hall.

Review/Film; Keeping Love Alive, Indefinitely
LEAD: Corinne (Cybill Shepherd) and Louie (Christopher McDonald) are madly in love, which is unhappy news for Louie's best friend, Philip (Ryan O'Neal), since Philip loves Corinne too.
But as the lovers are celebrating their first wedding anniversary, Louie is hit by a car.
After this, he is gone but not forgotten, since Corinne spends the next 23 years mooning over Louie's memory (''My psychiatrist says I suffer from the halo effect'') and leaving little snacks beside his picture.


Scientists Discover Site of Cold Virus Attacks
LEAD: Scientists reported yesterday that for the first time they had completely analyzed the site at which cold viruses attack human cells.
The successful analysis raises the long-range possibility of designing a new class of drugs to combat these widespread causes of human illness.


In Vitro Fertilization Clinics Vary Widely in Success Rates
LEAD: The first national survey of clinics that offer laboratory fertilization services to infertile couples has found wide variation in their success rates, a Congressional committee said today.

Review/Art; Sad Memory and Hope From Louise Fishman
LEAD: Louise Fishman is known for lean abstract paintings with muscular blocks of color.
Paint is applied in many layers, often with a palette knife, until color stirs and glows.
Her fields of squares and rectangles have clear roots in Cezanne, Mondrian and the expressionist abstraction of the 1940's and 50's, but they also have something of the matter-of-factness of the 60's.


Restaurants
LEAD:  Brive Robert Pritsker, the chef and proprietor of Brive on East 58th Street, is like a brilliant yet puckish schoolboy, capable of dazzling the class with his lightning intellect, yet at the same time prone to scattering tacks on your seat when you go to the water fountain.
His genteel town-house restaurant, with its pale yellow walls, Oriental rugs and antique furnishings, suggests tradition and consistency.

John Eastman Jr., Arts Administrator, 73
LEAD: John Eastman Jr., an arts administrator, died of heart failure Wednesday on the island of St.
Martin in the West Indies.
He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Aboard the Shuttle, Leg Room and Extras
LEAD: Just before takeoff, the flight attendants dutifully repeated the standard safety pantomime with seat belts and safety information cards.
But this morning, the performance was before 158 empty seats and just 19 passengers.


Review/Art; Flashing Aphorisms By Jenny Holzer at Dia
LEAD: In the large, darkened spaces of ''Laments,'' Jenny Holzer's new installation piece at the Dia Art Foundation, the artist's hauntingly pessimistic words flow between floor and ceiling in columns of moving colored light.
The same phrases also sit, stately and still, carved into the granite and marble tops of 13 stone sarcophagi.

BSN Reviews Plan For Athlone Seats
LEAD: The BSN Corporation, which owns 4.95 percent of Athlone Industries, said it was reviewing ''the feasibility and desirability'' of seeking control of the manufacturer of sporting goods and other products through representation on its board.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, BSN, a sporting goods company based in Farmers Branch, Tex., said it had offered unsuccessfully in Janurary to buy Athlone's Dudley Sports unit.


At The Movies
LEAD:  Feature-Film Debut ''I have incredible trepidation,'' said Gary David Goldberg.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.  76ers 106, Kings 96: Charles Barkley had 25 points and Ron Anderson added 18 last night as Philadelphia handed Sacramento its 12th loss in 14 games.
A jumper by Kenny Smith brought the Kings within 81-74 with 10:27 to play.
But Derek Smith, acquired by the 76ers last month after being released by the Kings, sparked an 11-2 surge and a driving layup by Gerald Henderson gave the 76ers a 92-76 lead with 7:34 to play.


Davis Returns
LEAD: Robbie Davis is riding again, having accepted two mounts at Santa Anita Park Wednesday almost five months after riding the horse that trampled and killed a fellow jockey, Mike Venezia, last Oct. 13 at Belmont Park.
Davis, 27 years old, was so upset by the accident that he would not return to the race track and considered retiring after having won 1,357 races and earned more than $37 million.


Rangers' Losing Streak Grows to 4
LEAD: Brian Mullen, still dazed after having been checked hard in the first period, probably had it easier than his teammates.
For reality was a terribly painful thing to have a good handle on in the Ranger locker room tonight.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 458 money market mutual funds rose by $1.2 billion, to $295.24 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Those of the 138 institutional funds decreased by $39.6 million, to $72.69 billion.
The assets of the 226 general-purpose funds were down by $19.9 million, to $95.14 billion.


Toronto Dominion
LEAD: The New York branch of the Toronto Dominion Bank is offering $150 million of 10 percent notes due 1999 at a price of 99.55 to yield 10.07 percent through Salomon Brothers Inc.
Noncallable for five years, the notes yield about 83-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.


Kitty Dukakis Seeks Privacy To Recover from Alcoholism
LEAD: Kitty Dukakis, the wife of Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, said today that she was an alcoholic and appealed to the news media to let her pursue her recovery in private.

Killer Ruled Eligible For Work Payments
LEAD: A New York State appeals court ruled today that a former Rochester schoolteacher who suffered job-related psychological problems and killed his supervisor 19 years ago should be given workers' compensation.

LEAD: Four former officials of the state-financed AIDS Outreach Program in New York City have been indicted on charges of stealing $350,000 from the progam, Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said yesterday.


NIGERIA AND ISRAEL MAY RESTORE TIES
LEAD: In a move that might mark a significant shift in strategic alignments in Africa, Nigeria's military Government is considering restoring diplomatic relations with Israel, according to diplomats and news reports here.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Meeting for Volunteers
LEAD: A dozen or more countries have established overseas volunteer programs since the United States created the Peace Corps in 1961, but there has been little interaction among the participants from different nations over the years.
That is changing.


Music by Amram
LEAD: David Amram, the composer, will present a concert of his music at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 97th Street, on Sunday at 3 P.M.
The program includes ''Zohar,'' for unaccompanied flute; a Wind Quintet; the New York premiere of ''Blues for Monk,'' for unaccompanied horn, and ''Native American Portraits,'' for violin, piano and percussion.

William Clay Ford Retires; Two in Family May Get Posts
LEAD: William Clay Ford, vice chairman of the Ford Motor Company, retired today from active management and several policy-making committees at the No. 2 auto maker.
At the same time, he indicated that his son William Clay Ford Jr. and nephew Edsel Ford 2d would be appointed to committees of the board within the year.


Pact on Yankee Games
LEAD: Several suburban cable companies yesterday added Yankee broadcasts to their basic package on the Madison Square Garden Network, which includes Knicks and Rangers games.
John Malone, head of the group that signed the deal, said there would be ''a modest basic subscriber rate increase.''


Campeau Plans Shifts At Federated
LEAD: In another effort to consolidate its operations and cut expenses, Federated/Allied department stores said yesterday that it would set up a centralized regional credit center in a Cincinnati suburb to take over the credit activities of its Ohio stores and its three New York area department stores.


Judge Limits Punitive Claims for Products
LEAD: A Federal judge declared today that multiple punitive damage suits against manufacturers and distributors of harmful products were unconstitutional.
Repeated punishment for a single course of conduct violates the right to due process, he said.

Simple Shrine Symbolizes Hindu-Muslim Rift
LEAD: Every day, khaki-uniformed policemen armed with rifles and bamboo staves ring a simple whitewashed shrine here that has become a symbol of the Hindu-Muslim rift in India.


Urgent Relief for Mexico
LEAD: The Bush Administration has abandoned the Baker plan for third world debt with its faulty premise that more debt can solve the problem of too much debt.
In its place, the Administration appears to have endorsed debt reduction in the form of interest relief, debt relief or a combination of both.
The change is welcome.


Surging Rutgers Gains N.C.A.A. Bid
LEAD: Playing in its most important game in six years, Rutgers added another chapter tonight to what has been one of the more remarkable success stories in college basketball this season.


Corning Name Change
LEAD: The Corning Glass Works said today that it would ask shareholders at its annual meeting on April 27 to approve a name change to Corning Inc. to reflect the non-glass portion of its operations.
The company said it derived one-third of its sales in 1988 from non-glass businesses.


Chrysler Incentives To Counter G.M.
LEAD: Countering the discount program announced by the General Motors Corporation earlier this week, the Chrysler Corporation introduced a more generous incentive program to take effect on Saturday.
Discounts will increase on 15 car and truck models, decrease on 7 and stay the same on 16.
The increases in rebates range from $100 for the Omni and Horizon models, which will carry a $500 discount, to $1,250 for the 1988


Indictments on Drug Money
LEAD: Thirty-three people were charged Wedjesday with hiding in jewelry businesses as much as $5 million a day in Colombian drug money profits.
In announcing two Federal indictments, United States Attorney Robert Bonner said more than $1 billion had been laundered since 1986.
Many of the suspects were arrested last month in raids on the jewelry district in downtown Los Angeles.


Police Call Death of a Bronx Boy a Murder
LEAD: The death of a 17-month-old Bronx boy this week was ruled a homicide after an autopsy revealed that he was beaten to death, the police said yesterday.

Metro Datelines; Panel Presses Koch To Testify in Private
LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch was urged by a New York State commission yesterday to testify in private about his administration's Talent Bank, ''so that we can avoid the necessity of serving subpoenas.''


Nine Who Have the Certain Something
LEAD: Merce Cunningham observed recently that there seemed to be more and more dancers these days -and good ones.
Technical expertise, and even bravura dancing, have become relatively familiar ingredients and may be enjoyed in diverse programs throughout New York City.
But there are also dancers who, for all their virtuosity, draw the eye with some mysterious extra essence.


How Eastern's Rivals Are Faring
LEAD: The airline industry has generally absorbed the passengers affected by the strike at Eastern Airlines as a threatened slowdown by pilots across the rest of the industry failed to materialize.
Most of Eastern's competitors report increased traffic on previously scheduled flights and some have added extra flights to meet overflow from Eastern.


A Former Jersey Mayor Tearfully Pleads Guilty
LEAD: The former Mayor of Wayne, N.J., tearfully pleaded guilty today to conspiring to extort $50,000 from a developer seeking approval for an $18 million condominium project.

Rock Date
LEAD: Miracle Room, an avant-garde rock band, will perform tomorrow at 10 P.M. at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055).
Tickets are $6.


Referee Angers Arbour
LEAD: When the game was over and nobody had managed to win it tonight, Coach Al Arbour angrily blamed his team's inability to post a 4-3 regulation victory and its ensuing submission to a 4-4 overtime tie with Philadelphia on a poor performance by the referee Don Koharski.


For Democrats, the Price of Victory
LEAD: Now, with any kind of luck, the Bush Administration can begin.
The Tower affair cast a shadow over almost all President Bush's 50 days in office.
The battle produced a few heroes and some serious casualties.
But the damage need not be permanent, if all sides turn quickly to urgent tasks postponed during the long weeks of bitter debate.

Eddie Palmieri
LEAD: The pianist Eddie Palmieri is leading his Latin-jazz group tonight through Sunday at Indigo Blue, 221 West 46th Street (221-0033).
Sets tonight and tomorrow at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M., Sunday at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M.

Robbins Show Eligible For Top-Musical Tony
LEAD: The Tony Awards administration committee ruled yesterday that ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' is eligible for the award as best musical.
The decision makes the show, at least for now, the prohibitive favorite in a category that carries the potential of millions of dollars in ticket sales.


Bleak Day for Eastern Ticketholders
LEAD: Ralph Kornblatt called his travel agent weeks ago and bought a $580 nonrefundable ticket for a round-trip flight to Atlanta on Eastern Airlines.
The flight was scheduled to leave La Guardia Airport tomorrow at 9:05 A.M.


Board of Estimate Sets a Midnight Curfew for Itself
LEAD: The Board of Estimate, whose twice-monthly meetings have been known to end only with the dawn, voted unanimously yesterday at the respectable hour of 8:20 P.M. to prohibit itself from voting after midnight on any item in the future.


Dollar Ends Lower in U.S.; Jobless Report Is Awaited
LEAD: The dollar drifted lower against other major currencies in dull United States trading yesterday as dealers marked time a day before the release of February's unemployment report.


FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company is offering $350 million of notes due 1994 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.
Underwriters gave the notes a 10.05 percent coupon and priced them at par, to yield about 70 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.
A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.


Abramowicz to Coach
LEAD: Danny Abramowicz, who set all the Saints' major pass receiving marks during his seven-year career with New Orleans, has been named head coach of the Jesuit High School Blue Jays in that city for next season.
He was selected from a field of 26 applicants to replace Frank Monica, who resigned to become an assistant coach at Tulane

British Now Lie Low With Rushdie
LEAD: Some British literary figures who spoke out and signed petitions for Salman Rushdie after the Iranian death threat against him for writing ''The Satanic Verses'' are now beginning to think that a quieter approach would be better both for them and for him.


Latin American Loan Issues Up
LEAD: Prices of bank loans to Latin American countries rose sharply yesterday in the over-the-counter market, where these discounted loan agreements are traded.
The sharp price gains of more than 10 percent for some countries' debt were in expectation of the Treasury's plan for Latin American debt relief to be announced today.


U.S. Charges Russian With Spying And Says He Will Be Sent Home
LEAD: The United States said today that it was expelling a Soviet military attache who was detained Wednesday night and accused of espionage.


FIRST CABINET VETO SINCE '59; BUSH CONFERS ON NEW CHOICE
LEAD: The Senate today rejected President Bush's nomination of John G. Tower to be Secretary of Defense, the first time in 30 years that a President was denied his choice of a Cabinet member.


New Snags For Japan Jet Project
LEAD: New differences between the Commerce Department and the Pentagon over safeguards for technology are delaying Bush Administration agreement to cooperate with Japan in developing and producing an advanced version of the F-16 fighter.


Judge Refuses to Open Proceeding
LEAD: A Federal judge who rebuked prosecutors this week and then sealed the transcript of his remarks refused a request yesterday to open a proceeding in which lawyers questioned jurors to determine if they had been prejudiced by wide publicity about the judge's comments.

Borden Inc. to Solin Associates, for its Aunt Millie's family style spaghetti sauce, with a budget of $3.5 million.


Health Chief Seeks Better Care for Poor
LEAD: The new Secretary of Health and Human Services said today that his top priorities were improving health care for the poor, providing health insurance for the 37 million uninsured Americans and strengthening preventive medicine and health education.


Topics of The Times; Good Reason for Higher Tolls
LEAD: In a victory for common sense, a Federal judge has rebuffed a bid by the Automobile Clubs of New York and New Jersey to roll back tolls on four hectic interstate crossings: the George Washington Bridge, the Bayonne Bridge, the Goethals Bridge and the Outerbridge Crossing.
The auto clubs' lawsuit, repeating one they lost in 1979, challenged the 1987 increase in tolls from $2 to $3.

In a new ad for the Acura Legend Coupe, the younger Saarinen shows an appreciation of elegant shapes.

Spanish Bank May Get Bid
LEAD: Deutsche Bank A.G. of West Germany said Wednesday that it planned to make a friendly takeover bid for the Banco Comercial Transatlantico of Barcelona.
The Deutsche Bank already owns 39.05 percent of the bank, known as Bancotrans.
Terms of the possible bid were not disclosed.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Consumer's World page on Feb. 18 about swimming pools misstated fencing requirements for outdoor residential pools in New York State.
Barriers at least four feet high are required by state law.


Northrop Accused of Selling U.S. a Faulty Missile System
LEAD: The Northrop Corporation's cruise missile guidance system was never properly tested, and many of the nearly 1,800 nuclear missiles aboard the United States bomber fleet may not work, according court papers unsealed today.

LEAD: Robert Dick and Marielana Arizpe, two flutists, are to play new-music solos and duets at 9 P.M. tomorrow at Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street (219-8242).
Tickets are $6.


French Ease Currency Rules
LEAD: The French Government announced today that it was lifting all foreign-exchange controls on companies in France.


Bush Vows Prompt Cleanup Of Federal Nuclear Wastes
LEAD: President Bush today vowed to ''waste no time'' starting a cleanup of tons of radioactive waste and widespread soil contamination from the Energy Department's 12-state nuclear weapon complex.


Safelite Glass Investor Gets Chance to Be No. 1
LEAD: Robert H. Morosky helped build the Limited into a major chain of women's clothing stores, but he did so as No. 2 to Leslie H. Wexner, the chain's chairman.
Now he wants to build a chain of stores that sell auto glass, and he wants to do it as No. 1.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Aeromaritime, Paris, a unit of UTA French Airlines, ordered two 737-300 Boeing jets for a total of $60 million, Boeing Commerical Airplanes said.


China's Failure in Tibet
LEAD: Since 1950, China has shown Tibet the rawest face of imperialism - destruction of thousands of monasteries, suppression of the Tibetan language and culture and widespread settlement by Chinese colonists.
This has resulted in the death of perhaps a million Tibetans.


Metro Datelines; Cost of AIDS Plan Put at $1.6 Billion
LEAD: A five-year state plan to combat AIDS could cost $1.6 billion, according to documents made public yesterday by Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo's office.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Army's Old Foe Rides High in Brazil
LEAD: When Brazil's armed forces toppled President Joao Goulart in 1964, they were no less intent on ousting the powerful man behind the throne, Leonel Brizola, a crowd-pleasing Socialist who had dreams of succeeding his brother-in-law in elections the following year.


Measles Cools Basketball Fever
LEAD: The elevator stopped on the lowest level of the parking garage of the Civic Center: a downtown shopping mall and the site of the Hartford Coliseum.
A quick glance to the left, then the right, revealed that no one was around.
That was good.
It would be better to be as inconspicuous as possible.


Johnson Had Control, Coach Insists
LEAD: Ben Johnson's attorney today continued his attempt to show that the sprinter was incapable of making decisions on his own and that he was a foil of a manipulative coach.
But much of his cross-examination of Charlie Francis, Johnson's coach for 12 years, failed to produce his desired effect.


Review/Art; Spanish Sensuality In Paintings by Zuloaga
LEAD: Anyone who is interested in the social as well as in the esthetic history of 20th-century painting should drop by the Spanish Institute, where a well-chosen retrospective of the Spanish painter Ignacio Zuloaga (1870-1945) fills two floors with paintings and drawings.
These are works that in their day enjoyed an exceptional apotheosis in this country.


Partial Solar Eclipse in West
LEAD: A partial eclipse of the Sun occurred Tuesday across western North America, where amateur astronomers gathered to view the event through telescopes.


'Murphy's Law' Series Is Canceled by ABC
LEAD: ABC canceled its second show in a week yesterday, announcing that ''Murphy's Law,'' ABC's 10 P.M. entry on Saturday night, would end after the broadcast of March 18.


Coach, Player Honored
LEAD: Joe Marsh of St.
Lawrence was named ECAC Hockey's coach of the year and Lane MacDonald of Harvard was named the most valuable player on the eve of the league's tournament in Boston.
Marsh coached the Saints to 27 victories, the most in that college's history.
MacDonald led Harvard to a 26-2 record, the best for the Crimson in 52 years.


The Judge Who Spoke Too Soon
LEAD: Judge John Sprizzo of the Federal District Court in New York may have a strong complaint against prosecutors appearing before him in an ongoing drug conspiracy trial.
But by scolding them out of turn he has embroiled himself and news organizations in a needless confrontation over the right of the press and public to know how justice is being dispensed.


AMERICAN TO LOSE VATICAN BANK JOB
LEAD: An American Archbishop who was at the center of an Italian banking scandal will step down soon as head of the Vatican Bank, and supervision of the bank will pass to a new commission of five cardinals.

LEAD: Ordinary citizens would be allowed to carry concealed pistols under a proposed bill to sell gun permits to ''law-abiding Texans.'' He shook his head, said there was no such animal and walked away.

Review/Recital; Ysaye Sonata By Violinist At Tully Hall
LEAD: Leonidas Kavakos hit his full stride late in the evening at Alice Tully Hall Tuesday, delivering a firmly shaped and atmospherically colored account of Ysaye's beautiful Fifth Sonata for Solo Violin.
Here the young Naumburg prize winner consolidated his formidable technical skills and matched them persuasively with a sense of musical purpose.


CANADA RULES OUT NEW CRASH INQUIRY
LEAD: After reviewing a narrow split by the official investigation board on the cause of a 1985 airplane crash in Newfoundland in which 248 American soldiers died, Canada's Transport Minister has rejected calls to name a special judge to look further into the matter.


Corrections
LEAD: A brief article in Business Day on Feb. 28 and an article last Monday, both about mutual funds, misstated the net cash flow into equity mutual funds in January.
The Investment Company Institute says the figure, not including reinvested dividends, was $72 million.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about nutrition labeling carried an incorrect description of an inquiry involving the Campbell Soup Company.
The company has not been fined by nine state attorneys general over health claims made for its products.
The issue is still under investigation in the nine states and by the Federal Trade Commission.

U.N. Rights Panel Takes Limited Action on Cuba
LEAD: The United Nations Human Rights Commission agreed today to maintain loose surveillance over Cuba's human rights performance for another year in a decision that appears to fall short of what the Bush Administration was seeking.


The Sounds of Brazil, Citified in Sao Paulo
LEAD: FOR some Americans, Brazilian music means Afro-Brazilian carnival processions and sambas in the street; for others, it means the whispered vocals, sly harmonies and delicate guitar work of the bossa nova.
Still others are catching up with the tropicalia movement of the 1970's, when young, politically progressive Brazilian songwriters reacted to the broadening of rock with their own electrified pop; a selection recently appeared on ''Beleza Tropical: Brazil Classics,'' compiled by David Byrne of Talking Heads.


Federal Drug Agency Takes Center Stage
LEAD: The Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, which found itself in a national spotlight yesterday as President Bush kicked off an anti-drug crusade, is the nation's primary agency - but far from the only one - in a diversified war against cocaine, heroin and other illegal drugs.


Topics of The Times; Soviet Progress, U.S. Delay
LEAD: The Soviet Union strikes a blow for world law and human rights.
Not many months ago, readers would have blinked in disbelief at such a statement.
Yet Moscow now says it will accept the binding adjudication of the World Court in cases arising from five basic human rights agreements, including the 1948 convention condemning genocide.

Norton Simon Resigns From Art Museum Post

Review/Theater; Mark Lamos's Cleaned-Up Version of Shakespeare's Vice
LEAD: The setting of ''Measure for Measure'' is a city teeming with vice.
Prostitution and alcohol plague the populace, unchecked by the state's lax law enforcement.
Although the city is Vienna, we recognize the scene from closer to home.
The questions raised - primarily, Where does justice intersect with morality, and how can it be obtained?

2 Players Say They Signed With Agents in School

Harelm's Promise
LEAD: Physically, Harlem has been a symbol of urban ruin.
Its decline over 70 years from a masterpiece of urban elegance and lucid city planning to a ruinous array of broken buildings and garbage-strewn lots could not have been more complete if it had been legislated or decreed.
Yet the paradox of Harlem is that even in the midst of what has become a physical wasteland, there is a creative energy that is alive and palpable.

Teeth, Picked
LEAD: Last fall, University of Michigan anthropologists showed that human tooth size has been shrinking twice as fast in the last 10,000 years as in the previous 90,000.
Why?
One night a Neanderthal threw a flash-frozen hunk of mammoth on the fire and rendered redundant the kind of choppers one needs to make mincemeat out of raw flesh.

Guidepost; Preparing for Planting
LEAD:  Cabin fever ends.
Gardening begins again.
What to do first?
The yard needs a thorough spring cleanup: remove dead grass, leaves and twigs, dropped tree fruits and other debris of winter.
Cut back overgrown hedges, shrubs and small trees.
All this gives you a head start before planting, which won't start until next month after the soil dries out.

Dr. Frank Curran, Veteran Psychiatrist And Professor, 84
LEAD: Dr.
Frank J. Curran, a Manhattan psychiatrist, died Wednesday at New York Hospital after being hit by a car.
He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.
From 1945 to 1947, he was chief psychiatrist at St.
Vincent's Hospital.
He resigned from the post after Msgr.
Fulton J. Sheen, then a professor at Catholic University, denounced psychoanalysis as an escapist substitute for confession.

Weather Vanes Get Attention At Eye Level
LEAD: Weather vanes, which have been around since antiquity, are more popular than ever and increasingly less visible - at least on American rooftops.
These days wind indicators are more often seen indoors - at museums, folk-art galleries, antiques shows and auctions.
Major dealers who handle these artifacts say they stock mostly rarities and choose them carefully for their special shape, an enviable patina, or both.


For Delivery Services, Buying From China is Cheaper
LEAD: Although diaper delivery vendors may have gained some market share from disposables last year, American producers of cloth diapers did not reap much of the benefit.
A surge in imports from China in 1986 all but drove American cloth diaper producers from the delivery market.
Imports of heavy-ply cloth diapers from China climbed to 1.06 million pounds that year, up from just over 82,000 pounds in 1985.

EDNA O'BRIEN: Reveling In Heartbreak
LEAD: ''WHAT'S YOUR ASTROLOGICAL sign?'' asks Edna O'Brien over the phone, a friendly but odd question from a serious writer.
I can't tell if she thinks this is the standard American get-acquainted question, a fey joke on that, if it's of real interest to her, or a sign of natural dizziness.
Cautiously, I reveal myself as a Pisces.

WESTCHESTER OPINIONNear the Heart Of White Plains, A Neighborhood
LEAD: ALTHOUGH quick to admire our modern city, more than a few of us in White Plains have begun to lament its meteoric growth.
Downtown, imposing structures of shimmering glass and colored concrete have added the ''plaza'' or ''center'' to their new business addresses.
A drive to the train station now winds you onto a approach similar to that of an airport.


Japan's Bad Mix Of Money And Politics
LEAD: WHEN influence must be peddled and money exchanged, Japan's most powerful politicians, bureaucrats and business executives meet behind the high walls of ryotei, luxurious restaurants where proprietors are known for discretion and ordinary Japanese can never get a reservation.

West Germany and Its Biotechnology Anxiety
LEAD: WEST GERMAN science passed a milestone of sorts this month when the Government's Central Commission for Biological Safety approved an experiment involving 37,000 petunias genetically altered to be pink when they bloom next May.

Serene Setting for Sichuan and Hunan
LEAD: AT Dragon Garden, on the Boston Post Road in Norwalk, near Ski Market, the potential for competent Hunan- and Sichuan-style Chinese dining is apparent.
The professionalism clearly exists, both in kitchen skills and in service.
And the gray and-pink decor has a restful, serene quality that could hardly be improved on, with smoking and nonsmoking sections kept well apart on separate levels and with generous space between the well-napped tables.

FASHION: On the Street; Snuggling Up With Classic Camel's Hair
LEAD: The camel's-hair overcoat is as dependable in cold weather as the camel is when it's hot.
Here is a cover-up that will go anywhere with practically anything, be it a pin-striped business suit or blue jeans and a turtleneck, silk scarf or wool choker.
It's dressy enough when it needs to be, but there's always that nice dash of informality and practicality.

'Hanussen': Foreseeing the Hitler Nightmare
LEAD: If you happened to be living in Berlin in the late 1920's or early 1930's and witnessed the episode in historical insanity that was the rise to power of Adoph Hitler, it is highly probable that the name Hanussen might ring a bell.
Hanussen was the stage name of one Klaus Steinshneider, a nightclub and stage clairvoyant of considerable fame during those years, widely accused of fraud in the newspapers, but, nonetheless, it seems, a magician of rather chilling abilities.

FICTION'S EMBATTLED INFIDEL
LEAD: I fail to see how Salman Rushdie can say about Islamic culture, ''I know it well'' (''Salman Rushdie: Fiction's Embattled Infidel,'' Jan. 29).
After all, from the age of 13, he worked to be accepted by a society that despises the culture from which he came.
However, if it is true that he understands Islamic culture well, this is proof that his current book is a conscious defamation of Islam.

Detroit Says Efficiency Has Gone Far Enough
LEAD: THE automotive industry accomplished a remarkable technological feat between 1975 and 1985 by nearly doubling the number of miles that cars and light trucks were able to travel on a gallon of gasoline.
But now further progress is in jeopardy.
At a time when oil imports are rising, domestic oil production is decreasing and environmentalists are warning of the need to curb atmospheric pollution, car makers are lobbying for relaxed fuel efficiency standards.

Switzer's Warning
LEAD: When Barry Switzer, the beleaguered Oklahoma football coach, decided to take his daughter, Kathy Switzer, on a skiing trip to Colorado during spring break last week, some of his friends were skeptical.

Taking the Mud at Saturnia
LEAD: IN Saturnia the smell of bad eggs wears off after two hours.
Initially overpowering, the sulfurous smell rises with the steam from the hot waters that for millenniums have been gushing out of an extinct volcanic crater in this village, midway between Rome and Florence, in southern Tuscany.
The waters of Saturnia have been considered a panacea for a number of ills for 3,000 years.


SMALL TOTS, BIG BIZ
LEAD: Your article on Kinder-Care reflects the popular but unwise trend to mix child day care with academic learning programs.
A day-care program genuinely focused on the needs of children would direct its objectives to achieve a representation of basic family, home-style care.
It would provide daytime surrogates who would offer the tots unconditional acceptance (love can't be bought), much consistency and sensory experiences to stimulate well-documented early learning needs.


THE WORLD: Overlooking the Unworkable; Apartheid Frays at the Edges, But Its Core Is Unchanged
LEAD: THE South African Government set a precedent last week that could hasten the demise of its laws on strict residential segregation.
In response to threats by a right-wing municipal council to cut off utilities used by ethnic Indians living in the officially white town of Boksburg, it asked provincial officials to give them temporary permits allowing them to stay.

Dance Theory
LEAD: THE EXPERIMENTAL CHOREOGRAPHY of Trisha Brown tends to defy standard characterization, even by the choreographer herself. ''I struggle with it,'' she admits. ''It's important to try and demystify it, yet not take away the mystery.

THE AMBIGUOUS YASIR ARAFAT
LEAD: I would like to clarify the caption accompanying a picture illustrating the article ''The Ambiguous Yasir Arafat'' (by Marie Colvin, Dec. 18).
In the caption, I am described as an Arafat associate.
I am not Mr.
Arafat's associate.
I am a Palestinian student, studying in Paris, and working as a journalist for an Arab news agency.


A Reluctant Burden
LEAD: IT was in India, during a month of intense heat, that I hired four men to work for me as beasts of burden.
I didn't hire them as porters to carry luggage or hiking gear.
I hired them to carry me.
I was not enthusiastic about it then and the event is not a pleasant memory now, but at the time it was the surest way to get where I wanted to go.

LEAD: Richard Martin can't suppress a smile of triumph as he shows off his prize acquisition.
Slick to the touch, and not much to look at, save to Martin's expert eye, it is, in pop parlance, a ''nerd shirt.''

Recuse, J'accuse!
LEAD: I HAVE ALWAYS RE-cused myself from anything to do with communications,'' said Clayland Boyden Gray, President Bush's legal counsel and chief ethics adviser.
I had just asked him, with no apparent malice aforethought, for copies of his financial disclosure forms for the past three years, a request that puts some Government officials on the defensive.


Frances Pennoyer, 92, J. P. Morgan's Child
LEAD: Frances T. Pennoyer, the last surviving child of J. P. Morgan, died yesterday after a stroke at her home in Locust Valley, L.I.
She was 92 years old.


Correction
LEAD: Because of a mechanical error, the Music View column on page 27 of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies the transcriptions of Wagner works performed in piano recordings by Glenn Gould.
They are by Gould himself.

Review/Theater; Exploring Improbabilities And the Human Comedy
LEAD: The whole is not as good as parts of ''The Sunday Promenade'' by Lars Forssell, but the good parts make this strange play at the New Theater of Brooklyn an amusing evening.
Mr.
Forssell's imagination is more poetic than dramatic; he can make you find connections among wildly conflicting ideas and his dialogue often reminds you of the snipped and elliptical lines of song lyrics.


Cold Comfort: The Ordeal Of Renovating a Home in Winter
LEAD: TO be inscribed in the Suburbanite's Handbook:


Showdown At 'Gunbelt' Savings
LEAD: The Sunbelt Savings Association sits in a nondescript four-story office building overlooking an endless stream of cars that whiz by on the Lyndon B. Johnson Freeway.
Dark tinted windows give it a secretive quality and it is hard to distinguish this building from at least a dozen others clustered like so many covered wagons and encircled by concrete freeways.


Just How Far Right Is Salvador's Right?
LEAD: The far-right Republican Nationalist Alliance is favored to win the Salvadoran presidency in an election next Sunday.
The prospect is raising questions in Washington and El Salvador about whether the party is controlled by its standard-bearer, Alfredo Cristiani, or Roberto d'Aubuisson, a former officer widely linked to political killings.

I am a hostess at our local historical society and my job is to show visitors through a restored early home, the Thomas Moore


Reviews/Music; From Haydn to Bolcom, By St. Paul Orchestra
LEAD: The first well-known conductor of the St.
Paul Chamber Orchestra was Dennis Russell Davies, who became music director in 1972.
He was followed in 1980 by Pinchas Zukerman.
When Mr.
Zukerman resigned in 1987, he was succeeded by a curious but innovative three-member artistic commission.


Douglas Fairbanks Jr. Is Turning 80, Going Like 60
LEAD: It seems the older you get, the more people want you to dig up the past,'' says Douglas Fairbanks Jr. as he hands a visitor a cup of English tea during an interview in his Park Avenue apartment. ''I'd much rather talk about the future or at least the present.
But not at all.
People insist on hearing about the good old days.


POSTINGS: Crystal-Ball Computer; Predicting Co-op Prices
LEAD: They laughed when Susan M. Wachter sat down at her computer keyboard two years ago and announced that she could predict the future of Manhattan cooperative apartment prices, an accomplishment that for years had defied the best efforts of real estate experts and economists.
Yet her prediction turned out to be about as correct as a computer- assisted human's could be.

LEAD: SPRING rains and thawing temperatures often cause basement walls to develop leaks.


LONG ISLAND GUIDE
LEAD:  ART FROM DROSS  Apparently, one man's garbage can be another's art.
So today, the always-adventurous Islip Art Museum opens ''Dross to Art,'' a group exhibition showcasing nine artists who use dross - defined as ''refuse, rubbish, impure matter'' - to make their creative statements.


Loudspeakers Climb the Walls
LEAD: The fevered rise of housing costs has put such a crunch on urban living space that many apartment dwellers simply can't find room for loudspeakers.
That's quite a switch from earlier times, when even a bulky piano in the living room was pretty much taken for granted by music lovers.
But, as they used to say then (when an occasional bit of Latin was also taken for granted), tempora mutantur.Today floor space has to be parceled out by the square inch.


Paying for Employee Education Benefits
LEAD: Thanks to several complicated tax changes, the price of an education is going up for some employer-subsidized students - at least for now.
Employees whose companies pick up the tab for their studies may soon find that their paychecks have shrunk because taxes are suddenly being withheld on those benefits.


U.S. Shapes Plan to Get Missiles From Afghans
LEAD: The Bush Administration is increasingly concerned that it may not be able to recover hundreds of sophisticated Stinger missiles still in the hands of American-backed Afghan rebels, senior Administration officials said today.


Question of the Week; Should the Mets Trade Strawberry?
LEAD: Besides the Mets' pitching staff, Strawberry is the only outstanding player the team has.
Sure Hernandez was, Jeffries could be, and McReynolds might be.
But, none brings the magic to the plate like Strawberry.
His ability to hit the long ball at a pitchers' park, his blazing speed, topped with his m.v.p.-like stats the last two years makes him the top everyday player in the National League, and maybe in the Major Leagues.


CLUB COMFORT
LEAD: I RECENTLY DINED IN ONE OF THE PATRI-cian clubs scattered throughout New York -those limestone oases that transport you from the tumult of city life.
In the library, attending maids passed prefatory drinks to our assembly, along with hot hors d'oeuvres: flaky spinach tarts; napoleons of Roquefort; smoked salmon on dark bread; shrimp with green mayonnaise.


Oprah Winfrey's Odyssey: Talk-Show Host to Mogul
LEAD: Here is a typical story from the pages of the improbable career of Oprah Winfrey: It's 1984, the 30-year-old host of a Chicago morning talk show is in North Carolina, on the set of Steven Spielberg's film ''The Color Purple.'' Though she has no previous acting experience, she has been cast in an important supporting role in a lavish production of Alice Walker's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel.


Reviews/Music; Handy Four-Part Harmonies, With Humor
LEAD: John Handy's first set at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night started out sluggishly; the rhythm section couldn't find a groove, and Mr.
Handy, when he improvised, just added to the set's sullenness.
About halfway through the second tune of the first set, Mr.
Handy and the rhythm section found equal ground, and like an engine finally starting up in the cold, they took off.

The Narrow Margin
LEAD: There is no more delicate responsibility for political leaders than nuclear weapons.
But from the beginning, in 1945, leaders made decisions about the weapons on flawed premises and with inadequate understanding of possible consequences.
We are lucky to have avoided the worst.

LEAD: It's a long season.

You just can't trade a player like that.

LEAD: Harriet Beecher Stowe was born there in 1881.

By Albert Lebowitz. (Louisiana State University, $15.95.) Albert Lebowitz, an attorney who lives in St.
Louis, has applied much ingenuity to fashioning an intertwined series of nine stories, each with the word ''day'' in the title, in which a small pool of characters make repeat appearances.

The Day Einstein Went Public Tom Mackin; Tom Mackin lives in Short Hills.
LEAD: ALBERT EINSTEIN, the world's most famous scientist and perhaps the greatest mind of the 20th century, lived in Princeton longer than any other place.
But Princetonians scarcely knew him.
He made only one public appearance in the town he called home for 22 years.

THE WORLD SERIES THAT STILL HAUNTS OAKLAND
LEAD: By their nature, the best relief pitchers respond to pressure.
They also respond to pressure questions.
And now, at his locker in the Oakland Athletics' clubhouse, Dennis Eckersley, who threw the pitch that Kirk Gibson of the Los Angeles Dodgers hit for the home run that turned last year's World Series, was asked what he had learned from the salt that still sears his wounds.

Trying to Fix a Statute Run Amok
LEAD: RICO, is a statute run amok and no one is beyond its reach.
Many times a day, unsuspecting citizens and businesses are shocked to find that they are targets of RICO suits.
The law's broad civil suit provisions cast a net so wide that virtually any commercial dispute becomes a candidate for civil RICO jurisdiction.

LEAD: In an 11th-hour stay worthy of the twisting tale it has provoked, Richard Serra's ''Tilted Arc'' was spared dismantling yesterday.
A Federal judge issued a temporary restraining order barring the Government from removing the giant sculpture from Federal Plaza in lower Manhattan until new legal arguments can be heard.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last week in The Week in Review on airplane repairs misstated the number of accidents and deaths related to metal fatigue on United States commercial airliners in the last five years.
According to the National Transportation Safety Board, there have been 16 accidents and one death.

Recycling Bill Draws Mixed Reviews
LEAD: Officials of the agency that buys supplies for New York City say a City Council bill on recycling - intended to ease the garbage crisis - will make life uneasy for them.
They say the bill's requirement that they give preference to products made of recycled material will slow down the purchasing process, possibly make it more expensive and cause the city to buy merchandise whose efficacy is unproven.

LEAD: Suppose a company has a letter to send to the Electronic Mail Association.

LEAD:  MAKEBA: My Story, by Miriam Makeba with James Hall. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) Born in South Africa, the black singer Miriam Makeba has drawn on her Swazi culture to endure a career in political exile.
Her autobiography is the story of ''life lived as communal dialectic, a matter of African creative will set against bureaucratized repression,'' Robert Farris Thompson said here last year.

LEAD: The glut of office space in New York City and throughout the metropolitan region persists and in some areas is growing worse, part of a national trend that followed a wave of growth earlier in the 1980's.


It's Not Easy Being Green
LEAD: HAVE you ever heard the grass say ''Ouch!'' when you step on it?
I have.
In squeaky voices, the slender stalks of green shout in fragmented choruses, sounding much like the cacophony you hear when entering a large cafeteria, only octaves higher.

Ferry, Davis No. 1 Players
LEAD: Danny Ferry of Duke and Clarissa Davis of the University of Texas have been selected the recipients of the 1989 Naismith Award as the players of the year in college basketball.


Tribute to Gehrig
LEAD: It was 50 years ago this year that baseball's Iron Man, Lou Gehrig, took himself out of the Yankee lineup for the first time since 1925 and brought an end to his remarkable record of 2,130 consecutive games.
The ailment that ended his career, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, which is known as Lou Gehrig's disease, is still considered incurable.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. My vacation house is used a few times a year, but not enough to leave the heat on between visits.
To protect against freeze damage, I winterize the toilets and sink traps by pouring antifreeze into them each time I leave.
I am concerned about the effects this antifreeze has on the septic tank and the environment.


Nature Sows Life Where Man Brewed Death
LEAD: Hard by the runways of Stapleton International Airport lies the strangest of environmental paradoxes: a blotch of grotesquely polluted land teeming with a profusion of wildlife that evokes comparisons to Yellowstone National Park.


Question of the Week; Should the Mets Trade Strawberry?
LEAD: For equal, or nearly equal value, yes.
Despite being a feared hitter, he does have significant failings.
His defense is suspect, if not downright poor.
He catches the ball off-balance and is then in a poor position to throw.
His powerful arm is more than negated by the number of extra steps he takes to release the ball.

Poll Finds Public Favors Sharp Cut in Arms Funds
LEAD: At a time when concern about war and international tension is as low as it has been at any time in the last 50 years, the American public favors sharp reductions in military spending to reduce the budget deficit while it opposes cuts in Medicare and Social Security, according a poll released last week.

On the Outs
LEAD: The saga of Joe Clark began in 1982, when he threw 300 troublesome students out of Eastside High School in Paterson, N.J.
Last week, the tough-talking principal, who patrols the school's hallways with a bullhorn and baseball bat, was himself suspended for five days.
School officials said he failed to supervise his building two weeks ago when three male dancers stripped to their G-strings during a variety show by professional entertainers at a school assembly.


Tracking the Green Fairy
LEAD: In 1882, Oscar Wilde effused: ''A glass of absinthe is as poetical as anything in the world.
What difference is there between a glass of absinthe and a sunset?'' Verlaine, Rimbaud, Toulouse-Lautrec, van Gogh, Daumier, Baudelaire - all took ''inspiration'' from absinthe, the cloudy green aperitif made from wormwood, a strong-smelling perennial herb.

Valentine's Day, she was shocked to see the newest message on the cannon on Tufts University's main quad. ''Jodie,marry me.'' it said.

John J. McCloy, Lawyer and Diplomat, Is Dead at 93
LEAD: John J. McCloy, the lawyer and diplomat who was the United States High Commissioner in postwar Germany and an adviser to Presidents from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Ronald Reagan, died yesterday at his home in Stamford, Conn.
He was 93 years old.

LEAD: Large numbers of Central American refugees continue to apply for political asylum in cities around the country, although on the Rio Grande at Brownsville, Tex., the Government has largely succeeded in stopping them.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  THE MEN FROM THE BOYS: Rites of Passage in Male America.
By Ray Raphael. (University of Nebraska, $19.95.) How does a young boy attain manhood - or learn what it is all about - in a society where there are no formal rituals to facilitate his passage?
Ray Raphael, the author of ''The Teacher's Voice,'' explores this question in ''The Men From the Boys: Rites of Passage in Male America.


Seeing Ground Zero in Nevada
LEAD: AT 5:30 in the morning, the Zeus Room of the Alexis Park Hotel in Nevada was packed with animated tourists.
Even in the predawn hours, a substantial assembly in one of the public rooms of a Las Vegas hotel would not have been unusual.
But in this case, not a single slot machine, roulette wheel or blackjack table was in sight; the Alexis Park is a nongambling hotel.

Midsummer Magic in the Lands of the Midnight Sun
LEAD: A STORY IS TOLD ABOUT THE AESIR, THE gods of Asgard.
It seems that they had to fashion a rope of tremendous strength, and they asked Odin the One-Eyed to obtain one for them.
He went away for a while and returned with what appeared to be a slender silken cord.
It didn't look very strong, but when the gods examined it they saw that it was woven from the roots of a mountain, the purring of a cat, the sinews of a bear, the breath of a fish, the beard of a woman, the spittle of a bird.

He was 65 years old.


Question of the Week; Should the Mets Trade Strawberry?
LEAD: My knee-jerk reflex was to trade him.
But then I witnessed his monstrous home run to the center-field wall in an exhibition game this weekend.
The beauty of his outstretched arms and bat acting as one, making contact with the ball and launching a rocket, would be lost to me if he did it for any other team but the Mets.

Children's Books
LEAD: To the Editor: ''A Book Lover's Los Angeles'' (Travel, Jan. 8) may have misled readers as to the first edition of Beatrix Potter's ''Tale of Peter Rabbit.'' Unable to get a trade publisher to produce her little book, the author arranged for 250 copies to be privately printed in December 1901.
Its unexpected reception led to a second edition printed (privately) in February 1902, with some slight changes in both the text and the binding.


Sectarian Killings in Ulster Continue to Mount
LEAD: An escalating series of sectarian killings in Northern Ireland continued Friday night, when a Catholic was shot dead by terrorists as he was leaving a bar in West Belfast.
Three other people, two of them Catholics and one a Protestant, were wounded in two other shootings in Ulster on Friday.

At the End of A Hard Drive, Maui Luxury
LEAD: THE road to Hana, a secluded town at the easternmost tip of Maui, second largest of the Hawaiian islands, is known as the Hana Highway, undoubtedly dubbed that by some waggish jofficial to encourage tourism.
A highway it is not.
It is rather a two-lane layering of macadam over a 54-mile course that takes more than two hours and 600 turns to maneuver, a pothole-pocked trail that tunels and twists along rain-eroded cliffs, between sea and rain forests, passing over 54 narroiw birdges.

The Glory of Tara Will Never Fade
LEAD: WHEN ''Gone With the Wind'' premiered in Bridgeport 50 years ago, it took me two weeks to persuade my mother to take me with her to see it.
She and all of her friends were in various stages of reading Margaret Mitchell's novel.
Unfortunately for me, Marion Bailey, among them, had finished it, and it was her cryptic four-word critique that sounded the death knell that nearly ruined my chance to view this spectacle at its first showing.

Rome's Venerable Ghetto
LEAD: FROM A BELVEDERE ON THE JANICULUM -that most verdant of Rome's hills, bounded on one side by St.
Peter's and on the other by Rome and the world - the eye picks out, from among the gorgeous clutter of Roman roofs, two declarative edifices: the Pantheon, its gray rotunda looking from this perspective like a hovering spacecraft; and the great dome of the Temple, Rome's eclectic neo-Byzantine synagogue.

TOUGH TALK FOR DEMOCRATS
LEAD: I am offended that Joseph A. Califano Jr. consistently equated the major social problems facing this country with blacks, in his article ''Tough Talk for Democrats,'' Jan. 8.
Poverty is not a race issue.
Crime is not a race issue.
Poor education is not a race issue.
The influence of unhealthful environments on otherwise healthy children is not a race issue.

Dunn's unpredictable dances have ranged from the austere to the complex. ''Sky Eye'' was rich in both choreographic invention and thematic implication.

Getting Around Fees on Singles
LEAD: FOR a person traveling alone, among the sour notes embedded in the small type of any tour brochure is the phrase ''single supplement.'' The supplement is the extra charge that the tour operator imposes upon a person occupying a room alone on a tour where double occupancy - two in a room - is the standard.

LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
LEAD: Cats as Cats Can WHEN show dogs win enough points they become Champions.
Show cats become Grand Champions.
Everything is grander in the world of cats.
Take cat show living quarters, for example.
Rum Tum Tugger, a red tabby Persian, had not a care in the world as he lounged in his blue velour bed, which took up only a small portion of his lavishly carpeted and curtained cage with the litter box discreetly placed in the far corner.

Tokyo
LEAD: To the Editor: Upon returning from a recent trip to Tokyo I was delighted to read Jared Lubarsky's ''Exploring the Heart of Old Tokyo'' (Travel, Oct. 23).
Travelers should know that they can stay in the Asakusa View, a Western-style hotel in Asakusa adjoining the Asakusa Kannon Temple.
The hotel has an attraction no other hotel in Tokyo offers: a huge wooden bath on the top of the building overlooking the Shitamachi section of the city.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Denmark  Question: During a stay in Copenhagen we would like to visit Legoland.
How would we get there?
Also, are there bed and breakfast places near Tivoli in the city, and are there discounts on local transportation? - H. K., Westport, Conn.
Answer: Vacationers bound for Legoland, the amusement park in Billund, from Copenhagen may use rental car or fly, but taking the train is the least expensive route.

A Diver's Map of Bermuda: Here There Be Treasures
LEAD: WHAT IS THIS THING?
A ship, you say?
Well, no.
Not anymore.
Once she was a ship, a few centuries ago.
Now she looks like something that spent a hundred years in a food processor and another hundred in a trash compactor.
She must have struck the reef over there and slid off into this sand hole and stuck, all of her, and wallowed and worked and rocked back and forth under the force of tide and current and countless storm seas, vanishing into the living coral and beneath the shifting sand until, back in 1983, a sharp-eyed Bermudian spotted an anomaly on the bottom and decided to investigate.

Correction
LEAD: An item in the Sports People column last Sunday incorrectly reported the number of players who have been members of the Parade Magazine high school all-America team for three seasons.
Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Patrick Ewing are the only ones to have made the first team three times.
Six players - Abdul-Jabbar, Ewing, Kenny Anderson, Alonzo Mourning, Sean Kemp and Jerrod Mustaf - made the team as either a first- or second-team selection in three seasons.

Back on the Water
LEAD: The Circle Line sightseeing boats have begun their 1989 season of three-hour sails around Manhattan.
The boats leave Pier 83, at 43d Street and the Hudson River, at 10:30 A.M. and 2 P.M.
The number of daily cruises is to increase to 12 by the summer; evening cruises are to begin on June 10.
Tickets are $15; $7.50 for children.

In Pursuit of Intimate Monumentality
LEAD: Forty or 50 years ago, an urban school was the centerpiece, the anchor, of its neighborhood, a building of both architectural grandeur and civic importance. ''DeWitt Clinton High School Clinton High School was the best building I ever walked into as a kid, except maybe church,'' Robert Esnard, the deputy mayor of New York City, said not long ago of his childhood neighborhood in the Bronx, and he had it exactly right.


IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; The Condo Watch in Downtown Stamford
LEAD: THE fate of an 18-story condominium under construction at Forest Street and Greylock Place in Stamford - it will be the city's tallest and most luxurious apartment building - is being watched closely by local officials, developers and realtors who consider it a key component in creating an upscale downtown housing market.


Freighters
LEAD: To the Editor: The directory of barges and freighters (Travel, Feb. 12) was greatly appreciated.
Many people just don't know much about that mode of travel.
But there was one slight misstatement: that freighter passengers are not accepted over 75 years of age.
Most lines are now up to a 79-year limit, and some are higher, such as CAST, which is 80, and Columbus Line, Chilean Line and Mineral Shipping, which accept passengers through 82.

LEAD: TWO years ago last summer, 64-year-old Jean Elbaum lapsed into a ''persistent vegetative state,'' a form of eyes-open permanent unconsciousness, following a stroke.

Preparing for Telemark Skiing
LEAD:  Bike riding is good preparation for telemark skiing because it strengthens the legs and knees, requires balance and contributes to aerobic fitness.
It is important to be limber for telemarking, so regular stretching exercises are helpful.
Watching the ''The Telemark Movie'' (available from the North American Telemark Organization for $34.95) is good preparation and review of the movements.

What they see is mostly a mystery to this viewer.
Mr.
O'Connor's newest piece, ''Four Sister Dances,'' presented Friday night at the Kitchen, looked as if he had poured a batch of decently interesting ideas into a grinder and remixed the minced fragments into an almost tasteless stew.

Review/Recital; A Boston Pianist at Merkin
LEAD: Jung Ja Kim, a pianist on the faculty of the Boston Conservatory of Music, came to Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday night with a program of Ravel, Schubert, Chopin and Isang Yun.
She played with seriousness and comprehension; one took away the impression of a thoughtful student and teacher of the literature rather than of a burning communicative drive, but in that context there were satisfactions to be had throughout.

U.S. Rig Count Declines
LEAD: The number of working rigs in the United States fell by 18, to a total of 743, in the week ended Friday, down from 946 a year earlier, the oil services company Baker Hughes Inc. said today.
The rig count reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and not the number producing oil.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Record Speed  Q. If a phonograph record spins at a constant speed, isn't it going faster along the outer edge than toward the innermost section?
Does the record-maker compensate for the difference?
Which part of the record has the better sound quality?
A.
There is a considerable difference in speed from the outer to the inner area of a record.

G.M. Inventories
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation is satisfied with its high inventories of unsold cars and trucks, the president of the company, Robert Stempel, said.
G.M., the nation's largest auto maker, has been struggling to reduce inventories and regain its dominance of the auto market.
Its domestic market share has fallen from a peak of 44.5 percent in 1984 to 36.1 percent last year.

Austrian Move on 1992
LEAD: Austria is planning to make its long-expected application for European Community membership this summer, an Austrian minister said today.
But the Minister of the Federal Chancellery, Dr.
Heinrich Neisser, told a management symposium in Bergen that formal talks about Austrian membership would not begin until after the European Community's internal market barriers were eliminated by the end of 1992.

Texas Track Plans Are Slow Out of the Gate
LEAD: When Texans voted to legalize parimutuel wagering 16 months ago, it seemed that a new era in American racing would soon begin.
Texas, because of its large cities and longstanding enthusiasm for horses and gambling, sounded like a natural to join New York and California as a national racing power.
Wealthy oilmen were expected to stampede to build fabulous new racing plants and offer spectacular new races.

Review/Opera; 'Orlando,' by Handel
LEAD: Handel's ''Orlando,'' a moral tale from Ariosto with superb music, may become a repertory opera.
This reviewer did not see the Peter Sellars production that ran for 40-odd performances in Cambridge, but heard the piece in Carnegie Hall's 1985 Handel Festival, saw it at the Chicago Opera and reviewed most of the title role on a recording by the countertenor Drew Minter.

LEAD:  Maurice Evans Dies at 87  Maurice Evans, popular for his Shakespearean portrayals in the 1930's and 40's, has died, Page D27.

LEAD: The images speed by in the blink of an eye: A woman in a puff-sleeved, belle epoque dress.
Horse-drawn trolleys.
Steaming locomotives.
Babies in perambulators, paraded by uniformed nannies.
The Queen of England and the Russian Czar.


Trusts Weigh Sale Of Cameron Stake
LEAD: Two trusts that control 47.5 percent of the shares outstanding of Cameron Iron Works Inc. said they might sell their shares of the Houston-based oil services concern.
The trusts, created by the company's founder, James S. Abercrombie, control 14.4 million of the 30.3 million Cameron shares.

LEAD: The Justice Department and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters reached a tentative settlement of the Government's racketeering suit against the union yesterday, calling for sweeping changes in the way national officers are elected and corruption in the union is policed.


Sexual Organ Surgery
LEAD: In a new surgical procedure, doctors at the University of Chicago Medical Center are using skin from the forearm to fashion a new penis to replace an organ lost to accident or disease.

LEAD: Two hundred years ago, ''liberty trees'' were planted throughout France to mark the French Revolution, which led Samuel R. Gammon, executive director of the American Historical Association, to suggest that the United States could make no better gift to mark the bicentennial of France's revolution than trees.

A Permanent Home for No. 1
LEAD: Frank Gagnon was more spy than scout, his chores more those of surveillance than evaluation.
Officially retired, Gagnon, living in Providence, R.I., kept unofficial tabs on Eddie Giacomin, less concerned with how the goaltender played than with whether other National Hockey League teams had sent someone to see him.


As the Image of Furs Suffers, So Does Profit
LEAD: Aside from the smell of mink, there is nothing glamorous about the street-level selling room at 345 Seventh Avenue in Manhattan.
Hundreds of mink pelts hang from hooks around the room.
Here, from behind a cluttered metal table, the Harf family - in the fur trade for three generations - buys and sells fine pelts to New York City furriers.


Eastern's Flights Up to 104 From 66
LEAD: Eastern Airlines, attempting to fly despite a strike by its machinists and pilots, operated 104 flights yesterday, up from the 66 a day that marked the airline's performance last week.
But the number fell short of the 140 daily flights the airline had originally estimated it would be able to get into the air.


Service's Chief Tilts Against an 'Oblique' Attack on His Policies
LEAD: Alan C. Nelson has survived more than seven years in what he calls the no-win job of immigration commissioner, a post that has made him a target of immigrant groups and some politicians.


Hearing, and Heeding, the Mayor
LEAD: Mayor Edward Koch, worried about selective news leaks, balks at testifying in private before the State Commission on Government Integrity.
He says he wants to answer the commission's questions about the Talent Bank - the Koch administration's part-patronage, part-affirmative action hiring program - only in public.


Rain Is Late, but Now Hope Flowers
LEAD: March came in like a lion, lashing California with rains from the Oregon border to the Mexican border and blanketing the Sierra Nevada with new snow.
It was late, perhaps too late, but it raised hopes that the largest agricultural state could avoid a third straight dry year, with consequences felt all the way to the East Coast.


DWG Stock Rises On Takeover Bid
LEAD: Shares of the DWG Corporation, which is headed by Victor Posner, an investor based in Miami Beach, were bolstered by a $22-a-share bid from Andrew N. Heine, a lawyer in New York who is chairman and chief executive of Kinney System Inc.
But the stock remained below the bid.


Church in Protest Will Reopen
LEAD: St.
Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church will reopen, church authorities said today.
On Feb. 18, the police were called to the church and masses were suspended, to end a protest by some parshioners.


Weather and New Tactics Slow Budworm's Advance
LEAD: Adverse weather, Forest Service ''search and destroy'' missions and its own insatiable appetite have slowed the advance of the Western spruce budworm, officials said.

Relief for Foreign Debtors, at Last
LEAD: Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady uttered the magic words last week: ''debt reduction.'' He conceded that third world countries, heavily in debt to Western banks, needed relief.
That reverses Washington's stubborn official opposition to debt forgiveness.
His proposal is still too vague to be called a plan, but the outline is as welcome as it is belated.

Reviews/Music; Joan Sutherland in Recital at the Met
LEAD: The final item on Joan Sutherland's recital program Sunday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera was ''Io non sono piu l'Annetta'' from ''Crispino e la Comare'': a good tune, lots of brio and smart rhythm in the rendition, showers of brilliant coloratura, a socko high D flat at the end, and bang!
Cheers, shouts and an instant standing ovation from what had up to that point been a friendly but hardly enthusiastic audience.

LEAD: The United States and Canada, which on Jan. 1 put an agreement into effect to end practically all trade barriers within 10 years, decided today to negotiate a new pact to speed up some tariff cuts that are already agreed on.

LEAD: If endangered species could be saved through the exertions of television, they would all be home free.
Hardly a month goes by without a plea on the tube in behalf of the elephant, the black rhinoceros, the whale, the shark, the eagle or some other creature being hard pressed by man.
Public television finds the subject irresistible.

8.8% Stake in CNW Is Bought by Japonica
LEAD: Japonica Partners L.P., a group formed by two former executives of the New York investment firm Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company, has acquired an 8.8 percent stake in the CNW Corporation and said it ''is considering seeking to acquire control'' of the Chicago-based railroad holding company.


Coastal Extends Texas Eastern Bid
LEAD: The Coastal Corporation again extended a $2.6 billion offer for the stock outstanding of the Texas Eastern Corporation.
It was the second extension since Texas Eastern had agreed to be acquired by the Panhandle Eastern Corporation.
The Coastal offer is scheduled to expire March 31.


Topics of The Times; A Principal's 'Punishment'
LEAD: Joe Clark, the bat-wielding, bullhorn-toting principal of Eastside High School in Paterson, N.J., has been suspended for five days, with pay, for allowing a striptease at a school assembly last month.
Given Mr.
Clark's history of bizarre and autocratic behavior, this ''punishment'' amounts to nothing more than a brief vacation.


Saudi Aramco Board
LEAD: King Fahd has appointed a Supreme Board to govern Saudi Aramco, the kingdom's new oil company, under his chairmanship, the Saudi Press Agency reported today.
The company was formed in November to run the kingdom's oil industry.
Saudi Arabia set up Saudi Aramco as part of a restructuring to increase its oil industry's efficiency and cut costs.


Mercury in Everglades Fish Worries Experts
LEAD: Game fish in the Everglades are suddenly showing mercury levels that are among the highest ever recorded in the United States.
The discovery has alarmed experts, who are unable to explain the cause.


Track Star Admits to Use of Steroids
LEAD: Angella Issajenko, Canada's best female sprinter, told a Canadian Government inquiry that she had used performance-enhancing drugs since 1979, corroborating testimony her coach, Charlie Francis, had given over the past two weeks.


German State Vote Seen as Anti-Bonn Protest
LEAD: Politicians and other West Germans analyzing the municipal elections here and across Hesse State say they see evidence of strong dissatisfaction with what is seen as weakness and indecision in Bonn and of a new willingness among voters to experiment with the political fringes.


Shearson Unit Gets New Head
LEAD: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. said yesterday that Jerome H. Miller, a vice chairman, had been named to head the firm's asset management group.
