Corrections
LEAD: The Wine Talk column in The Living Section on Feb. 15 omitted the name of one winery in the newly designated Stags Leap district in the Napa Valley.
It is the Chimney Rock Winery.


U.S. Urges Consumers Not to Eat Fruit From Chile
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration urged consumers today not to eat seedless grapes and other fruit from Chile after traces of cyanide were found in two grapes at the Port of Philadelphia.
The agency's action could remove a large portion of the fruit from supermarket shelves throughout the country.

Critic's Notebook; Is Genius Nothing but Quirk?
LEAD: As more and more biographies have sought to reveal the autobiographical sources of artistic creation and as the principles of psychoanalysis have gradually been taken for granted, we find it increasingly difficult to look at works of art in simple, formalistic terms.
The muses no longer show themselves as angelic visitations of inspiration, but surface instead as neuroses, obsessions and childhood traumas.

Mining Unit's Sale By Baker Hughes
LEAD: Baker Hughes Inc., the international oilfield equipment and service company, said it would put its Mining Equipment Group up for sale.
The mining group, which consists of six sizable businesses and a number of small ones, manufactures equipment used largely for coal mining.


Tuberculosis Deaths Increase
LEAD: The number of tuberculosis cases in New York City dropped to 2,197 in 1987 from 2,223 the year before, but tuberculosis-related deaths rose from 186 to 219, the New York Lung Association said yesterday.
The 1987 rate of cases was more than three times the national rate.
The Health Commissioner, Dr.


Pushing Back on the Revolving Door
LEAD: President Bush's Commission on Federal Ethics Law Reform moves his Administration a big step closer to his goal of a cleaner Government.
The commission reported promptly, six weeks after Inauguration Day.
That's none too soon given the frequency with which ethical issues have arisen, especially those concerning the ''revolving door'' between public and private service.


Trustcorp Losses
LEAD: Trustcorp Inc., citing losses on downtown Toledo projects and other real estate ventures, announced that it would write off $35.9 million, the second such move in three months for the bank holding company.
In January, the corporation said it would write off $40.7 million.
Trustcorp also rescheduled its annual shareholders' meeting for June 28.

Shoppers Exasperated by New Peril
LEAD: The regular customers stood in the normal afternoon lines at Ro &amp; Sons Produce in Philadelphia, carrying red shopping baskets that overflowed with fresh produce.
But where there might have been grapes and peaches and raspberries the day before, there were now oranges and apples and strawberries.
The day before, the customers made their usual requests for the ripest samples, but yesterday the question was, ''Are you sure this is safe?


Washington Talk: Briefing; White House Dog Day
LEAD: It was 6:40 A.M. in the silent White House press office.
Alixe Glen, a White House press officer, was sitting in her office writing a summary of the morning papers for a staff briefing when she heard a noise behind her.
Ms.
Glen did a double take.
There stood President Bush, with the family dog, Millie.

Is That Food Really Safe?
LEAD: FOR years people have been told to eat a variety of foods - something from each of the four food groups every day - in order to have a well-balanced diet.
Now there is more urgency to the suggestion.
To spread around the hazards in our food supply, hazards most people have become aware of only recently, it is best not to eat large quantities of any single food and to be more selective in what you eat.

Neighbors peek from their windows, then quickly retreat.


Europe Unemployment
LEAD: Unemployment in the European Community dipped in January but inflation rose sharply, the latest official figures showed today.
The European Community's statistics office, Eurostat, said that seasonally adjusted unemployment fell to 9.9 percent in January from 10 percent in December.
The community's jobless rate has been dropping since a peak of 11 percent in the fall of 1984.

LEAD: The head of a local school board in the Bronx was indicted yesterday on charges that he sought a bribe from an acting assistant principal to allow her to hold her job after she failed a qualifying examination.


'The Genius of the Carpathians'
LEAD: East Europeans have taken to calling Rumania's President, Nicolae Ceausescu, the ''Idi Amin of Communism.'' He has squandered billions on grandiose public works that don't work, and has left many of his people hungry and freezing in half-darkened homes.
Yet on his 71st birthday in January he was acclaimed as ''The Great Conductor,'' ''The Genius of the Carpathians'' and ''The Danube of Thought.


Federal Home Loan Banks In a $6.94 Billion Offering
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Banks yesterday priced six bond issues totaling $6.94 billion at par.
They are being offered through various securities dealers.


Administration Seeks to Explain Debt Plan
LEAD: The Bush Administration today appeared to be stepping up its efforts to refine the reversal in its developing-country debt policy and to answer critics who contend the plan lacks substance.


Agreement Said to Be Near On Digital Tape Recorders
LEAD: A dispute between record companies and electronics manufacturers over digital audio tape recorders may be nearing resolution, according to news reports from Japan and industry officials in the United States.


Critic's Notebook; Religion on TV: Whether More Is Better
LEAD: Should there be more religion on television?
Dan Wakefield, journalist, novelist and sometime television writer, thinks so.
In last's week TV Guide, he offered several examples of the sort of faith that he wants projected into the American home.
One episode got his special blessing.
It occurred on ''Thirtysomething'' on ABC, when Michael, shocked by an automobile accident involving his wife and baby daughter, wound up at a synagogue service.


Stern Seeks Expanded Rules to Curb Abuse of Parks in New York
LEAD: With dozens of newly explicit and expanded rules, the New York City Parks and Recreation Department is trying to cope with a park system that is increasingly the resort of homeless people and the range of the lawless and thoughtless.

LEAD: The Government has blocked access to money belonging to the Navajo tribe to prod it into resolving a dispute over the status of Peter MacDonald, its beleaguered chairman.

LEAD: Tom Clancy, the author of a number of novels that pit the good guys - Americans - against the dark forces of the Soviet Union, was encircled by a group of admirers one recent evening, not at a Washington book party but in the Baroque drawing room of the Soviet Embassy.
It was Mr.
Clancy's first visit to the imposing mansion on 16th Street where, he later said with a smile, ''One Soviet officer wanted to pick my brains.

LEAD: The Lindsay String Quartet's program at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night had largely to do with finalities.
Britten finished his Third Quartet only months before he died.
Beethoven's Opus 135 in F was his last quartet as well.

LEAD: J. William Moffett was pleased.
He sponsors the annual convention of vintners and vineyard managers east of the Rocky Mountains - ''a pulse-taking of the regional wine industry,'' he calls it.
A near-record 600 people from 139 wineries in 31 states attended the 13th such gathering here last month, an indication, he says, of a healthy future for the industry.


Alcoa Can Collection
LEAD: The Aluminum Company of America said Monday that it had collected a record 16.1 billion used aluminum beverage cans for recycling in 1988, up 35 percent over the 11.9 billion containers collected in 1987.

LEAD: In testimony that caused a juror and relatives and friends of the victim to cry, a medical examiner yesterday described in detail the devastation caused by five bullets fired into a rookie police officer's head at close range on a Queens street.

10 Boeing Jets Ordered by U.P.S.
LEAD: United Parcel Service Inc. has ordered 10 more Boeing 757-200PF jet freighters at a cost of about $500 million, the aircraft maker said today.
In 1985, U.P.S., based in Greenwich, Conn., ordered 20 of the 757-200PF's - for ''package freighters'' - and took options on 15 more.
Today's order converts 10 of those options into firm sales.

LEAD: *
Alamito Co., Tucson, Ariz., an electric power producer, said John Van Egmond had been named president and James Clancy had been named vice president and treasurer.


A SPOT OF TROUBLE IN THATCHER RULE
LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who has not exactly had to fight for her political life these last few years, made clear today that she viewed renewed inflation caused by her own Government's past miscalculations as the main threat to its future.


The Worm and the Apple: On the Right Track; One Swan, No Puddles
LEAD: Two pleasures greeted the hundreds of people running around the Central Park reservoir in Manhattan yesterday morning.
One was remarkable: Gliding alone across the still, black waters was a brilliantly white swan.
No chill wind, no icy chop.
Just a single swan in the dawn sunlight, a graceful portent, perhaps, of spring.


Now for New Think
LEAD: A senior Soviet defense analyst, Andrei A. Kokoshin, testified before the House Armed Services Committee in Washington last week, itself a sign of how fast the manners if not yet the hard facts of Soviet-American relations are changing.


AIDS Viruses Found Resistant to AZT
LEAD: Three teams of researchers have detected strains of the AIDS virus that have become resistant to AZT, the only drug licensed by the Government to treat the disease, researchers said yesterday.

LEAD: A Federal district judge in Manhattan approved the settlement of the Justice Department's racketeering lawsuit against the International Brotherhood of Teamsters yesterday, saying the agreement ''affords some hope that the union will become part of the mainstream of honest unionism.''

LEAD: In an amiable Senate hearing laced with humor and references to family and character, Representative Dick Cheney, President Bush's second nominee as Secretary of Defense, today began what Republicans and Democrats alike promised would be a quick confirmation process.

LEAD: THE annual shad run, which people in the Northeast associate with spring, actually begins in December as far south as the St.
Johns River in northern Florida.


Tindivanam Journal; Seeking Its Share, Rural Caste Tries Disobedience
LEAD: From their homes of mud and thatch nestled along country roads lined with tamarind trees, landless rural laborers have been coming out by the thousands to block roads, stop trains and join in other acts of mass disobedience.
They are demanding that affirmative-action laws deliver on promises to improve the lot of one of Hinduism's poorest rural castes.


Heavy Drain of Deposits Afflicts Savings Industry
LEAD: Depositors at savings institutions, seeking higher-yielding investments and nervous about the Bush bailout plan, withdrew a record $10.7 billion in January plus $8 billion to $9 billion in February, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today.


Helicopter Repaired Before Crash
LEAD: A main nut on the rotor shaft of a military helicopter was replaced just two days before it crashed, killing 15 servicemen, military officials said today.


Price Changing Jobs
LEAD: Two years ago, Mike Price, the football coach at Weber State, was beaten out by Dennis Erickson for the Washington State job.
Yesterday, Price was named to succeed Erickson.
Price, 42, had a 46-44 record in 8 seasons at Weber State, including a 5-6 record last season.
He was a leading candidate for the Washington State job when Erickson was picked in 1987 from Wyoming.


Mandarich to Drop Out
LEAD: Tony Mandarich, Michigan State's 320-pound tackle, is fed up.
Just 17 credits short of a bachelor's degree, Mandarich, a two-time all-American, plans to move to Los Angeles to escape allegations that he has used steroids.


President To Mediate Jet Dispute
LEAD: President Bush will preside over a National Security Council meeting on Wednesday to arbitrate conflicts between the Defense and Commerce Departments over helping Japan to build an advanced version of the F-16 fighter, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: The Xerox Corporation and the Raychem Corporation said today that they had submitted a proposal to the Defense Department to develop large-area, high-resolution displays for high-definition television and other applications.


Keady Will Continue To Coach at Purdue
LEAD: When Coach Gene Keady walked into a meeting yesterday with George King, Purdue's athletic director, he was unsure whether he would accept a reported offer of $300,000 a year to become the basketball coach at Arizona State.
Then he looked out a window, scanned the campus and made up his mind to stay put.


Belgium Reduces Rates
LEAD: The central bank today lowered Belgium's primary lending rate, the interest rate on three-month treasury bills, to 8.4 percent from 8.3 percent.
The rate on one- and two-month bills was cut by five-hundredths of a point each, to 8 and 8.2 percent, respectively.

LEAD: Thousands of Russians and other non-Estonians marched in Tallinn today, threatening a general strike if the Communist Party does not stem Estonian nationalism and ''creeping counterrevolution,'' journalists there said.

Correction

The column also misidentified the chef at the Duke University Diet and Fitness Center.
He is Michael Eddins.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  FIGURE SKATING  Soviet Skaters Take Early Lead: Soviet skaters took early leads in the men's and pairs events yesterday at the world championships in Paris.
Aleksandr Fadeyev led an East European sweep of the first three placings in the men's compulsories ahead of a countryman, Viktor Petrenko, and Grzegorz Filipowski of Poland.

LEAD: Zita, the last Empress of Austria-Hungary, died yesterday at her longtime residence, a Roman Catholic home for the elderly in Zizers, a village in eastern Switzerland.
She was 96 years old.

School District Slashes Staff
LEAD: The school district in this impoverished city is laying off 600 of its 1,800 employees, The St.
Louis Post-Dispatch reported today.
Elmo J. Bush, the Superintendent of Schools, said the state board of education had asked the district to trim about $12 million from next year's budget.
The district, whose budget this year is $70 million, has more than $10 million in unpaid bills, he said.

LEAD: Maurizio Pollini can lay strong claim to being the quintessential modernist pianist, and his Tuesday evening recital at Carnegie Hall -the third of his three appearances there this season - was an extraordinary event.
Extraordinary doesn't mean that it answered a listener's every emotional need.
But as brilliantly uncompromising programming and playing, it could hardly have been surpassed.

LEAD: Shamrock Holdings Inc., the investor group controlled by Roy E. Disney that has sought the Polaroid Corporation since July, extended its $2.95 billion hostile bid for the photography giant for two months.
Shamrock, based in Burbank, Calif., is offering $45 a share in cash for all of Polaroid's common stock, including the preferred shares associated with the company's shareholder rights plan.

Personal Health
LEAD: Within each eye a tiny transparent disk, the lens, repeatedly bulges and flattens to allow you to see objects near and far by focusing light on the retina.
As you age, the lens gradually loses its ability to return fully to its bulbous shape, which is why most people eventually require reading glasses or contact lenses.


Elxsi Names Chairman
LEAD: The Elxsi Corporation, a maker of minisupercomputers based in San Jose, Calif., said today that Joseph D. Rizzi had been elected chairman.
Mr.
Rizzi, vice chairman and a founder of Elxsi, succeeds Gene M. Amdahl, who is resigning to devote more attention to his new company, Andor Systems Inc., which is developing computers compatible with some products of the International Business Machines Corporation.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Worn Shingles  Q. Our house is about 38 years old and we are about to have the complete roof reshingled.
The roof has already had a layer of shingles placed on top of the original ones, but the shingles on the south side have curled and warped and are quite brittle.
Should the worn shingles be removed before new ones are applied, and can a third layer be placed on top of the two that are there?

Review/Piano; The Works of Julius Reubke
LEAD: Laid end to end as Michael Gailit did it on Sunday afternoon, Julius Reubke's keyboard compositions can be played in about an hour and a half.
Reubke, a German born in 1834, lived only to the age of 24.
Two years before his death, he went to Weimar, where he studied with Liszt and absorbed Wagner.


Prosecuting Officers; False-Arrest Case Shows It Can Take Time and Publicity to Redress Wrongs
LEAD: The conviction of two New York City transit police officers Tuesday in a false-arrest scheme leaves behind questions about why local prosecutors and the police failed for more than three years to disclose the allegations, refer them to other prosecutors or file any charges.


Israel Gives Disputed Resort to Egypt
LEAD: To the sounds of Egypt's national anthem, Islamic chants and Israeli protests, Israeli officials today handed over the last pocket of the Sinai captured from Egypt in the 1967 Middle East War.


Traffic Charges for Nussbaum
LEAD: Hedda Nussbaum, the former companion of Joel B. Steinberg, has been charged with two traffic infractons, the state police said today.
They said Ms.
Nussbaum, 46 years old, a patient at Four Winds Hospital in Katonah, was charged with failing to keep right and driving with an expired driver's license Monday night, when she was stopped on Route 35.


Israeli Price Index Up
LEAD: Israel's consumer price index rose 1.7 percent in February, compared with 4.7 percent in January and eight-tenths of a percent in February 1988, the Central Bureau of Statistics said today.
The bureau said inflation for the last 12 months was 21 percent and so far in 1989 was 6.4 percent.
The Finance Minister, Shimon Peres, said after January's rise - the highest monthly jump in three years - that he still hoped to keep 1989 inflation below 10 percent.


A Warning On Effects Of Bailouts
LEAD: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned today that the Government faced a monumental task in handling the bad real estate of almost 800 sick savings and loan associations, which will be taken over during the next three years.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption on March 1, with an article about the emergence of a new street gang in New York, misidentified Lee D. McCaskill.
He is assistant principal, not principal, of Brooklyn Technical High School, where the gang is thought to have started.

LEAD: Chile's Foreign Minister arrived here today for urgent talks with the Bush Administration about a poisoning scare that has prompted Federal investigators to detain hundreds of thousands of pounds of Chilean fruit at American ports.


Wide Brazilian Strike Winds Down in 2d Day
LEAD: A nationwide strike to protest a wage freeze imposed by the Government entered its second and final day today.
More businesses opened and buses operated, but a million Rio de Janeiro commuters were stranded, and scattered violence was reported.


Showtime Extends Pact
LEAD: Showtime, the nation's second-largest pay television service, extended an agreement yesterday that gives it exclusive rights to the films of Touchstone Pictures.
Touchstone is a division of the Walt Disney Company that has been highly successful in recent years.


Ex-Rep. James O'Hara, 63, Dies
LEAD: James G. O'Hara, a Democrat who represented a district from suburban Detroit in the House of Representatives from 1959 through 1976, died of complications of cancer Monday at George Washington University Medical Center.
He was 63 years old.


New York Facing Major Water Shortage
LEAD: New York State is facing what could be its worse water shortage in history.
A drought emergency, with mandatory restrictions on lawn watering and car washing, will be declared within the next week for New York City and much of the downstate region, top health and conservation officials said today.

He was 89 years old.
Mr.

In 1947 he founded and managed The Franklin Group of Mutual Funds, now one of the country's largest such organizations.

A Cleaner Teamsters' Union?
LEAD: The settlement of the Government's racketeering suit against the International Brotherhood of Teamsters falls short of total victory for the union's critics.
But as Federal Judge David Edelstein said in approving the agreement, it offers ''some hope'' that the teamsters can be converted from an outlaw union to an honest one.


Bernard King Finding New Ways to Score
LEAD: The lift and explosiveness have been diminished by knee surgery and age but Bernard King in the last month has been a reasonable facsimile of the Bernard King of the past.
He is again piling up points but in different ways.
He has become more of a finesse player, shooting the jumper from a little farther out and snaking and slashing his way to the basket behind the picks his Washington Bullet teammates set to get him open.

LEAD: Space agency officials said today that a problem with the space shuttle Discovery's electrical system had apparently been fixed, allowing the $1.2 billion winged spaceship to complete its five-day mission.

Close to Home
LEAD: ONCE, on a long-ago summer evening, I had a fight with a friend.
I had complained about how unpleasant it was to take my daughters to the swings in a nearby park because it meant wading through drunks.
He said drunks were as much entitled to that park as we were.
I said fine, but their presence was discouraging children from using it as the playground it was meant to be.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Campaign by Mensa
LEAD: American Mensa, the society for people with high intelligence quotients, is taking to the airwaves with its first television advertising campaign.
The Central South Carolina chapter of the organization has bought time on the network affiliates and the Cable News Network to attract new members.
The spot, which will be shown through March 26, is designed to appeal to ''extraordinary'' viewers, a Mensa official said.

Mr. Gorbachev's Bent Sickle
LEAD: The fertility of fields is declining. . . .
Mismanagement is responsible for the loss of up to 20 percent of everything raised. . . .
Sometimes one has to travel scores, even hundreds of kilometers to benefit from elementary services or buy primitive necessities. . . .
The situation is so grave in many regions that people are deserting the land.


Oratorios, Hosannas and Glorias In Celebration of Easter
LEAD: Holy Week, that solemn, inevitable progression in the Passion of Christ that proceeds from this weekend's Palm Sunday through Maundy Thursday and Good Friday to Easter Sunday, forms the culmination of the Christian year - and, by extension, the annual high point of Christian liturgical music.
The sheer richness and variety of the church-music concerts and musically accompanied services to be heard in the next 10 days provides an opportunity to examine that liturgical world in the New York area, and in particular the extent and diversity of music making in

LEAD: Maxicare Health Plans Inc., the wounded giant of health maintenance organizations, filed yesterday for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.


The Race for the Whip
LEAD: It may seem the ultimate in inside baseball, but the race for minority whip in the House of Representatives is providing some of the best theater on Capitol Hill these days.


All Irish, All Immigrants
LEAD: Years ago Robert Briscoe, the Jewish Lord Mayor of Dublin, came to visit this country and was greeted with a parade. ''What's going on?'' a little old lady asked.
When parade watchers told her, she was dumbfounded. ''The Jewish Lord Mayor of Dublin!
Why, only in America!''

A Fingerhold for Dissent in Salvador
LEAD: In 1981, in a symbol of the army-linked repression that turned criticism of the right into a capital offense, the armed forces put a bounty on the heads of 138 leftists by publishing a list of their names and describing them as wanted traitors.


U.S. and Laos Plan a Search For 547 Missing Servicemen
LEAD: The Laotian Government has agreed to go forward with a joint search for 547 missing American servicemen that was delayed two weeks ago because of a dispute over an American drug report, the State Department said today.

Review/Film; Pioneers in the Wilds Of Commercial Video
LEAD: ''Tapeheads'' sees the world of commercial video production as a new frontier, a wild and woolly place where rules don't exist yet and the pioneering spirit still prevails.
It's a funny idea, one that might have been more so if the film had worked solely in that satirical vein.
As it is, ''Tapeheads'' tacks on various cliched elements of intrigue - there's a blackmail plot against a political candidate - that dilute its humor.


Scrutinizing the Theory of a 'New' Rehnquist
LEAD: Is there really a new Rehnquist?


Mother Sentenced to Prison In Scalding Death of Her Son
LEAD: A Manhattan woman was sentenced yesterday to a prison term of 20 years to life for scalding her 3-year-old son to death after he soiled his diaper.


U.S. Charges Salvador Guerrillas Get More Arms From Soviet Bloc
LEAD: Senior United States officials here charged today that Cuba and Soviet-bloc countries had been upgrading the arsenal of the Salvadoran rebels to help them escalate their nine-year war against the American-backed Government.


Delta and Swissair To Form Venture
LEAD: Delta Air Lines Inc. and Swissair said they would become partners to insure they remained competitive in the travel market of the future.
The airlines will coordinate flight schedules to offer passengers fast connections on routes to and from North America.
They will also share reservation systems and airport space and advertise their services jointly.


Senate Refuses to Drop Charges Against a Judge
LEAD: The Senate today refused to dismiss impeachment charges that Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings of Miami conspired to get a $150,000 bribe and later lied about it at his trial.

Orrin Starr
LEAD: Orrin jStarr, a banjo player, will lead his bluegrass band tomorrow at 9 P.M. at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275).
Tickets are $7.


Herbert A. Brandon, Publisher, 76
LEAD: Herbert A. Brandon, the former publisher of Brandon's Shipper and Forwarder, a trade publication for the shipping industry, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Pleasantville, N.Y.
He was 76 years old.


The Real Inside Stuff
LEAD: Lynne V. Cheney, chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Humanities and the wife of Representative Dick Cheney, called The Washingtonian magazine this week with a bit of old but still good inside stuff.


U.S. Action On Unisys
LEAD: The Defense Department today suspended three divisions of the Unisys Corporation from doing business with the Government, in the latest move in its investigation of possible fraud and bribery in military procurement.


Roy Hanson, Editor at Newsday, Dies at 54
LEAD: Roy Hanson, a writer and editor at Newsday, died of lung cancer Tuesday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I.
He was 54 and lived in Copiague, L.I.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''He has to be everybody's President, not just the N.R.A.'s President.''  - Hugh Brock, a gun dealer, on Government curbs on the import of assault rifles.  [ A18:2. ]


U.S. Offers $250,000 Reward In Drug Agent Killing on S.I.
LEAD: The United States Justice Department yesterday offered a $250,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of Constabile Farace, who is suspected of killing a Federal drug agent on Staten Island last month.


ANNUAL RACE FOR CLERKS BECOMES A MAD DASH, WITH JUDICIAL DECORUM LEFT IN THE DUST
LEAD: The once-decorous process by which Federal judges select their law clerks has degenerated into a free-for-all in which some of the nation's most eminent judges scramble for the top law school students.


TW to Weigh Alternatives
LEAD: TW Services Inc., which has resisted the advances of Coniston Partners L.P. for months, said yesterday that it was now considering a leveraged buyout, a restructuring or selling the company or some of its assets to another bidder.


Dollar Finishes Day Mixed After Intervention Abroad
LEAD: The dollar closed narrowly mixed yesterday against the major foreign currencies.
Exchange dealers said trading slowed in New York after central banks in Europe intervened earlier to slow the dollar's rise.


Byrne Trial Prosecution Rests
LEAD: Prosecutors rested their case yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens in the trial of three men charged with the execution-style murder of a rookie police officer, Edward Byrne, in South Jamaica on Feb. 26, 1988.
Prosecutors say Officer Byrne was killed by four men at the order of a drug dealer seeking retaliation against the police.


Somoza's Soldiers Rejoining A Society Divided on Pardon
LEAD: Armando Parajon Juarez's last act as a free man came on July 19, 1979, when he surrendered the holdout battalion of 400 National Guardsmen under his command to Sandinista guerrillas, who were then sweeping to victory across Nicaragua.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  FIGURE SKATING  Canadian Wins World Championship: Kurt Browning of Canada put on a dazzling display of jumping, including a trademark quadruple, to edge Chris Bowman of the United States for the men's gold medal yesterday at the world championships.
Grzegorz Filipowski of Poland beat out Aleksandr Fadeyev of the Soviet Union to take the bronze.(AP)


COMMITTEE BACKS BAKER-AIDE CHOICE
LEAD: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted unanimously today to approve the nomination of Lawrence S. Eagleburger as Deputy Secretary of State, defusing a conflict over his relationship with two consulting firms headed by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

LEAD: Israel's Foreign Minister called Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on Wednesday to complain about the Secretary's statements before Congress that Israel might one day have to negotiate with the Palestine Liberation Organization, Israeli officials said today.

Taxes Fail to Cover Drinking's Costs, Study Finds
LEAD: Taxes on cigarettes cover the costs imposed on society by smoking, but taxes on alcohol do not pay for the costs of drinking, a new study reports.

Industrial Operating Rate Drops
LEAD: The nation's industrial operating rate declined last month for the first time since September, but economists and analysts said it was too soon to tell whether this signaled a sustained easing of inflationary pressures.


Some Tour Operators File for Bankruptcy
LEAD: Travel industry executives said yesterday that several tour operators who had sold tour packages based on flights on Eastern Airlines have declared for bankruptcy since Eastern machinists went on strike two weeks ago.
An undetermined number of travelers have been left with little financial recourse except to file as creditors in the bankruptcy proceedings involving the tour operators.


Boston Journal; City's Irish Newcomers Are Illegal, but Not Alien
LEAD: When Sister Veronica Dobson opened a pastoral center for illegal young Irish immigrants in this city last September, she had no trouble getting the word out: All she did was stop by one of the neighborhood pubs that are gathering places for the ''new Irish'' of Boston.


Assault Rifles Are Selling Like Blue-Chip Stocks
LEAD: ''It's like the Oklahoma land rush,'' Mike Nichols, a gun collector, said as he stood in line here at Brock's Army Surplus store to buy one of the last semiautomatic assault weapons in stock.
It was a Chinese-made SKS, a copy of the gun of his dreams, the AK-47 infantry rifle.

Cabinet Fever
LEAD: For decades, the United States managed to avoid the proliferation of cabinet positions that engulf other governments, keeping the total under a dozen.
By comparison, China has 44, Japan 22, Britain 21.
Indeed, Presidential study commissions have repeatedly urged simplifying the U.S. cabinet structure, creating, for instance, five supercabinet jobs.

Pilots Assert Eastern Transferred Airport Slots Before Bankruptcy
LEAD: Officials of the Eastern Airlines pilots' union released documents yesterday that they said show that the day before the airline filed for bankruptcy it transferred ownership of eight landing slots at La Guardia Airport in New York and eight at National Airport in Washington to Continental Airlines,


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Newspaper Ad Spending Rises
LEAD: Newspaper advertising spending rose 6.1 percent in 1988 over the previous year, according to an industry report, but the numbers will give little solace to jittery newspaper executives.


The Teamsters Take It on the Chin
LEAD: No heads rolled in the top echelons of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters as part of this week's settlement of the Justice Department's racketeering suit against the giant union.
Since it was well known that the Government had originally intended to force at least five international vice presidents with strong mob ties to walk the plank as the price of a negotiated peace, many observers have concluded that once again the forces of law have wound up on the short end of a major contest with the underworld.


Marquette Coach Out
LEAD: Bob Dukiet was dismissed yesterday as Marquette University's coach after two consecutive losing seasons and several conflicts with players.
Athletic Director Bill Cords said in a news release that Dukiet had been offered the position of assistant to the athletic director for the remaining three years of his contract.

Louis, said it would introduce a de-alcoholized beer, O'Doul's, in five Southern test markets next week.


Memo Hints Reagan Backed '85 Contra Supplies
LEAD: A classified memorandum read to the jury today at the trial of Oliver L. North suggests that President Ronald Reagan approved a ''very specialized intelligence'' mission in October 1985 to equip the Nicaraguan rebels with information and weapons to attack the Sandinista government's arms shipments.


Housing Construction Declines 11.4%
LEAD: Housing construction plummeted 11.4 percent in February, a decline that analysts attributed to colder weather and higher mortgage interest rates.


Sounds Around Town
LEAD:  Making Arrangements


Lilting About Manhattan, The Tunes Of Ireland
LEAD: One thing to celebrate on St.
Patrick's Day weekend is the vitality of Irish traditional music - the jigs, reels and Kerry slides for dancing, the harp tunes, ballads and slow airs for listening.
Around the world, traditional music is under siege by broadcast mass-marketed pop and rock.
Although Ireland has its share of U2 wanna-bes, the Irish and their diaspora in Britain and the United States have held onto old-fashioned instruments like the fiddle, accordion, pennywhistle, bodhran (hand drum) and uileann pipes


Top Teamster Informer Told F.B.I. That McCarthy Asked Mafia Help
LEAD: Evidence amassed by the Federal authorities for the canceled teamster racketeering trial in New York included an allegation that William J. McCarthy, now president of the union, sought Mafia help to get a high union job four years ago.


Senate Panel Gives Cheney Unanimous Approval
LEAD: The Senate Armed Services Committee unanimously endorsed the nomination of Representative Dick Cheney to be Secretary of Defense today, praising his ''high standards of personal conduct and integrity.''

LEAD: IN advertising, as in the theater, a smashing out-of-town tryout does not mean an act will succeed on Broadway.
Struggling to prove itself an exception to the rule, Keye/ Donna/Pearlstein has discovered that patience is one of several lessons it can impart.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Feb. 18 about political developments in Liechtenstein described the country's history incorrectly.
Formed in 1719, the principality was part of the Rhine and German confederations between 1806 and 1866.


Whistle-Blower Bill Approved
LEAD: The Senate today approved a bill to increase job protection for Federal workers who expose waste, fraud and abuse.
A similar measure was killed last year by President Reagan when he let Congress adjourn without his taking action on it.


U.S. Again Demands Release Of Hostage Held in Lebanon
LEAD: Terry A. Anderson began his fifth year as a hostage in Lebanon today, and the Bush Administration called his detention a ''criminal act which serves no cause'' and demanded his release.


Basic Issues Still Face Bush on Japan Jet Deal
LEAD: Although the Bush Administration will proceed with plans to let Japan build an advanced version of the F-16 fighter, ''at least three or four basic issues'' on sharing of the aircraft technology remain for Presidential decision, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said today.


With Fans Watching, Siena Shocks Stanford
LEAD: They had not played in front of a crowd in more than five weeks because of an outbreak of measles.
Making their first appearance ever in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, they were seeded No. 14 in the East Regional.
And after squandering a 16-point second-half lead, they saw their stellar playmaker misfire twice in the final minute on one-and-one free throws that could have put the game away.


Arizona Breezes Past Robert Morris to Gain
LEAD: Top-ranked Arizona scored the first 12 points, took a 21-2 lead and defeated Robert Morris, 94-60, in the first round of the West Regional today.

Information: 758-0447.


Ex-Radical Leader Sentenced
LEAD: Huey Newton, the former leader of the Black Panther Party, was sentenced to 6 months in jail and 18 months of probation after pleading no contest to misappropriating $15,000 in public money earmarked for a school the party ran in the early 1980's.
Mr.
Newton, who is in prison for a parole violation, and Mark Alexander, the former chairman of the Oakland Community School, were accused of diverting for their own use as much as $300,000 in state grants intended for the school, which closed seven years ago.


Brewers' Goal: Stay Healthy
LEAD: A Milwaukee Brewers executive, Ray Poitevint, walked into Manager Tom Trebelhorn's office the other day and tried to be helpful. ''You need first aid or the Red Cross here?'' he asked.


Japonica Nominees For CNW Board
LEAD: The New York investment partnership Japonica Partners L.P. has sent the CNW Corporation a list of eight candidates to replace the board of the Chicago-based railroad holding company at its annual meeting on May 16.
Japonica has said it would wage a proxy fight for control of CNW's board and then consider breaking up or selling the company.

LEAD: What is the point of racing around Washington grabbing Federal dollars for New York City if bureaucratic gridlock prevents the city from using the money?


Something Is Happening
LEAD: CORRECTION: In a recent column suggesting a ban on the sale to civilians of military-type assault rifles, the favorite tool of the drug killers, I called them automatic weapons.
Wrong.

LEAD: Ball State, seeded ninth in the Midwest Regional and cast as an underdog despite having the nation's best record and longest winning streak, gained a measure of respect tonight by upsetting eighth-seeded Pittsburgh, 68-64.


Queens Merchants Win More Bus Service
LEAD: The New York City Transit Authority has agreed to expand bus service in a Queens neighborhood after merchants there sued the authority, saying their businesses had suffered when bus routes were changed or eliminated.

LEAD: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, long engaged in rescuing and preserving historic buildings, will be honored by the National Building Museum at a dinner Wednesday for ''championing the quality in buildings and public places for over 25 years.''

LEAD: Apparently seeking to dispel reports of a conflict with the Treasury, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today endorsed the reorientation of the developing-world debt policy proposed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.

LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today that it had taken over 47 insolvent savings and loan associations in five states with assets of $6.8 billion.


Deficit at First Fidelity
LEAD: The First Fidelity Bancorporation, which stunned the banking community in December with the announcement of large problem loans at its new partner, the Fidelity Bank in Philadelphia, yesterday announced a loss of $176.2 million for the fourth quarter.
In the corresponding quarter a year ago, the company lost $34.6 million.

Restaurants
LEAD: There is something wonderfully primordial about watching Madison Avenue moguls roll up their shirtsleeves and tear into slabs of roasted lamb with their hands, then lick their fingers and snag a clump of cauliflower along with some barbecued shrimp.
This peculiar scene unfolds daily at Bukhara, the Indian restaurant that specializes in what is called frontier cooking.

LEAD: Three of Europe's largest space and military contractors plan to link up to provide a Pan-European private-sector alternative to state companies, one of the companies said today.

She is Elizabeth Draper.

He was 67 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

LEAD: In 1982, Dr.
Neil Aggett - a white South African - was found hanged in a Johannesburg prison, where he had been detained for his work with a multiracial trade union.
Dr.
Aggett's political activism, his relationships with his father and girlfriend and his brutal treatment by prison authorities are chronicled in a new play by Hilary Blecher called ''Brightness Falling.

Review/Film; In a Bordello, Innocence Mixes With Experience
LEAD: The theme of the delightful Hungarian fantasy film ''A Very Moral Night,'' made in 1977 and now playing at the Public Theater, could well be innocence, even if the action does take place in a bordello.
It is a good bordello, so sweet and wholesome that it seems a place of pure beauty and Eden-like charm.


Holtzman Said to Want Goldin's Post
LEAD: District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn will likely seek the Democratic nomination for New York City comptroller, joining an already crowded primary that will almost certainly be as contentious as the Democratic mayoral contest.


Budget Sword Hangs Over Schools for Disabled
LEAD: Christina Martin, a ninth grader at the Rochester School for the Deaf, knows what it would be like to go to a local public school where everybody else could hear, because she tried it a few years ago.


Emergency Is Declared Over Drought
LEAD: New York City and 11 other downstate counties were officially declared to be in a drought emergency in an executive order signed yesterday by Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo.
The order authorized New York State's Disaster Preparedness Commission to require municipalities to severely restrict water consumption, including placing a ban on watering lawns and washing cars and sidewalks and shutting off all ornamental fountains, even those that recycle water.

LEAD: Three Federal agencies, responding to growing public alarm about the safety of the chemical Alar, said in a statement today, ''The Government believes it is safe for Americans to eat apples.''

LEAD: Vice President Dan Quayle charged today that critics of the Bush Administration were looking for ''razzle-dazzle'' rather than substance and said that news organizations were promoting shallow politics to suit the needs of broadcast news programs.


TV Network Rule Lifted
LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission repealed a rule today that had limited contracts between television networks and their local affiliate stations to two years.
The F.C.C. said the rule, adopted in 1945 when TV networks were just forming and lining up local outlets for their programs, was no longer necessary to assist in the development of new TV networks in today's television industry of alternative delivery systems such as satellites and cable.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 460 money market mutual funds increased by $1.26 billion, to $296.55 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Those of the 138 institutional funds decreased by $213.6 million, to $72.47 billion.
The assets of the 228 general-purpose funds were up by $913 million, to $96.11 billion.

LEAD: Conservative judges hold that the Supreme Court should not reach out for controversy.
Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, uncharacteristically careless, tripped over that canon when she let her name be used in a political debate over religion.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; F.C.C. Overturns Ruling On Video Cigarette Ads
LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission ruled yesterday that a new technology to send advertising by telephone wires to in-store video monitors cannot be used for cigarette advertising.
The unanimous decision overturned a 1986 staff ruling by the commission that it had no jurisdiction over the system, created by the Marketing Technologies Group Inc.


REview/Music; 2 Major Vila Sonatas
LEAD: The viola can be a deeply poetic instrument - any good performance of Berlioz's ''Harold in Italy'' is proof of that.
But given its intermediary status between the brilliance of the violin and the richness of the cello, the viola can also sound genteel and bland as a solo instrument.
Within those muted terms, Rosemary Glyde's viola recital Monday night at Alice Tully Hall provided considerable pleasure.

Calvin Seabury, a fourth grader, had a report due this week on poems and at the new library he found a book - it was stuffed with poems!

Corrections
LEAD: A recipe in The Living Section on Wednesday, with an article about Irish cooking, omitted an instruction for colcannon.
The leeks and milk should be folded into the potatoes along with the cooked cabbage, and then beaten until fluffy.

LEAD: Judith A. Levitt, director of the city's Personnel Department, was named yesterday to replace Joseph DeVincenzo who was ousted as head of Mayor Edward I. Koch's controversial Talent Bank.
Mayor Koch named her as his special adviser for personnel, a post that makes her the Mayor's chief administrative officer.


Two Grapes, Two Decisions
LEAD: Two poisoned Chilean grapes add another puzzling dimension to the menace of global terrorism.
Warnings by public health authorities in Washington, Tokyo and Ottawa have brought Chile's huge fruit exports to a standstill, and Chilean fruit has been pulled off the market while inspectors investigate thousands upon thousands of crates.

Independent Films
LEAD: The 22d annual Film and Video Festival of the Brooklyn Arts Council continues tomorrow in the Uris auditorium of the Metropolitan museum of Art, from 1 to 5 P.M.
The festival focuses on independent film and video artists, and the program tomorrow features ''The Man Who Planted Trees,'' a 30-minute animated film by Frederick Back that won an Academy Award last year; Esther Duran's ''My Sin Is Loving You,'' a Brooklyn-made film that was selected as the festival's best narrative drama, and 11 other works.

LEAD: Ben Johnson might have taken stanozolol, the anabolic steroid found in his urine at the Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, within 22 days of the 100-meter final without knowing it, one of his former teammates told a Canadian Government inquiry today.

LEAD: Backer Spielvogel Bates lost its last piece of CBS's creative work yesterday when the network transferred its entertainment print assignment to Scott Mednick &amp; Associates, a Los Angeles agency known primarily for graphic design.


Two Rangers Injured
LEAD: The Rangers, eight regular-season games away from the start of the playoffs, added two injuries to their nagging list in the wake of Wednesday night's 6-3 loss to the Winnipeg Jets.
Both Brian Leetch and David Shaw left the game with injuries.
Leetch, the sensational rookie defenseman, suffered a hip injury and will be out a minimum of a week.


I.B.M. Unit Move
LEAD: I.B.M.
Japan Ltd., turning the tables on its Japanese competition, will sell mainframe computers that will be compatible with those of Fujitsu Ltd. and Hitachi Ltd., a spokesman for the International Business Machines Corporation said.
The two companies have gained slightly more than half the domestic Japanese market with mainframes compatible with those of I.B.M.

Los Angeles Bonds' Top Yield Is 7.45%
LEAD: A refunding of about $206 million of securities by the Los Angeles Department of Airports through competitive bid offers a maximum yield of about 7.45 percent for an issue due in 2010.
The underwriters are led by the First Boston Corporation.


Austerity Accord for Seamen's
LEAD: The corporate parent of the Seamen's Bank for Savings of New York announced today that it had entered into an agreement with Federal regulators that would prohibit it from paying dividends on its common stock and would severely limit its growth and investment activity.


Economic Scene; The Obstacles Facing Gorbachev
LEAD: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV's call for a ''drastic restructuring'' of Soviet agriculture, aimed at increasing food production long term, could aggravate his country's immediate fiscal crisis.
At a time of worsening agricultural shortages, Mr.
Gorbachev has proposed a farm price increase next January, somewhat greater flexibility for farmers to negotiate the prices of what they sell and, ultimately, ''complete freedom'' to choose ways of marketing their products.

It is about process.
Its selections are revealing.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in the Media Business columns of Business Day on Tuesday, about advertising in The Wall Street Journal and Barron's, described the trend in advertising at The Journal incorrectly.
Linage, not revenue, has declined for four years.

LEAD: The Transport Minister came under attack in Parliament Thursday for withholding from the public Government warnings sent to airlines and airports last November and December about terrorist bombs in radio-cassette players.
Such a bomb brought down a Pan Am jumbo jet in Scotland in December.


An Actor Acquires Control Of National Lampoon Inc.
LEAD: The actor Tim Matheson, who appeared in the hit film ''Animal House'' in the late 1970's, has gained control of National Lampoon Inc., which produced the picture.


Elmer Lee Fingar, 84; Served on Estates Panel
LEAD: Elmer Lee Fingar, a former partner in McCarthy, Fingar, Donovan, Drazen &amp; Smith, a law firm in White Plains, died Tuesday at Martin Memorial Hospital in Stuart, Fla.
He was 84 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.


No Vengeance Against Wright
LEAD: Dick Cheney, whose nomination will sail through the Senate in about an hour, is just what we need at the Pentagon.
He is an experienced, tough professional who won't be intimidated by defense contractors, Congress or the Soviets.


Review/Film; James Ivory's Version Of Janowitz's 'Slaves'
LEAD: It's unwise to wear an ashtray on your head unless you're certain you have more personality than the prop.
This is one of the few valuable insights to be obtained from ''Slaves of New York,'' the film based on Tama Janowitz's short stories about various denizens of the downtown art scene, stories that amount to ashtray-wearing in a literary vein.

OTB's Parlay Still an Unpopular Bet
LEAD: Parlay betting, introduced to New York racing last fall, always seemed likely to prove more popular at OTB parlors than at the track.
Lunchtime offtrack bettors were expected to like the idea of betting several races in advance, whereas on-track players could reinvest their own money.

LEAD: In a major but unacknowledged policy shift, Mexico is expanding its cooperation with American efforts to reduce the flow of illegal immigrants into the United States, officials here and along the border say.

Blasts of Color and Invention in Paris
LEAD: The fall and winter fashion collections opened here Wednesday with an explosive blast of color and invention.
The starting teams were a medley of Japanese, French and American players; Italians will show later.
It is fashion with a global sweep.


Astroland to Open
LEAD: Astroland Amusement Park will open Sunday - weather permitting -and will be open on subsequent weekends until mid-June.
Hours are noon to midnight Saturdays and Sundays.
Astroland is at West 10th Street between Surf Avenue and the Boardwalk, Coney Island, brooklyn.
Admission is free; individual rides cost $1 to $3.

Tonight at 9 on Channel 13, there is the hourlong Don Mischer Production called ''Gregory Hines's Tap Dance in America,'' a current state-of-the-art survey that gets you feeling good and keeps you that way until the taking-it-home finale.

Life in an Andean Village As Duelists Prepare to Die
LEAD: The Colombian film ''Details of a Duel'' takes place on a single morning, during which two decent and well-liked citizens of a small Andean village prepare to die.
The schoolteacher (Frank Ramirez) and the butcher (Humberto Dorado) have, for reasons that are not explained, challenged each other to a fatal contest.


Development Bank to Raise $26.4 Billion
LEAD: A committee of the Inter-American Development Bank has agreed to increase the bank's capital by $26.43 billion in a compromise that resolves a three-year dispute between the United States and Latin American countries over the organization's policies.


Gandhi to Release Report on Mother's Slaying
LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi said tonight that a judicial report on the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, which had been suppressed on the grounds of national security since 1986, would be released to Parliament in 10 days.


British Jobless Rate Dips
LEAD: Unemployment in Britain fell two-tenths of a percentage point in February, to a seasonally adjusted 6.8 percent of the work force, its lowest level in more than eight years, the Government said this week.
The unemployment rate stood at 7 percent in January and at 8.7 percent in February 1988.
The latest rate was the lowest since December 1980.


Belfast Man Killed at Home
LEAD: Gunmen killed a 42-year-old Roman Catholic man in front of his wife tonight in the latest in a series of apparently retaliatory sectarian killings.
The police said the killers smashed their way into the house of Niall Davies, a civil servant, and shot him.
No group took responsibility for the slaying.


American Express Unit in Expansion
LEAD: Systems Associates Inc., a unit of the American Express Company, will acquire the Health Systems Company unit of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
Jeremy Causley, president of McDonnell's Information Systems Company division, said the decision to sell the unit was one of many recent moves to focus the direction of the aerospace and technology giant.

Beatrice S. W. Fuerst, Foundation Official, 83

She was 83 years old and lived in Rhinebeck.


Vibrations Force Jet to Land
LEAD: A Continental Airlines jetliner bound for Denver shuddered for several minutes with severe vibrations today, forcing it to return here for an emergency landing.
The crew of the Boeing 737 with 69 people aboard made a normal landing at San Francisco International Airport about 1 P.M., and crews found a scorched area about 10 feet wide on the tail.


Temporary Halt Is Ordered In Northwest Timber Sales
LEAD: A Federal judge said today that he would issue a temporary order to delay 135 timber sales planned by the United States Forest Service because of the battle over protecting ancient trees and rare owls, a lawyer for environmentalists reported.


Abraham Berger, Librarian, 86
LEAD: Abraham Berger, retired chief of the Jewish division of the New York Public Library, died Tuesday.
He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Norway Approves Insurance Merger
LEAD: Norway approved the bid by the Swedish insurance giant Forsakrings A.B.
Skandia to acquire the Norwegian insurer Vesta for $118 million.
Skandia, the largest Scandinavian insurance company, moves closer to its goal of establishing a pan-Nordic insurance empire.
It already has stakes in a Danish and a Finnish insurance group.

LEAD: Prospect Group Inc. came closer to clinching its takeover of the Illinois Central Transportation Company when it announced yesterday that 70.5 percent of the railroad company's stock had been tendered to it under a $434 million agreement.

It is 5 percent of the total ontrack payoff.

Your Money; Pitfalls of Homes As Investments
LEAD: A home may be a poor investment in today's real estate market, even though it can be a source of comfort and pride, and even though mortgage interest and property taxes remain deductible.
Prices of residential real estate are declining in parts of the United States.
As a result, many experts say, home buying should represent a long-term life style decision.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Savings Bond Sales Decline
LEAD: Sales of United States Savings Bonds declined in February for the first time in five months, falling 14.5 percent, to $691 million, the Treasury Department said Thursday.


FIXING THE HAM
LEAD:  Ham, a traditional and popular main course for Easter dinner, is cured in a variety of ways.
It can be air-dried, aged, smoked, brined, fully cooked or treated with a combination of these processes.
Some smokehouses sell country hams that are fully cooked and ready to eat.
Ready-to-eatt hams are usually labeled as such.


Words To Get Gulled By
LEAD: A corporation is said to be ''in play'' nowadays when Wall Street types start fighting over who will control it.
The people who engage in these fights are called ''major players,'' and the culture that breeds them is called the ''high-stakes world'' of mergers and acquisitions.

Apple Wins Round in Microsoft Suit
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. today apparently won the first round of its closely watched copyright infringement lawsuit against the Microsoft Corporation, as a Federal judge tentatively rejected Microsoft's contention that it had a license allowing it to use Apple's technology.


Negotiating Role Is Curbed For Main Seabrook Owner
LEAD: In a setback for the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, a bankruptcy judge yesterday ended the utility's exclusive right to propose a plan to end its bankruptcy and gave himself a major role in future negotiations.


Westchester Classic Has New Sponsor In Its Future
LEAD: The Buick division of General Motors will take over sponsorship of the Westchester Classic next year, replacing Manufacturers Hanover, which has sponsored that PGA Tour tournament since 1979.
This will make Buick a rare sponsor of two regular stops on the PGA Tour.
The Buick Open in Flint, Mich., has been held since 1958.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on March 10 about the Federated/Allied department stores misstated the scope of their regional support services for the Northeast.
The unit will not be responsible for the credit operations of the Jordan Marsh department stores in Boston and other New England cities.


Patents; Foreign Licenses at Record High
LEAD: The United States Patent and Trademark Office reported yesterday that foreign inventors obtained 47.1 percent of all patents issued in this country in 1988.
This share is up five-tenths of a percentage point from 1987 and is the highest level ever for foreign inventors.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: CopingWith Spring Cleaning; Before you hire a service for those heavy chores, it pays to check around.
LEAD: It's spring, or almost.
The windows need washing and furniture and carpets are begging to be shampooed.
What to do?
Call for help.


Drastic Steps Are Voted to Reduce Southern California Air Pollution
LEAD: A new vision of the American urban future emerged today as regional officials in Southern California voted to impose drastic restrictions on everyday activities to reduce air pollution.


SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.
Answers appear on page 50.


Jesus de Leizaola, 92, A Basque Leader, Dies
LEAD: Jesus Maria de Leizaola, who headed the Basque government in exile for nearly two decades during the Franco dictatorship, died Thursday after a heart attack, doctors in this Basque provincial capital said.
He was 92 years old.


Dow Chemical Sees Record 1989 Sales
LEAD: The Dow Chemical Company said it expects to achieve record sales again in 1989 and predicts it will nearly double its revenues to $30 billion a year by the mid-1990's.
In the company's annual report to shareholders, Dow's president, Frank Popoff, said the Midland, Mich., company expects to exceed the record $16.7 billion in sales it posted in 1988.


Agreement Ends Sit-In at College After Fifth Day
LEAD: For five days this week, students occupied Sarah Lawrence College's administration building to protest the school's policies on racial issues.
But the occupation ended tonight with commitments by the school to increase minority faculty hiring and ''Afro-American and other multi-cultural'' offerings in the curriculum.


Bush Is Shooed by Wife As Puppy Love Intrudes
LEAD: ''Seriously, it's awful,'' President Bush complained today.
Mrs.
Bush told him this morning that he would be evicted from their White House bedroom tonight because their dog, Millie, was about to have puppies and was making too much noise.


ANSWERS TO QUIZ
LEAD: Questions appear on page 8.


Short Brothers
LEAD: The West German aerospace group Messerschmitt-Boelkow-Blohm G.m.b.H. has dropped out of the race to take over Short Brothers P.L.C., the Northern Ireland aircraft and missile maker that the British Government wants to sell.
The Northern Ireland Secretary, Tom King, said he had been told by Messerschmitt's head of aircraft production, Hartmut Mehdorn, that the company had decided not to pursue the bid.


Budding Ballerinas Learn to Dance Without Sight and Without Fear.
LEAD: Guided by squeezes and whispers from her ballet teacher and an inexact sense of the people and objects around her, Ivonne Mosquera curtsied, turned and let her hand fall gracefully on the hand of a waiting prince.

Perle Premiere
LEAD: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is to give the world premiere of George Perle's Sextet for Piano and Winds today at 6 P.M. at the Paula Cooper Gallery, 155 Wooster Street.
The program also includes the Brahms Horn Trio in E flat (Op. 40) and the Dvorak Piano Quintet in A (Op. 81).
The concert will be repeated at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday at 5 P.M.


Drive in House on Acid Rain
LEAD: More than 100 House members have introduced legislation to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions by more than 40 percent and nitrogen oxide emissions by about half that.

Syntex Stock Up
LEAD: The shares of the Syntex Corporation jumped $2.50 a share yesterday, to $43.25, despite a sharp decline among most issues on Wall Street amid rumors that F. Hoffmann-La Roche was interested in acquiring the pharmaceutical company.
Syntex said it did not comment on speculation involving its stock, and Roche said the company did not comment on rumors.

Theodore W. Oppel, Physician, 85
LEAD: Theodore W. Oppel, an internist at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center for almost 50 years, died of pneumonia Tuesday at the Sarah Newman Nursing Home in Mamaroneck, N.Y.
He was 85 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.


Cheney Confirmed With No Dissent
LEAD: The Senate voted without dissent today to confirm Representative Dick Cheney as Secretary of Defense, acting a week and a day after it rejected the nomination of John G. Tower.


Edwin Janss Jr., 74, a Developer Of Suburbs and Two Ski Resorts
LEAD: Edwin Janss Jr., a California real estate developer who helped expand and develop the ski resorts of Sun Valley and Snowmass, fell to his death Thursday when he jumped from the 12th story of a building in Santa Monica, Calif.
He was 74 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

LEAD: Rod Strickland, the Knicks' rookie playmaker, had a chance to be a hero tonight in the city where he went to college, but he failed.


Rates Soar on Producer Price Data
LEAD: Interest rates soared yesterday as prices of fixed-income securities plunged on the report of an unexpectedly sharp rise in February producer prices.


Oil Prices Pass $20 a Barrel With Fifth Consecutive Rise
LEAD: Oil futures prices soared past the $20-a-barrel mark yesterday as the momentum that began building early in the week swept the market higher for the fifth consecutive day.

LEAD: Stock prices plunged across a broad front yesterday, as the market was stunned by a higher-than-expected rise in producer prices and buffeted by heavy selling related to the quarterly ''triple witching hour.''

ITALIAN JET CRASH IS LAID TO MISSILE
LEAD: One of Italy's enduring mysteries moved an important step toward a possible solution today when a team of scientific experts announced that a missile had caused an Italian civilian airliner to crash into the Tyrrhenian Sea nine years ago, killing all 81 people aboard.

Reviews/Film Festival; A Soviet Youth Finds Brooding Is His Forte
LEAD: The youth whose errors are recounted in ''The Errors of Youth'' is Dmitri Guryanov, whom we meet as he is about to complete his army service.
His main error is restlessness, an inability to settle down with one or another of the pretty women who find him appealing.
The main error of this Soviet movie, which will be shown tonight at 6:30 and tomorrow at 3:30 P.M.


2 Are Killed as Medieval Tower Collapses in Italy
LEAD: A 900-year-old medieval tower collapsed in a downtown square of this northern Italian city today, killing two people, injuring 15 and burying parked cars and a newspaper stand, officials said.

Georgetown Survives Princeton Scare
LEAD: In the age of 360-degree dunks, more frequently publicized academic abuses and the 45-second clock, the Princeton Tigers tonight demonstrated their ability to compete in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament by creating a top-seeded team's nightmare.


Charles Billingslea Is Dead at 74; Retired Major General in Army
LEAD: Charles Billingslea, a retired Army major general who served in World War II and Korea and later helped to enforce judicial desegregation orders in Mississippi and Alabama, died of pneumonia Tuesday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington.
He was 74 years old and lived in Oxford, Md.


Ashton to Raise Interbase Holding
LEAD: The Ashton-Tate Corporation said it has signed a letter of intent to acquire a majority interest in the Interbase Software Corporation of Bedford, Mass., a privately held company specializing in data base software for minicomputers.
Ashton-Tate previously had acquired a minority interest in Interbase as part of a joint-technology agreement announced in April 1988.


Seton Hall Holds On to Win; Syracuse Rolls
LEAD: Syracuse does not have to be reminded about the perils of post-season play.
With the exception of 1987, when the Orangemen reached the final, the national tournament has been a series of narrow escapes and premature exits.


Movie and TV Producers Reach Accord With Actors
LEAD: In an unusual move in an industry that has recently been plagued with bitter strikes, Hollywood's 102,000 actors have reached tentative agreement with movie and television producers months ahead of schedule.


Halliburton to Sell Insurance Division
LEAD: The Halliburton Company said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell a subsidiary, the Life Insurance Company of the Southwest, to a West German-led investment group for $71 million in cash.
Halliburton announced last September that it was seeking a buyer for the company, which it has owned for 25 years.

Review/Music; The Leinsdorf Brand of Program-Making
LEAD: Erich Leinsdorf's concert Thursday evening with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall took a prize for imaginative programming.
Bringing together three seldom-heard pieces by Debussy, Brahms and Berlioz, it had great intrinsic interest.
Fortunately, the night also proved to have extrinsic interest as well, in the form of carefully prepared, gracefully realized performances.

Review/Theater; Perplexity of Meaning in Translation
LEAD: The mystery in a John Jesurun play invariably begins before the performance, as the audience tries to find its equilibrium in a nebulous theatrical space.
Often this turns out to be a simulated moviedrome or television studio, where actors talk back to their own images.
With ''Black Maria'' (in 1987), the entire floor space of the theater was filled with chairs.

LEAD: In a major surprise, the Producer Price Index, for the second straight month, soared by 1 percent in February, the worst inflation for a two-month period in nearly eight years.

Rethink the Japan Fighter Deal
LEAD: Congress and the Administration are having welcome second thoughts about the Japan fighter deal negotiated by the Pentagon.
It's by no means clear that the Pentagon took America's commercial interests fully into account or, as it contends, that it got the best deal available.


Egypt's Neglected Art Trove
LEAD: Egypt is harboring 19th-century Impressionist and other art worth millions, possibly billions, yet neglected in out-of-the-way museums or stored in chaotic conditions, Western specialists and Egyptian officials say.


Review/Pop; Cute, Fit and Leather-Clad
LEAD: In an arena filled with the squeals of teen-age girls, as the Brendan Byrne Arena in the New Jersey Meadowlands was on Wednesday night, Bon Jovi's popularity starts to make sense.
Seasoned rock listeners are dismayed by the multimillion-record sales of a band that blatantly borrows from other rock while dispensing cliche upon cliche; hearing Bon Jovi is like being locked in a greeting-card warehouse with a radio that plays only 1970's ''classic rock.


Cambodian Prince Says Bush Promised Him 'Full Support'
LEAD: Prince Norodom Ranariddh said today that President Bush promised him and his father, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, ''full support'' for the Cambodian opposition.
But he acknowledged that he had not received ''a clear and positive response'' from Washington to his request for weapons.


Program to Extend AIDS Drug Program Is Stalled in Senate
LEAD: A program that provides an expensive drug to AIDS patients who cannot otherwise afford it was not extended by the Senate today, and it seems certain that the program will expire at least temporarily.


Introduction Seen For Intel Chip
LEAD: The Intel Corporation is expected to introduce a long-awaited new microprocessor at the Comdex computer trade show in Chicago next month, analysts and industry observers said.
The new chip, named the 80486, is not considered a successor to Intel's best-selling 80386 microprocessor, but rather an effort to bolster the company's presence in the fast-growing workstation and mid-range computer markets, analysts said.


Bridge; Old friends and rivals battle at Spring Nationals.
LEAD: Some old friends and rivals battled here yesterday in the third round of Vanderbilt Knockout Team play at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.
Two decades ago Italian teams including Benito Garozzo and Giorgio Belladonna captured a pair of world team titles with a victory in the finals over American squads that included Edgar Kaplan, Norman Kay and Bill Root as members.


Soldier Sues for a Discharge So She Can Stay With Baby
LEAD: A servicewoman with a 6-month-old daughter has sued for a hardship discharge from the Army so she will not be sent to South Korea and be separated from her child.


Katha Quinn, Sports Publicist, 34
LEAD: Katha Quinn, the sports-information director at St.
John's University, died of liver cancer yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.
She was 34 years old.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on March 4 about Indian Government measures to placate Sikhs misidentified the place where a group of Sikh detainees had been held since 1984.
They were at Jodhpur, in Rajasthan State, and not Jubbulpore, in Madhya Pradesh.


A Muscovy Duck's Heart Can Also Break
LEAD: To the Editor:


Papandreou Realigns Greek Cabinet Posts
LEAD: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou shuffled 12 Cabinet posts today, a move that opponents called an attempt to salvage his waning popularity in the face of a widening political scandal.


A 'Club' Welcome
LEAD: Anyone who belongs to a club and can prove it can buy a ticket for $10 to the first preview of ''Welcome to the Club,'' the new Cy Coleman musical comedy about love, marriage and divorce.
Tickets will be available at the Music Box Theater when the box office opens Monday.
The first preview is March 27 at 8 P.M., and the show is scheduled to open April 13.


A.&amp;S. Moves to Fill Gimbels Void
LEAD: In making its first move into Manhattan, Abraham &amp; Straus, the Brooklyn-based retail chain, believes it can succeed in a market in which many other mid-price retailers have found it impossible to survive.
It is a risky move, but one the chain sees as necessary.


Pfft! Nets Waste Another Big Lead
LEAD: The Nets have never seen a lead they couldn't lose.
They have rarely encountered a full-court press that didn't shake their confidence.
And in a season that gets bleaker by the day, they have rarely suffered a loss more disheartening than tonight's.

LEAD: The 10th anniversary of the most joyous event in Israel's recent history - the signing of peace with Egypt - will, by deliberate choice, pass virtually unnoticed here.

LEAD: CAN New Yorkers, already short of space in kitchens and hallways, be persuaded to pile up newspapers and add a separate garbage pail for bottles and cans?
More, will they accept the inconvenience for the sake of a distant deadline?

POSTINGS: Wired for Law Firms; 125,000 Square Feet in White Plains
LEAD: Despite a glut of commercial space in the New York metropolitan area, another office building is being built in White Plains, which has one of the lowest vacancy rates in this area.
Louis Cappelli, a partner in the Cappelli Development Corporation of Valhalla, N.Y., which is undertaking the $23 million project, said ''construction of office projects in White Plains has been synchronized with demand, which has reduced the haphazard overbuilding that has led to the series of booms and busts in office space in other areas.


Substandard Subtitles
LEAD: To the Editor:


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Since insulating the ceiling of my vented crawl space under the house, I have had trouble with the water pipes freezing in cold weather.
I have wrapped some of the pipes with electric heating tape, but this is not possible under the main part of the house.
To prevent freezing, I am contemplating taking off the insulation under the main part of the house and insulating the walls of the crawl space.

LEAD: Searchers who followed directions given by Ted Bundy before his execution found bones and the tattered remnants of a blouse Friday near a site where the multiple murderer said he buried a 17-year-old girl in 1974.

War of Starvation In the Sudan Is Frustrating U.S. Diplomacy
LEAD: WITH the Prime Minister of the Sudan, Sadiq al-Mahdi, sitting just feet away, an American official told an international gathering here this month that the Sudanese Government had to improve the way it delivered food relief to the country's famine victims.
It was the most public message so far in which the United States Government called on Khartoum to allow neutral humanitarian relief operations into rebel and Government areas during a civil war that has caused devastating starvation.


Marinades and Herbs Enhance the Flavor of Fish
LEAD: WHEN it is absolutely fresh - straight out of the water - there is nothing better than fish cooked plain, brought sizzling to the table and served with a piece of lemon.
But the fish we buy is not always that fresh.
There are many ways to enhance its flavor, however, with fresh herbs like thyme or tarragon, or a marinade of soy sauce, spices and ginger.

LEAD: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today that the Jordanian Government was ultimately responsible for an ambush Friday night by guerrillas who slipped across the border and killed an Israeli soldier before escaping back to Jordan.

PASTIMES: Numismatics
LEAD: A near-complete collection of brilliant proof trade dollars is at auction in Sotheby's sale of the Harry Warshaw Collection of United States coins on Tuesday.
The trade dollar is an exotic coin evoking the long-lost days of the China trade.
The Warshaw pieces are in beautiful condition.

Renovations to make it suitable for jewelry companies and purchase of the building are costing the new owners $50 million.

A Big Deadline Looms for Keogh Plans
LEAD: Many owners of Keogh plans are facing a double tax deadline this year.
Like everyone else, they must file their regular income tax returns by April 17.
But if their Keoghs are considered ''frozen,'' they may also be facing a May 31 deadline to determine the future status of their plans.
A failure to act could set off stiff tax liabilities.

Prospects; Brady's Debt Plan Debuts
LEAD: In a recent speech, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady outlined a new plan for third world debt relief.
It calls for additional lending as well as increased use of debt-for-equity swaps.
It also advocates converting some of the $280 billion that debtor countries owe to private banks into low-interest bonds.

Water Companies Filing Requests For Big Rate Rises
LEAD: IN Greenwich, there is talk of a takeover of a water company that has been privately run for nearly a century. ''If they keep raising the rates, it's something we're going to have to consider,'' said First Selectman John B. Margenot Jr.
The utility that serves Greenwich, the Connecticut-American Water Company, is seeking a 33 percent rate increase, which would make it the third in as many years.


It's Time To Stop Our Busy, Busy Lives
LEAD: MY friend, a lawyer, takes his briefcase to the ball game.
He even takes it to a cocktail party.
He works a minimum of 70 hours a week and is proud of it.
The word ''leisure'' is not in his vocabulary. ''Can't waste a minute, you know,'' he says over his martini. ''Time is money.
If you're gonna make it big, you'd better get started.

LEAD: IN symbolic terms, the French Revolution started 200 years ago in Paris at what is today La Divine, a pizza joint in the Place de la Bastille.
