Finally, a Composer's Music Catches Up to His Words
LEAD: For practically 50 years, George Perle has been known for his ability to unravel in words the intricacies of 12-tone music.
Such a classic is his 1962 book ''Serial Composition and Atonality,'' one of the first attempts to explain how Schoenberg, Berg and Webern could make musical sense out of the chaos of atonality, that it will be published in Beijing, in Chinese, this year.


Pesticide Regulation, Slow and Unsteady
LEAD: WHAT is the public supposed to think?
Last month, the Environmental Protection Agency identified Alar, a chemical used to make apples redder and crisper, as a carcinogen and said that it should be banned - though not until 1990.
The E.P.A.'s Acting Deputy Administrator, John Moore, told a Senate subcommittee that if the substance had just been invented, the agency would not allow it to be sold.


4 Senators Charge Auto Group Is a Foreign Agent
LEAD: Four Democratic Senators have asserted that a group representing sellers of imported cars is a foreign agent, and they have asked the Justice Department to investigate it.


Knowing the Rules of the Road Wherever You Are
LEAD: WHEN you drive into another state, you become subject to that state's vehicle laws.
The sign that welcomes you is often accompanied by warnings about speed limits and littering and sometimes about radar detectors.
But there are many other laws and regulations in effect, with or without warnings by the roadside, that you may not be clear about.

The Last of the Kaweskar
LEAD: To the Editor:


PASTIMES: Stamps
LEAD: So much of a stamp's design seems predictable - the name of the country, the denomination, ''postage,'' ''par avion.'' A casual glance fails to note the extraordinary skills required to produce what are often miniature masterpieces.


2 Men Shoot Subway Rider After Trying to Take Earrings
LEAD: Two young men trying to steal a sleeping subway passenger's earrings shot her in the face yesterday when she awoke during the robbery attempt, the police said.


Bush Must Keep Steady Fording the Rapids
LEAD: President Bush said in Texas last week that changes in the Soviet Union, and China, are ''profound.
It will never go back to the way it was.'' This is true, and it is of great importance that it is recognized by America's leader because it highlights a whole new era confronting the U.S.


RICHARD TAYLOR, PROFESSOR EMERITUS
LEAD: I am sorry that Richard Taylor cared so little about teaching.
He should not, however, use his own laziness in the classroom to impugn the hard work, dedication and commitment of other university professors.
Perhaps Professor Taylor (and his students) would have been better off if he had stayed in that ''other warm place.

LEAD: They say clothes make the man, but it's a rare man who doesn't turn that maxim on its head from time to time, bending fashion's dictates to his own tastes and whims.

Reviews/Theater; Second Series of One-Act Plays
LEAD: Stream of consciousness is always a tricky business in the theater.
Shakespeare was a master, and the Greeks employed choruses to similar effect.
Sam Shepard and Lanford Wilson are among the modern playwrights who can seamlessly weave asides to the audience into their dramas.


Brigantine Journal; Mammal Aid Center's Use of Town Name Criticized
LEAD: IN an immersion tank at the Marine Mammal Stranding Center on Brigantine Boulevard here, a weary harbor seal bobbed and turned as concerned volunteers monitored its progress.
Whether it would live or die would depend on the animal's inherent strength, said Robert Schoelkopf, the center's director and founder.


Kuwait Orders a Crackdown on Its Shiite Minority
LEAD: Kuwait has ordered a crackdown on its large Shiite Muslim minority, reflecting what Western diplomats call continued concern over Iranian-inspired terrorism despite the ending of the Persian Gulf war and efforts to improve ties with Teheran.

Make More Goods and Prices Will Fall
LEAD: After nearly eight years of overcapacity, the American rust belt has revived.
The upturn is the first decent chance in several years for American companies to gain ground on their foreign competitors.
The question now is whether this upturn will only be a short-lived illusion - or whether American companies can use this breathing spell to improve their competitive position.

Reviews/Music; Bach's 'St. John Passion,' With a Few Additions
LEAD: A special point of interest in the performance of Bach's ''Johannespassion'' at St.
Thomas Church Tuesday night was the inclusion of five numbers added to the work in 1725, two years after its first performance.
They have been made easily available to performers within the past decade by their appearance as an appendix to the Barenreiter edition of the score, but have not been generally adopted; this listener had never heard them in a performance of the complete ''Passion.

LEAD: Two forest fires in southern New Jersey burned more than 4,000 acres of environmentally important Pinelands before being brought under control yesterday.

Q and A
LEAD:  Inside Co-op Buyer


With Soviet Weapons to Lean On, Kabul Is No Pushover
LEAD: RESIDENTS of Kabul had little trouble waking last week.
Shortly before dawn on most mornings, a noise like a giant thud echoed across the Afghan capital, followed by a roar that rapidly faded away.
The sound would be repeated before quiet returned, and then on sporadic occasions later in the day.


TALKING: Gardens; Planning Plots for Condos
LEAD: A DRAWBACK to suburban condominium living, in contrast to owning a one-family house with a backyard, is the limited opportunity for gardening.
Those who seem to feel the loss most, managers report, are older people who have spent a lifetime tending a favorite plot at a former home.


New Yorkers Strengthen Seton Hall
LEAD: Six years ago, when they first met as teammates for New York's Riverside Hawks in the church league, John Morton and Gerald Greene were high school juniors with a penchant for playing fancy and footloose basketball.


Air Fares
LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding first-class air fares: I bought a round-trip ticket to San Francisco, coach fare, for $284.
I had asked for a business-class fare and was told there was none from San Antonio to San Francisco.
First class would have been about $1,300 at that time, but now I understand that if space is available you can get a ''coach upgrade'' to first class for $860.


Arizona Stops Clemson
LEAD: Arizona, ranked No. 1 in the last regular-season Associated Press poll, held Clemson scoreless for more than nine minutes today and beat the Tigers, 94-68, to advance to the semifinals of the N.C.A.A.
West Regional.


Wurstel
LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding the Fare of the Country (Travel, Feb. 5), Austria's favorite Wurstel is likely these days to be loaded with MSG, which the Viennese seldom label as glutamate but rather as Geschmackverstarker or taste strengthener.
Those allergic to this chemical should avoid the street stalls; when buying at groceries, check the product's ingredients.


Out-Patient Surgery Is Making Gains
LEAD: AT 7 A.M. on a recent day, a 70-year-old woman from Tarrytown walked into the ambulatory-surgery unit at Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in North Tarrytown.
At 3 P.M. she walked out.
Only the patch over her right eye revealed that she had undergone a one-and-a-half-hour operation to remove a cataract and implant a lens in her eye.

LEAD: Q. Since insulating the ceiling of my vented crawl space under the house, I have had trouble with the water pipes freezing in cold weather.
I have wrapped some of the pipes with electric heating tape, but this is not possible under the main part of the house.
To prevent freezing, I am contemplating taking off the insulation under the main part of the house and insulating the walls of the crawl space.

Under Siege, N.R.A. Fights 'The Hysteria'
LEAD: The gun museum on the ground floor of the National Rifle Association's headquarters here is very calm, or as calm as any place can be that features displays of double-barrel shotguns, bolt-action rifles, toggle-breach semiautomatics, Smith &amp; Wesson .44 magnums, pocket Derringers, British muskets, Japanese ceremonial guns, Bowie knives, powder horns, boar and lion heads and a prize photograph of a woman with a large snake around her neck.

The Vatican and the American Ways
LEAD: THE room where Pope John Paul II and his chief aides met earlier this month with 36 American Catholic cardinals and archbishops is austere, its brick walls adorned only with a crucifix.
Now known as the Old Synod Hall, the Vatican chamber was once a storage room for fragments of Greek and Roman statuary, and was called the Hall of Broken Heads.

POSTINGS: Expansion in L.I. City; Warehousing Art
LEAD: Twenty years ago, E. William Judson opened a real estate office on the East Side of Manhattan and began leasing space for the many midtown galleries that sprang up as New York became the art capital of the world.
As he leased more and more space for galleries, he noted that the typical gallery used half its space for storage, making such storage increasingly expensive as rents shot up.


A Wooden Nickel in The Tin Cup
LEAD: It should have been easy to predict a few decades ago, when American symphony orchestras and opera companies first began to rattle their tin cups and plead for government aid, that majority taste would eventually affect and probably erode their artistic independence.
Why not?
The prime business of a democratic government is to discover what most people want and try to please them.

Correction
LEAD: A picture caption last Sunday about the Fifth Annual New York Flower Show misidentified the display shown.

WHAT'S DOING IN: New Delhi
LEAD: The scholar Percival Spear, who devoted more than 50 years to the study of India, had a special fascination for New Delhi, which he called ''the stop-go capital.'' He meant that the city had an unusually uneven and protean history, changing its face, its ethnic composition, its religious character and its role as a subcontinental metropolis from century to century or decade to decade.

RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?
LEAD: THE CARIOCAS, AS THE NATIVES OF Rio de Janeiro are known, have marvellous qualities - an infectious joie de vivre, a refined sense of the ridiculous, the most sophisticated and beautiful popular music in the world - but the ability to handle money isn't one of them.
So it came as no surprise to learn last fall that the city had declared bankruptcy.

The officer was also wounded, but not critically.

Spouting Off
LEAD: ONE WANTS TO CALL IT A TEMpest in a very large teapot.
Or maybe a controlled weather experiment.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  SHEEP FROM THE GOATS: Selected Literary Essays.
By John Simon. (Weidenfeld &amp; Nicolson, $24.95.) Gore Vidal once called John Simon a ''literary gangster,'' adding that there was nothing Mr.
Simon - best known for his trenchant theater reviews in New York magazine - could not ''find to hate.'' Yet as ''The Sheep From the Goats,'' a discerning, highly idiosyncratic collection of literary essays, attests, within the gangster lies an equally ferocious, uncompromising champion of literature.

Preventing Work Injuires Can Curb Corporate Health Costs
LEAD: Companies are taking more aggressive steps to prevent workers from becoming disabled and to speed the recovery of those who do.
And for a good reason.
Claims for workers' compensation have skyrocketed, jumping 60 percent since 1983 to more than $26 billion last year, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

LEAD: A county court judge has ruled that doctors may remove 100 metal objects, including bedsprings and razor blades, from the stomach of a prison inmate, Carl E. Rhoades, 32 years old, without his consent.
Mr.
Rhoades, who is considered suicidal, is serving 10 to 20 years at the Kansas State Industrial Reformatory for drug possession and battery.

It happens in midtown, at the Art Students League.
And it happens downtown, at the New York Academy of Art, at 419 Lafayette Street, which was set up as recently as 1981.

LEAD: You do not have to travel as far north as Vermont to watch maple syrup in the making.
At Warrups Farm in Redding, Conn., about an hour-and-a-half drive from Manhattan, Bill Hill and his brother Bob welcome visitors to their sugarhouse on weekends.


SUITS: A NEW TWIST
LEAD: Running from jammed airport terminals to leg-numbing flights, from cramped cabs to crowded conferences, can put a wrinkle in any man's schedule - not to mention his clothes.
In addition to the heat, haze and humidity of summer, basic business wear is to blame: A man in a dress shirt and tie has at least a dozen layers of cloth bound snugly around his neck.


Spotlight on Colorado State
LEAD: It happens every year as a few overlooked or lightly regarded teams from college basketball's boondocks are thrust into the spotlight during the national tournament.
The coaches are usually self-deprecating, the players just happy to be here, while opponents build them up as giant killers capable of making the Final Four.

New Yorkers, etc.
LEAD: Every man and woman who has ever dated knows that the process is not simple.
If it's a blind date, a first date or one of the first dates, it boils down to a game of chance.
The other person may be pleasant and presentable, but that's no guarantee of anything.
Thousands of pleasant, presentable people are boring, pedestrian and erased from the mind as quickly as they disappear from view.

LEAD: The former Czechoslovak leader, Alexander Dubcek, who has become increasingly critical of the Prague leadership, was not allowed to travel to Italy for the opening today of a Communist Party congress, his wife said by telephone.
Mr.
Dubcek, leader of the Government crushed by a Soviet-led Warsaw Pact invasion in 1968, last month condemned the Czechoslovak authorities for police attacks on protesters.

Trust Your Agent
LEAD: To the Editor:


IT'S KOSHER
LEAD: Beginning about a decade ago, a younger generation of Jews decided that there was no reason why they had to be masochistic to be observant when it came to the High Holy Days.
Many of them ba'alei teschuva (returnees to the faith), they were also sophisticated in matters of food and drink.
They refused to accept the viscous, sweet sacramental wine of their elders and demanded something better, or at least something more in tune with their modern tastes.


HOME WORK
LEAD: For many busy men, exercise has become a little too much like work: getting up early, putting on the required clothes, traveling at least some distance, toiling alongside hordes of others and then returning home - exhausted.

Correction
LEAD: An article on page 10 of the Travel section today, about New Delhi, gives an incorrect telephone number for the Diplomat Hotel in some copies; the number should be 301-0204.
The article also misstates the price of a book, ''Old Delhi: 10 Easy Walks''; it costs $5.

Reviews/Music; The Mystical Golem as Subject of a Concert
LEAD: The Jewish Museum is presenting, through April 2, an exhibition called ''Golem!
Danger, Deliverance and Art,'' in which artistic and popular-culture responses to the ancient golem legend are brought together.
A golem is a clay man brought to life through mystical incantation.
Created as a protector, it grows independent of its maker and is destroyed.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  REFLECTING ON THINGS PAST: The Memoirs of Peter Lord Carrington. (Cornelia and Michael Bessie/Harper &amp; Row, $22.95.) Oh, to be an Englishman!
Or rather, to write like one.
Peter Lord Carrington is a man of his class and times - an aristocrat whose line began in the mid-17th century with one Thomas Smith of Nottingham, a draper who kept accounts for farmers.

LEAD: Imagine the freedom of suddenly being able to write what you think - after years of censorship, of suddenly being able to say the things you want to say instead of only the things the authorities will let you say - and you will have some idea of both the excitement and the difficulty of being a writer in the Soviet Union today.


Central America Negotiates on Its Own
LEAD: HOPES for peace and democracy in Central America are built on a series of agreements named for the obscure towns where they were signed.
The effectiveness of these accords has been questioned, particularly by United States conservatives who contend that the more recent ones omit some guarantees found in the earlier pacts.

Tragedy of Abuse As Entertainment
LEAD: Perhaps Edith L. Ellenbogen  [ Letters, March 5 ]  did not read the article by Geraldine M. Fox (''Abuse on TV,'' Jan. 29), for which I wrote a comment.
The idea seems to be that networks are using abuse victims as drawing cards.
Talk shows use the tragedy of abuse as a form of entertainment.
Anyone who is unaware of this terrible suffering would have to be living in a cave.

Kevin Zraly and Raymond Wellington - Wine Buyers
LEAD: Wine aficionados in the United States are faced with a staggering embarrassment of riches.
So many wines from around the world are available here one could spend a lifetime studying them.
Two young New Yorkers who do that, and in the process set wine trends in New York City and far beyond, are Kevin Zraly, 38, wine director for Inhilco, which runs Windows on the World and 21 other restaurants in the World Trade Center, and Raymond Wellington, 35, wine director for the New York Restaurant Group, in Manhattan, which includes Smith &amp; Wollensky, the Post House and the Manhattan Ocean


; Tall Ships and Modern Times
LEAD: ALL that the general public sees of the shipyard here in Greenport is the high wooden fence painted gray, which serves as a gallery wall to display large nautical artifacts of iron.
There are anchors, propellers, a winch and other curious and mysterious things.
Not junk, these, though old and rusty, but objets d'art, well spaced, resting on wood chips.

PASTIMES: Bridge
LEAD: A long-debated puzzle concerns the fact that at the highest levels of the game men are far more successful than women.
In more than half a century no woman has ever won an open world title, and very few have come close.
The pattern is similar in national championships, both in North America and other parts of the world.

LEAD: In the hotly competitive world of big-time college football, Notre Dame has always remained aloof from the controversial practice known as redshirting, extending selected players' careers by sidelining them during one of their first four seasons so they can play a fifth season.

Deneuve, Depardieu And Happenstance
LEAD: A man.
A woman.
A deserted rest area by the side of a highway, where the man and woman meet by chance.
She (Catherine Deneuve) has been abandoned there by an abusive husband who has left her stranded, in her fur coat and fur hat and dark glasses, in the middle of the night.
He (Gerard Depardieu) has already been there for a couple of days, trying to fix the engine of his car, an engine that -symbolically, no doubt - will not go.

It's Spring. Go Balance an Egg.
LEAD: Assuming fair weather and enough spring fever, scores of people will gather tomorrow morning in the plaza at the World Trade Center in Manhattan.

Many will succeed, in a small triumph of folklore over common sense, if not science.

LEAD: JANET TABERER, 66 years old, has been going to the Neighborhood Facility at Nelson Avenue in Peekskill every day for the last several years to get a hot lunch.
The hot-lunch program is one of several nutrition programs for the elderly sponsored by the County Office for the Aging.


In Other Towns, Memories of 1789
LEAD: IT began with peasant risings, went on to arson throughout the provinces and finally caused mass executions in several major cities: the French Revolution, in spite of the primacy of Paris, was very much a national affair.
Of course, not every city was as enthusiastic about the new order as the capital, but there is hardly a corner of France that did not participate in the great upheaval that ended the ancient regime.

Mr. Greenspan, Lower Rates Now!
LEAD: We cannot claim we have not been warned.
Federal Reserve Board chairman Alan Greenspan has been unusually explicit for months.
The economy is at full capacity and inflation is rising.
There are only two ways to deal with this problem: raise interest rates or reduce the budget deficit.


From the 50's, a Series of Brushes With Greatness
LEAD: The 1950'S and abstract expressionism, the heroic painting style that put American art on the map, are ever with us.
Anyone with a passing interest in contemporary art can recite the great names of that bygone yet omnipresent era when Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning, Mark Rothko, Clyfford Still, Barnett Newman and others arrived.


BACK IN TIME
LEAD: TIME WAS, a man's watch was just a timepiece: classical, understated and functional.
Now watches tell a lot more than the time of day.
They seem to offer a number of clues about the men who wear them, and serve, at the same time, as conspicuous status symbols.
These days, more and more men concerned with quality as well as image are returning to the classic mechanical-movement watch of the past.


Versailles Recovers Its Gilded Glory
LEAD: FOR Americans who have not recently seen Versailles, this is the ideal year for a return visit, both because of celebrations marking the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution and the recent conclusion of a five-year, $70-million restoration.


Italy
LEAD: To the Editor: We were delighted to read ''A Town of Crystal and Old Artistry Near Florence'' (Travel, Jan. 8) about Colle di Val d'Elsa.
We found Colle by running low on gasoline, driving from Volterra to Florence in May 1984.
The medieval hill town contrasts with its newer city in the valley, and the rolling Tucson hills complement the modern and ancient structures.


Alan V. Davies, 47, Real-Estate Executive
LEAD: Alan V. Davies, president of the J. Clarence Davies real-estate concern in Manhattan, died of a heart attack Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital.
He was 47 years old and lived in Manhattan.


TAILOR-MADE
LEAD: I was told to measure up, so I did.
But rather than shuffling off to shrink, shrine or spa, I went to meet my makers.
And in this material world, that meant suiter, shirter and shoer.
I admit that I'm too old to be a yuppie, and too young to be an old boy, but I do like nice things.
So when asked to venture on an odyssey into the world of custom-made clothing, I was more than ready to dress up my dressed-down appearance.

Against the Wall
LEAD: What is 12 feet tall, 120 feet long and red, or at least rust, all over?
It is ''Tilted Arc,'' a curving steel wall by the sculptor Richard Serra that was at the center of a prolonged artistic battle.
The work, commissioned by the Federal Government in 1981, bisected a portion of Federal Plaza in Lower Manhattan.


MY FATHER, MY FICTION
LEAD: A NOVEMBER DAY, 1988, and I am sitting in my study in our house in Princeton, N.J., as dusk comes on, listening to my father playing the piano in another wing of the house.
Flawlessly, he's moving through the presto agitato of Schubert's ''Erl King,'' striking the nightmarish sequence of notes firmly but rapidly.

HOLLYWOOD'S UNCOMMON EVERYMAN
LEAD: GENE HACKMAN IS BEING PURSUED.
A man has been haranguing him, calling on the phone, leaving letters in his apartment-house lobby.
He wants Hackman as his ally, a comrade to help thwart a plot, something inscrutable about ''Hollywood borrowers.'' Hackman has been stalked before.
There was the quick-draw artist with the loaded revolvers in Alamagordo, N.M.; the Las Vegas drunk brandishing a .357 magnum; the rifleman in Seattle who left his gun case at the cast's hotel, but this time, the interloper is unusually persistent.

Transplant seedlings to a one-one-one soil mixture.
Use rakes to clean up lawns and remove winter debris; add to compost pile.

RICHARD TAYLOR, PROFESSOR EMERITUS
LEAD: Richard Taylor's claim that his case is ''fairly typical'' is a gross libel on his colleagues.
His letter does not mention that 20 years before retirement, he moved to a house 90 miles from his university, abandoned all but the bare minimum of his academic activities, and, for a number of years, devoted himself mainly to the keeping of bees.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Since insulating the ceiling of my vented crawl space under the house, I have had trouble with the water pipes freezing in cold weather.
I have wrapped some of the pipes with electric heating tape, but this is not possible under the main part of the house.
To prevent freezing, I am contemplating taking off the insulation under the main part of the house and insulating the walls of the crawl space.

SLEEPING PILLS
LEAD: Dr.
Bruce Dobkin states that Dalmane is a short-acting drug.
In fact, Dalmane has the longest half life (the time it takes for half of the drug to be metabolized by the body) of any of the benzodiazepines, or 40 to 200 hours.
This means that the drug accumulates in the body when taken regularly, especially in the elderly.

To Look at the Hits Is Often to See the Misses
LEAD: There can be no easier way of feeling culturally disenfranchised than to insist on seeing the most popular film in the nation each week, whatever it may be.

ORDEAL ON I-80
LEAD: Jay Belsky gives the impression that the safest course of action in an accident is to remain in the car (About Men: ''Ordeal on 1-80,'' Feb. 19).
As a trauma surgeon, I have seen countless injuries sustained by people who stayed in a disabled vehicle.
The safest course of action is to walk away.
There is something about a car on the shoulder that acts like a magnet to attract other cars.

Bitter Harvest: AIDS and the Arts
LEAD: It would hardly be an exaggeration to describe American culture in the late 1980's as art in the era of AIDS.
Art has confronted AIDS the way people confront AIDS - with fear, anger, sorrow, defiance and confusion.
In a country that idolizes youth and health, AIDS has struck at the very heart of the American self-image.


Reviews/Music; Strings, Winds, Percussion and Computer
LEAD: The New York New Music Ensemble's Wednesday-evening performance at Merkin Concert Hall began with two older scores that have not lost their shine.
Peter Maxwell Davies's ''Antechrist'' (1967), a set of inventive and colorful variations on a 13th-century motet, and Henry Cowell's amusing ''Set of Five'' (1951), with its lyrical violin line, propulsive piano part and exotically varied percussion component, served as light-spirited appetizers.

Paranoia: Fearful Delusions
LEAD: MY WIFE and I purchased our home from the estate of a woman who had recently died.
All we knew about her was that she had been an elderly widow.
Yet you could tell that her last years had not been happy ones.
One clue was the heavy steel doors she had had installed front and back.
The front door was equipped with an apartment-style peephole, which was needed because she had had the windows in and around the door covered over with contact paper.

Lifted Voices From Women Of a Certain Age
LEAD: Bonnie Raitt starts her new album, ''Nick of Time'' (Capitol 91268; LP, cassette and CD), with quiet, plain-spoken, telling words.
In the title song, to a subdued drumbeat that ticks like a biological clock, she sings about a friend who:  Sees babies everywhere she goes
And she wants one of her own
She's waited long enough, she says
And still he can't decide
Pretty soon she'll have to choose
And it tears her up inside
She's scared
Scared to run out of time.

NOVEL APPEAL

Report on Prices Delivers a Jolt
LEAD: A jump in wholesale prices gave economists and the markets a shock.
The 1 percent increase in the Producer Price Index for February matched the January rise, and put the annual rate at an alarming 12.6 percent, triple the 4 percent rate of 1988.
The wholesale report on Friday followed other statistics that seemed to offer hints that the economy might be cooling a bit and inflation pressures might ease.

LEAD: A Federal grand jury has issued fraud indictments against three former executives of the Sundstrand Corporation, which last fall paid a record $115.3 million in fines for overcharging the Government on military contracts.


Grace &amp; Rothschild
LEAD: Grace &amp; Rothschild was the beneficiary last week of the Century Furniture Company's decision to move its in-house advertising account to an outside agency.
The Hickory, N.C., company, one of the nation's largest independent furniture makers, will spend about $5 million a year on print and television ads, said Roy Grace, the agency's chairman.

Police Kill Fugitive, Freeing Children Held Hostage
LEAD: An escaped murderer was shot to death and his accomplice captured early today when police stormed a town house and freed two children who had been held hostage for more than a day.

Making Child's Play Count
LEAD: DAVID SCHMELTZER, director of physcial education at the 92d Street Y in Manhattan, watched a plump girl of elementary school age clamber up and down a 10-foot high set of horizontal bars and then lie under a dangling rope and pull herself into a sitting position by walking her hands up the rope. ''When we told her mother she could do things like that, she was amazed,'' Schmeltzer said.

LEAD: Jeffrey M. Mondschein, a busy foreign exchange trader, was entertaining some corporate prospects at lunch at La Cote Basque in Manhattan.

OLYMPICS Officials Suspended For Events in Seoul
LEAD: The International Amateur Boxing Association imposed two-year suspensions today on five judges and referees accused of inefficiency and not officiating in accordance with international rules at the 1988 Olympic Games.
Five South Korean boxers and officials involved in a brawl during the Games were also given two-year suspensions.


Running in the Path of Explorers
LEAD: A 19th-century trek that took the explorers Lewis and Clark 17 days to complete is being refashioned into a modern eight-day foot race.


4 Palestinians Killed, Reports by Arabs Say
LEAD: Israeli soldiers shot and killed 4 Palestinians and wounded 18 in the most intense clashes in months in the occupied territories, Arab reports said.
The Israeli Army confirmed two dead and nine wounded in the clashes.


150 Trapped on Cable Cars at Disneyland
LEAD: An aerial ride stalled Saturday, leaving about 150 people stranded 40 feet over Disneyland for up to five hours while firefighters worked to rescue them.

Anti-Drug Official Backs a Ban on Assault Rifles
LEAD: The head of the Drug Enforcement Administration, John C. Lawn, called upon American gun manufacturers today to halt the sale of semiautomatic rifles and said he would support a Federal ban on the weapons.


Shot Strikes Senator's House
LEAD: A plainclothes police officer struggling with a suspect yesterday fired a shot that shattered a window and a flower pot in the home of a state senator in South Jamaica, Queens.
Officer Jospeh Libertelli saw the man trying to break into a car at 173-23 113th Avenue, the police said.
When the officer approached, the suspect ran into an alley, pulled out a knife and slashed the officer's wrist.

French Pesticide Hunt
LEAD: Bad weather forced the French Navy today to suspend a search for a container of toxic insecticide lost off the Channel Islands.
The container, packed with up to six tons of Lindane, one of the world's most potent pesticides, was being carried on a freighter that sank Monday 35 miles northwest of Guernsey.

Editors' Note
LEAD: An article on the Law page on July 22 described concerns raised by stu dents about instructors' comments in two review courses that train law graduates for the New York State bar examination.
Three women in one course, BAR/ BRI, complained in a letter to the State Board of Bar Examiners that they had been warned their scores might suffer if they used feminine or neutral pronouns or constructions like ''he/she'' in essays.

LEAD: WHEN oil topped $20 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange on Friday -for the first time since October 1987 - that was good news for the big oil companies but even better news for the companies that specialize in exploring and drilling.
This sector has been under severe pressure for the last three years.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Golf  A First for Garbacz: Lori Garbacz, who has been on tour for 11 years, captured her first Ladies Professional Golf Association title, fighting off Martha Nause en route to a four-stroke victory yesterday in the $300,000 Tucson Open in Arizona.
Garbacz and Nause were tied from the sixth through the 10th holes, but Nause then bogeyed four straight holes as Nancy Lopez moved into second place.

Boeing Spending Plans
LEAD: The Boeing Company plans to spend $1.1 billion on plants and equipment in 1989, a 63 percent increase over last year, the company's annual report said.
Boeing's spending on plant and equipment totaled $690 million in 1988, $738 million in 1987 and $795 million in 1986.
Last week, Boeing officials announced plans for a $430 million expansion and renovation during the next five years at the plant in Renton, Wash., where production of 757 and 737 jetliners is being increased to 24 a month from the current 19 a month.

Atmos Energy Corp., Dallas, a natural-gas distribution company, said Dennis S. Gillmore had resigned as executive vice president to pursue other business interests.

LEAD: United States policy toward Japan is so confused and uncoordinated that many American officials say they cannot figure out how it is made or why economic concerns are regularly subordinated to military and political objectives.

LEAD: The struggle between unions and management at Eastern Airlines enters a crucial phase in Federal bankruptcy court this week.

LEAD: Jack F. Kemp Jr., Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, plans to start a touch football team.
He is eager to challenge teams of his former colleagues on Capitol Hill and says he hopes William J. Bennett, the Administration's anti-drug chief, will start his own team to do battle with the H.U.D.


India Paper's Investment Bothers Rival Publishers
LEAD: One of India's oldest, largest and most influential newspaper companies is being denounced for buying a substantial share of another newspaper.
Editors and owners of other publications fear a takeover bid.
That, in turn, could set a precedent for other big companies, some in which the Government has a big stake, to try to take over smaller papers without a commitment to maintaining their editorial freedom.

LEAD: Eddie Sutton, whose Kentucky basketball program has been under investigation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, announced his resignation today.
He coached the Wildcats for four seasons.

LEAD: The crude oil supply by 12 of the 13 OPEC members was below their combined quota ceiling in February, the Middle East Economic Survey said today.

Strong Quake in Alaska
LEAD: An earthquake capable of doing considerable damage was felt in central Alaska Sunday but no injuries or damage were reported.
The tremor, at 4:07 P.M., was centered 170 miles southwest of Anchorage, said Don Finley, a spokesman for the United States Geological Survey in Washington.
Geological Survey monitors in Golden, Colo., recorded the quake at 5.3 on the Richter scale of ground motion.

Shield Law Bill Advances
LEAD: The law that protects New York journalists from being forced to reveal sources or produce notes and film in court would be strengthened under a bill approved today by the State Assembly.
The proposal would extend the state's Shield Law protection to include non-confidential information - the notes, photos and video footage gathered by reporters without any promise of confidentiality.

Speaking at a news conference, Mr.
Allen also said he does not think the company would be fully deregulated soon, despite predictions by analysts.

Donoher's 25-season record at Dayton was 437-275.
In 1966-67, he guided the Flyers to the N.C.A.A. tournament final, where they were defeated by U.C.L.A.
The Flyers were 12-17 this season.(

Obstacle to Seabrook Lifted
LEAD: The builders of the Seabrook nuclear plant said yesterday that they had removed the last obstacle to a low-power license for the plant by reaching agreement with an insurance company to provide money to decommission the reactor if it fails to operate above low power.

UConn Tops California On George's Foul Shots
LEAD: Tate George sank two free throws with five seconds left tonight to give the defending champion Huskies a 73-72 victory over California in the second round of the National Invitation Tournament.


Data Network to Use Code to Insure Privacy
LEAD: Officials of Internet, the computer network that ties together hundreds of academic, government and corporate networks, are planning to begin a program that will permit users to send messages to one another in what is intended to be an unbreakable code.


Soviet Poets Are Heard in Philadelphia
LEAD: Yunna Morits was born in 1937, during the peak of Stalin's terror.
As a young poet, she was praised by Anna Akhmatova, a badge of mythic proportions for any Russian writer.
She earned another badge when she was accused of ''unhealthy tendencies'' and was not published in the Soviet Union for nine years.

BRIEFS
LEAD: *
British Airways said one of its Concorde jets would make the first all-supersonic flight around the world beginning April 1.
On its three-week trip, the plane could set more than a dozen world speed records.


Del Monte Studied By RJR Nabisco
LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. said it had retained an investment banking firm to study the possible sale of Del Monte and consider other options, but it has not yet decided whether to sell the food subsidiary.
The company made the statement after The Wall Street Journal reported today that Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts &amp; Company, which bought RJR for a record $24.53 billion in February, had assigned Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company to seek bids for Del Monte.


Cuomo Vetoes Death Penalty Seventh Time
LEAD: Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo vetoed legislation today that would have restored the death penalty in New York State, the seventh time he has done so in as many years.
But this year, the Legislature appears to be closer than ever to overriding a veto.


Prices of Treasuries Sag Further
LEAD: With worries about rising inflation continuing to plague participants in the credit markets, prices of Treasury notes and bonds sagged further yesterday as interest rates on short-term Treasury bills surged.

Seoul Seems Unruffled by Referendum Delay
LEAD: A day after President Roh Tae Woo indefinitely postponed a referendum on his performance in office, Seoul's streets were oddly quiet today and opposition leaders seemed more relieved than angry.

Henry G. Hay, Executive, 68
LEAD: Henry G. Hay, a former vice president of Eastern Airlines, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla.
He was 68 years old.


London Issues a Report on Jan. 8 Jet Crash
LEAD: Accident investigators said today that they found no evidence that the cockpit warning system of a British Midland passenger jet malfunctioned when the crew shut down the wrong engine shortly before it crashed Jan. 8, killing 47 people.

Dallas Prosecutors Resist Freeing Murder Figure Who Won Appeal
LEAD: A prisoner who has served 12 1/2 years for a murder to which another man has all but confessed remained in prison today after one judge granted him release and another judge reversed that decision hours later.


Toxic Chemicals Found in Great Lakes Birds
LEAD: Birth defects among birds in the Great Lakes region have increased over the past two decades, the Sierra Club, an environmental organization, said.


How to Say a Lot in a Hurry
LEAD: PRODUCTIVITY Plus, reviewed here last year, is a handy program that can considerably improve both the speed and accuracy of anyone who does a lot of typing.
With PRD+ in memory, you type an abbreviation, ''ASAP,'' for example, and your computer expands it to ''as soon as possible.''


Japanese Test Illustrates Big Lead in TV of Future
LEAD: Next month, while Congress and the Pentagon are nudging American electronics makers toward a new generation of television technologies, Japan plans a quiet demonstration of how far ahead of other nations it is.
It will begin the world's first daily broadcasts of high-definition television, which produces images as sharp and detailed as movie images.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Cigarette Advertising Attacked on New Front
LEAD: A prominent Congressional foe of smoking opened another front yesterday in his battle against cigarette advertising.
Representative Thomas A. Luken, Democrat of Ohio, asked Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to investigate whether two cigarette manufacturers violated Federal law by paying to have their products featured in films.


Dow Slumps 29.64 More, To 2,262.50
LEAD: Stock prices yesterday continued the sharp slide that began on Friday in reaction to the report of a larger-than-expected rise in producer prices.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; D'Arcy Masius Sells Office to DDB Needham
LEAD: D'Arcy Masius Benton &amp; Bowles/ U.S.A. announced the sale yesterday of its San Francisco office to DDB Needham.
No terms were disclosed, but people involved in the deal said it was a non-cash transaction that included DDB Needham's assumption of D.M.B.&amp;B.'s lease, and potential payments to D.M.B.&amp;B.


Manila Seeks Aid on Debt
LEAD: The Philippines will seek a combination of new loans and debt reduction in talks next month in New York with commercial banks, the Finance Secretary, Vicente Jayme, said today.


More Organs Being Donated By Survivors for Transplant
LEAD: More Americans are offering dead relatives' organs for transplant, a national transplant network reported today.


Rangers' Skid Is Slowed
LEAD: It might have been a laugher if the Rangers had not been hurting so much.
So in the locker room afterward, they managed just smiles: small, perfunctory smiles born more of relief than confidence.

In the World of the Organized Jewish Community, Money Talks
LEAD: To the Editor:


2d Resignation At Kentucky
LEAD: One day after Kentucky's head basketball coach, Eddie Sutton, resigned, an assistant involved in a controversy over a recruit has also left the school.


Review/Guitar; Adding to Flamenco's Form
LEAD: The Spanish classical guitarist Andres Segovia used to complain that true flamenco had become debased and commercialized during the 20th century, and that in its pure form, the style was dead.
Younger flamenco players have refused to accept that verdict, and in recent years, several have devoted themselves to reviving and extending the style's traditional repertory.


Israeli Intelligence Report Links Peace Hopes to Talks With P.L.O.
LEAD: An internal intelligence agency report concludes that the Palestinian uprising cannot be brought to an end in the near future and that the Government will find a political solution only if it agrees to talk with the Palestine Liberation Organization, reports here said today.


Emhart Plans Merger With Black &amp; Decker
LEAD: The Emhart Corporation, which has been resisting a $2.4 billion takeover attempt by a New York investment group, announced a merger agreement yesterday with the Black &amp; Decker Corporation valued at $2.8 billion.


Review/Music; Rock's Cool Observer Turns Into a Chatterbox
LEAD: Lou Reed, once as deadpan and taciturn as his music was ferocious, has reincarnated himself as a talkative avuncular elder statesman of rock.

MacAndrews To Acquire Coleman
LEAD: The Coleman Company, a maker of lanterns and camping equipment, agreed yesterday to be acquired by MacAndrews &amp; Forbes Holdings Inc., which is controlled by Ronald O. Perelman, for $74 a share, or $545 million.


Crude Oil Prices Tumble; Wheat Is Down Sharply
LEAD: Crude oil prices plummeted in heavy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, partly reversing last week's strong rally.


Honduras Bars Journalists From the Contras' Base Area
LEAD: The Honduran Army barred journalists today from the border region where Nicaraguan rebel camps are situated after two soldiers were killed by mines in the area.


Syrup Maker Stake To Archer-Daniels
LEAD: The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, the agribusiness giant based in Decatur, Ill., has acquired a 5.9 percent stake in the American Fructose Corporation class A common stock.
American Fructose, a maker of high-fructose corn syrup based in Stamford, Conn., has 5.2 million class A shares outstanding.


Girlfriend Offers Hotel Alibi For Suspect in Officer Killing
LEAD: The girlfriend of one of four men accused of murdering a police officer in Queens testified yesterday that the man was with her at a hotel when the officer was slain two miles away.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Star Distances  Q.How do we know how far away the stars are?
A.''This is something that takes up weeks in an introductory astronomy class,'' said Andrew Fraknoi, an astronomer, who is the executive officer of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific.
However, he said, modern measurements depend on a relatively simple initial principal.

LEAD: THE mystery involving an object that astronomers believe was ejected by a supernova has taken another twist.


White House Keeps an Eye On Inflation
LEAD: The Bush Administration, which during its first weeks in office chafed openly about the risk of recession, seems now to have been convinced that the more serious danger is that of resurgent inflation.


Women Attacked at the Wailing Wall
LEAD: A group of Jewish women trying to hold a prayer service at the Wailing Wall were attacked today by rigorously Orthodox men and forced to flee when the police fired tear gas to disperse the attackers.


4 Boeing Jetliners Ordered by Varig
LEAD: The Boeing Company said that Varig, the Brazilian airline, had ordered four Boeing 767-300 extended-range jetliners valued at about $300 million.
Boeing has had a rash of orders in the last 15 months, including a record 636 airplanes valued at $29.7 billion in 1988.
So far this year it has announced orders for 67 airplanes valued at $6.3 billion, a company spokesman said.


Intriquing Studies Link Nutrition to Immunity
LEAD: RESEARCHERS studying the often-surprising effects of nutrition on immunity report that dietary manipulation can become a promising new tool to foster recovery or prevent disease in millions of people.


CHINA AGAIN MOVES CENTRAL PLANNING TO CENTER STAGE
LEAD: Cautioning that China had tried to change its economy too quickly in recent years, Prime Minister Li Peng called on China today to increase its reliance on central planning rather than market economics.


Stripping America's Forests
LEAD: President Bush could extend his promising environmental record by abandoning an ill-conceived scheme to speed the deforestation of the United States - already far advanced - for the benefit of Japan.


U.S. Lawsuits Settled by G.E.
LEAD: The Justice Department said today that the General Electric Company had agreed to pay $3.5 million to settle four Federal lawsuits contending that the company had defrauded the Government on military contracts.


Manhattan Dentist Charged With Sexual Abuse of Patient
LEAD: A Manhattan dentist was arrested yesterday afternoon and charged with sexually abusing a patient while she was under anesthesia, the police said.

Panhandle Eastern
LEAD: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation, the Houston-based natural gas pipeline company, extended its $53-a-share cash tender offer for the Texas Eastern Corporation, also based in Houston, until midnight April 3.
The offer, which began Feb. 21, had been set to expire at midnight today.
Panhandle Eastern said that almost 13.5 million of the 48.7 million Texas Eastern shares included in its offer had been tendered as of the close of business today.


Cuomo Shifts Stance on Blocking State University Tuition Increase
LEAD: Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo, who had in recent weeks vowed to block any attempt by the State University to raise tuition, said today that he might not stand in the way after all.

Ethics, Reporters and The New Yorker
LEAD: Janet Malcolm, a staff writer for The New Yorker, returned her magazine to the center of the long-running debate over ethics in journalism this month with her two-part article about the relationship between a murderer and an author who wrote about his crime.


Informality Reigns
LEAD: The formal, evening news conferences that came to be President Ronald Reagan's principal connection to the press and the voters, infrequent as they were, are becoming even more of a dinosaur in the Bush Administration.
There are a couple of reasons President Bush has no plans for such an event, White House officials say.


New York Tax On Limos Stirs Jersey Protests
LEAD: New York City's new $250 tax on out-of-town limousines has prompted more anti-New York grumbling from some politicians running for governor in New Jersey.


Winfield Seeks a 2d Opinion on Back
LEAD: Dave Winfield, who left the Yankees' spring camp Sunday to explore options for his ailing back, is seeking advice from as many as three specialists on the West Coast.
A team source said surgery is considered imminent.


Devaluation in Hungary
LEAD: The National Bank of Hungary said today that it would devalue the forint by an average of 5 percent against convertible currencies, effective on Tuesday.
The move will help to increase exports and ease demand for hard currency, which is growing because of import liberalization, the bank said in a statement reported by the Hungarian press agency M.T.I.-Econews.

U.S. Rig Count Declines
LEAD: The number of working rotary oil-drilling rigs in the United States fell by three, to 740, in the week ended Friday, Baker Hughes Inc. said today.
There were 943 rigs working a year earlier.
The rig counts show the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not the number producing oil.


Philip Morris Notes
LEAD: The Philip Morris Companies is offering $300 million of 10.85 percent notes due in September 1990 at a price of par through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley &amp; Company.
Noncallable for a year, the notes are priced to yield about 99 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

The Middle East Lie
LEAD: The only thing new in the world is the history you don't know.
Harry Truman said that.
Yes, and the most dangerous thing in the world is the history we do know but pretend never happened.
That is when people and nations squirm and twist and finally act in duplicity.
Trying to escape the truth of the past creates a new episode in history, usually sadder than it might have been.

Mario M. Cuomo.


By Design; In the Cafes, the Look Is Short
LEAD: The most popular expression here of the continuing popularity of short skirts are the versions one sees everywhere in the streets and cafes.
These are not skirts, in fact, but hip-length, fitted jackets with slightly flaring hems worn over opaque, skintight pantyhose or leggings and accompanied by flat-heeled, sturdy shoes.

Rose Inquiry Is Said to Involve Possible Betting on Baseball
LEAD: Pete Rose is being investigated by major league baseball for possibly betting on baseball games, Sports Illustrated has reported.


Defendant in Officer's Slaying Won't Take Stand
LEAD: One of four men charged with murdering a police officer in South Jamaica changed his mind yesterday and did not testify in his defense after his lawyer had said that he would.


U.S. Farm Stockpile Cut
LEAD: The stockpile of Government-owned grain and other commodities has been reduced by half in the last year, the Agriculture Department reported on Monday.
The department's Commodity Credit Corporation, which handles price support operations, said the value of products under its control as of Dec. 31 totaled $15.8 billion, down from $29.6 billion a year earlier.


Time Inc. Soars on Reports Of a Small Stake by Bass
LEAD: The stock of Time Inc. surged yesterday on reports that the Robert M. Bass Group held a small stake in the media company, which has agreed to merge with Warner Communications Inc.


Roy Jones Jr. Still Fighting For the Gold
LEAD: Even before the Olympic torch arrived in Seoul, South Korea, last year, the coach of the United States boxing team, Ken Adams, knew who might get burned.
Two days before the opening ceremony, Adams sat in an upstairs room in the Olympic Village and talked about how many gold medals his boxers might earn.

LEAD: WHEN Roland Shackelford, the wine maker at Chateau DeBaun in Santa Rosa, Calif., writes instructions for an assistant, they might read, ''Transfer 2,000 gallons of Overture from Debussy to Beethoven.''


Few Officers Face Charges In Park Melee
LEAD: A draft report by New York City's Civilian Complaint Review Board concludes that only a small number - perhaps only a dozen - of the 115 civilian complaints of police misconduct last summer in a clash at Tompkins Square Park have been substantiated and the officers positively identified, according to people who have seen the document.


Dalai Lama Sees a Culture Endangered
LEAD: Fearful of both hard-liners in the Chinese leadership and young Tibetans eager to challenge Beijing with violence, the Dalai Lama appealed today to China, his own followers and the West to help save Tibetan culture from annihilation.


Review/Theater; A 2d Drama in a Shakespeare Play
LEAD: When Mandy Patinkin is on stage emoting - or, these days, on record crooning - there is always a second suspenseful drama percolating just beneath the official script.
Will the actor keep his volatile emotions within the bounds of the character he's playing, or will he fly over the rainbow into an unedited orgy of tears and strangled tenor sobs that call more attention to his own overwrought sensitivity than to his role?


Who'll Profit From Victory In Salvador?
LEAD: Assuming that the right-wing candidate Alfredo Cristiani would win the presidency, a group of Salvadoran businessmen recently assembled $10 million to start a bank.


John J. McCloy Is Eulogized in Manhattan Service
LEAD: John J. McCloy, the lawyer, banker and administrator who made public affairs a life's work in the administrations of seven Presidents, was euologized yesterday in a Manhattan church by leaders in law, finance and government from both sides of the Atlantic.


Review/Film; A Tragic History in 'Lodz Ghetto'
LEAD: An atmosphere of funereal quiet pervades ''Lodz Ghetto,'' Kathryn Taverna and Alan Adelson's powerful documentary chronicling the history of the Polish ghetto where more than 200,000 Jews were forced into slave labor by the Nazis before being sent to death camps.

Eating Well
LEAD: FIVE servings of fruits and vegetables, six servings of starches and just six ounces of meat a day: this recommendation last month by the National Research Council, unlike previous ones in reports on the relationship between diet and health, was quite specific.


Centel's Sale Of Cable Unit
LEAD: The Centel Corporation said today that it expected to sell its cable television division this month for more than $1.4 billion and use the proceeds to pay a special dividend to shareholders.

LEAD: Tony Woods, a Seattle Seahawks linebacker, and Everett Gay, a Dallas Cowboys wide receiver, told a Federal jury today that they received threats from the sports agents Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom, who at one time represented each of them.

LEAD: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. is expected to make an offer Thursday for Financial News Network, the New York-based cable network that specializes in business news.


No Progress, as Usual, in Cayton-King Talks

Math Teachers Push for Reasoning Over Rote
LEAD: Saying society now requires mathematical knowledge far beyond the ''shopkeeper arithmetic skills'' traditionally taught in schools, the nation's largest association of mathematics teachers recommended today that reasoning should be emphasized over rote memorization as the best way to develop mathematically literate students.


60-Minute Gourmet
LEAD: SINCE my extended family is scattered around the country this Easter, I have decided to prepare a simple and quick dinner at home.
Instead of the traditional roast ham or leg of lamb, I will make medallions of pork with lentils, a favorite combination of mine.


Lawyers Challenge Steinberg Jury Chief
LEAD: The foreman of the jury that convicted Joel B. Steinberg was improperly coached to manipulate other jurors, Mr.
Steinberg's lawyers argued in a motion filed yesterday.
They said the verdict should be overturned.


Paris Opera Ballet Is to Perform At Radio City Music Hall in May
LEAD: The Paris Opera Ballet will perform at Radio City Music Hall from May 17 to 21, in its only American engagement of the year.
The season was announced yesterday afternoon by Rudolf Nureyev, artistic director of the company, in a press conference at the Music Hall.


Agency Allowing More Fruit From Chile Back on Market
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration today lifted more restrictions on importing fruit from Chile, announcing that pears and nectarines could again be marketed in the United States.


Bolivia Shifts Tactics in Drug Fight
LEAD: After years of American-assisted efforts to slow cocaine production and exporting through raids and other enforcement measures, Bolivia has switched its priorities to voluntary crop substitution and eradication.


Legislators in Arizona Reject Move to Pay Mecham Costs
LEAD: Legislative leaders Monday rejected a proposal to pay Evan Mecham, removed from the governorship in an impeachment trial, more than $200,000 in costs he incurred preparing for a recall election that was never held.


Antisubmarine Plans Criticized For Lacking Focus on the Future
LEAD: The Navy has failed to focus its research far enough into the future to maintain its technical advantage over Soviet and other submarines, which are becoming ever harder to detect, submarine warfare specialists said in a report released today.

Alan Civil, Hornist Of BBC and Beatles; Londoner Was 59
LEAD: Alan Civil, a British musician who was regarded as one of the world's most accomplished soloists on the French horn, died of liver and kidney failure on Sunday at King's College Hospital in London.
He was 59 years old.


Navy Trident 2 Missile Explodes In Its First Underwater Test Firing
LEAD: A Trident 2 missile exploded today four seconds after it shot out of the water off Cape Canaveral, Fla., in the first undersea test launching of the Navy's newest and most powerful nuclear ballistic missile.


Schubert Theme In Hoiby Piece For Quintet

Mr.
Hoiby complied, and on Sunday afternoon, the ensemble opened its Merkin Concert Hall performance with the result, ''Overture to a Song.

U.S. Delegation to Press Iraq On Reparations in Stark Case
LEAD: Frustrated that Iraq has not paid compensation to the families of 37 American sailors killed in the 1987 attack on the guided-missile frigate Stark, the Bush Administration is sending a high-level delegation to Baghdad this week to resolve the problem, State and Defense Department officials said today.

LEAD: The Government today defused a potential diplomatic incident with West Germany by assuring four black political detainees who sought refuge in the West German Embassy that they could leave without fear of arrest.

Rate Caution By Fed Seen
LEAD: When the Government's report on producer prices hit the news wires last Friday morning, many economists figured that the Federal Reserve would have no alternative but to slam the economy with much higher interest rates to stop inflation.


Principal's Lawyer Ejected And a Mistrial Is Declared
LEAD: The defense lawyer for a New York City school principal charged with drug possession was ejected from Criminal Court in Manhattan yesterday and a mistrial was declared after the lawyer said photographic and television coverage of the trial had caused him to withdraw from the case.


A Gentler Touch, and More Short Skirts
LEAD: Fashion has moved into a gentler mode as the fall and winter openings continue here.
In the last two days, designers showed pretty clothes rather than blockbuster change-the-world collections.


Transit Police Union Ratifies 3-Year Pact
LEAD: The transit police union has ratified a three-year contract that maintains pay parity with the Police Department and calls for annual raises of 6 percent, the union president, William McKechnie, announced yesterday.
The vote was 1,645 to 797.
The membership had rejected an earlier accord approved by the executive committee of the Transit Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

Traveler's Check Policy
LEAD: The American Express Travelers Cheque Group announced yesterday that it would deliver traveler's checks by hand to customers whose checks were lost or stolen, generally within three hours.


Klaus Tennstedt, Ailing, Cancels at Philharmonic
LEAD: The conductor Klaus Tennstedt is to undergo hip surgery and will not conduct the next 12 New York Philharmonic concerts as scheduled.
Replacing him tomorrow, Friday, Saturday and Tuesday is to be Yoel Levi.
The program and soloist remain as scheduled.


30th Inmate Is Executed in Texas
LEAD: A Texas prison inmate was put to death by lethal injection early today for killing a man 11 years ago by smashing his head in with the butt of a shotgun.

New York Needs Life, Not Death
LEAD: Every year for the last 12, New York's Legislature has passed death penalty bills but failed to override governors' vetos.
On Monday, Governor Cuomo again vetoed a death penalty bill.
But this year the Assembly has registered 99 votes for it, one shy of the two-thirds majority needed to override.
That challenges every opponent of the override to hold firm.

LEAD: The state of Washington has a problem.
Prison officials are scheduled to hang triple-killer Charles R. Campbell on March 30.
Trouble is, they may not have a hangman.

LEAD: R. J. Reynolds Tobacco U.S.A., a unit of RJR Nabisco Inc., said it would offer two voluntary separation programs to reduce its hourly work force by about 700 employees.

A Vintner's Labors In War-Torn Land
LEAD: STOIC admirers of Chateau Musar, a famous and exotic Lebanese red wine, profoundly understand Longfellow's maxim ''All things come round to him who will but wait.'' Musar typically takes 12 to 15 years to mature, if not longer.

Mild Quake Rattles California
LEAD: A mild earthquake shook towns along the Pacific coast north of Los Angeles this morning, but the police said there were no reports of injuries or serious damage.
The earthquake measured 3.8 on the open-ended Richter scale of ground motion, meaning it was strong enough to cause minor damage, scientists at the California Institute of Technology reported.

Bomb Kills Five in Colombia
LEAD: A bomb destroyed a three-story building, killing 5 people and injuring 11 in an expanding war between drug-trafficking groups, a military official said.
The bomb was thrown Monday at a ground-level food shop in a suburb of Medellin.
It was the third attack in a week against businesses owned by members of the Medellin drug cartel.

Chamber Society in SoHo 'Tryout'
LEAD: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center likes to try out its programs a little farther downtown.
Thus this week's four formal performances in New York and Washington were prefaced early Saturday evening by a dress-rehearsal-as-concert at the Paula Cooper Gallery in SoHo.
The big gallery space -stripped of most exhibits as insurance against careless listeners - is a bit too resonant to house a grand-piano sound comfortably, but it is a happy musical atmosphere, with listeners (a responsive and intelligent lot) seated on the floor.

Corrections
LEAD: The Eating Well column in The Living Section last Wednesday described a former use of the synthetic hormone diethystilbesterol (DES) incorrectly.
It was widely prescribed before 1971 as a safeguard against miscarriage, not for morning sickness.

Prudential Unit Had '88 Profit
LEAD: Prudential-Bache Securities said yesterday that it earned a record $111 million last year, a dramatic turnaround from the $164 million loss it recorded in 1987.
George L. Ball, the firm's chief executive, attributed the improvement to gains in risk-arbitrage trading and in investment banking.
The retail business, he said, registered a loss of a few million dollars.

A 2,700-Mile Running Path To a Sacred Cree Symbol
LEAD: Ten years ago, Jim Thunder, a Cree Indian, had a powerful dream.
In it, a revered ancestor and Cree warrior, Big Bear, commanded him to retrieve a sacred Cree symbol - Big Bear's bundle, a two-foot-long grizzly bear paw sewn to a sacred red cloth, with a plug of tobacco and a batch of sweet grass encased in layers of fabric.

He was 40 years old.
Mr.
Suppon died of brain lesions, his assistant, Bruce Cudd, said.

A Boy Who Killed Coldly Is Now a Prison 'Monster'
LEAD: Willie Bosket, a self-proclaimed ''monster'' whose five-year sentence for two subway murders when he was 15 years old led New York to toughen its juvenile criminal laws, will be sentenced this morning for his latest crime, stabbing a prison guard.


Review/Film; Vietnam, From a Cameraman's Vantage
LEAD: Charlie Duncan, the Vietnam veteran who wrote and directed ''84 Charlie Mopic,'' has said he wanted to make an intimate portrayal of war, to show what really happens to young men in battle.
The device he hit on was to mimic the making of an Army documentary. ''84 Charlie Mopic,'' which opens today at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, consists of film taken by a military cameraman as he follows a six-man patrol on a jungle reconnaissance mission in Vietnam, interviewing the soldiers and filming them in action from his shoulder-held camera.

Fast-Curing Cement May Help Road Builders
LEAD: For more than a century, engineers have used the same basic material to construct many of the nation's roads, bridges and buildings: portland cement.
When mixed with water, gravel and sand, it produces concrete, a substance as hard as stone after it dries.

Amerifirst Bank
LEAD: Amerifirst Bank said the Transohio Savings Bank had ended its agreement to acquire Amerifirst because Transohio had been unable to get regulatory approval for the deal, which was announced last May.
Transohio, a unit of the Transcapital Financial Corporation, offered $20 a share, or $230 million.
Amerifirst said Transohio had requested the return of a $25 million deposit made in conjunction with the agreement but that it did not intend to return the money.

LEAD: The Philadelphia 76ers have signed their center, Mike Gminski, to a multiyear contract to prevent him from testing his value as an unrestricted free agent after this season, the club announced yesterday.
The four-year contract also contains an option on a fifth season.

PARENT &amp; CHILD
LEAD: THE 6-year-old stood almost alone on his half of the soccer field.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  A Noisy Floor  Q.About two years ago a new kitchen floor was installed in my apartment.
Two layers of old tile and one layer of linoleum were removed, down to the original subfloor.
Plywood was then stapled down, and new linoleum was glued down over this.
Several weeks later crackling noises were heard in many areas when the floor was walked on.

Review/Television; Pilot News Program for Schools
LEAD: When the commercials came on, there was a flurry of chatter in the room.
Nothing astounding in that - television commercials have long since become occasions for chatting, snacking and letting out the cat.
But this audience was made up of students at Samuel C. Mumford High School here, and the 12-minute news program they were watching had stirred controversy mainly because of the inclusion of four 30-second commercials.

In Paris, Twiddle and Twitter
LEAD: Unlike tennis matches, where the heads move side to side, at fashion shows they go up and down.
Illustrators furiously pen silhouettes, looking up to catch another detail before the models vanish backstage.
Buyers circle important items on their programs, and fashion editors doodle incomprehensibly on theirs.

LEAD: As Secretary of State James Baker searches for useful diplomatic initiatives, let him consider South Africa.
Ever since its ailing President, P. W. Botha, resigned in January as leader of the ruling National Party, new voices - including the Soviet Union's - have called for a political solution to racial strife.

Corning to Acquire Testing Concern
LEAD: Corning Glass Works announced that it would acquire Enseco Inc., an environmental testing company based in Somerset, N.J., for $14 a share, or about $125 million.
Corning officials said Enseco would become part of a laboratory testing group within the company that already includes subsidiaries specializing in clinical, life-sciences and new-drug testing.

Forecast: No Recession
LEAD: Although the Federal Reserve Board's tighter monetary policy has apparently slowed economic growth, the economy is not about to fall into a recession, a University of Michigan forecast said today.
The economist Saul Hymans, director of the university's Research Seminar in Quantitative Economics, forecast a 4 percent annual growth rate in the first quarter.

Once again a spoiled, princessy character is forced to rough it, in this case as the troop leader commanding a group of equally spoiled little scouts.

LEAD: A HAND plane is an essential woodworking tool and an important item in any home-repair tool kit.
With a plane, the fit of doors and cabinet parts that have warped can be restored, lumber can be flattened and shaped and wood too rough for sanding can be smoothed.

LEAD: The Bush Administration's oft-reported sluggishness in assembling a team of senior officials has been noted by any number of Washington kibitzers, but one outsider with a real stake in the matter is taking it in stride. Review/Recital; Pianist Plays Mendelssohn
LEAD: Kathryn Selby, an Australian-born pianist whose technical facility is well above average, gave a satisfying recital Sunday afternoon at the 92d Street Y. The distinguishing characteristic of her work in Mendelssohn, Schubert, Corigliano, Debussy, Chopin and Liszt was a security of finger control that allowed her to use the pedal very sparingly and to keep firm control over musical shape in fast movements at tempos that could easily have spilled over into skittering haste.

As a result, the value of the company's stock has risen.

CLOSE TO HOME
LEAD: ONCE, when she was small, one of my daughters complained that our place was like a museum: white walls, many displays and an array of objects about which I was always screeching, ''Don't touch!'' She was more right than she realized.
Our place isn't like a museum, it is a museum, and some day I propose to schedule a walk-through for her and her sister.

LEAD: The Hughes Aircraft Company is a target of a Federal grand jury investigation into the quality of mirrors that were used to make guidance systems for cruise missiles and the Bradley armored personnel carrier, company officials said today.

LEAD: ''I had this picture of what it would be like to be a grown-up theater director,'' said Michael Engler, the grown-up theater director. ''Well, my life is like that now - doing an interesting variety of pieces in an interesting variety of places.
It makes me giddy sometimes to realize that I am really, at last, able to make my living at it.


Brooks Leaves School
LEAD: Tony Brooks, a Notre Dame tailback who faces two misdemeanor charges in a hit-and-run accident last month, has left the university and returned to his home in Tulsa, Okla., college officials said.
Brooks, 19 years old, withdrew voluntarily for personal reasons, said John Heisler, a spokesman for the athletic department.

Bauhaus Furniture Stars At a Los Angeles Gallery
LEAD: WHO needs an Aprica stroller when one can have a Bauhaus-style cradle, designed by Peter Keler in 1922 and based on the forms and colors of Wassily Kandinsky?


The Right Way to Rule New York
LEAD: There was no surprise but plenty of electricity in yesterday's unanimous Supreme Court decision that New York City's Board of Estimate cannot survive as now constituted.
The handwriting has been on the wall for years: this unique, antique and powerful governmental body violates the rule of one person one vote.


Reviews/Dance; Sampling the Wares of Several Troupes, in Annual Series
LEAD: A sense of adventure is not out of place in the Morningside Dance Festival; the first program on Tuesday night featured seven choreographers from the city and out of town.


Chrysalis Deal Made by Thorn
LEAD: Thorn EMI P.L.C., a diversified British concern, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 50 percent of Chrysalis Record Companies, a part of Chrysalis Group P.L.C., for an initial payment of $79.1 million in cash and as much as $25 million more, depending on profits in the next four years.


In the Quilting Egg, Two Folk Arts Meet
LEAD: AN ancient Ukrainian tradition and an American folk art come together when the artist Jane G. Pollak decorates eggs with quilt designs.
She will demonstrate the process today and tomorrow at two shops of the Museum of American Folk Art.


Koch Backs Pilot Plan to Aid the Mentally Ill
LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch will urge the State Legislature today to approve a pilot program to ease overcrowding in psychiatric emergency rooms in New York City by committing some patients to a regimen of outpatient care.
The program is also intended to improve supervision of potentially dangerous mentally ill patients.

LEAD: Hikari Baba has a hauntingly lovely face and a resilient body.
But she set herself such a difficult task in ''Images: Being Then and Now,'' performed Sunday night at the Mulberry Street Theater, that those attributes were not enough to save her.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a listing in the Advertising column of Business Day yesterday, about an executive appointment at Ingalls, Quinn &amp; Johnson, described the agency incorrectly.
It is independent, not part of Omnicom.

LEAD: Adela Holzer, the former Broadway producer indicted on charges of posing as David Rockefeller's secret wife to swindle investors out of more than $4 million, was accused by prosecutors yesterday of trying to bribe her way out of jail.

LEAD: Willie Bosket, the self-proclaimed ''monster'' of the New York State correctional system, used his knowledge of the law today to delay his sentencing for attempted murder.

LEAD: Sugar futures prices plummeted to a two-week low yesterday, and the market braced for further declines amid reports that the Soviet Union had said for the second time in as many weeks that it had finished its sugar buying for this year.

Escapees Leave Haven Of Pretoria Embassy
LEAD: Four black political detainees who escaped to the West German Embassy left the building today after the police guaranteed their freedom.


Knicks Set Ticket Lottery
LEAD: Tickets for Knicks playoff games at Madison Square Garden will be made available to the public by a lottery system.


Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses
LEAD: The largest and most conclusive study of drug use in pregnancy has found that the use of cocaine or marijauna impairs fetal development.

LEAD: A Nassau County grand jury heard evidence today in the slaying of a 13-year-old Valley Stream girl, and the lawyer for the two brothers who are the main suspects in the case said that at least one of them would surrender to the authorities Thursday.


Critic's Notebook; The Rockers Discover Broadway
LEAD: No wonder the ushers looked nervous.
The crowds trooping in to Broadway's St.
James and Lunt-Fontanne theaters wore black leather and jeans, and there wasn't a blue-haired head to be seen.
Half the crowd showed up late; by the end of each performance, people were on their feet and headed for the stage.


New York City Government: Eight Years on the Docket
LEAD:  Dec. 2, 1981: The New York Civil Liberties Union files suit in Federal District Court in Brooklyn charging that the allocation of one vote on the Board of Estimate to each borough president violates the United States Constitution's one-person-one-vote principle.
Judge Edward R. Neaher is assigned the case.


Review/Television; 13 Hours' Worth of British Spying on the 'Mystery' Series
LEAD: Costly and ambitious, the 13-hour production of ''Game, Set and Match'' - taking over public television's ''Mystery'' series for the next three months - is a mess.
And that's something traditional British television can hardly afford right now.


Review/Music; Heinz Holliger and Winds, With Mozart
LEAD: Heinz Holliger, the renowned Swiss oboist, has assembled a wind octet consisting of himself and seven topnotch Americans, which he is presenting in two venturesome programs at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
If Monday's first installment is any guide - and it certainly should be - this coming Monday's concert should be well worth attending.


Koch Orders Strong Steps to Bar Wasting of Water
LEAD: New York City imposed a wide range of drought-emergency measures yesterday as Mayor Edward I. Koch ordered strong steps to prohibit the wasting of water.


Britain to Sell Ulster Shipyard
LEAD: The British Government said today that it would sell the state-owned shipbuilders Harland &amp; Wolff in Northern Ireland to a management-employee group backed by a Norwegian shipping company, Fred Olsen.
The sale would spare the 130-year-old yard, which built the Titanic, from having to close when existing ship orders run out in 1991.


New Chief Is Named by Arthur Andersen
LEAD: The board of Arthur Andersen &amp; Company has nominated Lawrence A. Weinbach to become the firm's top officer, succeeding its departing chief executive, Duane R. Kullberg.


Drysdale Group Buys Visalia Club
LEAD: A corporation headed by Don Drysdale, the Hall of Fame pitcher, has purchased the Visalia Oaks of the California League, Drysdale's agent said today.


AIDS IN NEW YORK TO COST $7 BILLION
LEAD: New York City's official AIDS planning agency projected last night that the epidemic in the city will cost at least $7.2 billion in the next five years for outpatient care, hospitals, nursing homes, home care and housing.
Until now, city and state health officials have skirted the issue of AIDS costs.


Holiday Weekend
LEAD: Tomorrow is Good Friday and Sunday is Easter.
Here are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK  Parade: Fifth Avenue will be closed between 44th and 57th Streets on Sunday for the Easter Promenade, which begins at 11 A.M. and ends at 3 P.M.
Government offices: Open tomorrow.
Post office: Regular delivery.

High-Definition TV Hearings
LEAD: The chairman of the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology said today that he planned to push for $100 million in next year's budget to assist the nation's development of high-definition television.
The committee chairman, Robert A. Roe, Democrat of New Jersey, made his remarks after the panel heard four hours of testimony by government and industry representatives on the importance of the new technology, known as HDTV, which analysts say will have wide applications in personal computers, semiconductors and telecommunications.

LEAD: A Swiss civil court has ordered RJR Nabisco Inc. to deposit money in Switzerland before it sells any assets so that the rights of Swiss bondholders are protected.

He was 84 years old and lived in Yonkers.

LEAD: The Federal agency that enforces national gun laws will soon begin a survey to determine whether military-like semiautomatic rifles are used for target shooting and hunting.
