House Republicans Elect Gingrich of Georgia as Whip
LEAD: House Republicans ventilated 34 years of frustration at Democratic rule today and elected a telegenic firebrand, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, to their No. 2 leadership position.


Canada Banks Lift Rates
LEAD: Canadian banks, feeling the crunch of higher borrowing costs, pushed up their prime lending rates today to 13.5 percent, the highest in nearly five years.
The three-quarter-point rise was the biggest increase since Feb. 14, 1986.
The five leading Canadian banks took the action only minutes after the central bank, the Bank of Canada, said at a weekly rate announcement that its key lending rate had risen to 12.40 percent from 12.18 percent.

LEAD: G. Bennett Larson, a former vice president of WPIX-TV in New York and a former communications industry consultant, died of pneumonia Saturday at St.
John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif.
He was 79 years old and lived in Brentwood, Calif.

LEAD: A 16-year-old boy, apparently enthralled by the film character Rambo, killed his father, mother and brother and wounded his sister early today in a shooting rampage at the family's house on the outskirts of this city, the police said.

LEAD: Bo Schembechler, Michigan's football coach, testified today that two of his former players violated National Collegiate Athletic Association rules when they signed contracts and accepted loans from agents before their college eligibility expired.
He said he immediately revoked the scholarship of one of the players when he learned of the player's actions.


Debt Relief for Farmers
LEAD: More than 80 percent of the applications from farmers seeking special debt relief from the Farmers Home Administration have been processed, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday.
Under the Agricultural Credit Act of 1987, the farm agency sent more than 66,000 notices to borrowers who were delinquent by more than 180 days.


U.S. Believes Some Contras Abused Prisoners
LEAD: Bush Administration officials said today that they had tentatively concluded that some of the Nicaraguan guerrillas tortured prisoners and committed other human rights abuses in their camps in Honduras.


Stunning Owners, Rozelle Says He's Retiring
LEAD: Pete Rozelle announced today that after 29 years as commissioner of the National Football League he would resign as soon as a new commissioner was found.


Yanks Plan To Renew Trade Talk With Braves
LEAD: The Yankees, stung by injuries and concerned more than ever that Rafael Santana's aching right elbow might require surgery, resumed talks today with the Atlanta Braves about Jeff Blauser, their rookie shortstop.


Brazil, Smarting From the Outcry Over the Amazon, Charges Foreign Plot
LEAD: Embarrassed by the international outcry against the destruction of the Amazon rain forest, the Brazilian Government has begun a nationalist campaign that includes denunciations of foreign meddling and charges that the rich nations themselves covet the region's immense spaces and mineral wealth.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Law page on Friday about a suit that sought Government documents concerning the Iran-contra scandal incorrectly characterized the relationship of Tony Avirgan, the plaintiff in the suit, and Daniel Sheehan of the Christic Institute.
Mr.
Sheehan is representing Mr.
Avirgan; the two men are not opponents in the case.


Semi-Tech Is Winner: $38 a Share for SSMC
LEAD: The two-month takeover battle for control of SSMC Inc., the old Singer Sewing Machine Company, ended today with the announcement of a sweetened offer of $38 a share, or $206 million, by Semi-Tech Microelectronics Far East Ltd., an electronics company based in Hong Kong.


Living the Beautiful Life, By 3 Who Should Know
LEAD: THOSE who purvey bibelots are now writing bible-ettes.
The latest permutation of the decorating and life-style book may be found in three new volumes: ''Memories of Childhood'' by Barbara Milo Ohrbach (Clarkson N. Potter, $8.95), ''With Thanks &amp; Appreciation'' by Pat Ross (Viking Studio Books, $8.95) and ''Living Beautifully Together: How to Live Graciously in a Hectic World by Finding Time to Love Your Family, Your Friends, and Yourself'' by Alexandra Stoddard


Sun and Cray Pact On Work Stations
LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc. and Cray Research Inc. said they had signed an agreement under which Sun's work stations would be integrated with Cray's supercomputers.
The companies also said that the first product resulting from the alliance - the Cray FEI-3 channel interface, which would provide high-speed data transfer between the Sun and


Neighbor Is Charged in Murder of 13-Year-Old
LEAD: Robert Golub, an unemployed 21-year-old weightlifter who lives with his parents, was arrested today and charged with the murder of his 13-year-old Valley Stream neighbor, Kelly Tinyes.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Washington Talk: Congress; Garn and Bush Aides Hit Snag on Savings Plan
LEAD: He is a diehard conservative, a believer in deregulation, a Bush supporter and an intensely loyal Republican.


House Roll-Call Vote Approving Rise in the Minimum Wage
LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 248 to 171 by which the House or Representatives today approved an increase in the minimum wage to $4.55 an hour by October 1991.
A ''yes'' vote is a vote to approve the bill.
Voting ''yes'' were 226 Democrats and 22 Republicans.
Voting ''no'' were 24 Democrats and 147 Republicans.


Review/Film Festival; Romantic Summer Break At a Japanese Boys' School
LEAD: It comes as no surprise to learn that all of the earlier films by Shusuke Kaneko, the young Japanese director of ''Summer Vacation: 1999,'' have been soft-core porn.
Only a man utterly exhausted by the second-rate pleasures of grunting-and-groaning simulated sex could make a film as chastely, madly romantic as ''Summer Vacation: 1999.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Benafuels Inc. of Atlanta, a coal mining company, named Robert Hesse chairman and chief executive, succeeding Bruce Davis, who resigned for undisclosed reasons.


Southeast; Michigan's Fervor Thwarts Tar Heels
LEAD: This was not the same team he had watched on tape, Dean Smith said.
This was not the same team that has been whipped by Smith's North Carolina Tar Heels two years in a row in post-season play.
Many of the names are the same, but the Michigan Wolverines are playing with a sense of renewed purpose that makes videotapes and scouting reports irrelevant.


Democrats in House Warn Bush Against G.O.P. Partisan Warfare
LEAD: House Democratic leaders sent the Bush Administration some warning signals today, saying that bipartisan cooperation between Congress and the White House could be jeopardized if other Republicans are fanning partisan warfare.


U.S., Saying It Hopes to End Expulsions, Ousts Soviet Trade Envoy
LEAD: The United States has ordered a Soviet trade official to leave the United States in retaliation for Moscow's expulsion of an American military attache last week.

LEAD: ''In a Glass Cage,'' an elegant, unsettling first feature by the young Spanish writer and director Agustin Villaronga, is a revenge fantasy of the most icy viciousness.


Steinberg Is Punished For Makeshift Weapon
LEAD: Joel B. Steinberg, facing sentencing today in the fatal beating of his adoptive daughter, has been placed in ''punitive segregation'' for 30 days because a makeshift weapon was found among his belongings, New York City corrections officials said yesterday.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Hollywood 'Imperialism'
LEAD: Vigilant against what he called ''imperialism,'' Representative Lawrence J. Smith, a Florida Democrat, took the House floor Tuesday afternoon to defend the name and the rights of his hometown. ''My colleagues,'' he declared, ''heed my words.
If Hollywood, Fla., falls, one of your cities may be next.


Development Changes Urged for West Side
LEAD: To preserve the character of the Upper West Side of Manhattan, a special planning committee recommended yesterday that builders of luxury towers be required to provide low-income housing and that a zoning device used to create extra-large buildings be curtailed.


Judge Sets Court Date in 2 States' Tax War
LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday gave two states a day in court over a New York tax law that raises the levy on some New Jersey commuters.


N.F.L. Is Looking Ahead As Rozelle Looks Back
LEAD: As Pete Rozelle reflected today on his retirement after 29 years of joy and pain as the commissioner of the National Football League, a six-member team was already taking the initial steps in the arduous task of finding a replacement.


Penn Hires Coach
LEAD: Gary Steele, Penn's defensive coordinator, has been appointed the Quakers' head football coach.
Steele replaces Ed Zubrow, who resigned after three years to work on fighting drug abuse in Philadelphia's public schools.(AP)


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Feb. 1 about the Environmental Protection Agency referred incorrectly to William K. Reilly, the agency's new Administrator.


Rangers Still Hurting
LEAD: Coach Michel Bergeron of the Rangers said yesterday that three injured defensemen, James Patrick, Brian Leetch and Mark Hardy, would all miss the games this weekend against the Flyers and Penguins.
But Bergeron said he was optimistic that they could return next week for a game in Detroit.


Arcature to Chiat/Day
LEAD: Chiat/Day New York yesterday won the account of the Arcature Corporation, a niche marketing concern established earlier this year by two former executives of Backer Spielvogel Bates.
The agency will create a series of ads for consumer brands marketed by Arcature.
Don Zuckert and Larry Light started the firm in January with the reported $500 million they obtained from the merger of Ted Bates Worldwide with Backer &amp; Spielvogel.

LEAD: More and more pop songs seem to issue from faraway impersonal factories, shorn of local references and gleaming with precision.
Yet the more mechanical pop becomes, the more listeners seek music with a regional character and a human scale - singers with a twang, songs that reveal specifics.

South Africa Party Said to Mend Rift
LEAD: The leadership confrontation between President P. W. Botha and the National Party leader, F. W. de Klerk, which has paralyzed South Africa's governing white party, appears to have been resolved.

Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders remained deeply divided today over how much money New York can afford to spend in a year when it is facing its worst financial problems since the mid-1970's.

Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption on Wednesday about an ordinance in Old Saybrook, Conn., prohibiting the sheltering of homeless people at motels, misstated its intent.
Those already housed in motels will not be required to leave, but no new homeless residents will be allowed.


Centaur Ends Pennwalt Bid
LEAD: Centaur Partners ended its $110-a-share hostile takeover bid for the Pennwalt Corporation today.


Where Value Is a Specialty of the House
LEAD: OF all the questions posed to a restaurant critic, the most typical is: ''Can you suggest a really nice place for dinner: good food, a lively ambiance, efficient service, and it shouldn't be too far off in the boondocks?
Oh yes, it has to be inexpensive.''


Banker Fined In Money Plot
LEAD: A former president and chairman of the United Orient Bank in Manhattan was sentenced to probation and fined $25,000 yesterday for masterminding a scheme to launder $18 million.


New System to Deliver TV Spots by Satellite
LEAD: If the growth of the ''unwired network'' has challenged the traditional networks in the race for advertisers, a new satellite delivery system for ads will turn up the heat another notch.
The system beams TV spots from advertising agencies to hundreds of stations around the country, just minutes after a media purchase is made.

Washington Talk; Rescuing the Saving Industry
LEAD:  THE LEGISLATION: PRIME MOVERS  Donald W. Riegle Jr.: Michigan Democrat Chairman, Senate Banking Committee.


Formica Disclosure
LEAD: The Formica Corporation said that an unidentified industrial company wanted to acquire it for about $259 million, $29 million more than a management group was offering, but that the offer was still short of Wall Street's expectations.
The shares of Formica, known for its laminated and other decorative surfaces, fell $1 today, to $21, on the New York Stock Exchange.


Holiday Weekend
LEAD: Today is Good Friday and Sunday is Easter.
Here are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK  Parade: Fifth Avenue will be closed from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. between 44th and 57th Streets on Sunday for the Easter Promenade.
Government offices: Open today.
Post office: Regular delivery.
Banks: Open.


Taiwanese Violinist
LEAD: Nai Yuan Hu, the Taiwanese violinist who won the Queen Elisabeth Competition in Brussels in 1985, is to play Beethoven's Sonata in E flat (Op. 12, No. 3), Faure's Sonata in A (Op. 13) and Ysaye's ''Ballade'' Sonata tomorrow evening at 8 at Alice Tully Hall.
The program also includes shorter works by Kreisler, Dohnanyi and Sarasate.


Phone Rates Cut by F.C.C.
LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission has ordered the nation's local telephone companies to reduce their interstate access charges by $705 million, which will require the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to cut its long-distance rates again.

Can Collection Drive
LEAD: The City of New York Parks and Recreation Department and We Can, New York City's can redemption center for the homeless, are joining to support homeless New Yorkers.
Containers - cans and deposit bottles -will be collected at 72d Street and Central Park West tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.
The profits will be shared by We Can and the Parks Department's Homeless Youth Recreation Program.

LEAD: George Lynn, a composer and the former music director of Westminster Choir College in Princeton, N.J., died of heart failure on March 16 at Penrose Hospital in Colorado Springs, Colo.
He was 73 years old.

LEAD: THREE interconnected riddles are worrying business and the markets: How serious is the inflationary threat?
How high will interest rates go?
And will rising interest rates produce a recession before the year is over or early next year?

LEAD: A 14-year-old Palestinian was shot to death and eight other teen-agers were wounded today in clashes between stone-throwing demonstrators and Israeli soldiers in the occupied territories, Palestinians said.

Group Opposes Accord In Blacks' Suit of G.M.
LEAD: A group representing several hundred salaried black employees at the General Motors Corporation said today that it would file a petition opposing a proposed $3 million settlement of a lawsuit charging G.M. with discrimination.


Private East Berlin Shops
LEAD: More than 40 percent of the stores in East Berlin are privately owned or operated, but the shops account for only 9 percent of the city's retail trade volume, the official East German press agency said today.
The city's 1,731 private shops and hundreds of itinerant traders sold goods worth 1.1 billion marks ($590 million) in 1987, up from 876 million marks ($470 million) in 1980.


Importer to Be President Of Glenmore Distilleries
LEAD: The Glenmore Distilleries Company has named Frank D. Casciari, head of a champagne company in New York City, to be president and chief operating officer.


20.17 Drop Puts Dow At 2,243.04
LEAD: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday in pre-holiday trading, reflecting weakness in transportation issues and some program trading.

Trailing him were Greg Norman, Tim Simpson, Bill Sander, Tom Byrum, Pat McGowan and Lee Chill.(AP)  Finney Leads: Allison Finney birdied her first three holes and her final four for a 7-under-par 66 and a two-shot lead over Beth Daniel yesterday after the first round of the $400,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Turquoise Classic in Phoenix.(AP)


Winfield to Have Surgery To Repair Ruptured Disk
LEAD: Dave Winfield, the Yankees' injured right fielder, is scheduled to undergo surgery for a herniated disk as early as Friday morning, his attorney, Jeff Klein, said today.


Koch and 3 Rivals Spar in the Same Ring
LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch and three Democratic challengers offered considerably different views of New York City's problems and their proposed solutions last night at a meeting of Queens Democratic leaders.
The leaders will play a critical role in the Sept. 12 mayoral primary.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 461 money market mutual funds increased by $2.8 billion, to $299.4 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 139 institutional funds increased by $449.1 million, to $72.97 billion.
The assets of the 228 general-purpose funds were up by $1.3 billion, to $97.42 billion.


Black in Taped Scuffle Wins Dismissal of Case
LEAD: At the prosecutors' request, a municipal judge has dismissed a charge of resisting arrest against a black man who says he was roughed up by a white police officer in a confrontation that was secretly recorded on videotape.


On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof
LEAD: When he was growing up, there was little to set Robert Golub apart from the other children of Horton Road, a tiny, friendly street tucked in a corner of this Nassau County village.
He haunted the usual haunts with his high school friends; his passion was lifting weights at the gym on Merrick Road.


Islanders Survive a Close One; End Streak
LEAD: The game was a tenuous one, with the Islanders, a team unaccustomed to grooming, much less sitting upon, small leads, in possession of a 2-1 advantage heading into the third period.
At tenuous times of late, the Islanders were the club used to getting close and then getting beaten by tiny margins: they knew they had to handle this lead gingerly, but not so cautiously as to relinquish it.


General Cinema
LEAD: The General Cinema Corporation completed the sale of its soft-drink bottling unit to Pepsico Inc. for $1.78 billion, producing a pretax gain of $1.4 billion.
The sale of the largest independent Pepsi-Cola bottler in the United States will be reflected in General Cinema's results for the second quarter, ending about April 30.


New Face: Isaach de Bankole; An Actor's Road Taken To Cameroon Of 'Chocolat'
LEAD: With few words to say in the new French film ''Chocolat,'' Isaach de Bankole manages to express resentment, pride, scorn, amusement, outrage, sexual desire and - primarily - nobility, and to dominate the film all along the way.

24-Hour Trading Is Planned
LEAD: In a major step toward round-the-clock electronic trading of securities, Reuters Holdings P.L.C. and its Instinet subsidiary have joined with the Chicago Board Options Exchange and the Cincinnati Stock Exchange to plan a network for trading options and stocks, they announced today.


U.S. Judges, Held Hostage
LEAD: Chief Justices of the United States are not given either to holding news conferences or crying wolf.
So when William Rehnquist called a news conference last week to plead for a salary increase for Federal judges, it signaled how grave the judicial pay situation had become.


U.S. Eases Restraints On Exports to Soviets
LEAD: Responding to pressures from exporters, the Commerce Department announced action today to reduce controls and simplify licensing procedures for computers and medical equipment bound for the Soviet Union.

LEAD: Norm Stewart, the Missouri basketball coach, shows no sign of any residual tumor or cancer, and can resume coaching next year if his condition continues to improve, his doctor said Wednesday.

Examiner to Get Job of Reviving Eastern Airlines
LEAD: The Federal bankruptcy judge overseeing the Eastern Airlines case has ordered the appointment of a powerful examiner with a broad mandate to end the 20-day-old strike at the airline quickly and get all of Eastern's planes back in the air.


7.8% Inflation in Britain
LEAD: Britain's annual inflation rate jumped to an unexpectedly high 7.8 percent in February, from 7.5 percent in January, largely because of rising mortgage rates, the Government said today.
The higher mortgage rates stem from the Government's drive to push interest rates up to fight the nation's resurgent inflation, which Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has said is her top economic priority.


Dallas Will Not Retry Man in Killing of Officer
LEAD: The Dallas District Attorney's office announced this afternoon that it would not retry Randall Dale Adams for the 1976 murder of a Dallas police officer, saying that it lacked ''sufficient credible evidence'' against him.


Jets Sign Linebacker
LEAD: The Jets, who are seeking help at outside linebacker, yesterday signed Jackie Walker, a new free agent, to bolster that position.
The 6-foot-5-inch, 255-pound Walker was the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' second-round draft choice in 1986 and played three seasons for them.
On Feb. 1, the Bucs left him unprotected, which meant he could sign with any other National Football League team by April 1.


And There Are Decent Wines That Aren't Indecently Priced
LEAD: FINDING the perfect little restaurant can be tough; finding one with the perfect little wine list is even tougher.
Face it: a small restaurant, almost by definition, has to have a relatively short wine list.
A place with 30 tables simply can't afford to tie up capital by buying and holding large stocks of wine: it costs too much, there may not be any place to store it and there probably won't be enough guests to drink it.

LEAD: The Achilles' heel of the Mets, so to speak, is Gary Carter's right knee.
And today, with a week and a half to go to opening day, Carter's knee was swollen.

LEAD: Timothy Meyers, an actor who received a Tony Award nomination for his performance as a tough teen-ager in the 1972 Broadway musical ''Grease,'' died of acquired immune deficiency syndrome on March 14 in Cabrini Hospital.
He was 43 years old.

LEAD: Platinum and silver futures prices fell sharply yesterday as the dollar gained strength, but analysts said the tumble resulted mainly from thin market conditions as traders got an early start on the long Easter weekend.

He was 78 years old.

Tate &amp; Lyle to Buy Stake in Redpath
LEAD: The British sugar refiner Tate &amp; Lyle P.L.C. said it agreed to buy the Canadian Government's 49.9 percent stake in its Redpath Industries Ltd. unit for $240 million.
Tate &amp; Lyle owns the remaining 50.1 percent of the Toronto-based Redpath.
The deal is worth $17.14 a share, the company said.

Review/Art; Public Art at New Federal Building in Queens
LEAD: The first art completed for a Government building in New York City since Richard Serra's ''Tilted Arc'' in 1981 is a far cry from the confrontational steel sculpture that was removed from Federal Plaza in downtown Manhattan last week.
The new works are much smaller and gentler than ''Tilted Arc.''


Donald Appleton, Executive, 94
LEAD: Donald Appleton, a retired senior vice president of the Oxford Paper Company in Manhattan and a former executive of paper companies in New England, died Tuesday at the Beverly Hospital in Massachusetts.
He was 94 years old and lived in Manchester, Mass.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times.
Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

Heavy Shelling Continues in Besieged Beirut
LEAD: Lebanese huddled in bomb shelters today after another day of bombardment reminiscent of the worst days of the 14- year civil war.


West; Seton Hall Surprises Indiana By 78-65
LEAD: Seton Hall nudged its way to one victory from the Final Four with a 78-65 triumph over Indiana tonight in the West Regional semifinals at McNichols Arena.
Let's make that bullied its way there.
Seton Hall used old-fashioned, elbow-to-elbow, sweat-till-you-drop defense that made the Big Ten champions look out of sync.


NOTEBOOK: Horse Racing; Houston Remains A Mystery
LEAD: Houston to date has seemed more like a top-secret weapon than a race horse: rarely glimpsed, highly controversial, and developed under a virtual cloak of darkness.

LEAD: Ida Davidoff Martus, who coordinated a theater program for the New York City public schools, died of heart failure yesterday at St.
Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan.
She was 93 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Forests Are Still Vanishing
LEAD: The Eastern region of the United States once was covered with dense forests.
Westward to about the 95th meridian, beyond the Mississippi River, mighty trees covered the land, save in what are now Illinois and Iowa.

Here Comes the Columbus Dollar, Gold-Color Son of Susan B.; Bring Back $2 Bills
LEAD: To the Editor:


Bronx Zoo Hours
LEAD: The Bronx Zoo's summer hours and rates go into effect today.
Admission is $3.75 for adults, $1.50 for children (admission is on a donation basis Tuesdays through Thursdays).
The elderly and children under 2 years of age are admitted free everyday.
The zoo, on the Bronx River Parkway at Fordham Road, is open 10 A.M.

LEAD: The CBS and ABC networks have dropped an advertisement for an MGM/UA videocassette, saying it generated an avalanche of complaints from viewers.
CBS and ABC dropped the advertisement, for a horror film called ''Child's Play,'' on Wednesday, two days after it first appeared on the air.

To Alaska Station, 'Today' Funnyman Is Funny No More
LEAD: One of Willard Scott's off-the-cuff remarks as weatherman of the ''Today Show'' has led the NBC affiliate in Fairbanks to cancel the morning news program, the most popular in the country.


Keene Resigns L.I. Philharmonic Post
LEAD: Christopher Keene, who formally assumed the general directorship of the New York City Opera on March 15, has resigned as music director of the Long Island Philharmonic, the orchestra announced Wednesday.
He will continue in that post until the end of his current contract, through the 1989-90 season.


Market Holiday
LEAD: Stock, bond and futures markets will be closed today in observance of Good Friday.
Federal Government offices are scheduled to be open, but some banks and local government offices will be closed.


More Wheat for China
LEAD: Private exporters have sold an additional 400,000 metric tons of United States wheat to China at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday.
The sale increased to 8.2 million tons the wheat sold to China for delivery in 1988 or 1989.


Yakima Valley Journal; Farming Without Alar, Suffering With the Rest
LEAD: Harvey Coleman, who farms 29 acres of apple trees on a hillside near here, has never used Alar to make his fruit round and crisp.
But Alar-free fruit received no special consideration when the Government raised alarms last month by declaring that the chemical might pose a cancer risk to children.

Southeast; Oklahoma Is Outmuscled by Virginia
LEAD: Stacey King, Oklahoma's all-America center, was held to 2 points in the first half.
Mookie Blaylock, the shifty point guard, looked like he had just come from a sparring session with a light heavyweight.
His left eye was swollen shut, a red scar traced under it.
The Sooners had survived one close call in the national tournament, but Virginia made it clear that it was not going to happen again.

LEAD: John H. Wallace, a chemical company executive and former director of the James Forrestal Research Center at Princeton University, died Wednesday at his home in Princeton after a long illness.

LEAD: Most people seeking a suburban home are looking either for a single-family house or its condominium equivalent - the town-house unit.
Nevertheless, there has always been a segment more attuned to the urban-style apartment in an elegant building served by a concierge and doorman.


Vegetable Acreage Plans
LEAD: Processors of five important vegetables expect to reach contracts for 1.48 million acres this year, a 10 percent increase from 1988, when production was plagued by drought, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday.
Acreage plans for all five vegetables are up, led by a projected increase of 18 percent for tomatoes.

All players know their parts.
They have much practice.

LEAD: Domestic car sales stayed in the doldrums in mid-March, and analysts said the 6.8 million annual selling rate would not be strong enough to clear bloated inventories.

LEAD: President Ronald Reagan is history, but his smiling visage still greets visitors at many American embassies around the world.


GAF Jury's Position Argued
LEAD: A Government prosecutor asserted yesterday that defense lawyers in the GAF stock manipulation case had acknowledged that most jurors favored a conviction at the time a mistrial was declared on Wednesday.


Fear Is Target in This War on Crime
LEAD: For decades, the police believed that fear of crime, a powerful social and political force capable of shaping the daily lives and voting patterns of millions, was inextricably tied to the facts of crime.
The best way to combat public fears, they reasoned, was simply to fight crime itself.
Now, they're not so sure.

ABORTION PROTEST LEADS TO ARRESTS
LEAD: Two hundred anti-abortion protesters, many waving pictures of aborted fetuses, were arrested today as they blockaded a suburban health clinic.
The demonstration was the first in an Easter season offensive undertaken with the blessing of the head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles.

Nuclear Power Gain Reported But Experts Express Doubts
LEAD: A professor at the University of Utah said yesterday that he and a British colleague had achieved nuclear fusion in a test cell simple enough to be built in a small chemistry laboratory.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Concorde to Visit
LEAD: The French Government, which is giving the Smithsonian Institution a present of a Concorde jetliner when its days aloft have ended, is giving the prize a fly-in next month.
When it arrives April 16, it will carrying some weighty cargo: The Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen and the French Constitution of 1791.


Sudanese Factions Agree to Allow Relief Agencies Into Famine Area
LEAD: The Sudanese Government and the nation's southern rebels have agreed to allow the United Nations and international relief agencies to take more than 100,000 metric tons of food to the south of the country in April to avert famine, United Nations officials said today.

LEAD: The musical ''Peter Pan'' is back: Mary Martin and friends are soaring around the rafters once again and, for two hours beginning at 8 tonight on NBC, all's right with the world.
The magic holds.
The enchantment works, especially if you have a youngster in the vicinity.

California's Air, America's Future
LEAD: For people in the Los Angeles Basin, the best hope for a livable future may lie in recreating a simpler past.
Mowing lawns by hand.
Starting backyard barbecues with paper and sticks.
And above all, driving less in many fewer cars.


Risk Seen in Pain Relief Drugs
LEAD: Drug manufacturers are warning doctors that commonly prescribed arthritis and pain-relieving drugs pose a serious risk of peptic ulcers, intestinal perforations and other gastrointestinal problems, the Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday.


Heavy Drug Use In Middle Class Noted by Ward
LEAD: Middle- and upper-class drug users consume 70 percent of the cocaine used in New York City and the police should go after them just as aggressively as less-affluent crack users, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday.


Shamrock to Tender Its Shares to Polaroid
LEAD: The Polaroid Corporation scored a major victory in its effort to remain independent yesterday as the Delaware Supreme Court refused to halt the company's plans to repurchase 22 percent of its shares.

The Rent's Due, and for Many It's Homelessness Knocking
LEAD: One tenant said she couldn't pay the rent because her husband had walked out.
Another tenant was laid off.
Still another can't get welfare benefits.
One woman said she couldn't cover the rent because she had bought shoes for her children with the rent money; another had bought a color television.
Someone else is chronically ill, or struggling with a death in the family, or addicted to crack.

LEAD: The Con Brio Ensemble called its Tuesday evening program at Weill Recital Hall ''Vienna Retrospective 1888-1910.'' Those 22 years edged toward a time of ferment in the Viennese compositional world, and the changes wrought eventually affected the course of the Western musical tradition.

LEAD: The operator of a Japanese supertanker that collided with an overloaded fishing boat, apparently drowning about 130 Vietnamese refugees, said today that three other ships within sight of the accident in the South China Sea ignored calls to help save the victims.

William Schieffelin 3d, 67, Dies; Headed Wine and Spirit Importer
LEAD: William Jay Schieffelin 3d, the seventh generation of his family to head Schieffelin &amp; Company, the Manhattan wine and spirit importer that was founded in 1794 as a pharmaceutical company, died yesterday at his home in Mount Kisco, N.Y.
He was 67 years old.


Cooper Buys 83.2% Stake in Champion
LEAD: Cooper Industries has acquired 83.2 percent of the Champion Spark Plug Company under a merger agreement.
Cooper, based in Houston, bought the shares for $21 each.
After the merger, the common shares not acquired in the original cash tender offer will be exchanged for $21 each in cash, a Cooper spokeswoman said.

LEAD: Administration officials and Congressional leaders reached tentative agreement today on a bipartisan policy toward Central America, including additional aid for the Nicaraguan guerrillas.


Review/Film; A Cheyenne Mystic Who Transmutes Bitterness
LEAD: The scene-stealing figure in ''Powwow Highway,'' a road movie populated by Cheyenne Indian characters in the vicinity of Lame Deer, Mont., is a sweetly mystical giant named Philbert Bono (Gary Farmer).
Philbert is notable for his tremendous appetite, his unflappably even keel, and his determination to find some kind of spiritual core in contemporary American Indian life.

LEAD: The Waseda Symphony Orchestra, which played its first New York concert Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall, is a 75-year-old ensemble staffed by students at Waseda University in Tokyo.

LEAD: More than $100 million in Federal aid for the New York City Board of Education was withheld last year because the board failed to meet deadlines for developing plans to spend the money, the New York State Department of Education said today.


Parade Tomorrow
LEAD: Fifth Avenue between 44th and 57th Streets will be closed between 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. tomorrow for the Easter Promenade.


British Concern's Unitel Video Stake
LEAD: U.E.I.
P.L.C., a British broadcasting equipment maker, has acquired 47 percent of Unitel Video Inc. and will consider buying the remaining shares of the New York video recording services company.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, U.E.I. said it had acquired its stake in private placements on March 14 for an average price of $14 a share.


Korean Leader Turns to Compromise
LEAD: When President Roh Tae Woo surprised South Korea and his own party this week by canceling a referendum on his first year in office, the country braced for more of the chaos and protests that have marked its uneasy transition to democracy.


Businessland Deal Seen for Next Inc.
LEAD: Next Inc. has agreed to sell its personal computers through Businessland Inc.'s stores, an industry official said.
The move would mark a significant shift in strategy.
Since its inception, Next has said it would sell its sophisticated computers only to students and educational institutions.


Some Legislators Oppose Plan to Aid Contras
LEAD: Some liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans oppose the agreement to help the Nicaraguan rebels that was announced today by President Bush and Congressional leaders.
But leaders of both parties said they expected Congress to approve the plan.


Crumbling English Cathedrals Go Abroad for Aid
LEAD: The medieval cathedrals of England are crumbling, and their custodians are looking with increasing desperation to wealthy private donors in Britain, the United States and elsewhere to save them.

LEAD: Harry Schnell, a retired surveyor whose projects included Lincoln Center and Madison Square Garden, died of pneumonia Tuesday at Parkway Hospital in Forest Hills, Queens.
He was 85 years old and lived in Forest Hills.

LEAD: Americans' personal income shot up 1 percent last month while consumer spending advanced at a more restrained pace, raising the savings rate to its highest level in nearly three years.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency yesterday moved further toward allowing Northeastern states to cut air pollution by imposing stricter standards than the Federal Government does on the formulation of gasoline.

LEAD: The longer the Nets' losing streak gets, the more frustrating it becomes for the organization.

LEAD: Many top executives work so hard running their companies that they neglect their personal finances.
That situation has created a demand for financial planning as an executive perquisite.

LEAD: After more than a decade of political setbacks, Italy's Communist Party has unveiled its latest modern look, hoping that its new emphasis on ecology, feminism and family issues can attract an electorate that no longer seems interested in Marx and the masses.

LEAD: Randy Gordon, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, said yesterday that Bill Cayton had a valid manager's license during 1988 and has one for 1989, refuting assertions by the promoter Don King.

Tiboris has presented concerts in Carnegie Hall and Avery Fisher Hall featuring combined college, adult and high-school choruses.

LEAD: Wally Heider, a recording engineer whose studios were used by big bands and rock musicians in the 1960's and 70's and who recently produced a series of jazz videotapes, died of lung cancer Wednesday at the home of his daughter, Leslie Lee.
He was 66 years old.

LEAD: By taking a fresh look at some old technology, Frank E. Wicks, a mechanical engineer, has designed a gas-powered air-conditioner that he said could cut cooling bills in half.

Ms.
Cruz, a 42-year-old New Yorker who is the mother of three children 9 to 24 years old, says she believes God has chosen her now.

LEAD: As they prepare for their annual planting, farmers in the Sacramento Valley in northern California, the American Rice Bowl, are trying again to see if there is a way to open Japan's tightly sealed rice market.

LEAD: The leaders of this sheikdom on the Persian Gulf have expressed concern at the continued stalemate in Iran-Iraq peace talks, reflecting their fears that hostilities might resume and their worries about the effect on Kuwait's own politics.

Griggs has caught 16 passes in his N.F.L. career.(AP)

LEAD: Dave Winfield, the Yankees' injured right fielder, underwent surgery this morning to remove a herniated disk in his lower back and is expected to remain hospitalized for several days.
Jeff Klein, the player's attorney, said it was not known when Winfield would begin a rehabilitation program or how soon he might expect to return to the team.


Odyssey Of Emigre With Nerve
The memory of Mickey Hargitay is still vivid in Hungary.
To his old friends in Budapest, as well as to people who never knew him at all, Mr.
Hargitay is a living testament to the infinite possibilities of the American Dream.
Having emigrated to the United States at the age of 14, he went on to win the Mr.
Universe title, appear as a professional strong man and supporting actor to Mae West in her nightclub act, marry Jayne Mansfield and become a great movie star.
That's the way he's recalled (with tongue firmly in cheek) by Gyorgy Szomjas's cheerful, cockeyed, Hungarian-American road movie, ''Mr.
Universe.'' The film will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art today at 6:30 P.M. and on Monday at 8:30 P.M. in the New Directors/ New Films Festival.

LEAD: Near the main thoroughfare of this dusty port city, down a narrow alley and off a courtyard for cooking fires, a local entrepreneur sought to impress a visitor with prized samples from the business he runs with his three sons.

LEAD: Americans are so worried about the safety of their drinking water that last year they bought $2 billion worth of bottled water and spent $265 million more for purifying equipment and services.

LEAD: In a case watched closely for an indication of the safety of top-secret workplaces, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration cited the Lockheed Corporation's airplane-building division today for widespread violations of safety and health standards and said it would seek a fine of nearly $1.5 million.

He was 80 years old and lived in New Hyde Park.

LEAD: The Buffalo Bills aren't saying whether they will keep Bruce Smith, their two-time All-Pro defensive end, who has signed an offer sheet with the Denver Broncos for a reported $7.5 million over five years.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it would shut its assembly plant in Linden next week to reduce inventories of Chevrolet Corsica and Beretta cars.
The shutdown will affect about 140 workers.
Ward's Automotive Reports, a weekly trade journal, said that as of Feb. 28 G.M. had a 103-day supply of the Corsica-Beretta cars on hand.

He wreaks anatomically gruesome vengeance on his tattooed tormenters.

Rover and Mittens Offered Chance to Give Gift of Life
LEAD: A hospital here is seeking new breeds of blood donors - dogs and cats - to help set up a blood bank for pets.


NONFICTION
LEAD:  DEAF IN AMERICA: Voices From a Culture.
By Carol Padden and Tom Humphries. (Harvard University, $17.95.) Deafness means a great deal more than simply being unable to hear.
In ''Deaf in America,'' Carol Padden and Tom Humphries - themselves deaf - argue that the deaf have developed a distinct culture that includes sign language, shared experiences and ideas that often set them apart from the hearing world.


BITES OF SPRING
LEAD: Just when we think there will be no relief from the winter doldrums, the first proof of spring pokes its way through the snow and thaw.


POSTINGS: Subsidized Rentals in Warwick; Housing the Elderly
LEAD: A project to house the elderly in Warwick, N.Y., is to be formally opened Friday as the third phase of an ambitious plan to provide tax-subsidized apartments to the growing number of elderly in the Orange County village.
Named the Creekside Apartments, the $4.5 million development is providing 65 one-bedroom apartments to eligible people who are either 62 years of age or older, or 55 and handicapped.


YANKS NARROW FIELD IN SHORTSTOP BERBY
LEAD: When the deal with the Atlanta Braves suddenly collapsed on Friday afternoon, the Yankees essentially opened their shortstop job to two players who have been in camp since the middle of February: Alvaro Espinoza and Randy Velarde.
Hardly household names.
Espinoza and Velarde are neither veterans nor known commodities.

Move to Oust Hunter Shakes Refuge He Runs
LEAD: Dorothy Richards loved beavers.
She loved them so much that they lived in her house, Beaversprite, for 42 years, eating with her at the dining room table when they weren't filing their incisors on the table's legs.
She loved them so much that she left Beaversprite and 735 acres in this Adirondack foothill town for their preservation.

NOTE
LEAD: Because of an editing error, the Federal deficit figures for 1960 and 1969 were improperly charted.
In both years, the Federal Government operated with a budget surplus, and thus the figures for those years, $3 billion and $8.4 billion respectively, should have been charted as negative numbers in the first chart.

Under a Cloud
LEAD: Pete Rose was always considered a sure bet for baseball's Hall of Fame.
Last week, the odds may have changed because of accusations that the Cincinnati Reds manager was linked to gambling activities.
The baseball commissioner's office said an investigation was under way into ''serious allegations'' against Rose, and Sports Illustrated reported that he may have bet on baseball games.


Princeton Corridor
LEAD: To the Editor:


Visits to Valhalla: The Ectasy And the Agony
LEAD: The earliest audiences for Wagner's ''Ring,'' like audiences everywhere and always, fussed over trivia as readily they waxed eloquent over the spectacular experience of the monumental opera cycle.
Nineteenth and early 20th-century reactions to Wagner, the ''Ring,'' and Wagnerian theater, from musicians and laymen, cover a number of genres: the historical, the comical, the gastronomical, the tragical, the metaphysical, the gastronomical-metaphysical and the comical-historical.


Missing From the Classroom
LEAD: AFTER more than 25 years of teaching, I have left toiling in the classroom for the tranquility of a job in the central office.
I never thought I'd do it.


Creating Theatrical Worlds for Dancers to Inhabit
LEAD: Throughout this century, prominent artists have collaborated with choreographers.
Many of their stage designs for dances have been attractive to look at.
But the best of these designs have been more than pretty pictures.
By calling attention to some aspect of a work's choreography, a design can enhance that work's meaning.

The Mystical Enigma That Is Arvo Part
LEAD: When Arvo Part's music was first performed in New York, less than a decade ago, the temptation was to think of the Estonian emigre composer as a Minimalist.
Works like ''Tabula Rasa'' and ''Fratres,'' the first of his scores to gain any currency in this country, were solidly, unequivocally tonal, and they used repetition as a central structural element.

Some Tips on Taxes and Bank Ads
LEAD: Below are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column.
Q.I want to file my tax return, but the company I used to work for still hasn't sent me my W-2 form showing my 1988 wages.
What should I do?
A.You should contact your former employer and request that the document be sent to you, said Frank Keith, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service in Washington.


Review/Opera; First 'Walkure' Of Met Season
LEAD: For anyone who believed in signs and portents, the season's first ''Walkure'' at the Metropolitan Opera had to be a cheerful event.
The performance on Friday evening, first of three in the final weeks leading up to the company's long-awaited presentations of Wagner's complete ''Ring'' in proper sequence, went smoothly enough to suggest that the cycle may be rounding into shape at just the right time.

But either way, don't worry.
You can still keep your department store charge cards and no one will revoke your subscriptions to fashion magazines.
For the most part, the takers appear to be younger women whose figures allow them to wear the shorter lengths without a trace of self-consciousness.

Still the Nevilles, But Reaching Out For a Pop Audience
LEAD: In many ways, the story of the Neville Brothers of New Orleans, who have just released ''Yellow Moon'' (A&amp;M 5240; all three formats), is also the story of the tension in American society between the outsider and mainstream culture.
The Neville Brothers - Art, 51, Charles, 50, Aaron, 48, and Cyril, 41 - are part of New Orleans's most important postwar pop musical dynasty, a family steeped in both the Mardi Gras culture of the city, as well as its pop music-making side, which at best has had an off-and-on-again flirtation with the American music business.

DEFICIT FIGURING DOESN'T ADD UP
LEAD: Curiously, the graphs accompanying Mr.
Morris's essay include some inexplicable anomalies.
In the graphs, the dollar value of the deficit is expressed as a positive number; therefore, the quotient of the deficit divided by the G.N.P. must also be a positive number, because, by definition, the value of the G.N.P.

Home Buying Is an Official Cause Again

When Audience and Cast Combine
LEAD: THE killer, the victim - maybe, even the corpse - could be seated at your table.
During the new Friday night murder-mystery series at the Spinning Wheel Inn, in Redding Ridge, the audience and the cast mingle in what may well be the most informal sampling of environmental or participatory theater yet.


A Bristol Visit Anchored In the Past
LEAD: MY favorite spot in Bristol is the damp, cobbled floor of the Great Western Drydock.
From down there, hemmed in by stone walls fitted almost a century and a half ago, amid mossy puddles, a voluptuous sweep of red-orange hull looms above.
The hull belongs to the Great Britain; launched in 1843, she was the fist iron-hulled, propeller-driven trans-Atlantic liner - in fact, the first such vessel to cross any ocean.

The Aging Eye
LEAD: WHEN MY 4-YEAR-OLD THRUSTS her latest drawing in front of me, I seem to grow older on the spot.
I take my daughter's hand, push it and her picture back away from my nose, stretch my neck backward a couple of inches, and peer.
At the age of 35, I am encountering one sign of age that no amount of exercise or high-fiber foods or Retin-A can forestall.

RESULTS
LEAD:
Rowing  Oxford Defeats Cambridge: Oxford claimed its 13th victory in the last 14 years by overcoming an early clash of oars to defeat a heavier Cambridge crew by two lengths in yesterday's 135th edition of the annual University Boat Race, the first race in which both coxswains were women.
Oxford finished the four and a half miles along the Thames River in 18 minutes 28 seconds, almost 2 minutes slower than the record of 16:45 it set in 1984.

Permanent Lent
LEAD: Easter celebrates resurrection and renewal.
It also marks the end of Lent, 40 weekdays of fasting and special penitence when millions of Christians forsake the sinful pleasures of the palate and the perils of strong drink and nicotine, and give themselves over to abstinence of all kinds.

LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; A 6-Mile Sliver of Sand and History
LEAD: If you hunger for a look at sand and sparkling water now that spring has officially arrived, an hour's ride to Sandy Hook, N.J., will take you to another world.


FICTION
LEAD:  STAR.
By Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The butler admits you to a mansion in San Francisco's Pacific Heights and leads you into a wood-paneled dining room.
You circle an antique table laden with Limoges until you find your name on a place card in a silver holder.
By the light of a crystal chandelier, you sup on smoked salmon and oysters.


Nothing Amiss in Circulating Bush Note
LEAD: To the Editor:


PASTIMES: Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: Use a stiff metal rake over the lawn to finish spring cleanup; add leaves and small debris to compost.
Shake cayenne pepper or dried chili peppers around spring bulbs, especially crocus, chionodoxa and early tulips to discourage feeding by squirrels and other rodents.
Finish pruning fruit trees.


FICTION
LEAD:  THE RISING.
By Edgar White. (Marion Boyars/Kampmann, $18.95.) ''West Indians,'' we are told in this first novel of a projected trilogy, ''never say no.'' Instead they slide around the negative with suggestion and innuendo, but God help those who misread the signals.
Mother Frances rules the society of a small Caribbean island, manipulating her way unscathed through the prevailing hurricanes of sex and (usually) psychic violence.


CARIBBEAN REVENGE
LEAD:  THE BAMBOO CANNON  By Donald McCaig.  233 pp.
New York:  Crown Publishers. $18.95.


Anne Fannon, Banker, to Wed in April
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs.
Marcy B. Fannon of Bronxville, N.Y., and Saunderstown, R.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Anne Linwood Fannon to John Lockman Appleby 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
William C. Appleby of Atlanta.
An April wedding is planned.


Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Car
LEAD: CABBIES HONK APPROVINGLY.
Pedestrians applaud.
Diners gather at restaurant windows.
Around New York, Eric Staller's ''Lightmobile'' (right) is a little bit famous.
Ever since its maiden voyage in 1985, the Volkswagen beetle with its ebullient adornments - 1,659 light bulbs, computer-controlled and capable of flashing in 25 different patterns - has effervesced regularly all over town, wreaking a pleasant sort of havoc wherever it goes.


Keep Profit Motive Out of High School Sports
LEAD: Earlier this month a national cable network announced a five-year contract with the National Federation of State High School Associations - composed of the 51 state high school athletic/activity associations in the United States - to televise a weekly package of high school sporting events, mostly basketball and football games.

Helen Hadley to Marry P. L. Johnstone in April
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs.
John W. B. Hadley of Huntington, L.I., have announced plans for an April 15 wedding for their daughter, Helen Morris Hadley, and Peter LeGrand Johnstone, a son of Robert and the Rev.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  LORD NELSON: The Immortal Memory.
By David Howarth and Stephen Howarth. (Viking, $24.95.) A danger in retelling the life of a national hero is that the subject's virtues often are inflated and his shortcomings diminished.
Thus, in ''Lord Nelson,'' an unguardedly affectionate biography of Britain's most notable mythologized naval hero, conspicuous character deficits - cynicism, vanity, decadence, infantilism and cruelty - are largely dismissed, defended or recast as attributes.


PASTIMES: Chess
LEAD: The late great Estonian Paul Keres used to say: ''I like to play opposite from my opponent.
If he wants a positional game, I will strive to make it tactical; if he wants a tactical struggle, I will strive to make it positional.''


Why Seek The Sound Of the Past?
LEAD: The early-music movement, once the domain of antiquarian scholars and minimally skilled dilettantes, has been gathering professional momentum for decades.
It is now a small steamroller, if not a juggernaut.
The movement has spawned a new generation of well-trained musicians who play their instruments well and proselytize for correct performance practices with evangelical zeal.


CONNECTICUT GUIDE
LEAD:  THE COMPLETE 'PEER GYNT'  The Hartford Stage Company will perform the uncut ''Peer Gynt,'' Henrik Ibsen's fantasy based on the Norse legend of a young man's wanderings through universal perils and pleasures.
Because of its length, the piece is usually performed in truncated versions.


PASTIMES: Numismatics
LEAD: In the western territories of the United States around 1850 gold abounded but gold coins were rare.
To stem the growing shortage for coins, private mints began making their own coins and these are the ones called territorial gold coins.
Of these private mintings one of the strangest might be those of the Mormons' Deseret Mint of Salt Lake City, Utah.


No Free Lunch
LEAD: To the Editor: Reading Ron Nowicki's article ''Yes, There Is No Free Lunch'' (Travel, Jan. 29) brought back memories of a similar experience my late wife and I had in October 1969, except that it took place in Rome.
We were among the thousands in the crowd in St.
Peter's Square after the Pope's Sunday noon balcony appearance and blessing.


Power Panaceas Are a Delusion
LEAD: John Hurley's letter  [ ''Shoreham: The Hydro Option,'' March 5 ]  illustrates the anti-nuke delusion as no Lilco advocate could.
He suggests hydro power or natural gas as Shoreham alternatives.
Natural gas is not new.
Hydro power is not new.
It is the prime mover that launched the Industrial Revolution.

James A. Van Allen of Iowa City and Southampton, L.I.
A May wedding is planned.


New York, Hanging in the Balance
LEAD: New York City has come to an extraordinary moment in its history, one filled with opportunity and hope, a chance to right wrongs and address old failings.
Its hand forced by a Supreme Court decision, America's most tumultuous city must now reinvent itself.

A.
ELIZABETH EICHMAN Rosemont, Pa.

LEAD: A United Airlines jumbo jet bound for San Francisco with 357 people aboard returned to Manila today after a piece of one wing peeled off over the Pacific Ocean.

LEAD: After the Friday noon service, hundreds of worshipers streamed out of the Sultan Selim Camii mosque, and to a man they dropped worn paper money onto a bright red rug that served as a collection plate.

I Musici Cancellation
LEAD: The Italian ensemble I Musici has canceled its April 23d Carnegie Hall concert because of a schedule conflict.
The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra will play instead, at 3 P.M.
The program will include works by Corelli, Dvorak, Schoenberg and Bartok.
I Musici tickets will be honored.
Additional tickets, at $18 and $14, are available at the box office.

LEAD: The United States has asked the Afghan rebel government in exile to curb the soaring production of opium poppies in areas of Afghanistan that its guerrillas control, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: All but one of 25 decorative art objects brazenly stolen during visiting hours from six museums this year have been recovered, and two Brooklyn men have been arrested, Federal authorities said yesterday.

He walks with the aid of a stick, stands erect and moves along at a respectable gait.

'We're Basically Writing a Constitution,' Says Charter Panel Chairman
LEAD: New York City, which has one of the nation's most peculiar forms of government, might be headed for a system with new elements that are common elsewhere.
These could include a larger legislature or one with two houses, a voting method that gives small groups a bigger voice and management procedures aimed at avoiding last-minute decisions.

Magna Cum Laude Isn't Everything
LEAD: In criticizing Charles Schnabolk's ''Cheers for the Lower Half'' (Opinion page, Jan. 8) Robert Wechsler's letter to the New Jersey editor on Feb. 12 confuses the point of the article.
He should have read it one more time; it was, indeed, a parody of our obsession with grades and did not, as Mr.
Wechsler suggests, downgrade intellectual achievement.

Wobbly Chair Woes
LEAD: WOBBLY chairs are annoying and, if allowed to worsen, can lead to accidents.
Most wobbles are caused by broken glue joints, due either to deterioration of old glue or to excess strain placed on chair parts.


Louis Malle's World of Innocence
LEAD: There are moments in the best Louis Malle films when it is possible to believe in innocence, in an Edenic world of childhood goodness that is soon shattered in some understated, irrevocable way.
AU REVOIR LES ENFANTS, now available on video (Orion Home Video, $79.98), is Mr.
Malle's magnificently subtle and profoundly moving account of a Jewish boy hidden in a Catholic school in France during World War II.

Time to Be Frivolous With Artichokes
LEAD: IN spring when artichokes are abundant and prices are reasonable the cook can be frivolous with them.
Instead of serving them whole, to be savored leaf by succulent leaf, try using just the tender, fleshy bottom (or heart), discarding the rest.

THE WORLD: The Soviet Vote; A Guide to the Election Process
LEAD: Soviet voters go to the polls today to elect a Congress of People's Deputies, which is to be the supreme state body in a redesigned Soviet Government.
For the first time in seven decades, most voters will have the opportunity to choose among competing candidates.
But even some architects of the new system concede it falls short of full democracy.

LEAD: IN scenes reminiscent of science-fiction movies in which the world's peoples band together to face a common threat from outer space, delegates from around the globe have come together in the last month to confront the dangers posed by planetary warming and the depletion of the earth's protective ozone shield.

Paths of Glory, Giant Steps of Prudence
LEAD: ''The paths of glory lead but to the grave,'' that memorable phrase from a poet of yesterday, Thomas Gray, whose words have never died, came close to leading me to a premature breakdown at the age of 10.
As I sat in the crowded third-grade classroom, listening to the poetry being read aloud, I raised my hand it interrupt the gentle teacher who was determined to bring literature into our young lives and asked for an explanation of the short phrase.

LEAD: EVEN in the best of times, anxiety and confusion are the hallmarks of shopping for mortgage money.

Correction
LEAD: An article March 23 about the Chicago mayoral campaign incorrectly described a public opinion poll commissioned by WLS-TV as the most recent.
The most up-to-date polling figures were not from the WLS poll but from a telephone survey of 821 registered voters conducted March 16 through 18 for WBBM-TV.


Why Business Turns to Teen-Agers
LEAD: In the last few years, as America's jobless rate plummeted to the lowest levels since the mid-1970's, ''Hiring'' signs have proliferated at fast-food restaurants, department stores, supermarkets and countless other businesses.
Increasingly, those jobs are going to people like Margie Lobaton in Warwick, R.I., and Patrick Gannaway in Huntington Beach, Calif.

LEAD: The Legislature has refused to call a referendum on dropping ''North'' and renaming this state Dakota, deciding North Dakota will be just as cold by any other name.

LEAD: If ever there was an irreplaceable exhibition, it is the one now signaled all over Amsterdam with banners and stickers and inscriptions in Cyrillic letters on the sides of bright yellow trams. ''Kasimir Malevich'' is the message, and ''The Stedelijk Museum'' is the place.

LEAD: Few best-selling bands seem so schizophrenic as the Bangles.

PASTIMES: Bridge
LEAD: The Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League, which ended a week ago in Reno, Nev. were the biggest ever, with a table count of 13,807 eclipsing a record set 21 years earlier in New York City.
They were also slightly longer than usual, since the entry of 107 teams in the Vanderbilt Knockout made it necessary to play the final on Monday, when the other contestants had departed.


Correction
LEAD: The Personal Finance column last week misidentified the type of ''frozen'' Keogh retirement plans that must be amended by May 31.
A Keogh plan is frozen when it no longer accepts contributions.
Individuals who hold frozen ''defined-contribution'' Keogh plans - those to which they had contributed a fixed percentage of annual income - do not have to amend their plans.

LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
LEAD:  Dog Training 101  ''THIS is going to be a comic piece, right?'' said Stephanie Reyer of Great Neck, holding her dog Sasha in a vice grip as dogs in various stages of terror and excitement entered the auditorium of Great Neck's Cumberland Elementary School.
Sasha, a large German shepherd-husky-mix, was going into a barking frenzy every time a new dog came in.


Trip Insurance
LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding Gilbert Weiner's experience with trip insurance (Letters, Jan. 15), he should have had a travel agent calculate the amount of insurance necessary to cover the actual costs incurred for changing his return; adequate coverage includes the cost of penalties for cruise, tour and hotel cancellations plus airline ticket penalties or the purchase of a new return ticket.


Wagner's 'Ring': Stagecraft As Ideology
LEAD: Grand and crabby, beautiful and ugly, rhapsodic and boring, primordially mythic and progressive in ways we don't yet fully understand, Richard Wagner's four-opera, 16-hour cycle ''Der Ring des Nibelungen'' still counts as the greatest challenge - for singers, conductors, stage directors, designers, critics and audiences alike - in the standard operatic canon.

The Struggle for Land in Latin America
LEAD: IN 1985, President Jose Sarney of Brazil argued for a new land-redistribution plan, saying that ''no modern country has developed without first dealing with its agrarian problem.'' But this month, in a stark illustration of what happened to that idea, the police fired at random as they evicted some 500 landless families who had taken over a private farm to protest the Government's broken promises.


THE ARTIST, SOARING AT LAST

CHILDREN'S BOOKS/POETRY: Bookshelf
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:


Question Of the Week; How Good A Job Has Ueberroth Done?
LEAD: Ueberroth has done an excellent job.
When he became commissioner, 21 of the 26 major league teams were nonprofitable.
Since then, clubs are making a combined $100 million this year.
He made lucrative contracts with CBS-TV, ESPN and CBS for radio rights.
And best of all, he's sharing the major leagues' wealth by proposing a ticket-price freeze.


When the Job is Done, the Play's the Thing
LEAD: The world would be poorer if a shop owner could not don a flounced purple dress once in a while to portray a tuba player in a marimba band, or if a genial teacher could not become - for a few performances, anyway - the horrible Mr.
Hyde.


When the Ballpark Cost Just a Nickel
LEAD: RECENTLY the sports pages, radio and television announced three-year contracts for Orel Hersheiser at $7.9 million, Roger Clemens at $7.5 million and Dwight Gooden at a mere $6.7 million.
Not quite in the same league as Henry Kravis, the leveraged buyout king, or Mike Milliken, the indicted junk-bond potentate but still pretty good for throwing the ball in a kids' game.

LEAD: Just off the coast of South Carolina, about midway between the old mansions of Charleston and the new condos of Myrtle Beach, is an island kingdom ruled by animals.

CLASH AT DARTMOUTH
LEAD: As a Dartmouth alumnus, I keep hoping that an observer will come up with commentary that will bring participants to their senses.
Alas, John Casey's piece (''At Dartmouth, the Clash of '89,'' Feb. 26) falls short.
Most alumni, I suspect, would agree that there is precious little to like about The Dartmouth Review.

Joseph Romer, Executive, 76
LEAD: Joseph Romer, a former account executive in the advertising department of The New York Times, died Thursday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan from complications after suffering a stroke.
He was 76 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.


Trekking With the Kids in Nepal
LEAD: IT was late in the afternoon of our hardest day of trekking in Nepal, a day in which we dropped from the frosty ridge of Tharepati at 11,800 feet to a suspension bridge over the Malemchi Khola nearly 4,000 feet lower.
The views were spectacular, the people we met on the trail were friendly, and the thick evergreen and bamboo forest around us was rich with new discoveries.

A Crowded Race for Mayor In Jersey City
LEAD: ST.
PATRICK'S DAY has passed, and the Governor's mansion is up for grabs this year.
People in Jersey City know that this means a mayoral campaign is brewing in the state's second largest city.
The campaign may be one of the liveliest in years.


It's Expensive, but the Benefits Are Clear
LEAD: In 1987, Los Angeles's smog plan was rejected by a Federal Appeals Court in response to a lawsuit I filed.
That plan failed to meet Clear Air Act requirements.
A follow-up lawsuit by the Coalition for Clean Air and the Sierra Club resulted in another court order.
Under continued legal pressure, the new Los Angeles smog plan was developed.


Young Inventors Solve Life's Problems
LEAD: WHAT does one do ''when you are growing and your clothes get bigger and you need a larger hanger?'' A New Rochelle fifth grader, Justin Friedman-Hurvitz, asked himself this question and the answer was the ''Everlasting Hanger,'' a simple aluminum affair with three screws that expands, and expands and expands.

LEAD: A drunken driver traveling west in an eastbound lane of the Long Island Expressway smashed into three cars Friday night, killing a Manhattan woman and critically injuring her daughter-in-law, the Suffolk County police said today.
Four other people - including the driver, Willis Vaughan, 52 years old, of Westbury, L.I.

Resisting The Temptations of Wall Street
LEAD: I JUST had my first real job interview, and it was with a brokerage.
I was not very serious about getting the position, but there was an open slot in the all-campus interviews schedule, so I took it.
It would be a good interviewing experience, I thought.
I quickly ate my lunch and hurried upstairs to change into my suit, while words like ''dress for success'' and ''corporate image'' went through my mind.

LEAD: President Bush intends to nominate William Howard Taft 4th, the former Deputy Defense Secretary, to be Ambassador to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the White House said Friday.


Against Apartheid
LEAD: To the Editor:


Outside In
LEAD: Garden elements have been a recurring theme in the decorative arts for centuries, but it is only recently that materials and objects meant for use outdoors are finding their way inside.
Terra-cotta vases and wire tables, stone benches and twig furniture - pieces that traditionally adorned patios or porches or gardens - are becoming as integral a part of interior schemes as the living-room sofa.


The Easter Egg as a Vocation and as Art
LEAD: IN many homes today, eggs are pastel and they nest in baskets lined with cellophane grass.
Easter eggs are also the subject of an exhibition at a New Milford art gallery this month.
And for a a Norfolk woman, they are a career.


Anglican Archbishop to Visit Pope in Fall for Unity Talks
LEAD: The Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev.
Robert Runcie, leader of the 70 million-member Anglican Communion, will visit Pope John Paul II in Rome this year for talks aimed at increasing unity between their two churches.


Fears Confine Abortion Pill To France
LEAD: THE revolutionary new abortion pill, RU 486, is increasingly popular in France, and is considered by the medical profession to be a far better means of abortion than surgical procedures.
But given pressures from anti-abortion groups, among other obstacles, it could take years before the pill becomes available in other countries.

The official is Wendy Gramm, chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, and not only is she in the hot seat, so is her agency.

TALKING: Jumbo Loans; Shopping Around for Good Deals
LEAD: AS the prices of homes have soared - particularly in areas like the Northeast and West Coast - so have the needs for buyers to seek jumbo, or ''nonconforming,'' mortgage loans.
These are loans that exceed $187,600, the limit for individual dwelling set by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac, the Government-chartered corporations that regularly buy home loans from lenders.


'Heathers': Light Look at a Dark Topic
LEAD: His classmates at Riley High School in South Bend, Ind., voted Daniel Waters ''most unforgettable'' eight years ago.
Some of them may come to rue the irony of that vote when ''Heathers,'' a dark new satire written by Mr.
Waters that transforms teen-age suicide into blackest farce, opens Friday.


WHAT'S DOING IN: Beijing
LEAD: As it sheds the chilly sandstorms and its wintry pall of coal dust, Beijing seems to go through a metamorphosis: the trees and grass in the parks and the bustling activity at temples and monuments and marketplaces light up the place the way color brightens up a drab black and white picture.

Or will any gun do, just for the sense of it, there in the bureau at night, powerful enough to stop the worst nightmare?

My husband and I loved them.
We had the perfect ploy.
After playing along and enjoying the dinner, we listened ''excitedly'' to the banter and, in fact, even reached out as if to sign the contract.

LEAD:  MORE LIKE US  Making America Great Again.
By James Fallows.  245 pp.
Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company.


A Short Skyscraper With a Tall Assignment
LEAD: ''The tallest building in Bridgeport'' sounds like a punch line.
And at just 16 stories, Bridgeport Center, the new headquarters complex of People's Bank here, is so small that it would barely muster notice in most other cities.
There is a reason, however, that this toy-sized skyscraper merits attention: it marks the high-rise debut of Richard Meier, the New York- and Los Angeles-based architect whose career so far has been limited to museums, houses, institutional buildings and low-rise corporate structures.


Little Speakers With Big Voices
LEAD: With many music lovers, among others, chronically short of cash, space or both, there has been a steady demand for cheap, small loudspeakers.
In the past, most such speakers sounded thin and tinny; some still do.

Review/Film Festival; Iranian Director's Mournful Trilogy
LEAD: Though its production company is the Arts Bureau of the Organization for the Propagation of Islamic Thought, the Iranian film ''The Peddler'' is in no way a work of propaganda.
In fact, it takes for granted a devastating, almost unbearably high level of misery.
Though it aims at times for an incongruously rueful, almost whimsical tone, its overall impression is one of unadulterated suffering.

Parrots, Dragons And the Uses of Enchantment
LEAD: ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' and ''Long Ago &amp; Far Away'' have something in common: Both are wonderful and yet each leaves you feeling a bit sad, the stage production because it's a reminder of the sort of great musicals that aren't being made anymore, the television series because its unmistakable quality makes you keenly aware once again of the generally woeful state of programming for children in this country.

Some Slight Signs Of a Cooling
LEAD: The statistics shifted enough last week to offset anxieties of inflation thatwere stoked the previous week by a report that wholesale prices had surged by 1 percent in February.
This week's report on February's Consumer Price Index showed a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent - less than most analysts had predicted and lower than January's increase of six-tenths of 1 percent.

'Glory' Resurrects Its Black Heroes
LEAD: The Matthew Broderick who stood silently before 200 black soldiers and one Panavision camera was certainly no teen-age Eugene Morris Jerome.
This was a mustachioed, portly, somber-looking Matthew Broderick, dressed in the midnight blue coat and crimson sash of a Union Army colonel.
And as he began to speak his lines, he seemed very much older than his 26 years.

One witness said he had been alone at the scene but stopped short of confessing to the killing.

Riot in Indian State Assembly
LEAD: A brawl broke out in a south Indian state legislature today, with opposition and ruling party members trading punches and throwing files, desks and microphones, Indian news agencies reported.
The leader of the opposition, Jayalalitha Jayaram, once a leading lady in Indian films, fled the Tamil Nadu state assembly in tears after being hit by a stack of files.

Au Naturel
LEAD: Don't be fooled by the natural look.
It is a product of pure artifice - foundation that is so well blended as to be imperceptible, blusher swirled artfully on the cheeks, lipstick blotted down to become a mere stain, brown eyeshadow deftly powdering the eyelids and a little trail of eyelining pencil.

Recycling Law's Mechanics: Symphony of Sorting, Maybe
LEAD: With New York City facing a garbage crisis, the City Council is expected to approve a bill tomorrow that would make the recycling of newspapers, magazines, cardboard, glass bottles and metal cans mandatory.
Under the bill, each household would be required to sort the recyclable materials.
The bill raises questions as to how a city as large as New York will coordinate and enforce such a law.

An out-of-town family gets there early and finds a choice location behind a police barrier.
The children sit neatly on the curb.

Fifteen or twenty minutes pass before one of the adults shyly approaches a vendor and asks, ''So where's the parade?

LEAD: Just four days before his election, George Bush promised that he would continue to protect the steel industry against imports.
The political motive was clear: He was worried about Rust Belt votes.
But the economics were faulty.
America's steel industry is healthy again.
The Reagan Administration's ''temporary'' import curbs ought to go.

LEAD: SPRING is the time when skiers attempt to navigate snow that turns into a peculiar wet, sticky mush on warm days.
It requires a technique different from that used on packed snow.
It is similar to powder skiing, but there is a slow finesse required in slush, and the deeper it gets, the more finesse is required.

Nobody knows that better than book dealers.

Find May Be Oldest Evidence of Humans in U.S.
LEAD: A DISCOVERY of broken stone tools, charcoal and bison bones in Oklahoma may be evidence of the earliest known presence of humans in North America, archeologists reported last week.
Analysis of the charcoal and some snails found in the same sediments has yielded dates going back 26,000 to 40,000 years.

Avondale Navy Contract
LEAD: The Navy has awarded Avondale Industries a $319 million contract to build three T-AO fleet oilers, the shipyard announced today.
The announcement brought to 16 the number of contracts for the oil-replenishment ships awarded to Avondale since 1982, with the total value of the contracts amounting to $1.9 billion, said Albert L.


Motorola Sets Stage For Battle With Intel
LEAD: Motorola Inc. today announced key features of its next-generation microprocessor, the 68040, opening a new round in its battle with the Intel Corporation, which is set to introduce its newest chip on April 10.


At Least 5 More Killed By Shelling in Lebanon
LEAD: Muslim and Christian forces continued their fierce artillery battles in and around Beirut today, with at least five more people reported killed.


Neighbors Ask What Lured L.I. Teen-Ager to Her Death
LEAD: Shocked and saddened, residents of the Strathmore neighborhood here were asking one question over and over today: Why did 14-year-old Jessica Manners leave her house late Saturday?

Captain Has History of Drinking and Driving
LEAD: Joseph J. Hazelwood, the captain of the ship that has been spilling oil since it ran aground off Alaska last Friday, has been convicted of charges involving drinking and driving twice in the past five years, a period in which his driver's license was suspended or revoked three times.


'When I Don't Know.. I Will Tell You'
LEAD: Margaret D. Tutwiler, formerly Assistant Treasury Secretary for Public Affairs (when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was Secretary of Treasury Baker), is now Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs and the State Department spokesman.
Ms.
Tutwiler, the first woman to hold that post, made her debut at the State Department's daily briefing today, opening with a prepared statement.

LEAD: In the early 1930's, the great Luisa Tetrazzini - a star of the operatic stage in pre-World War I days -came back to New York to sing in variety at the Plaza Theater, three times an evening, ''between smiling crooners, animal acts, conjurors and acrobats,'' as the opera historian Michael Scott tells it.
