Home Resales Drop Again
LEAD: Sales of existing homes fell 3.1 percent in February, the second straight monthly decline, as buyers put off purchases because of higher mortgage interest rates, a real estate trade group reported today.


Review/Music; Chicago Youth Orchestra
LEAD: The Chicago Youth Symphony Orchestra is an ensemble of the best orchestral players from high schools in Illinois, Wisconsin, Indiana and Iowa.
The group rehearses weekly, and has sectional coaching sessions with members of the Chicago Symphony.
On Sunday afternoon, the orchestra performed in Carnegie Hall, as part of the Mid-America


Architecture Rejuvenates Main Streets
LEAD: Here, as in many small towns, it is no longer a matter of survival: after 20 years of doing battle with malls, Highland Park's main street, Raritan Avenue, has proved it can stand up to the air-conditioned competition.


Greenspan Willing to Wait For Years for 'Zero' Inflation
LEAD: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told the Senate today that while he desired ''approximately zero'' inflation in the economy, he could wait ''several years'' to get there.

Review/Television; Two Shows on Teen-Agers in Trouble
LEAD: Permissiveness on the wane?
Some of the signals on television shows being produced for younger audiences are unmistakable.
Two unusually strong examples are available this week: ''15 and Getting Straight,'' a CBS ''Schoolbreak Special'' at 4 this afternoon, and ''The Cheats,'' an ''Afterschool Special'' at 4 P.M.


M.I.T. Economist to Be Bush Adviser
LEAD: President Bush will nominate Richard Schmalensee, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, to the President's Council of Economic Advisers, the White House said yesterday.

T.W.A. Order To Airbus Is Expected
LEAD: Trans World Airlines Inc. is expected to announce today that it has ordered more than $3 billion worth of wide-body jetliners from Airbus Industrie in a major move to upgrade its aging fleet, industry officials said yesterday.


General Nutrition
LEAD: General Nutrition Inc. said it had hired investment bankers to explore ways to maximize shareholder value, including the possible sale of the company or a recapitalization.
The company said Lazard Freres &amp; Company and C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc. would review financial alternatives.
General Nutrition's shares jumped $1.25 today, to $9.


Our Towns; Abuse Goes On, But Caseworkers Often Cannot
LEAD: After six years on the job, Roger Burchell is practically the Methuselah of Westchester County child-abuse caseworkers.


Texas Instruments
LEAD: Texas Instruments Inc. said its joint venture with the Raytheon Company will begin shipments this month of high-speed anti-radiation missiles that contain gallium arsenide microwave monolithic integrated circuits, or Mimic.
It said it was the first production use of Mimic chips.
Texas Instruments said the venture manufactures the missiles for a joint United States Navy and Air Force program.

LEAD: NOT long ago, someone asked Sid Bernstein, who for six decades has served, led and pontificated at Advertising Age magazine, about his longevity.
Mr.
Bernstein replied with a story about his father, who at the age of 85 ordered his tailor in Chicago to make him a suit.
When he returned several weeks later to pick it up, the elder Mr.


3 Borough Leaders Seek Strategy to Save Board
LEAD: Three of New York City's five borough presidents, the future of their offices deeply in doubt, held a private meeting yesterday to try to forge a strategy to preserve the powerful Board of Estimate on which they sit.


American Express Ads Strike Back at Visa
LEAD: For several years, Visa International has encouraged viewers to bring their card to major events like the Olympic Games ''because they don't take American Express.'' In a new print advertising campaign, American Express seems to be returning the favor.
Modeled on its print campaign featuring celebrity card holders, the new magazine ads depict several of the nation's finest restaurants - all of which accept only the American Express card.


Beijing Calls for a 'New Pattern' In Its Relations With Washington
LEAD: China's Foreign Minister called today for ''a new pattern'' in Chinese-American relations, characterized by mutual trust and apparently by a lack of American criticism of Beijing's human rights record.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: An Entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day on Tuesday about the United Asset Management Corporation described the company incorrectly.
It is an investment management concern that serves mostly institutional clients.


A Cabinet Mnemonic for Wall Streeters
LEAD: To the Editor:


White House Rebukes Counsel on Pact
LEAD: The White House today rebuked President Bush's legal counsel, C. Boyden Gray, for challenging the Administration's agreement with Congress on Central America as diminishing the President's powers.


New Northwest Flights
LEAD: Northwest Airlines said today that it would begin nonstop service linking Boston and Los Angeles on May 1.
The airline, a unit of NWA Inc., said it would also increase the number of daily round-trip flights between Boston and Washington to four, from one.


Talking Business with Shea of Worldwatch Institute; Cleaning Up On Cleaning Up
LEAD: The environment and the economy are inextricably linked, says the Worldwatch Institute, a research organization based in Washington.
The institute's 12-member staff regularly publishes reports exploring that connection, covering subjects like the global warming trend, the hole in the ozone layer, ocean pollution and soil erosion.


Has the Gun Lobby Become One of the Unexpected Casualties of the President's War Against Drugs?
LEAD: The worst accusation that can be leveled against anyone here is to be called naive.
Score one point, then, for naivete.
For what else fits the view that a Republican President who belongs to the National Rifle Association would be willing to take on the gun lobby?

American Express Title
LEAD: The American Express Company said yesterday that its board had named James D. Robinson 3d, chairman and chief executive, to the additional position of president, succeeding Louis V. Gerstner Jr.
Mr.
Gerstner left American Express this month to become chief executive of RJR Nabisco Inc., which is now owned by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts &amp; Company.


Rig Count Up in Week
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs jumped last week by 26, to 766, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
A year ago, the total was 935.
The rig count is a widely watched industry index of drilling activity and reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.


Merger in Plant Research
LEAD: Calgene Inc., a leading company in agricultural biotechnology, said today that it planned to acquire its rival, Plant Genetics Inc., in a stock transaction.


Fan's Prize: Bon Jovi's Jersey Roots
LEAD: When Jon Bongiovi was a tyke, 3 or 4 years old, growing up in a pleasant subdivision here, his mother, Carol, used to dress him up ''like a little doll,'' as she put it, for little performances.

Cell Growth Factors Emerge as Potent Therapies
LEAD: EXPERIMENTAL drugs made of rare growth-promoting substances are producing dramatic benefits for some seriously ill patients.


Riches of Jazz History Just Keep Growing
LEAD: It was between sets at the 1959 Newport Jazz Festival that Gunther Schuller conceived the idea of writing his exhaustive, analytical history of jazz, the second volume of which has just been published.
At the time, he was a 32-year-old French horn player in the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and had composed a handful of orchestral and chamber works in the complex atonal idiom that remains his style.

LEAD: JCB International, the largest provider of bank-related credit cards in Japan, is about to take a major step toward allowing its cards to be accepted by American merchants.


New York Files Suit To Recoup Foster Aid
LEAD: New York State today sued the Federal Government to recover $156 million in child welfare payments that state officials said had been improperly withheld over the last decade.

LEAD: Grain and soybean futures prices fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday amid forecasts for April showers in the nation's major crop-growing areas.

LEAD: Taiwan today announced a sweeping set of revisions aimed at liberalizing its foreign exchange market and reducing the role of its central bank in determining the value of the Taiwan dollar.

LEAD:  Flies and Mosquitoes  Q. Where do flies and mosquitoes go in the winter?
And where do the large flies that show up in the house with the first warm days come from?
A.
Many adult flies die off with the arrival of cold weather, but others live through the winter, said Louis N. Sorkin, an entomologist at the American Museum of Natural


Keep the Justice Windows Open
LEAD: The trial of Joel Steinberg, convicted of killing the 6-year-old he and Hedda Nussbaum, his companion, had taken into their home, awakened America to the problem of child abuse.
In the process, it also awakened New Yorkers to the benefits of cameras in the courtroom.


Review/Recital; Violinist Offers Beethoven
LEAD: Nai Yuan Hu, the Taiwanese violinist who won the Queen Elisabeth competition of Belgium four years ago, was presented in recital Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall by the Chinese-American Arts Council.
It was a respectable showing by a musician whose technique is more than well in hand and whose feeling for the shape of a musical phrase or of a piece is generally sound.


By Design; A Shakeup on Shoulders
LEAD: As this year's fall collections are being shown, it is clear that shoulders are headed for a shakeup.
Silhouettes are becoming less hard-edged, with shoulders narrowing in breadth and softening in shape.
Shoulder pads are being chipped away.


'Cafe Crown' Closes
LEAD: ''Cafe Crown,'' the revival of Hy Kraft's 1942 comedy, closed after the Sunday matinee at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street.
The play, which was directed by Martin Charnin, ran for 45 regular performances on Broadway.

Trade-Gap Warning
LEAD: Failure to reduce the large United States trade deficit could cause a collapse in foreign confidence in the dollar, which would send interest rates soaring and tip the economy into recession, a group of international economists said today.


Reviews/Film Festival; From Iceland, 2 Brothers With a Grudge
LEAD: Barren and endless as the Icelandic landscape appears, it is made to seem frighteningly claustrophobic in ''Foxtrot,'' a tightly knit thriller about two brothers on a cross-country journey. ''Foxtrot'' follows a handsome, well-known soccer star named Kiddy (Valdimar Flygenring) and his quiet, Tommy (Steinarr Olafsson) as they embark on what is meant to be a business trip, driving a delivery of cash from one city to another.


Muscovites Taste Polling
LEAD: Even as Soviet voters were pondering their first relatively free ballot alternatives in seven decades, Western reporters waited impatiently just outside the doors of polling places to introduce them to their very first election day poll, however informal.

Baker, Outlining World View, Assesses Plan for Soviet Bloc
LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that the Bush Administration was cautiously considering a proposal to seek discussions with Moscow on a new political arrangement for Eastern Europe.


Jury to Get Wells Fargo Robbery Case
LEAD: After three years of hearings and six months of testimony, the Wells Fargo robbery trial of five suspected members of a Puerto Rican terrorist group is finally nearing an end.

Oil-Output Rise Asked
LEAD: Kuwait's oil minister, Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, was quoted today as saying that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries should raise its oil output ceiling by at least 8 percent, to 20 million barrels a day, in the second half of 1989.
He told the Nicosia-based Middle East Economic Survey that ''in the second half, we ought to be talking of an increase of at least 1.5 million barrels per day.


Court Backs Fed Bank Rule
LEAD: The Supreme Court today let stand a Federal Reserve Board requirement that bank holding companies with more than $150 million in assets submit annual financial statements certified by an independent public accountant.


A Matador at 2d Base? Ole for Mets' Jefferies
LEAD: ''It's like a bullfight,'' Davey Johnson said, depicting the fine but highly perilous art of turning the double play. ''The second baseman is the matador.
His left leg is the red flag.
You plant it on the bag, and the runner comes sliding in straight for it.
He's the bull.'' It is one week to opening day, and the manager of the Mets is nearing the end of his six-week seminar on how to play second base without getting gored.


Prosecutor Told To Stick to Facts In Police Killing
LEAD: The judge in the trial of three men charged with murdering a New York City police officer in Queens admonished a prosecutor yesterday, telling him to stick to ''the evidence alone'' and not ''appeal to the jury to convict the defendant to protect the community.''


S.E.C. Move in Check Case
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it planned administrative action against Mark L. Stahl, a convicted former Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. executive, that could bar him from the industry.

Needed Fast at Continental: Profits
LEAD: Of the many brickbats that the striking employees at Eastern Airlines have thrown at Frank Lorenzo, one most frequently heard is that he is a corporate raider interested in a fast buck who knows nothing about running an airline.


4-Year-Old Boy Killed In Clash in West Bank
LEAD: A 4-year-old Palestinian boy was shot to death in the West Bank today during a clash between demonstrators and the Israeli police, Arabs and the army said.


Air Force and Union Agree on Furnishing Civilian Child Care
LEAD: The military is offering child care to the 83,000 American civilian employees of the Air Force Logistics Command, ending a decade of bargaining between the command and a Federal employees' union.

Curfew Ordered After 3 Die in Yugoslav Riots
LEAD: Yugoslavia ordered a curfew in the southern province of Kosovo today after two policemen and a demonstrator were shot dead in the fifth day of violence by ethnic Albanians protesting moves to curb their autonomy.


New York Will Ban New Pit Bulls After Oct. 1 and Restrict Others
LEAD: No new pit bull terriers would be allowed in New York City after Oct. 1 under strict rules adopted yesterday by the city's Board of Health.


Davis Cup Team
LEAD: John McEnroe, Andre Agassi, Ken Flach and Robert Seguso were named yesterday to compete for the United States in a quarterfinal Davis Cup match against France April 7-9 in San Diego.(AP)


L.I. Minister Sentenced to Jail
LEAD: The Rev.
Eugene Profeta, the preacher Jessica Hahn said she turned to for solace after her sexual encounter with Jim Bakker, the deposed P.T.L. organization leader, was sentenced today to six months in jail and five years' probation on witness tampering and tax charges.
Under a plea-bargain agreement, the Long Island minister was also ordered to pay about $26,000 in back taxes, interest and fines.


Bomb Explodes in Pakistan Near British Cultural Center
LEAD: A bomb exploded near a British cultural center early today, hours after Foreign Secretary Sir Geoffrey Howe of Britain arrived to discuss the controversy over the novel ''The Satanic Verses.''


Nicaragua: A Bipartisan Advance
LEAD: President Bush and Congressional Democrats have amicably agreed on a formula for resolving the once rancorous issue of aid to the Nicaraguan contras.
That was possible chiefly because Mr.
Bush has altered President Reagan's stubborn course.
He explicitly promises to couple military pressure with serious pursuit of diplomacy.


Seagram Purchase
LEAD: Joseph E. Seagram &amp; Sons Inc., the United States subsidiary of the Seagram Company, said it had acquired the American Natural Beverage Corporation, makers of Soho Natural Sodas.
Terms of the cash transaction were not disclosed.
The president of Soho Natural Sodas, Sophia Collier, who founded the company in 1977, will serve as consultant and spokesman for Soho Natural Sodas.


In Mexico, a Bold New President Is Surprising Both Friends and Enemies
LEAD: Splashed across the front page of virtually every newspaper in the Mexican capital recently were pictures of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari shaking hands with one of his most bitter adversaries, Manuel Clouthier, who as candidate of the National Action Party in the presidential election last year campaigned under banners calling Mr.


Bridge
LEAD: The most unusual bridge event of the year, and perhaps of any year, will begin Saturday.
It is the Marathon Trans-Atlantic Bridge Battle of the Sexes, and play will be non-stop, 24 hours a day for two weeks.
One table, with men sitting North-South and women East-West, will be at the Cavendish Club at 105 East 73d Street in Manhattan.


Mr. Reilly's Message on Two Forks
LEAD: William K. Reilly, the new head of the Environ-mental Protection Agency, sends three important messages with his unexpected decision to review the $1 billion Two Forks Dam project in Colorado: He intends to run his own agency.
He takes at face value President Bush's announced concerns for the environment.


Review/Dance; A Mix of Steps Between God and the Devil
LEAD: It is possible to look at Demetrius A. Klein's ''Garden/Alone,'' performed by Mr.
Klein and his company on Friday at the Mulberry Street Theater, in a number of ways.
At its deepest level, the piece suggests life lived by ordinary mortals as a steadily continuing measured contest of allegiances to God and to the devil.

On Horse Racing; Amid a Dull Outing, an Exciting Breakaway
LEAD: Parimutuelly speaking, the result of the eighth race at Aqueduct last Saturday was as dull as they come.
The heavy favorite won in a romp and he paid a measly $3 to win.
But for anyone who looks at and likes horses, or has any interest in the Kentucky Derby 40 days hence, it was the most electrifying moment of this racing season.

LEAD: To look at the best-seller lists in England, France and West Germany, one might think there was no such thing as a European Common Market, in books at least.

LEAD: When the Giants failed to protect Jim Burt, a favorite of the fans, in the National Football League's new free-agency system, he became available to the 27 other teams.

LEAD: The dollar rose sharply yesterday, reaching its highest level against the yen and mark since last year.
It also moved very close to the level considered the Group of Seven's ceiling against the mark.

LEAD: A 10-year-old boy died yesterday shortly after divers pulled him unconscious from the East River, the police said.

NBC Wins Ratings Race
LEAD: NBC narrowly won its 40th consecutive prime-time ratings race last week, tying a television-industry record set by CBS in the 1962-63 season.
NBC had an average rating of 14.9, with 25 percent of the viewing audience, according to the A. C. Nielsen Company.
Each rating point represents 904,000 homes with televisions.


Soviets to Put a Japanese in Space
LEAD: A Japanese television network said today that it had signed a contract with the Soviet Union to send a reporter to the Mir space station, the first journalist to report from space.

LEAD: George M. Hart, a lawyer and a former three-term Republican County chairman on Staten Island, died of pancreatic cancer March 20 at the University of California Hospital at San Diego.
He was 57 years old and lived on Staten Island.

LEAD: In New York City's largest demonstration over AIDS to date, about 3,000 chanting marchers, demanding more government funds and services, ringed City Hall Park yesterday and briefly blocked the Brooklyn Bridge, Broadway and other streets.

LEAD: Proposals to let parents choose their children's public schools have become embroiled in ideological controversy: in theory, choice is supposed to be a pillar of democracy; in practice, letting parents choose their childrens' school is opposed by many who consider it an assault on equality, an invitation to elitism.


Topics of The Times; Fido Calling, and Calling
LEAD: Imagine the house dog or cat marooned on a doorstep, its plaintive bark, meow or scratch drowned out by passing traffic or its owner's TV set.
Imagine rain making the scene all the more pathetic.
Or imagine the same dog or cat desperate to get out and thus avoid a spanking for sullying the rug yet again.

Emhart to Provide Data to Topper
LEAD: The Emhart Corporation has agreed to give Topper L.P. confidential financial information that the New York-based investment group has requested.
Topper has sought the data to help in deciding whether to raise its offer of $35 a share, or $2.4 billion, in the face of a bid of $40 a share by the Black &amp; Decker Corporation.

LEAD: Jim Fifield has been appointed chief executive of EMI Music Worldwide, effective Saturday.
Mr.
Fifield, currently president and chief operating officer, will continue as president.
In his new position, he will be responsible for EMI Music's operations in 37 countries.
Those include record companies, manufacturing plants, recording studios and music publishers.

Seagram to Sell Rights to 17 Brands
LEAD: Joseph E. Seagram &amp; Sons Inc. said it would divest itself of trademark or sales and marketing rights to 17 brands of distilled spirits in the United States.
Seagram, the American unit of the Seagram Company of Canada, said Heaven Hill Distilleries Inc., based in Bardstown, Ky., would acquire Harwood Canadian Whisky, Wilson Blend, Paul Jones Blend, Mattingly &amp; Moore Bourbon, Henry McKenna Bourbon and Vandermint Liquor.


Review/Music; Student Chamber Players Offer Six Modern Works
LEAD: The Stony Brook Contemporary Chamber Players, a remarkably well-trained student ensemble, offered finely polished renderings of six new works at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday evening.
The ensemble's directors are Raymond DesRoches and Gilbert Kalish, both of whom have long histories of involvement in contemporary music.

LEAD: Palestinian guerrillas set off an explosion today at an Israeli post in southern Lebanon, and two other guerrillas were captured inside the buffer zone that Israel maintains north of its border.

Fast Growth in Malaysia
LEAD: Malaysia's economy grew 8.1 percent in 1988, the most in nine years, but the Government is worried about rising inflation and unemployment, the nation's central bank said today.
The gross domestic product is expected to grow 7.3 percent more this year.

LEAD: The National Transportation Safety board, ending its investigation of a school bus accident in which 27 people died, recommended today that more than a fifth of the nation's school buses be retired as unsafe.

Sony Mae Issue Of $90 Million
LEAD: The State of New York Mortgage Agency, which provides low-interest-rate financing for first-time home buyers, priced a $90 million reoffering of mortgage revenue bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns &amp; Company.


Public-Private Venture Aims to Improve Child Health Care
LEAD: Pediatricians are being asked to contribute up to $100 each and their best ideas to a new national partnership to give children greater access to health care and reduce the country's high rate of infant mortality.


Joel Fineman, 42, Shakespearean Scholar
LEAD: Joel Fineman, a professor of English at the University of California here who was a Shakespearean scholar, died of colon cancer Saturday at his home in Berkeley.
He was 42 years old.


Ex-Official Indicted in Japan Bribery Case
LEAD: A former Japanese deputy minister was charged and another was arrested today, both accused of taking bribes in postwar Japan's biggest political scandal, news reports said.


Intel in Pact With I.B.M.
LEAD: The Intel Corporation said today that it had reached an agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation to develop circuit-board products that will bring Intel's Digital Video Interactive technology to the I.B.M.
Personal System/2 computers.


Rule Change to Add 500 Beds to jails Is Rejected
LEAD: A request by the New York City Correction Commissioner for permission to make room for 500 more beds was turned down yesterday when the City Board of Correction said the city's overcrowded jails cannot squeeze in any more prisoners.

Displays of books, photos and other memorabilia will be at these celebrations of the tradition of oral poetry.

60-MINUTE GORUMET
LEAD: SOFT-SHELL crabs are a delightful harbinger of spring around my house.
They are in season in the Northeast from now through mid-May, the period in which blue crabs shed their hard carapaces, puff up as they enter a period of fast growth and begin forming new shells.
Frozen, cleaned soft-shell crabs are available year-round, but


Missile Shield Must Be Balanced Against Other Goals, Cheney Says
LEAD: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that the Reagan Administration ''oversold'' the effectiveness of its proposal for a shield against missile attack and cautioned that the plan should be balanced against other strategic needs.


Upshaw Recital Canceled
LEAD: A recital by the soprano Dawn Upshaw scheduled for Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall has been canceled because James Levine, who was to have accompanied her, is suffering from a pinched nerve.
Refunds are available at the box office.
Information: 362-1911.

Books for Cooks and Stove-Top Travelers
LEAD: THIS is the time of year when gardeners dream once more of earth and seeds and growing things.
Cooks who are lucky enough to have a little space for gardening, even if the ''garden'' consists of nothing but a few herb plants on a sunny city windowsill, will find a number of useful books among recent publications.

LEAD: In expressing his admiration for ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' Max Beerbohm wrote: ''What differentiates this farce from any other, and makes it funnier than any other, is the humorous contrast between its style and matter.

Corrections
LEAD: A news analysis article in the Word and Image pages on March 21 about the writer Janet Malcolm and her recent essays in The New Yorker on reportorial ethics referred imprecisely to her position in a lawsuit against her.
The suit alleged that she libeled Jeffrey Masson in a profile of him in The New Yorker, later published as a book.

Anthony Riolo, 46, An Arts Administrator
LEAD: Anthony Riolo, an administrator for several arts organizations including the Joffrey Ballet and the New York City Ballet, died of complications from AIDS yesterday at the University of New Mexico Hospital in Albuquerque.
He was 46 years old.
Mr.
Riolo, who was also a lawyer, was the executive director of the Santa Fe Opera at the time of his death.

Corrections
LEAD: A caption in Science Times yesterday, with a chart about safety worries in food, described the potential dangers of shellfish incorrectly.


AIR FORCE GROUNDS B-1'S AFTER A WING PUNCTURES A TANK
LEAD: The Air Force grounded the entire fleet of B-1 bombers after the movable wing on one of the $280 million aircraft swung too far forward in a preflight check and punctured a fuel tank, the Pentagon said today.

After Rumors, NWA Cites Buyout Approach
LEAD: After more than a month of persistent takeover rumors, NWA Inc., the owner of Northwest Airlines, said yesterday that a shareholder group with 4.9 percent of its stock had approached the company about a possible buyout.


Cousin Sought For Questioning In L.I. Slayings
LEAD: A cousin of a woman who was found slain along with her two sons in their house here late Monday is being sought for questioning in the murders, the Suffolk County police said today.

Unorthodox Path to a Language Teaches Schoolchildren to Live It
LEAD: In her unorthodox kindergarten, 6-year-old Brooklyn Schwartz spends one day learning in English, one day in Spanish, one day in English, alternating languages in this manner throughout the year.


Getting Serious About Smog at Last
LEAD: It is the not-so-secret shame of us here in so-called lotus land that we have befouled our air almost beyond breathability.
In the hotter months particularly, our seaside paradise sits under a thick ceiling of polluted sky.
Our geography - the fact that we sit in a basin - coupled with our car lust has given Los Angeles the worst air of any city in the country; 199 days out of the year we exceed air pollution standards set by the Environmental Protection Agency.


Melville E. Stone 2d, Bookseller, 84
LEAD: Melville E. Stone 2d, the former owner and managing director of the Sporting Gallery and Bookshop, died of throat cancer Saturday at his home in York Harbor, Me.
He was 84 years old.


Oscars! Ludwigs! Shad Roe!
LEAD: It's prize time all over America.
Tonight the Oscars.
Tomorrow the Pulitzers.
Next week the Windermeres.
Or is it the Ludwigs?
At this time of year they come so thick and fast it's hard to keep them sorted out.


A Growing Harvest Of Organic Produce
LEAD: ORGANIC agriculture, espoused by those who went back to nature in the 60's, is on the verge of changing from a movement to an industry.
In ever-increasing numbers and at ever-increasing speed, growers, distributors, retailers, governments, agricultural scientists and economists are responding to consumer concerns about food safety by exploring organic agriculture.

Arsenal of Lasers vs. an Angry, Oily Sea
LEAD: In a fight against time and an angry sea, experts from the Exxon Corporation have brought high-powered lasers and a battery of other pollution-fighting devices to bear against the catastrophic oil spill in Alaska's Prince William Sound.


State Dept. Challenged On Trade
LEAD: Prodded by the aerospace and electronics industries, the Commerce Department is challenging the State Department's exclusive authority over exports of commercial technology that has military applications.


Ernest B. Gorin, Executive, 77
LEAD: Ernest Bartley Gorin, a retired vice president of the RCA Corporation, died of congestive heart failure Sunday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital.
He was 77 years old and lived in Riverside, Conn.


Review/Piano; Filling In for a Recitalist
LEAD: David Bar-Illan's scheduled piano recital at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night was frustrated by an injury to his hand.
He was replaced on short notice by the young pianist Alexander Peskanov.


U.S. Tells Milken's Lawyers That He'll Be Indicted Today
LEAD: The Government has informed lawyers for Michael R. Milken, the head of the ''junk bond'' unit of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., that Mr.
Milken will be indicted today on charges of racketeering, securities fraud, mail fraud and other illegal activities, people involved in the case said last night.

LEAD: Blue-chip stocks rose moderately yesterday for the second consecutive day, joined this time by strength in the broader market.


2 Papers Seek Joint Operation
LEAD: The Justice Department said today that the two daily newspapers in York, Pa., The Daily Record and The Dispatch, had filed an application for a joint operating agreement.


Panel Rejects Zoning Shift For Developer
LEAD: New York City refused yesterday to change its zoning to suit an Upper East Side apartment tower that was built 12 stories too tall, making it possible that the developers will have to tear down those floors.

LEAD: At first glance, the growing debate over how the nation's school children should learn mathematics seems far removed from Steven Epstein's seventh-grade class here at the May V. Carrigan Middle School, a low, large building at the end of a cul-de-sac.

LEAD: The makers of Parliament Lights are hoping to sell cigarettes by appealing to smokers' ears as well as their palates.

The unusual promotion was created by Alex Aliksanyan, the brand manager for Parliament at the Philip Morris


Holly Farms Board Supports Conagra
LEAD: The Holly Farms Corporation said its board had unanimously reaffirmed its recommendation that stockholders approve its merger agreement with Conagra Inc.
The board also reaffirmed its rejection of an amended offer from Tyson Foods Inc. of $63.50 a share and its recommendation that stockholders not tender their shares under the offer, the company said.


NASA Is Urged to Focus on Cutting Shuttle's Risks
LEAD: A safety panel yesterday told the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to consider scrapping its plan to produce an advanced solid-fuel rocket booster for the space shuttle in the 1990's.
The panel said NASA should focus more immediately on reducing current risks in the winged spaceship and its boosters.

Extending the Life Of a Bottle of Beer
LEAD: The Aquanautics Corporation of Alameda, Calif., has spent several years developing an artificial gill, based on a novel technology for extracting oxygen from water.
That product remains in the development stage, but the technology may reach the market in a more common medium - beer bottle caps - where its properties could extend the shelf life of beer by reducing oxygen-related spoilage.

Soviet Insurgent Basks in Victory's Glow
LEAD: Arkady N. Murashev was the one candidate in the Soviet elections willing to come out plainly for a multiparty democracy, and he has survived atop a landslide to tell about it.


Rent-A-Wreck Names A New Chief Executive
LEAD: Rent-A-Wreck of America Inc., which became well known as a specialty renter of used cars, has a new president and chief executive, J. Richard Haigh.


OPEC Wants Its Prices To Stay Under a $20 Top
LEAD: Demand for oil produced by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has pushed prices up by 50 percent since November.
Now Saudi Arabia and a majority of other OPEC members are determined to hold the prices below a ceiling of $20 a barrel.


A Martyr to the Drug War
LEAD: The Miami police did not permit Lee Arthur Lawrence's murder last week.
But they did little to prevent it.
As a result, Miami's citizens are a bit more cynical about law enforcement.
And drug dealers are feeling a bit more confident.


Real Estate; Recycling: A New Issue For Builders
LEAD: MOST people think of waste recycling as an environmental issue, but it is also becoming a real estate issue affecting builders, developers and operators of office and commercial properties.


Bush Sends Team to Assess Cleanup
LEAD: President Bush, facing criticism over how his Administration is responding to the worst oil spill in North American waters, sent a delegation of high-ranking officials to Prince William Sound off Alaska today to inspect the damage.


BRIEFS
LEAD:  Debt  *
Colorado Housing and Finance Authority is tentatively offering $28.8 million of tax-exempt single-family program senior bonds with a top yield of 8.25 percent through Goldman, Sachs.
Yields for shorter maturities range from 7.20 percent in 1991 to 7.60 percent in 1999 and for longer maturities from 7.90 percent in 2009 to 8 percent in 2017, all subject to the alternative minimum tax for certain investors.


Gossage Is Given Release by Cubs
LEAD: Rich (Goose) Gossage, only 39 saves short of baseball's career leader, was released yesterday by the Chicago Cubs.
Gossage, a 16-year veteran who had a 4-4 record with 13 saves in 1988, said his release was not his farewell to baseball.

Court Rules America's Cup Is New Zealand's by Forfeit
LEAD: A New York State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the San Diego Yacht Club had beaten its challenger unfairly last September and must forfeit the America's Cup, yachting's oldest and most prestigious trophy, to New Zealand.


Israel Astir Over Press Imposters
LEAD: Israel's Police Commissioner today ordered the police and security agents in the West Bank and Gaza Strip to stop putting signs in their cars identifying them as journalists.
The order came five days after the plainclothes police in the West Bank created a furor by using signs that said press in their cars while patrolling and making arrests.

Darling and Aguilera Displaying Top Form
LEAD: Six days from the start of the season, Davey Johnson sat on the Mets' bench today and thought, ouch: Gary Carter's swollen right knee; Howard Johnson's weak right shoulder; Keith Hernandez's inflamed left elbow; trade jitters sweeping the camp; cutdown blues wracking the rookies.


EDUCATION: LESSONS
LEAD: One of the most famous - and certainly most literate - curriculum debates that ever took place occurred in the early 1880's between Matthew Arnold, the poet and educator, and Thomas Huxley, the biologist.
The issue in both England and this country was whether college curriculums, which at the time focused entirely on classical literature, should be expanded to embrace the natural sciences.


Reviews/Music; Folk-Rock From Israel
LEAD: In Israel, as in the United States, folk-rock goes with protest songs.
For Ehud Banai and the Refugees, who opened a two-night stand at Dance Theater Workshop on Monday, folk-rock means a combination of local ingredients - modal melodies, jar drums, lead guitar played like a Middle Eastern oud (lute) and lyrics in Hebrew - with arranging ideas imported from Bob Dylan, the Police and other American and European rockers.


Tax Curb on Raiders Proposed in Albany
LEAD: New York State companies would be less vulnerable to hostile takeovers under a proposal in the state's Senate that would deny certain tax benefits to corporate raiders.


Soviet Chess Star, 14, Is Said to Request Asylum
LEAD: The Soviet Union's leading young chess player and his father requested political asylum in the United States yesterday, said Lev Alburt, a former United States chess champion who defected from the Soviet Union in 1981.


Crude Oil Drops Below $20; Gold, Silver and Platinum Off
LEAD: Prices of crude oil slid below the $20 level yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid short selling and profit taking.
Much of the selling was prompted by the belief that the energy market might have overreacted a day earlier to news of the Alaskan oil spill.

Wardrobes Tailored By Social Concerns
LEAD: BARBARA RODMAN stopped wearing her full-length mink coat last winter.
The animal-rights advocates had finally gotten to her, and soon she began to feel good about her new-found social consciousness.
Then she was maligned by an animal lover for sporting a coat, pants and boots in black leather.
After all, where did she think leather came from, she was asked.

LEAD: As expected, Trans World Airlines Inc. said it planned to modernize its fleet by buying up to 40 jetliners from Airbus Industrie, the four-nation European consortium, for more than $3.6 billion.
T.W.A.'s chairman, Carl C. Icahn, said the airline would place firm orders for 20 A330 twin-engine planes and take options on an additional 20 of the wide-body aircraft.

Medical Schools Getting More Applicants

British Bank to Cut Jobs in Revamping
LEAD: Midland Bank P.L.C., Britain's third-largest commercial bank, said it would cut 2,000 jobs in a reorganization of its domestic operations.
The reductions, totaling about 5 percent of the bank's total work force, will be through attrition, a spokesman, Kyle Fraser, said.
About 4,000 employees are expected to leave the bank in 1989 because of usual turnover, and only 2,000 will be replaced, he said.

New Threat: Poison-Tipped Missiles
LEAD: An intensive arms race is under way in the Middle East to obtain a ''poor man's atom bomb'' - a ballistic missile armed with a chemical warhead.
As the Iran-Iraq War demonstrated, there is a willingness to use these terrible weapons on civilian populations.
Thus, the prospect of the Qaddafis and Khomeinis of the world acquiring - and using -long-range missiles with a chemical capability is real.

From Soviet Voters, a Call for Change
LEAD: The big winner in Sunday's extraordinary Soviet elections could well turn out to be Mikhail Gorbachev.
Voters sent a devastating message of rejection to the old guard in the Communist Party he leads.
But they also lent powerful impetus to Mr.
Gorbachev's campaign for renewal.


Chip Maker to Shut Connecticut Plant
LEAD: The National Semiconductor Corporation, striving to cut its losses, said it will close a chip-making plant in Danbury, Conn., next February.
The company said the closing was intended to reduce its excess manufacturing capacity, ''particularly in older products and processes.'' The plant, which employs about 400 people, makes transistors and other microelectronic products.


Robert Cushman Hunt, Psychiatrist, 84
LEAD: Dr.
Robert Cushman Hunt, a psychiatrist and former assistant commissioner of the New York State Department of Mental Hygiene, died Monday at Coral Reef Hospital in Miami.
He was 84 years old and lived in Miami.
Dr.
Hunt was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania Medical School.
He headed New York State hospitals in Rochester and Ogdensburg before becoming assistant commissioner in 1952.

The Albanians have been protesting legislative changes that will curb the autonomy of the predominantly Albanian region.

LEAD: The Arab League re-elected Chedli Klibi of Tunisia today to a third five-year term as its Secretary General.

British Aerospace
LEAD: British Aerospace P.L.C. said it had won the first American order for its advanced turboprop airliner in a deal with Air Wisconsin Inc. worth $200 million.
The deal is for 14 ATP aircraft, with options on six more.
Three planes are to be delivered in the fourth quarter of this year, while six will follow in 1990 and the rest in 1991.

Charles Armijo, head of the Police Department's homicide unit.
The five, described by a neighbor as in their 20's and 30's, were killed ''within the last day,'' Sergeant Armijo said.

LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation is offering a total of $2.77 billion in debt securities with three-month, six-month and one-year maturities.
Priced at par, the securities are being sold through various securities dealers and dealer banks in book-entry form only, which means the ownership of the securities is recorded electronically and no paper bond is issued.

Since then both beds creak when you turn over in bed.

HEALTH: PERSONAL HEALTH
LEAD: For tens of thousands of Americans afflicted with inflammatory muscle diseases, simple tasks may be overwhelmingly difficult or fatiguing.
Even before they know what is wrong, they may have difficulty raising an arm, climbing stairs, getting up from a chair or even raising the head from a pillow.
Prolonged standing or walking can exhaust them, and even swallowing and breathing may be impaired.

LEAD: As law-enforcement authorities in New York City exert more pressure on drug sales, they are discovering an increasing number of dealers operating out of restaurants, grocery stores, automobile parts shops and other seemingly legitimate businesses.

LEAD: SINCE the middle of winter, most of my gardening friends in many parts of the East have been worrying about another year of drought ahead - really just a continuation of the one last year, with enough rain in the interim to foster the illusion that we were back to normal.

Reactor to Be Restarted
LEAD: A research reactor at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee, shut down in November 1986, can be restarted, the Energy Department announced Tuesday.
It had been found to be suffering from embrittlement of the reactor pressure vessel.
Since then, more than 20 studies of the reactor have been undertaken to determine its safety.


Poles Meet on Reform Plan
LEAD: Lech Walesa and other Solidarity leaders met Poland's Interior Minister today to try to remove the last obstacles to a deal on economic, political and social reforms. ''We want to resolve unsolved issues,'' Mr.
Walesa told reporters, but he declined to give details.
The Government has agreed in seven weeks of talks to legalize Solidarity after a seven-year ban, create a state president and a democratically elected senate, and liberalize parliamentary elections.

LEAD: A Nevada-Las Vegas basketball player said he accepted $20 from his summer league coach to pay for lunch, unaware that the man was a convicted East Coast gambler.

LEAD: Of all Scandinavian craft works, those by Danish artisans are the most easily identifiable, the most precise, the most symmetrical, the most likely to exploit geometric design, the quietest in color and generally the most subtle.

LEAD: Barbara Bush disclosed today that she had lost 18 pounds in the last three months as a result of a recently diagnosed thyroid condition.
Mrs.
Bush said she began taking ''very simple medication'' for it two days ago.

Depressed Parents Put Children At a Greater Risk of Depression
LEAD: The first careful observations of normal encounters between seriously depressed parents and their children are leading researchers to conclude that the parents may treat their children in a way that will make them more susceptible to depression themselves as they grow up.


Fond Memories of Draper
LEAD: To The Home Section:


From Budget to Land Use: The Powers of the Board of Estimate
LEAD: Any restructuring of New York City's government will begin with the Board of Estimate, because the United States Supreme Court has ruled that its voting system is unconstitutional and because the board is at the center of civic life.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; WPP to Buy Millward
LEAD: WPP Group P.L.C. continued on the acquisition path yesterday, signing an agreement to buy Millward Brown, a British-based marketing research company.
The marketing communications conglomerate will pay Millward's stockholders $3.56 a share in a deal that values the company at $25.1 million.
The deal could be worth as much as $50.6 million if shareholders opt for a alternate payment plan based on the firm's profitability in the next five years.


Loss of House Seat Dims G.O.P. Hopes
LEAD: After all the buoyant talk in recent days about gaining a majority in the House of Representatives, Republicans awoke today to a painful embarrassment: the loss of a seat in Indiana that the party had held for 12 years, a seat once held by Vice President Dan Quayle.


Review/Jazz; The New Orleans in Wynton Marsalis
LEAD: Wynton Marsalis is coming to terms with his hometown, New Orleans.
The style he honed through the 1980's hails primarily from such New York City bands as Miles Davis's groups from the late 1950's through the mid-1960's, Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers and to a lesser extent the John Coltrane quartet.

2 Juries Convict All 3 Defendants In Queens Murder of Officer Byrne
LEAD: Three drug dealers were convicted last night of murdering a New York City police officer in an execution-style slaying in Queens that led to major new drives against narcotics traffickers across the city.

Richard H. Ellis, 69; Was SAC Commander
LEAD: Richard H. Ellis, a retired Air Force general who served as commander in chief of the Strategic Air Command, died of cancer Tuesday at Malcolm Grove Medical Center.
He was 69 years old and lived in McLean, Va.

LEAD: Does the Exxon tanker spill show that Arctic oil shipping is being mismanaged?
Should the industry have been better prepared to cope with the accident?
Should the spill deflect President Bush from his plan to open more of Alaska to oil exploration?


'Junk Bond' Revolution Will Outlive Its Creator
LEAD: With his indictment on securities fraud charges, Michael R. Milken will no longer dictate the fate of companies from the helm of his ''junk bond'' empire in Beverly Hills, Calif., and he will have to leave Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the securities firm he helped build into a Wall Street powerhouse.


Metro Datelines; Salmonella Outbreak Is Linked to a Death
LEAD: An elderly woman died and three other residents of a nursing home here were hospitalized during an outbreak of salmonella poisoning earlier this month, the state Public Health Department said today.

An L.A. Bungalow: Heavy Metal
LEAD: ''THIS is not the Aaron Spelling residence,'' said Sheila Klein as she described the window grates of her house, which appear to have been designed by drunken spiders.
Unlike the television producer's mammoth palace in Beverly Hills, Ms.
Klein's house was a typical stucco Los Angeles bungalow before she and her husband, Ries Niemi, a metal artist, got hold of it.


America's Cup, Lost in a Legal Breeze
LEAD: Yacht races are often lost in a sudden change of wind direction at sea.
A wind shift in a New York City courtroom has now deprived the United States of the America's Cup.


Honoring The Past: Renewed Zeal
LEAD: MEMORIALS are made of this: Duke Ellington seated at his piano, elevated by eight maidens 28 feet above Central Park; a tilted mirror incised with the names of 14 deceased astronauts; Jack Kerouac's description of his hometown carved into slabs in a park in Lowell, Mass., and Joe Louis's outstretched arm and fist at an intersection in Detroit.


New Post for Fogler
LEAD: Eddie Fogler, the Wichita State basketball coach, announced yesterday that he was resigning to accept the head coaching position at Vanderbilt University.


Support for Brady Debt Plan Seen Among Latin Leaders
LEAD: The Latin American debt plan proposed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady is likely to be endorsed by a group of Latin American leaders gathered here this week, the President of Venezuela, Carlos Andres Perez, said today.


The Expensive Oscar-Nomination Manipulations
LEAD: If Academy Awards are the rubies and emeralds in Hollywood's crown, then Academy Award nominations are the garnets and tourmalines.
Like semi-precious stones, Oscar nominations give a definite sheen to the studio that wears them.


Ruling Is Upheld Blocking MAI Bid
LEAD: A United States Court of Appeals upheld a lower court injunction blocking a hostile tender offer for Prime Computer Inc. by MAI Basic Four Inc.
Prime, a maker of minicomputers, has battled the takeover attempt on the ground that MAI has not fully disclosed its relationship with the Wall Street firm Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.


38 Held as Drug Dealers in Manhattan Raid
LEAD: Thirty-eight suspected drug dealers were arrested last night during a raid in upper Manhattan by officers from a Police Department special Tactical Narcotics Team.


Corrections
LEAD: A brief article in Business Day on Monday about the Century Communications Corporation misidentified the parties who agreed to sell the company 900,000 series A common shares of the Citizens Utilities Company for $48 million.
They were Richard L. Rosenthal Sr., Citizens' chairman and former chief executive, and other individuals.


Review/Film Festival; An Advertising Man Battles the Boil
LEAD: In the wonderful world of London advertising, Bagley (Richard E. Grant), a handsome young man given to immaculate tailoring, has a reputation as a genius.
He behaves appropriately, being overbearing to the members of his staff and completely self-assured to his superior.
Then suddenly, unaccountably, he faces a block on his new campaign for a skin cream.


Polls Say Kohl Is in Political Trouble
LEAD: It is Chancellor Helmut Kohl's custom to use the Easter break to pare down his considerable weight at an Austrian spa.
The big question that awaits his return at week's end, however, is not whether he has trimmed his girth, but whether he can stanch a precipitous loss of political support.


HEALTH SECRETARY TO GET SEVERANCE
LEAD: Dr.
Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, has reached an agreement with the Morehouse School of Medicine whereby he will receive $215,000 in severance pay.

LEAD: As Leningrad's Communist Party leaders waited in smug confidence for last Sunday's elections, they were given a poll by sociologists at the Soviet Academy of Sciences showing the city's party chief trailing an upstart 28-year-old engineer by 60 percentage points.

I.R.S. Count on Returns
LEAD: Heading into the final three weeks of the tax preparation season, more than half of Americans still had not mailed their tax returns, the Internal Revenue Service said today.
Through last Friday, the I.R.S. had received 53.1 million returns, up slightly from 52.8 million in the same period a year ago.

LEAD: Residents of Staten Island, facing a loss of influence in citywide governmental matters, would be asked on their November election ballots if they want to secede from New York City under legislation approved today by the State Senate Committee on Local Government.

Bid to Buy and Revive Eastern Is Awaited
LEAD: The directors of the Texas Air Corporation are expected to receive a plan today in which Eastern Airlines would be sold and all parties would join in an urgent effort to get most of Eastern's planes back in the air within the next 10 days, sources involved in the talks said yesterday.


Rabbi and Son Held in Beating Of Black Man
LEAD: A Hasidic rabbi and his son, both members of a neighborhood anti-crime patrol, were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday and charged with assault and fomenting a riot in connection with the beating of a black man who they believed had just slashed a Hasidic woman and her son.


A Museum Store In the Truest Sense
LEAD: For years, members of the Freeport Historical Society had hoped to restore the two properties donated to it in the mid-1970's: the 159-year-old Greek Revival-style Harrington House in town and Pettingill Farm, with its 179-year-old farmhouse on 100 waterfront acres about a mile northeast of Freeport.


Impeachment in West Virginia
LEAD: State Treasurer A. James Manchin, one of West Virginia's most popular political figures, was impeached today over bad investments that lost the state $279 million.
He faces a trial in the State Senate.


Queens Man Arrested In Bomb 'Gift' to Gotti
LEAD: A Queens man wanted for placing a crude bomb outside a social club in Little Italy as a ''gift for John Gotti,'' was arrested yesterday in Polk County, Tenn., the New York City police said.


AIR FORCE INSPECTS 25 MOST-USED B-1'S
LEAD: The Air Force inspected the most heavily used of its grounded B-1 bombers today to determine if a mishap that caused a fuel leak in one plane was an isolated breakdown or a problem with the entire fleet, an Air Force spokesman said.


Cancer Study Backs Less Radical Operation
LEAD: Women with an early stage of breast cancer live just as long if they have just the cancerous lump removed as they live if they have their entire breast removed, a new study confirms.

LEAD: Searching for an appropriate description of what has come over the Washington Capitals this spring, Pete Peeters scanned the locker room to take inventory of the new faces there.
He seemed reassured by the result.


Farmland Next In Pension Funds?
LEAD: PENSION funds, which used to be cautiously invested in stocks and bonds, moved into commercial real estate in substantial ways only a few years ago.
Now, says Dean LeBaron, it is time for them to start buying farmland.


Polaroid Suit Delay
LEAD: A Federal judge has postponed until May 1 a trial to determine the damages that the Eastman Kodak Company is liable for after infringing instant-photography patents of the Polaroid Corporation, a Polaroid spokeswoman, Marcia Phillips, said.
Polaroid is seeking $5.7 billion in damages; Kodak lawyers have said that $200 million would be ''more than ample.

LEAD: All pupils, teachers and administrators at a private high school here will be checked for illegal drug use, officials say.

William D. Cox, 79, Team Owner Who Was Banned From Baseball
LEAD: William Drought Cox, a former owner of the Philadelphia Phillies who was banned from baseball after he admitted betting on his team in 1943, died Tuesday at the Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y., after a long illness.
He was 79 years old and lived in Somers, N.Y.

LEAD: In what would be Britain's largest management-led buyout ever, directors of Magnet P.L.C. have offered to purchase the company, a maker and retailer of home improvement products, for a total of $:630.4 million, or $1.07 billion, in cash.

LEAD: In failing to claim about $80 million in Federal funds, New York City's Board of Education flunks basic management.


Israel, Fearing Strife, Orders New Curbs for Palestinians
LEAD: Israeli troops imposed a curfew on Arab residents of the occupied Gaza Strip today and said Palestinians in the West Bank would be barred from Israel beginning at midnight.


Lebanese Exchange Shellfire; Ignore Appeal for Cease-Fire
LEAD: Lebanese factions traded artillery fire between East and West Beirut today despite a cease-fire appeal by Arab League foreign ministers meeting in Tunis, the police said.


'JUNK BOND' LEADER IS INDICTED BY U.S. IN CRIMINAL ACTION
LEAD: In the largest criminal action against a Wall Street figure, a Federal grand jury today indicted Michael R. Milken, the Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. executive who transformed corporate takeovers through the pioneering use of high-yield ''junk bonds.''


Hewlett-Packard Distribution Shift
LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company said it would begin selling leading models of its computer work stations through the nation's two largest industrial distributors, a move reflecting the falling prices of the machines throughout the industry.
The company said it had signed distribution agreements with Schweber Electronics and the Hall-Mark Electronics Corporation to sell some models of its HP 9000 Series 300, which adheres to the Unix standard developed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

LEAD: Seijiro Matsuoka, a real-estate entrepreneur and art collector, died of heart failure on March 20 in Toranomon Hospital in Tokyo.
He was 95 years old and lived in Tokyo.


Liberal Muslim Is Killed in Brussels Mosque
LEAD: The spiritual leader of a liberal mosque here who had asked for moderation in the Salman Rushdie affair was shot dead in his office today.
An assistant was also killed.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Ralph W. Cutler Gallery Owner, 41
LEAD: Ralph W. Cutler, an owner of Fifty-50, a Manhattan gallery devoted to American mid-century decorative arts, died of complications from AIDS Saturday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 41 years old and also had a home in Columbia County, N.Y.


A Panel Presses To Reopen Case In Black's Death
LEAD: The State Commission of Investigation said today that a special prosecutor should be appointed to reopen the case of a black man who died in Wallkill in December 1986 after a struggle with two white off-duty police officers.

Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, was in fact a New Calliope Singers choral concert with organ interludes, and it was one of those interludes that provided the most interesting fare of the evening.


Abbott to Join Rotation
LEAD: Jim Abbott, who was born without a right hand, was officially named the Angels' fifth starter, Doug Rader, the California manager, said yesterday.
Abbott will probably make his first big league start April 8 against the Seattle Mariners at Anaheim Stadium.(AP)

LEAD: Seeking to end an impasse in international trade talks, the United States is continuing to try to resolve differences with the European Community on the elimination of farm subsidies.

LEAD: Among the rarest of the rare manuscripts and books at the New York Antiquarian Book Fair, which opens in Manhattan this afternoon, is a one-page fragment of notes against slavery made by Lincoln several years before he became President.

Gerald H. Lipkin, who is taking over the bank's leadership, said he was not about to fool with its formula.

Topics of The Times; The Prism of Paris
LEAD: This April in Paris, there will be fresh excitement in the air with the opening of I. M. Pei's high-tech glass pyramid in the courtyard of the venerable Louvre.
The latest of President Francois Mitterrand's ambitious ''Grands Projets,'' the monument has been a subject of controversy since plans for its construction were announced five years ago.

LEAD: Federal law-enforcement officials today announced the indictment of 127 people in the breakup of a money-laundering operation that shipped more than $1 billion a year in drug profits from the United States to Colombian drug kingpins.

LEAD: Officials of the Exxon Shipping Company acknowledged today that they had effectively lost the opportunity to control most of the 240,000 barrels of fast-spreading crude oil that spilled after the tanker Exxon Valdez ran aground Friday.

LEAD: The J. J. Kenny Company, one of the nation's largest and oldest bond brokers, said yesterday that it was acquiring another large broker, Clifford Drake &amp; Company.

Treasury Prices Dip in Hectic Day
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved lower yesterday in a hectic session dominated by concerns about the dollar and news that Congress might ask the Treasury to issue $50 billion worth of bonds before Sept. 30 to deal with the savings and loan crisis.

She remembers when it was sometimes played outdoors rather than in the weather-oblivious comfort of the Tacoma Dome.


Griffey, Tekulve Sign
LEAD: Ken Griffey and Kent Tekulve signed one-year contracts with the Cincinnati Reds yesterday, and the signing of Griffey had historical significance.
Griffey's son Ken Jr., an outfielder, has signed with the Seattle Mariners, and for the first time a father and son will play in the major leagues at the same time.

Midway Airlines Buys MD-80 Jets
LEAD: Midway Airlines, a big regional carrier based here, said today that it would buy 37 McDonnell Douglas MD-80 series long-haul aircraft over the next five years at a cost exceeding $900 million and had taken options for another 37 planes.
The investment is large for a carrier the size of Midway, which has a fleet of 42 older aircraft.

LEAD: At meetings this weekend with the world's top economic officials, the Bush Administration will address confusion and doubts about Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady's proposal to help ease the debt burdens of countries like Mexico and Venezuela.


Landlord Charged In Deaths of 8 in Fire
LEAD: The owner of an illegal rooming house in Yonkers where eight people were killed in a fire earlier this year was indicted yesterday on homicide charges, the authorities said.


To North Korea, Tokyo Regrets the Past
LEAD: In a renewed effort to improve relations with North Korea, Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita directed an unusual apology to Pyongyang today for the ''great suffering'' inflicted by Japan's past subjugation of the Korean peninsula.


Richard Wilson, 60, Cancer Surgeon, Dies
LEAD: Dr.
Richard E. Wilson, a medical educator and researcher who specialized in cancer surgery, died of a brain tumor Tuesday at the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston.
He was 60 years old and lived in Wellesley, Mass.


For the Record
LEAD: Phone Sex and AIDS From a brief filed as a friend of the court Saturday in the United States Supreme Court by the San Francisco AIDS Foundation and National Gay Rights Advocates.
The case, Federal Communications Commission v.
Sable Communications of California, involves a challenge to a 1988 law aimed at banning sexually oriented telephone services.


Reviews/Film Festival; 'Vera,' a Russian Love Story, Abrasive and Comic
LEAD: The camera pans across a bleak industrial landscape of factories, smokestacks, warehouses, rows of identical apartment blocks.
On the soundtrack can be heard the occasional call of a dove mixed with the noises of urban intercourse.
There is a sense of activity, purpose and routine, of the heavy momentum that carries a great modern society from one day to the next, possibly forever.

Review/Art; Tales of Ordinary People Told in Bits and Pieces
LEAD: Dona Nelson, a painter who has exhibited in New York City for more than 15 years, has developed slowly.
She began in the early 1970's as an abstractionist before moving to landscape painting and then to bluntly painted interiors and increasingly figurative work.
But at the Scott Hanson Gallery, her current exhibition, which consists of seven paintings made in the last three years, shows an artist hitting her stride.


Review/Television; The Oscars as Home Entertainment
LEAD: The 61st Academy Awards ceremony began by creating the impression that there would never be a 62d.
The evening's opening number, which deserves a permanent place in the annals of Oscar embarrassments, was indeed as bad as that.
Barely five minutes into the show, Merv Griffin was on hand to sing ''I've Got a Lovely Bunch of Coconuts,'' and that was only the beginning.


Greek Prime Minister Files Suit for Divorce
LEAD: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou today filed for divorce from his American-born wife, Margaret, citing irreconcilable differences and separation from her long before he began living with his current companion.

LEAD: Rebellious inmates today ended a five-day uprising that left at least seven people dead and trapped hundreds of women and children inside the prison here.

LEAD: A student's experiment on the effects weightlessness might have on fertilized chicken eggs in space has raised new scientific questions after eight of the embryos died.

Baker 3d urged Venezuela's President today to use his influence with the Central American presidents to insure that any demobilization of the contras in Honduras is explicitly linked to a calendar of steps by the Sandinistas to make Nicaragua more democratic, an Administration official said.

LEAD: The career of Jill Wine-Banks has been a series of firsts.
At 44 years of age, she has already been the first woman to be a Watergate prosecutor, general counsel to the Army and now executive director of the American Bar Association.


Orr Honored Again
LEAD: Vickie Orr, a 6-foot-3-inch senior center from Auburn, has been voted to the Kodak women's all-America Division I basketball team for the third straight year.
Three other seniors - Clarissa Davis of Texas, also a center, Bridgette Gordon of Tennessee, a forward, and Penny Toler of Long Beach state, a guard - were named to the 10-woman team for the second time.


Inquiry in Trident Missile Loss Reports No Electrical Flaw
LEAD: Investigators examining the explosion of a Trident 2 missile in its first undersea launching believe the accident was probably caused by a mechanical failure, not a breakdown in the missile's computer or electrical system, a Pentagon spokesman said today.


Murphy's Bands
LEAD: Murphy's Law, a rock bank, will be headlining a quadruple bill tonight at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800).
The program also includes Lost Cause, Sock of It All and Underdog, and begins at 10 P.M.
Tickets are $14.50.


El Diario Night Editor Held In Stabbing of Photographer
LEAD: The night editor of the Spanish-language newspaper El Diario La Prensa was arrested yesterday and charged with slashing a freelance photographer during an argument in a Cuban restaurant in Greenwich Village.


Review/Recital; An Evening of the Old and the New
LEAD: Alan Feinberg is building a major career as a champion of new music but his identification with the avant-garde does not rule out sympathy for and expertise in the traditional literature.
His stimulating recital at Town Hall on Wednesday evening allowed him stretching room in both areas.


Ailing Coach Shifted
LEAD: Bob Waters of Western Carolina once said he had to keep coaching football to fight amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, the incurable degenerative nerve and muscle affliction known as Lou Gehrig's disease.
But school officials reassigned him yesterday.


Penney to Cease Teleaction Service
LEAD: J. C. Penney Inc. said it would discontinue its Teleaction television shopping service on April 7, taking a $20 million write-off and laying off 164 employees.
The Dallas-based retailer said that it would take the accounting charge in the quarter ending April 29, adding that it had invested $106 million to develop the at-home shopping service.


Prosecution Rests in the Iran-Contra Trial of North
LEAD: After six weeks of testimony, the prosecution completed its case against Oliver L. North today.


World Psychiatrists Panel Votes To Readmit Soviets to Membership
LEAD: The executive committee of the World Psychiatric Association granted provisional readmission to the Soviet Union today, a move that is likely to be strenuously opposed by a number of Western human rights groups and psychiatric associations, a member of the committee said.


Noguchi Museum
LEAD: The Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum, at 32-37 Vernon Boulevard in Long Island City, Queens, will reopen tomorrow.
The four-year-old museum includes more than 250 of Noguchi's sculptures and many of his other works.
The museum is open 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.
Saturday and Wednesday through November.
Buss service from Manhattan is offered every hour on the half-hour from 11:30 A.M.

LEAD: Smartly uniformed members of the Garde Republicaine band were playing fanfares last night in the marble lobby of the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan, which was not like them.

LEAD: At 5 P.M. today, the deadline will pass for the three race tracks in the Miami area to file their schedules for next year, and the future of Florida thoroughbred racing may hang in the balance.

LEAD: ''Plaff!'' (which is translated as ''Splat!'') is a contemporary Cuban comedy about Concha, a ferociously overprotective mother whose life falls apart the day her son marries and brings his bride into the house to live.

Sanders Is Turning Pro
LEAD: Barry Sanders, who set National Collegiate Athletic Association records for touchdowns (39) and rushing yardage (2,628) and won the Heisman Trophy last season as a junior at Oklahoma State, notified the National Football League yesterday that he is turning pro, setting up a potential test of the league's restrictions against drafting underclassmen.


Chairman Steps Down At Troubled Trustcorp
LEAD: George W. Haigh resigned yesterday as president, chairman and chief executive of Trustcorp Inc., a bank holding company in Toledo, Ohio, that ran into troubles with problem loans.
The resignation is effective April 30.
Mr.
Haigh, 57 years old, will be succeeded on an interim basis by Chester Devenow, 80.

LEAD: John Z. DeLorean, the former automobile maker, lost an important battle today with the creditors of his failed sports car company when a Federal judge dismissed his challenge to a $53 million judgment made against him in Britain.

LEAD: The wrenching legal fight over the $500 million estate of J. Seward Johnson was settled three years ago, but the fallout continues, spreading over some of New York's most prestigious law firms.
A malpractice suit has aired angry charges against a top firm involved in the Johnson case while provoking a legal attack on an outspoken judge.

LEAD: Robert Evans will become chairman of British Gas P.L.C. when the current chairman, Sir Denis Rooke, retires in June, the board of Britain's largest utility announced yesterday.

LEAD: Reacting to a move on Wednesday by the Ford Motor Company, the General Motors Corporation sweetened its incentive program, offering auto loans at annual interest rates as low as 2.9 percent.
The Chrysler Corporation has announced no changes in its program.


Third World Debt: The Brady Plan
LEAD: WHEN economic policy makers are the prisoners of circumstances and lack the resources to control events, they are well advised to be vague about their proposals.
In searching for a solution to the third world debt problem, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady is employing the economics of vagueness.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Grey Acquisition
LEAD: Grey Advertsing said yesterday that it had acquired an ad agency in New Zealand, tripling its presence in that country.
Grey bought a majority share in Wood &amp; Mitchell, an independent agency with billings of $5.8 million in 1988.
Grey already owns an Auckland-based agency, Ward &amp; Grey, which had billings of $2.9 million last year.

LEAD: In the first public policy statement of his campaign, Ronald S. Lauder, a Republican candidate for mayor, declared that New York City has the worst public schools in the world and called for dismissal of the Chancellor.

LEAD: Two subway workers, apparently with their backs to the danger, were struck and killed yesterday by a fast-moving Lexington Avenue express train as it roared through a curved local station in Manhattan's East Village, transit officials said.

LEAD: The Japan Air Lines Company said today that it planned to sell $1 billion in four-year warrant bonds in markets other than the United States.

LEAD: Confined behind barbed-wire fences - in a wind-pounded tent city here and in bleak, overcrowded apartment blocks elsewhere - Kurdish refugees who fled to Turkey from Iraq feel they are the near-forgotten.

LEAD: It's two days before New York's budget deadline, and state leaders are contemplating about $1 billion in new taxes.

They don't want to upset them.

LEAD: A day after announcing a management realignment intended to bolster its non-advertising communications services, the Ogilvy Group yesterday sold a language-translation and graphics subsidiary to Macmillan Inc.
Macmillan said it paid $6.75 million for the subsidiary, Euramerica.
Ogilvy said it sold Euramerica to concentrate on its core communications businesses.

LEAD: The parent of Northwest Airlines received a takeover offer yesterday of $90 a share in cash, or about $2.6 billion, from a group led by Marvin Davis, the oilman and investor.

Compensation To Occidental
LEAD: The Venezuelan Supreme Court has ruled that the Occidental Petroleum Corporation is owed compensation for assets lost when Venezuela's oil industry was nationalized in 1976, the court president, Rene De Sola, said today.


Prices Paid to Farmers Rise 0.7% in Month
LEAD: The prices that farmers received for raw products rose seven-tenths of 1 percent from February to March, averaging 15 percent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

Review/Photography; Slices of Time, Preserved in Deft Images
LEAD: A PHOTOGRAPH, whether intended to or not, speaks of the time in which it was made.
This is obvious in the case of images taken years ago -pictures from the first days of Israel's independence, for example, or from the tumultuous decade of the 1960's.
But it is also true of contemporary art photographs of the sort one finds displayed in SoHo galleries.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''In most spills, you see 20 or 30 percent of the water covered by a slick, with large gaps of open water between patches of oil.

Can It Be? Income-Tax Talk in Connecticut?
LEAD: As the decades of the 20th century rolled by and other states in the Northeast gave in and enacted income taxes, Connecticut held firm to the old image of small-government New England, where the state's business was to mind its own business and keep taxes low.
The income tax is still the issue on which all candidates must make their stand known, and in many towns, sworn opposition has become almost a requirement for election.

Musical Traditions: Some Hardy Breeds With Staying Power
LEAD: AT its best, music has a mystical, indefinable quality that transforms it from a succession and combination of tones into a coded message from a composer's sourl to a listener's.
If this wordless communication is not crystallized densely enough, the message is ephemeral - capable of stirring a response just once or twice, or only at a particular time and place.


Review/Art; Charting 2 Centuries Of Design in France
LEAD: As everyone knows by now, the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution falls due this year and will reach its climax on July 14, the day on which the Bastille was stormed in the face of minimal opposition and a raggle-taggle group of prisoners was set free.
In almost every big city in the developed world, the bicentenary will be celebrated, sometimes with full-hearted pleasure and at other times with a certain sneaky embarrassment.

Review/Art; Otto Dix's One-Sided View of War
LEAD: If you have never seen ''The War,'' now is your chance.
The 50 etchings in Otto Dix's celebrated series are on display in all their corrosive detail on the third floor of the New York Public Library.
These are sermons without preaching.
This is Expressionism without romance.
No one in these engravings has any good war stories to tell.

LEAD: A New York City audit of medical supplies at Bellevue Hospital Center found that more than 120,000 hypodermic syringes were unaccounted for, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said as he released the report yesterday.
The syringes are the type often used by intravenous drug abusers.
