LEAD: In perhaps his most ambitious attempt to end the war against his Soviet-backed Government, President Najibullah has offered guerrilla military commanders a chance to set up regional administrations, supplied by the Government, in return for locally negotiated cease-fires.


Bill Chappell Jr. Is Dead at 67; Served in the House for 20 Years
LEAD: Bill Chappell Jr., a Florida Democrat who served 20 years in the House of Representatives before being defeated for re-election last year amid reports linking him to a Pentagon procurement scandal, died of bone cancer today at the National Institutes of Health.
He was 67 years old, Mr.
Chappell, who had represented northeast Florida's Fourth Congressional District, was hospitalized at the institutes on Feb.


Arbitration Case Ruling
LEAD: Investors who demand arbitration in disputes with brokers have the right to take the case to the American Arbitration Association, rather than to the stock exchanges or the National Association of Securities Dealers, a New York State Supreme Court justice has ruled.


Books Focusing on 60's Among Pulitzer Winners
LEAD: Echoes of the dramatic turbulence of the 1960's dominated the 73d annual Pulitzer Prize awards as Neil Sheehan's book about the Vietnam War and Taylor Branch's study of the civil-rights struggle gained honors, along with ''The Heidi Chronicles,'' Wendy Wasserstein's play about a child of the 60's alienated from the consciousness of the 80's.


Sears to Shift Management And Eliminate 800 Positions
LEAD: In a further move to cut costs and bolster sales, Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company today announced a reorganization aimed at strengthening its store management and eliminating 800 of 7,700 jobs.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Atari Games Subsidiary Chooses Keye/Donna
LEAD: Tengen Inc., the home video games subsidiary of the Atari Games Corporation, yesterday selected Keye/ Donna/Pearlstein, Los Angeles, as its first advertising agency.
The account will bill $10 million annually.
Tengen creates cartridges for the Nintendo home video game system and games software for personal computers.


South African Music
LEAD: The Izulu Dance Theater and Music Company, featuring Thokoza, a vocal group led by Thuli Dumakude, is to perform South African and gospel music in a program called ''From Soweto to Selma,'' at 7 and 10 P.M. tomorrow at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street (840-2824).
Tickets are $15.


Washington Talk; The Legislative Veto, An Accommodation That Goes On and On
LEAD: Old habits die hard, particularly comfortable habits.
Take the legislative veto, a handy device for turning conflict into accommodation that was concocted in 1932, when Herbert Hoover wanted to reorganize the Government and Congress wasn't sure it wanted him to.


Reviews/Film; A Greek Exile Returns Amid Existential Anguish
LEAD: There are mysteries in ''Voyage to Cythera,'' among them that Cythera, which is an island, is never glimpsed.
The question is: does that give this movie, by the Greek director Theo Angelopoulos, spiritual depth, the fascination of an elusive metaphor?
Or does it merely make it incomprehensible?


Convictions Are Overturned In Beech-Nut Labeling Case
LEAD: A Federal appeals court has overturned last year's convictions of two top executives of the Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation for distributing phony apple juice.

School Festival
LEAD: The Rodeph Sholom School, 7 West 83d Street, will have its Spring Book Festival from 7 to 9 P.M. tomorrow and 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.
Sunday.
It includes children's entertainment, author appearances and refreshments.
Admission is free.
Information: 362-8800.


Berlin Chamber Group
LEAD: The Berlin Chamber Orchestra, an East German ensemble that performs without a conductor, is to play Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons,'' Mozart's Divertimento in D (K. 334) and Dvorak's Serenade for Strings in E (Op. 22) at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, on Sunday at 2 P.M.
Heinz Schunk, the orchestra's concertmaster and artistic director, is to be the soloist in the Vivaldi.


Review/Film; A New Telling of the Crusoe Story
LEAD: Any Robinson Crusoe movie that takes more than five minutes to get Crusoe onto his desert isle is in big trouble.
Caleb Deschanel's ''Crusoe,'' opening today at the Paris, not only takes 10 to 15 minutes, but it also goes out of its way to give Crusoe spurious social relevance.


Why Can't Men Take Demeaning Depictions of Them as a Joke?; TV Insults Everyone
LEAD: To the Editor:


OPEC's Price Outlook
LEAD: Eight oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, meeting here today to assess the world oil market, said the limits they placed on production in November had paid off, with oil prices climbing more than $5 a barrel.
They pledged to maintain their discipline, restricting output through the second quarter.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Aon Corp., Chicago, an insurance holding company, said Stephen L. Lunsford had joined its Aon Risk Services Inc. unit as executive vice president.


Pritzker Joins Bidding For Eastern
LEAD: Jay Pritzker, the Chicago financier, yesterday presented the Texas Air Corporation with a proposal to acquire Eastern Airlines, and his offer apparently topped a bid made by the departing baseball commissioner, Peter V. Ueberroth, and a partner.

Review/Piano; Bartok, With Humor
LEAD: A high point in Diane Walsh's piano recital Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall came with the rumbustious opening movement of Bartok's Piano Sonata.
Miss Walsh gave it a jaunty, dancing interpretation not devoid of humor; she did not slight the elements of modernist angularity, but she did not insist on them as the governing characteristics of the piece.


Jail Cases Raise Questions On Justice Dept. Nominee
LEAD: Civil rights organizations and Senate investigators say they will closely review two court decisions in which William Lucas, named to head the Justice Department's civil rights division, was accused of tolerating brutality and overcrowding in county jails he oversaw in the Detroit area.


Defense Case Rested in Agents' Trial
LEAD: After just three days of testimony, the defense in the trial of Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom rested today without calling either agent to testify.


Harvard Gains Final in Rout

The Crimson routed Michigan State, 6-3, to move into the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament, In the final N.C.A.A.
Division I poll of the regular season, Harvard and Michigan State were tied for first.
But tonight, there was no question about which team was superior as a capacity crowd of 15,842 at the St.


Braselton Journal; Actress Buys Town A Place on the Map
LEAD: Herbert Braselton, a 69-year-old member of the family that for 113 years has owned this town except for 200 acres or so, said today he was satisfied that the family had done the right thing by selling it.

Maria Shriver Signs Contract With NBC
LEAD: NBC News announced yesterday that it signed Maria Shriver, the correspondent and anchor of the ''Sunday Today'' program, to a new four-year contract.
In new assignments, Ms.
Shriver, who joined NBC News in 1986, is to become a co-anchor of the planned prime-time news program ''Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow,'' and she is to anchor the network's Saturday evening newscast.
